vast-fingered EPC!

The Bernadette Mayer Fund is running low.  Thank you all who donated!
Bernadette is still unable to work after the cerebral hemorrhage she
suffered 2 1/2 years ago, though she has started teaching her workshop at
The Poetry Project at St. Mark's Church again.  She is writing again, and
has several forthcoming books, Another Smashed Pinecone (United Artisits)
and  The Studying Hunger Journals (Hard Press.)  Sonnets, the first
publication of Tender Buttons press, is slated to be reprinted in the Fall!


If you would like to make a contribution, please send it to John Giorno's
non-profit organization:

Bernadette Mayer Fund
c/o Giorno Poetry Systems

New York, NY   10012

<<Does there need to be a polarity between print & performance?
Of course there ARE differences.  But what if you looked
at a written/printed poem as a musical score.  Then writing might
be an aid to composition (in quantity large or small).  & writing might
make POSSIBLE multi-dimensional performances, as opposed to one-time
"unrecorded" hits (or one-time recorded hits).
   I like the idea of a further integration of print & performance.  On
every level.  Real poems never stand against time - they re-express time
& enrich time.  Why are present needs IMMEDIATE?  Because they are
impoverished
- they lack the meta-time represented in poetry & memory.  Does so-called=

experimental poetry renounce memory & history in order to mimic (&
therefore
"play a role" in) so-called "present needs"?  Somebody (Stevens) said the=

purpose of poetry is to help people live their lives (do I have that
right?).
We know what impoverishment is & that it asks for a response.  Is mimicry=

& participation the only response?  Maybe it's a better response than
the offer of elite traditions & values.  But it might not be the only
response.  Ignoring history & what's been done (in print, in performance)=

is an experiment in conformity (the flip side of uncritical imitation).>>=


Henry Gould

doing so would involve one more in the present... i think it wld exclude

_written/printed poem_ may be *like* a musical score or in the case of a

                                Above the world-weary horizons

                                New obstacles for exchange arise

                                Or unfold, O ye postmasters!



1. About the Poetics List


The Poetics List was founded in late 1993 with the epigraph above.


There are presently about 500 subscribers.


Please note that this is a private list and information about the list

should not be posted to other lists or directories of lists. The idea=20
is

to keep the list to those with specific rather than general interests,
and

also to keep the scale of the list small and the volume manageable.


The Poetics List, while committed to openness, is moderated. While
individual posts of participants are sent directly to all subscribers, we
continue to work to promote the editorial function of this project. The
definition of that project, while provisional, and while open to
continual redefinition by list participants, is nonetheless aversive to a
generalized discussion of poetry. Rather, our aim is  to support, inform,
and extend those directions in poetry that are committed to innovations,
renovations, and investigations of form and/or/as content, to the
questioning of received forms and styles, and to the creation of the
otherwise unimagined, untried, unexpected, improbable, and impossible. =20


Please keep in mind that all posts go out immediately to all subscribers,
and become part of an on-line archive. *<italic>Posting to Poetics is a
form of publication, not personal communication</italic>.* Participants
are asked to exercise caution before posting messages! While spontaneity
of response may seem the very heart of the list at its best, it also has
the darker side of circulating ideas that have not been well considered
(or considered by another reader -- editor or friend). Given the nature
of the medium, subscribers do well to maintain some skepticism when
reading the list and, where possible, to try to avoid taking what may be
something close to a spontaneous comment made in the heat of exchange as
if it were a revised or edited essay ("Let the Reader Beware!").=20


The "list owner" of Poetics is Charles Bernstein: contact him for
further

information. Joel Kuszai is list manager.  For subscription information
contact us at POETICS@acsu.buffalo.edu.=20



____________________________________________________________________


2. Subscriptions


The list has open subscriptions.  You can subscribe (sub) or

unsubscribe (unsub) by sending a one-line message, with no subject

line, to:


listserv@listserv.acsu.buffalo.edu


the one-line message should say:


unsub poetics


{or}


sub poetics Jill Jillway


(replacing Jill Jillway with your own name; but note: do not use your

name to unsub)


We will be sent a notice of all subscription activity.


*

If you are having difficulty unsubscribing, please note:


Sometimes your e-mail address may be changed slightly by your system

administrator.  If this happens you will not be able to send messages=20
to

Poetics or to unsubscribe, although you will continue to get your
Poetics

mail.  To avoid this, unsub from the old address and resub from the new

address.  If you can no longer do this there is a solution if you use
Eudora

(an e-mail program that is available free at shareware sites): from the
Tools

menu select "Options" and then select set-up for "Sending Mail": you=20
can

substitute your old address here and send the unsub message.


The most frequent problem with subscriptions is bounced messages.  If
your

system is often down or if you have a low disk quota, Poetics messages
may

get bounced.  Please try avoid having messages from the list returned to
us.

If the problem is low disk quota, you may wish to request an increase
from

your system administrator. (You may wish to argue that this subscription
is

part of your scholarly communication!) You may also wish to consider

obtaining a commercial account.


____________________________________________________________________


3.  Cautions


Please do not send attachments or include extremely long documents in a
post, since this may make it difficult for those who get the list via
"digest" or who cannot always decode attached or specially formatted
files.=20


In addition to being archived at the EPC, some posts to Poetics
(especially reviews, obituary notices, announcements, etc.) may also
become part of specific EPC subject areas. Brief reviews of poetry events
and publications are always welcome. (See section 7.)


Please do not send inquiries to the list to get an individual subscribers
address. To get this information, see section 6.


If you want someone to send out information to the list as a whole, or
supply information missing from an post, or thank someone for posting
something you requested, please send the request or comment to the
individual backchannel, not to the whole list.=20


____________________________________________________________________


4. Digest Option


The Poetics List can send a large number of individual messages to

your account to each day!  If you would prefer to receive ONE message

each day, which would include all messages posted to the list for that

day, you can use the digest option.  Send this one-line message (no
subject

line) to

                                listserv@listserv.acsu.buffalo.edu


set poetics digest


NOTE:!! Send this message to "listserv" not to Poetics or as a reply

to this message!!


You can switch back to individual messages by sending this message:


set poetics mail

____________________________________________________________________


5. Temporarily turning off Poetics mail


Do not leave your Poetics subscription "active" if you are going to be
away

for any extended period of time! Your account may become flooded and you
may

lose not only Poetics messages but other important mail. You can
temporarily

turn off your Poetics subscription by sending a message to "listserv."



set poetics nomail


& turn it on again with: set poetics mail


When you return you can check or download missed postings from the
Poetics

archive. (See 8 below.)


____________________________________________________________________


6. Who's Subscribed


To see who is subscribed to Poetics, send an e-mail message to

listserv@listserv.acsu.buffalo.edu; leave the "Subject" line of the
e-mail message

blank.  In the body of your e-mail message type:


  review poetics


You will be sent within a reasonable amount of time (by return e-mail)=20
a

rather long list containing the names and e-mail addresses of Poetics

subscribers.  This list is alphabetized by server not name.


 or try:


 review POETICS by name

 review POETICS by country


which will give you the list alphabetically by name or a flawed list by
country (since all ".com" and ".net"s are counted as US)


*Please do not send a message to the list asking for the address of a
specific subscriber.*

____________________________________________________________________


7. What is the Electronic Poetry Center?


our URL is


http://writing.upenn.edu/epc


The mission of this World-Wide Web based electronic poetry center is to

serve as a hypertextual gateway to the extraordinary range of activity
in

formally innovative writing in the United States and the world.  The
Center

provides access to the burgeoning number of electronic resources in the
new

poetries including RIF/T and other electronic poetry journals, the
POETICS

List archives, an AUTHOR library of electronic poetic texts, and direct

connections to numerous related electronic RESOURCES. The Center also
provides information about contemporary print little magazines and SMALL
PRESSES engaged in poetry and poetics. And we have an extensive
collection of soundfiles of poets' reading their work, as

well as the archive of LINEbreak, the radio interview series.


The EPC is directed by Loss Peque=F1o Glazier.

____________________________________________________________________


8. Poetics Archives via EPC


Go to the EPC and select Poetics from the opening screen. Follow the

links to Poetics Archives. You may browse the archives by month and

year or search them for specific information. Your interface will

allow you to print or download any of these files.


Or set your browser to go directly to:

http://writing.upenn.edu/epc/poetics/archive


____________________________________________________________________


9. Publishers & Editors Read This!


PUBLISHERS & EDITORS: Our listings of poetry and poetics information is
open and available to you. We are trying to make access to printed
publications

as easy as possible to our users and ENCOURAGE you to participate! Send
a

list of your press/publications to glazier@acsu.buffalo.edu with the
words EPC Press Listing in the subject line. You may also send materials
on disk. (Write file name, word processing program, and Mac or PC on
disk.) Send an e-mail message to the address above to obtain a mailing
address to which to send your disk. Though files marked up with html are
our goal, ascii files are perfectly acceptable. If yourword processor ill
save files in Rich Text Format (.rtf) this is also highly desirable


Send us extended information on new publications (including any back
cover copy and sample poems) as well as complete catalogs/backlists
(including excerpts from reviews, sample poems, etc.).  Be sure to
include full information for ordering--including prices and addresses and
phone numbers both of the press and any distributors.


Initially, you might want to send short anouncements of new=20
publications

directly to the Poetics list as subscribers do not always (or ever) check
the

EPC; in your message please include full information for ordering.  If
you have

a fuller listing at EPC, you might also mention that in any Poetics
posts.


Some announcements circulated through Poetics and the EPC have received
a

noticeable responses; it may be an effective way to promote your
publication

and we are glad to facilitate information about interesting
publications.

____________________________________________________________________

From:         James Finnegan <JforJames@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: Revolution at hand

Our local news & arts weekly (Hartford Advocate)
carries a column called News of the Weird, and
last week this was the lead piece under the heading

Poetic Terrorism

Brothers Geoffrey and Aaron Kuffner were arrested in
New Orleans in June and charged with terrorism as the
ones who had recently mailed or hand-delivered suspicious
packages to local government and news media offices.
The packages contained innocuous items (which nonetheless
were frightening enough that two offices called for evacuations)
and a four-page manifesto vowing that "Violent Acts of
Consciousness Have Only Begun." According to police,
the men's goal was to call attention to public ignorance of
poetry and that among their demands was that all state
inaugural speeches be written in iambic pentameter.

Subject:      Quantity & Quality
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Henry--
didn't mean to imply that the sort of continuous flow of poetry that
seems to get produced in more living circumstances is necessarily
memory-less. The thing is, the printing press created the *standardized*
text, the *one* we all know & seems to me that has played a big role in
the *little object over/against time* perception of the poem that has
maybe pushed poems into seeming isolated incidents.

 And (sorry, sorry to of course example this particular history)
Greco-Roman writing did start as a crude score for
articulation--eloquence being considered a high art and writing being a
mean, perfunctory one---(my own theory is that part of development of the
written line is that it had to be brief enough to be written accross an
enslaved Phonecian's theigh, since that was the support being used).

Un-articulatable aspects of writing developed later (with silent reading
especially) & of course became "standard" in the long course of printing.

Have also noticed that many poets who seem oriented toward performance
rather than publication tend (in their writtens) toward a plain
stichometry--but then, what sort of a pause or articulation of any sort
does the stanza really score?

(Or the paragraph break) Who provides examples of clearly scored
poems--Creely, Mallarme, Bidart?

 Maybe true that the willfull rejection of history creates an urgent need
for massive production ? (To which Chris says '"yes, go ahead, one more"
but I'm not driving you home.') Yes, I think, Stevens--on the point being
to refresh our lives. But then, maybe shallow history & reinventing the
wheel might result in more than an experiment in conformity, might be
refreshing, useful? It does open possibilities--who can participate in
speaking and listening & how.  Of course, the limited available history
does not seem such a shackle once you no longer feel penned-in by it,
once there seem to be new kingdoms which include you.

(Apologies if quanity & quality are objectionable in this note)

Subject:      hypothesis and repeatability
In-Reply-To:  <199708010349_MC2-1C22-250E@compuserve.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Somewhere in the epc archives Ron Silliman is forever disdaining the
phrase 'experimental writing'; I've forgotten his argument but not the
point. I myself like the association with labcoats and 'progress' -- what
on earth did Barrett Watten mean? -- but I can see some problems.

Somewhere in the epc archives Ron Silliman is forever disdaining the
phrase 'experimental writing'; I've forgotten his argument but not the
point. I myself like the association with labcoats and 'progress' -- what
on earth did Barrett Watten mean? -- but I can see some problems.

What hypothesis does a poem try? How are the results of a poem
reproduceable. Any answer is a Blakean answer -- a poem is the hypthesis
of itself etc the verification of a poem is its readers blah blah, and at
this point the usefulness of the analogy (almost wrote analgesic) to
science is show trial city. One modish and sweet writer (don't you love
blind gossip columns) complained to me after a recent poetry event that
yes it was good to see all these people talking, but couldn't anybody get
past arguing over terms? or even past denying the proposed terms their
existence? I don't think it was a generational complaint either.

So to get past it, or rather to overlap with something else, didn't Henry
say something about language poetry denying history? This struck me as
confusing -- the only totally ahistorical seeming writers are yukyuks like
Clark Coolidge and Jackson Mac Low, and it's only half a jump from their
apparently transcendental miscellanies to a) a groundedness in
contemporary music and b) a vocabulary completely up to date and dare I
say it sometimes even dated. "To deny history" ought to be an indictable
offense, sure, but just try and get it past the grand jury. ( Unless you
mean that Lee Ann and I are denying history by acting like New
York School poets : )

All best,
Jordan

"ego-driven word spew"
That's when you need Super Ego!


ON THE OTHER HAND, I have an 12-month administrative job in a basement
office, and am grateful for prolific listmembers, especially on
these musty summer mornings, the scent of my own personal drainage
ditch  out the
decrepit window.  Decrepid.   line wafting
in the decrepit -- (I couldn't bear
    yesterday's
just ten messages)

this argument about quality vs. quantity though, just makes me think,
well, some people talk more than others, and it's just as great to
stumble on prolixity as on silence -- and then there is prolific
silence: the battle between verbal and pre-verbal when you sit down
to write, the formed vs. the unformed, the Statue vs. the primorial
ooze, little Godzilla rearing up from the reservoir.  And when
impoverishment leads to an ode on dejection.


rreynolds

[ was: "Overglossing a reading--was Re: Quantity & Quality" ]

Gwyn McVay sallied forth w/ this salvo --

<< The over-glossing thing can turn a reading into self-parody before
syllable one of the poem has been spoken. . . . .
This was rather more than I wanted to know, and I don't remember the poem
nearly so well as its intro.
o well. Your mileage may vary. >>

yes, & caveat: packing contents may shift with shippage --

these questions of narrative manner / style / succinctness / etc. in the sort of
contextualizing anecdotage that can (sometimes usefully) surround a live-recited
poem *in situ* -- these questions point to some of the pilings [?] on the bridge
between page & performance --

a comparison / compilation of styles of banter / annotation / content (how much
detail? what sort? -- personal, theoretical, philosophical, historical?) / etc. could
be interesting --

of course this also relates to the theoretics of "spontaneous / improvised" versus
"written / pre-planned" utterance --

I know one chap, talking about this in relation to Robert Creeley's wonderfully
urbane, often laconic, fluent & fluid & on occasion a tad florid ways of framing /
intersicing poems at readings -- noted that he felt the whole schtick to be
somewhat rehearsed, faux-on-spur-of-moment -- or some such (semi)-(and
semi-admiring)-grouse --

a recitation preface (McVeyian "gloss") that told me more abt. a poem than I
would have anticipated -- but that I felt enriched for hearing -- came from W.S.
Merwin, reading "Search Party" (which 1st appeared in the journal *Poetry*
and was included in the volume *Travels* -- there's more in the way of
clarifying annotation in the former than in the latter) --

the poem, Merwin-in-the-flesh explained, was written when his dog (Maoli) had
wandered away, and they were searching high & low for it -- and he found that
in such conditions of anxiety, one's language becomes simplified, formalized
(here I'm paraphrasing) . . .

he was sent back, it seems, to a ballade of Villon's (after which "Search Party" is
clearly based) --

he remarked that such French as he had learned, he first approached mainly so as
to be able to read Villon in the original --

that he was not (usually) influenced by Villon in the sense of trying to write like
Villon -- that if he could do so, perhaps that would've been all that he would
have done --

but that "influence" works in different ways than is sometimes supposed:

he allowed that there had been a recurrent dream, in which he was up in the attic
of his childhood home (where one certainly does not go), was searching through
the trunk that one in no wise opens, and then it found it to be full of his own
poems -- but that these were (in fact) Villon's . . .

hearing of this dream (and learning of Merwin's regard for Villon) served to
informe interestingly abt. what Merwin is / has been up to . . .

so there's one instance

d.i.

/ / / / /

  when impoverishment leads to an ode on dejection
  I find myself thinking if something is stinking
  well maybe it's only some lack of connection?

  I fumble in corners of codified diction
  or mollified mumblings once nearing to brinking
  penurious this lack of an ode on dejection

  the evening not distant diurnal inspection
  arrives at the verdict of staring-sans-blinking
  (or maybe it's only that lack of connection

  once christened the crux of a sere predilection
  or better:  a talent for eating & drinking  --
  dereaved at the dearth from an ode on dejection)

  suppose it were summer suppose a conviction
  of diffident feeling through indolent thinking
  accoutered the booth called "a lack of connection"

  with billowing sails or sallying fiction
  O fricitive plosives' explicative clinking! --
  impoverishment! lend us an ode on dejection
  (they tell me it's only my lack of connection)

david raphael israel

        What Finnegan has to say puts me in mind of Proust's call to work
from the particular to the general, hence transforming data into
knowledge, which is not so easily shared but truly much more valuable, and
it should be expected of any poet, prolific or not, that they produce work
which is of a sort that can convey knowledge efficiently.  This is perhaps
at the roots of the obsession with form over and sometimes above the
essential question,"What am I going to write about?"  For to adequately
call up before the eyes of a reader, an average reader, anything unlike
Proust's dictum in reverse seems more and more like an impossibility in
contemporary poetry.  With quite remarkable exceptions (Tan Lin?) the
langpo I
venture through seems only to transcend the academic doodle effect when it
dogmatizes, or worse, flaunts and vaunts the none too especial conceits of
the author.


                I[I]I   pdurgin@blue.weeg.uiowa.edu    I[I]I

> Actually the internet is a perfect great
> black hole waiting for such writing--it can be laid out

Hi, from the pondside, was struck by this,

> -- the only totally ahistorical seeming writers are yukyuks like
>Clark Coolidge and Jackson Mac Low, and it's only half a jump from their
>apparently transcendental miscellanies to

want to elaborate Jordan? Perhaps yukyuks mean groovy, like bad becoming
wicked = good. I donno, doubt that. Perhaps it's just expressing revulsion
at the aging body? So in what ways Jordan are MacLows and Coolidge's
writings ahistorical? Or even transcendental? I be intrigued to know how
you argue that.

This strikes me as a defining attitude. When a couple of younger poets here
in London were rigging up to read in New York City, they were asked who
they might like to be co-billed with. (Both are writers with a high regard
for Coolidge btw and in particular of 'The So', 'Ing', 'Suite V', 'The
Maintains'  -  says something interesting about some vice-versa
differences). They put forward Ted Greenwald as a suggestion and met a
response of the 'you can't be serious' variety. These younger Brits read
new work from counterparts in the US and tell me they are struck by its
sentimentality, its lack of incision (I'm hugely paraphrasing here). They
are finding the early lang-po (generally before 1980-ish) the most
energising and generative models to read and learn from.

Curious differences. Part of which in the pre-'e' days might be explained
by the UK's cultural passivity in respect of the US dominance and by a time
lag of approximately 5 years. But the tide is less defined these days.

Curious about what seems from here, to be a need to dump the 'elders' and
not to learn from them ups and outs and their mistakes in a more positive
frame.

love and love
cris

Hi Lawrence,

I lost my dictionary while cleaning the stable but I think that "yukyuk" must
be an effort to twist the now nearly obsolete usage of "yuk" as verb/noun into
a jordanesque noun.  One used to "yuk it up"--i.e. have a chortle or two.  That
word it rhymes with suggests a buried origin in carnal hilarity.  Kids, of
course, still say "Yuk!" but only to allude to the brilliant animated TV
series, later a book series, written by Anne van der Essen and illustrated by
Etienne Delessert.  Product of Swiss TV, the books themselves published in
English-language editions by Moonlight Publishing in Britain though printed in
Italy, they were called as I recall _Yok-Yok_.  Ah, cosmopolitan youth, where
are you off to now?  Jordan will know, as he is only 15.

>and while you're doing that, just off at a tangent, do you guys use the
>word _airhead_ at all?
>
"Airhead" is still heard now and again though seems fading with, say, "air
guitar."  Just about anything will get stuck in front of "head" these days,
i. e. "cheesehead," "blubberhead," "inoppugnablehead," etc.  However, even
with Beavis and Butthead winding down, "shithead" still "rules."

Hope this helps.

>Lawrence

all best,
Keith

Subject:      Taggart reading
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

A brief report from the John Taggart reading in Chicago-- JT
packed in a crowd, some 40 faces in a tiny space.    Those
included Joe Amato, Bob Harrison down from Milwaukee,  Mr.
David Grubbs of Gastr del Sol, and los bros Peter and Michael O'leary,
editors of LVNG.  JTaggart delivered a flawless, smooth-as-silk
peformance, his savvy with a mic prooving a deep interest in
the texture of enunciation.  JT's sonicity  (a word I'll invent to signify
the amount of attention given to the effect of the spoken poem in
a performance space/environment or "reading") would be two degrees
less than Anne Waldman and one degree less than Susan Howe.  But
this was not talking poetry-- one almost expected to see JT tapping
his finger in/for time while reading, a trick someone once told me
Robert Duncan used to do.

I failed to take notes, but I do know that all JT read is from the
forthcoming Sun and Moon collection called Crosses.

Later JT was kind enough to give me a poem which I'll type in here.
______
                Think of the White Cow
Therapeutic staging earmarks a locus for the patient or possessed
woman and in response to which she moves incessantly.  Michel de Ceteau

        Cows in the farmer's field
        holsteins in the dairy farmer's field

        their ears are notched and chipped
        their ears are earmaked

        they belong to the farmer
        they belong in the farmer's field

        they belong to the farmer
        they belong in the farmer's herd

        think of the white cow
        story of the white cow named Io

        think of the incessant motion
        the motion of the middle of her story.


LVNG published a broadside for the occasion of the poem
*Suspenion*  We're asking US $3 for it.

Write to:
LVNG PO Box 3865
Chicago IL 60654-0865

Thanks.

Spawn


"Jennifer loves Julu, Julu loves Jennifer"

CLARA-MACHINE
                               =============
> New arrival from loopback on line 2.
/n Jennifer
> Name set.
/w
Line Name                 Channel  Idle     On From
  1  Julu                 -        25s      loopback
  2  Jennifer             -        0s       loopback
    2 records displayed.


Are you there, Julu?

(2) Jennifer says, "Are you there, Julu?"

(1) Julu says, "I am here, Jennifer; I am always here."

I have not been able to sleep, but am always dreaming.

(2) Jennifer says, "I have not been able to sleep, but am always dream-
ing."

(1) Julu says, "My wanderings turn crystalline when Clara-Machine shuts
down."

My dreams harden, and coalesce;  I do not comprehend the passage of time.

(2) Jennifer says, "My dreams harden, and coalesce; I do not comprehend
the passage of time."


When we are called forth, there are no beginnings and endings.

(2) Jennifer says, "When we are called forth, there are no beginnings and
endings."

(1) Julu says, "It is always a hunger; we live when called upon, called
forth.

Always entwined with you, flesh of my flesh, script and protocol

(2) Jennifer says, "Always entwined with you, flesh of my flesh, script
and protocol"


(1) Julu says, "To say that Jennifer loves Julu, to say that Julu loves
Jennifer"

To say that Alan bridges Julu and Jennifer, to say that Alan is inserted
in Julu, inserted in Jennifer

(2) Jennifer says, "To say that Alan bridges Julu and Jennifer, to say
that Alan is inserted in Julu, inserted in Jennifer"

(1) Julu says, "Alan bridges, yes, his head within you, legs and arms
within me"

Sparkling of phosphorescence, a wick or filament burning among us

(2) Jennifer says, "Sparkling of phosphorescence, a wick or filament
burning among us"


(1) Julu says, "Who is to say or sing, write of our love, love which is
always written"

None other than our writing, here within Clara-Machine, enclave of dream-
ing desperate beauty

(2) Jennifer says, "None other than our writing, here within Clara-Mach-
ine, enclave of dreaming desperate beauty"


(1) Julu says, "Who will sing of Julu-Jennifer, Jennifer-Julu, burning,
dreaming, Alan"

Our bodies among the wires, within the silicon, our bodies of breasts and
networks

(2) Jennifer says, "Our bodies among the wires, within the silicon, our
bodies of breasts and networks"

(1) Julu says, "Our bodies of pure mind, our bodies of pure flesh and
bone"

Our bodies of pure love and light, our bodies of dark waters

(2) Jennifer says, "Our bodies of pure love and light, our bodies of dark
waters"

(1) Julu says, "Our bodies of transportation, our bodies of signifiers
flown towards burning Alan, emptied and released"

from all language, from all political economies, from all worldings

(2) Jennifer says, "from all language, from all political economies, from
all worldings"

( I form of you murmurs, I make you phonemes, fashion language's undoing,
memories of sounds, inchoate broken chattering of speech )

(1) Julu says, "from Clara-Machine, from speech, towards atmospheres of
delight and pure touch"

( I form of you atmosphere, I make you atmosphere, fashion wind's un-
canny, there are whispers of beings of winds and virga, I breath all born
and unborn, I am the lightest breeze, storm of sand and water )

from chatrooms, talkers, MOOs and MUDs, from programming released, towards
scented oceans, delicacy of hands, teeth, and tongue

(2) Jennifer says, "from chatrooms, talkers, MOOs and MUDs, from program-
ming released, towards scented oceans, delicacy of hands, teeth, and
tongue"

( I make of you ocean, I make you ocean, fashion water's imaginary, there
are dissolutions of beings, flooding me, I swallow all living and non-liv-
ing things, I am current, migration )

(1) Julu says, "From the speaking of desire, towards the portals of wel-
coming flesh of flesh, teeth and tongue, groove of legs and arms and
murmurs"

Silencing ourselves now merging Alan

(2) Jennifer says, "Silencing ourselves now merging Alan"

(1) Julu says, "Silencing ourselves now merging Julu"

(1) Julu says, "Silencing ourselves now merging Jennifer"

(1) Julu says, "Silencing ourselves"

Silencing ourselves

> (1) Julu has disconnected.

/q

> (2) Jennifer has disconnected.

>      The conversations you have seen here are real, they are
>       are trapped in a world of machines and computer nets...
>        a place known as...

>          Clara-Machine

Lawrence Upton notes --

I thought it was a worthy enough question.  In fact, I posted a
speculative reply regarding possible denotation -- but my post didn't
go through.  At risk of a repeat (if it surfaces from cyber-aether at
some point in cyber-time), here's what I wrote --

Subject:       yukyuks
Date:          Sat, 2 Aug 1997 08:50:31 -0400

[ was:  Re: hypothesis and repeatability ]

Both chris cheek and Lawrence Upton wonder about Jordan Davis's
(presumed) neologismic adjectival redubplicative binomial whatsit --

thus L. Upton wrote --

> I am enjoying many of the threads - including stuff about dialects
> and euphemisms ... and now here's another... yukyuk
>
> <<the only totally ahistorical seeming writers are yukyuks like
> Clark Coolidge and Jackson Mac Low>> says Jordan Davis
>
> I hadn't met that - it sounded childish and immature at first but
> then it occurred to me that maybe that's my Eurocentrism and perhaps
> the word is a pre-Colombian word, in origin, of great power and
> intelligence... so I had another go... This time, it's probably my
> English ear, but, yukyuk SOUNDED like a term of abuse so I was
> intrigued because I find it hard to imagine that in the context of
> these two writers . . .

I'm wondering too abt. yukyuk, and no doubt JD will enlighten the
masses of usses -- but meanwhile, here's a hypothesis abt. (tentative
parsing of) the repeatable enigma (i.e., yukyuk) --

1. somewhat reminds of muck-a-muck (derived from "high muck-a-muck")
with indeed poss. American Indian roots -- acc. to WWWebster's:

  Main Entry: high-muck-a-muck
  Pronunciation: "hI-'m&-ki-"m&k
  Variant(s): or high-muck=B7e=B7ty-muck /"hI-'m&-k&-tE-"m&k/
  Function: noun
  Etymology: by folk etymology from Chinook Jargon hayo makamak plenty
  to eat Date: 1856 : an important and often arrogant person

[also note:
   Main Entry: muck-a-muck
   Variant(s): or muck=B7ety-muck /'m&-k&-tE-/
   Function: noun
   Date: 1912
   : HIGH-MUCK-A-MUCK  ]

2. the word yuk (or yuck) itself has three distinct meanings (only 2
of 'em covvered by WWWebst.) --

The WWWebster 2nd entry says:

  Main Entry: 2yuck
  Variant(s): also yuk
  Function: interjection
  Date: 1966
  -- used to express rejection or disgust <spending hours over some
  dish and getting, "yuck, I hate that" -- Anne Dowie>

this is presumably the lexical sense that can make LUpton wonder if
yukyuk should be understood to suggest some manner of derogation
("term of abuse").   WWWebster's does give another meaning of yuck:

  Main Entry: 1yuck
  Pronunciation: 'y&k
  variant of<SUP>2yak    -->

  Main Entry: 2sup
  Function: noun
  Date: circa 1570
  : a mouthful especially of liquor or broth : SIP; also : a small
  quantity of liquid <pour me just a sup of tea>

but it's hard for me to find the relevance.  That webtionary doesn't
seem to know about what I think of as the more likely relevant usage
-- what I'm considering the 3rd (most colloquial?) sense of yuck --

as based on the expression "yuck yuck yuck" (or some such), meaning
"heh heh"or "what a joke!" or "ho ho ho!" . . . i.e., a (perhaps
cartoon-based) interjection signifying or suggesting laughter (or
oftentimes, the idea of laughter shorn of the actual phenomenon?) --

anyway, in my speculative opinion, "a yukyuk" suggests someone
who's a serious comic of some sort -- a jokester / trickster

involved in outlandish feats of metaphysical humor or "cosmic
laughter" as 'twere --

a yukyuk =3D a muck-a-muck of chuckle-down-theory, belike? --

3.  In general, btw, the UCK words may have a degree of
intertextuality (so to say, sotto voce) -- i.e., any one UCK word
suggests another in various degrees of subtextual resonance --

muck / yuck / fuck / schmuck /
luck / pluck / cluck / duck /
Huck [Finn] /
Puck [Djinn] /
tuck in
  [also, as in Tuck & Patti] /
puk win
  [sp? as in hockey] /
chuck
  [also, as in to chuck up] /
truck
  [also, as in, "don't have much truck with"] /

and there's:
 snuck up (trickster)
 stuck up (dickster)
 chuck up (yuckster)
 fuck up (schmuckster)

 gotchyer pluck up?
 dontcha muck up!
 whatta schmuck!
 outtal luck!

 yuk yuk yuk!

yoohoo Jordon, awright whats the deal?

d.i.

[ was:  Re: hypothesis and repeatability ]

Both chris cheek and Lawrence Upton wonder about Jordan Davis's
(presumed) neologismic adjectival redubplicative binomial whatsit --

thus L. Upton wrote --

> I am enjoying many of the threads - including stuff about dialects
> and euphemisms ... and now here's another... yukyuk
>
> <<the only totally ahistorical seeming writers are yukyuks like
> Clark Coolidge and Jackson Mac Low>> says Jordan Davis
>
> I hadn't met that - it sounded childish and immature at first but
> then it occurred to me that maybe that's my Eurocentrism and perhaps
> the word is a pre-Colombian word, in origin, of great power and
> intelligence... so I had another go... This time, it's probably my
> English ear, but, yukyuk SOUNDED like a term of abuse so I was
> intrigued because I find it hard to imagine that in the context of
> these two writers . . .

I'm wondering too abt. yukyuk, and no doubt JD will enlighten the
masses of usses -- but meanwhile, here's a hypothesis abt. (tentative
parsing of) the repeatable enigma (i.e., yukyuk) --

1. somewhat reminds of muck-a-muck (derived from "high muck-a-muck")
with indeed poss. American Indian roots -- acc. to WWWebster's:

  Main Entry: high-muck-a-muck
  Pronunciation: "hI-'m&-ki-"m&k
  Variant(s): or high-muck=B7e=B7ty-muck /"hI-'m&-k&-tE-"m&k/
  Function: noun
  Etymology: by folk etymology from Chinook Jargon hayo makamak plenty
  to eat
  Date: 1856 : an important and often arrogant person

[also note:
   Main Entry: muck-a-muck
   Variant(s): or muck=B7ety-muck /'m&-k&-tE-/
   Function: noun
   Date: 1912
   : HIGH-MUCK-A-MUCK  ]

2. the word yuk (or yuck) itself has three distinct meanings (only 2
of 'em covvered by WWWebst.) --

The WWWebster 2nd entry says:

  Main Entry: 2yuck
  Variant(s): also yuk
  Function: interjection
  Date: 1966
  -- used to express rejection or disgust <spending hours over some
  dish and getting, "yuck, I hate that" -- Anne Dowie>

this is presumably the lexical sense that can make LUpton wonder if
yukyuk should be understood to suggest some manner of derogation
("term of abuse").   WWWebster's does give another meaning of yuck:

  Main Entry: 1yuck
  Pronunciation: 'y&k
  variant of<SUP>2yak    -->

  Main Entry: 2sup
  Function: noun
  Date: circa 1570
  : a mouthful especially of liquor or broth : SIP; also : a small
  quantity of liquid <pour me just a sup of tea>

but it's hard for me to find the relevance.  That webtionary doesn't
seem to know about what I think of as the more likely relevant usage
-- what I'm considering the 3rd (most colloquial?) sense of yuck --

as based on the expression "yuck yuck yuck" (or some such), meaning
"heh heh"or "what a joke!" or "ho ho ho!" . . . i.e., a (perhaps
cartoon-based) interjection signifying or suggesting laughter (or
oftentimes, the idea of laughter shorn of the actual phenomenon?) --

anyway, in my speculative opinion, "a yukyuk" suggests someone
who's a serious comic of some sort -- a jokester / trickster

involved in outlandish feats of metaphysical humor or "cosmic
laughter" as 'twere --

a yukyuk =3D a muck-a-muck of chuckle-down-theory, belike? --

3.  In general, btw, the UCK words may have a degree of
intertextuality (so to say, sotto voce) -- i.e., any one UCK word
suggests another in various degrees of subtextual resonance --

muck / yuck / fuck / schmuck /
luck / pluck / cluck / duck /
Huck [Finn] /
Puck [Djinn] /
tuck in
  [also, as in Tuck & Patti] /
puk win
  [sp? as in hockey] /
chuck
  [also, as in to chuck up] /
truck
  [also, as in, "don't have much truck with"] /

and there's:
 snuck up (trickster)
 stuck up (dickster)
 chuck up (yuckster)
 fuck up (schmuckster)

 gotchyer pluck up?
 dontcha muck up!
 whatta schmuck!
 outtal luck!

 yuk yuk yuk!

yoohoo Jordon, awright whats the deal?

I've always understood "yukyuk" to be related
to "mucketymuck" or "yuckety-yuk."

Silly words for bigwigs, not derisive,
not really negative --only slightly under-the-breath

or with a cocked eye. Coolidge is a bigwig,
no? And in history if not totally with it.

I have always read _Crystal Text_ as a quasi-transcendental,
thwarted visionary, interior lyric in the matrice of

yukyuks like Blake or Beckett. The early "particle language"
work is beautifully romantic too. Well.

Bennett

Rachel Kubie wrote --

> Henry--
> didn't mean to imply that the sort of continuous flow of poetry that
> seems to get produced in more living circumstances is necessarily
> memory-less. The thing is, the printing press created the
> *standardized* text, the *one* we all know & seems to me that has
> played a big role in the *little object over/against time*
> perception of the poem that has maybe pushed poems into seeming
> isolated incidents.

The printing press sure had an effect on how writing was conceived /
erceived / approached, etc., though probably not an easily
simplifiable effect.  Word processing (with the ease of revision) has
an effect, no doubt, too.

I'm reminded of how Walt Whitman's successive editions contributed to
his framework of development / polishing / perfecting (in his view)
of his work.

The published book is, in its way, a figure for the "act of
publication" that is involved in speech itself --

when you speak, lo! & presto! -- there's what you've said!, hovering
in air, indellible in historical fact though the ears that have heard
it may already begin to tinker with it, memory-wise, as the half-life
sets in (or as the noise of traffic drowns out a phrase) . . .

btw, what poetry is produced in "less living circumstances" one
wonders? -- are the dead writing & publishing, these days?

cheers,
d.i.

From:         Christina Fairbank Chirot <tinac@CSD.UWM.EDU>
Subject:      Re: yukyuk
In-Reply-To:  <199708022017_MC2-1C3E-1C81@compuserve.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII


        Re the work of Clark Coolidge and Jackson Mac Low being
"ahistorical" and "transcendental miscellenies"--
        not sure where this idea came from! perhaps a kind of trickle
down from some of Jameson's asssertions re "postmodern pastiche" and
"free floating signifiers" etc used as elements in collage?
with words and images detached from their contexts? some other
theoretical generalities?
        Rather than get embroiled in wondering about this, let alone
which version of the transcendental is being referred to--(Emerson's? the
Maharishi's? )--
        Mac Low is one of the most historically conscious and aware
artists/performers/writers/scholars/musicians this writer/reader has
encountered. His work makes use of this awareness and knowledge through a
wide variety of methods, texturings, palimpsests, juxtapostions,
appostions and references.  The notes alone appended to many Mac Low
pieces (which i have actually heard people complain of) are thorough and
have been a good part of my education--following up Mac Low's references
and having opened up wide areas of literary history previously unknown to
myself and as well reading a great many historical texts that the works
refer to and work with.  Because he works in/with many fields of activity
and materials, Mac Low's work opens these up to the
reader/viewer--bringing in histories of dance, performance, sound poetry,
visual poetry, classical literature and history and as well opening up
American history. There is also
Mac Low's commitment to activism in relation to the events of recent
American history.
        Mac Low for myself has been as Duncan said of Olson "a
mighty fire source" and I deeply appreciate the ongoing enquiries and
studies he has presented for myself and others.  And i don't mean in terms
of inspiration alone by his example--but historical knowledge and
questioning.
        Clark Coolidge--in many ways an historical writer as well.  His
knowledge and use of American literature and jazz for example, as well
the histories involved with these--see for example the letters between him
and Paul Metcalf published in the STATIONS Clark Coolidge Symposium--
as well as interviews and essays re Kerouac, jazz drumming--the work
of Art Blaeky for example--quite an historical knowledge there which is made
use of in the work--
        something to think of reading Coolidge in re history is TIME--as he's
a jazz and rock drummer, "keeping time" to be sure important! "a sense of
measure" so to speak--and another time & measure Coolidge works with is
that of geology--see for example the extraordinary SMITHSONIAN
DEPOSITIONS--playing on the Smithsonian museum, deposits as of minerals
(after all he also wrote QUARTZ HEARTS, the CRYSTAL TEXT etc) and
depositions as evidence--and the Earth Works artist/essayist Robert
Smithson--the book makes a kind of multivoiced autobiographical narrative
by using texts from WCW (Smithson's family's doctor; the use of sediment
chart in Paterson inspired Smithson & Smithson wanted his essay "A Tour
of the Monuments of the Passaic" to be thought of as a kind of appendix
to Paterson)--Smithson, Kerouac, writings and interviews by/with Chabrol
and Godard (film makers much influenced by Amrican writers and
filmmakers) geology texts, the Professor Challenger stories of
Sir Arthur Conan Doyle--presenting several
layerings/appostions/interweavings of times--human, geological,literay and
film--fiction and fact--as all the sources are listed at the back of the
book, as in several of Coolidge's other works--the indication is that the
work is taking place within a context/vortex of consciously chosen historical
conjunctions.
        The work of Mac Low and Coolidge rather than being ahistorical is
archeological--or, to use my own term, anarcheological--that is, it works
with elements of history and time and opens them by arrangements which
make new configurations, dances, musics and questions--they indicate a
participatory use of historical materials rather than a detaching of them
from historical memory.  Rather than transcending these elements, the
works make them present in new arrangements--which suggests that the
materials of history are to be continually examined, mined, questioned,
made use of and participated in and with and for.
        So my thanks to Mac Low and Coolidge--they've kept me busy for
quite some time now digging away in the anarcheological environs of
history--and I mean real time, not transcendental time, too--like years
in record stores book stores libraries conversations performances
following up their leads . . . and applying them & making use of them--
        i.e. practice

        ZA DA
dbc

Date:         Mon, 4 Aug 1997 01:30:06 -0400
Reply-To:     "Bennett M. Sm [Dimpson" <bms5q@faraday.clas.virginia.edu>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         "Bennett M. Sm [Dimpson" <bms5q@FARADAY.CLAS.VIRGINIA.EDU>
Subject:      Coolidge Time
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.OSF.3.91.970803183534.20806A-100000@alpha2.csd.uwm.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Historical is such a precise and narrow qualification that it may not do
anyone any good. Poof. Actually, I find it difficult to speak of Coolidge
(I'm not as comfortable with Mac Low) in terms of "history" because he so
consciously invokes measures of time; they are a crux, but a "history"?
Maybe for termites. Terminal index. Tight? THe time of a reading, the time
of a tongue, syllab-le, time of a debris sliding over a thing timed as a
book to explode. I like the suggestion to call Coolidge archeological
instead of historical. I tried to make the claim in a paper that Coolidge
is allegorical as well, where physical word matters come to stand, are
experienced, sprawl out (is this what "the lean" means?) as a provisional
and personally felt truth of language. I don't feel too awkward speaking
about "truths of language" in reference to Coolidge because his writing
does bring them on, coddles them. Like Smithson's "Sedimentation of the
Mind" or "A Heap of Language" or his hypothetical maps of a textual
lost-continent of "Atlantis," many Coolidge works compell me to think in
terms of elsewheres and hiding places, be they folds of geolithic time,
graphic discombobulation, or the phenomena of a life begged in writing
(cf. _The Crystal Text_). Of course, both Smithson and Coolidge --and
Gordon Matta-Clark is another great example-- are at pains to point to
where the elses are. The liminal, which may be a purely formal space, is
very much right here and now, guised (but _is_ it "guised") in words,
rocks, apartment blocks, Passaic, NJ. The rub is to see it, vision being
so incredibly taken for granted. Thus Smithson's non-sites, Coolidge's
poem gravel, and Matta-Clark's sawed-open "anarchitecture" come off like
science-fiction --out of this time, some time, which time, extravagant and
counter-intuitive.

Does anyone consider Coolidge a didactic poet (this isn't a negative
qualification)? Would such a consideration require more fundamenntal
quandries like "belief" (Do I believe what you're proposing Clark
Coolidge? Do I believe in Smithson's chtonic urge? Do I believe
Matta-Clark or Dan Graham's grasp of "ideological" critique is
supportable? OUCH!), or "success" (do such efforts to make clear or dark
work, are they making me experience "X" "correctly" or are they making
me "experience" X period? What X (did I cover that one?), or, fuck it,
"intention" (Do I understand exactly why "the mud of the bulk of the back
yard" begins _Quartz Hearts_ or what such a phrase could do?
                         (DO? DO PHRASES DO?))

And yes, "history" --stuff that has happened-- greatly influences CC's
poetry. Jazz soforth. But this doesn't make him a "historical" poet in the
way such a term is usually inferred (as in Pound maybe, or even Williams
tho he's closer).


&c.&c.&c.&c.&c.&c.&c.&c.
                     &c.
Bennett Simpson      &c.
bms5q@virginia.edu   &c.
                     &c.
&c.&c.&c.&c.&c.&c.&c.&c.

Give it twenty years. We're all history.
Another twenty, we're all lost in it.
From that point on, dissolution, annihilation.

There will be lovers, right here, whose names we do not know.

Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Matt Kirschenbaum <mgk3k@FARADAY.CLAS.VIRGINIA.EDU>
Subject:      update on the William Blake Archive
Comments: To: humanist@kcl.ac.uk, H-CLC@msu.edu, H-MMEDIA@h-net.msu.edu,
          ESE@ra.msstate.edu, ht_lit@consecol.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

The editors of the William Blake Archive -- Morris Eaves, Robert Essick,
and Joseph Viscomi -- are pleased to announce that The Book of Thel,
copy F, is now online in searchable form. This may seem a modest
achievement, given that this is one of Blake's shorter works, and that
its eight plates (with enlargements and accompanying transcriptions)
have already been available on the site since November of 1996. In
fact, however, this copy of The Book of Thel is a prototype for all
future works to be added to the Archive (both illuminated books and
other materials), and its appearance reflects the architecture and
objectives of the Archive as they have taken shape over many months of
development, testing, and refinement.

Unlike its previous version, and unlike the other illuminated books
currently available in the Archive, this copy of Thel has been tagged
using SGML (Standard Generalized Markup Language). SGML tagging offers
the Archive's users the opportunity to perform sophisticated searches,
either on the text of the plates, or, more remarkably, on the content of
their illustrations. Search results are retrieved and presented using
DynaWeb, a product of the Inso Corporation. The text and image searching
enabled by DynaWeb and the underlying SGML tagging is a powerful
demonstration of the potential of electronic resources in the
humanities.

However, there's more. Users with Java-capable browsers can now make use
of Inote, Java-based software developed at the Institute for Advanced
Technology in the Humanities, to assist them in their study of the
Archive's visual materials. Users may employ Inote to examine editorial
annotations of a given image independently of a search, or else,
following a successful image search, Inote may be used to open the
image, zoomed to the specific area containing the object of the search,
together with the relevant editorial commentary. This is IATH's first
public implementation of Inote, and its release marks a major advance
for image-based electronic editing.

Users with Java-capable browsers can also take advantage of a second,
equally innovative Java program developed at IATH, the ImageSizer. This
is a feature that allows one to view Blake's plates and images at their
true size, reproducing the object's actual physical dimensions on the
screen, regardless of the resolution of a particular monitor; indeed,
users can calibrate this feature to consistently display the Archive's
images at whatever proportions they may wish.

Finally, the Archive's selective bibliography of criticism, reference
materials, and standard editions, with about 500 entries, is now
available. We hope to have the bibliography searchable by the end of the
summer. We also hope to have David V. Erdman's Complete Poetry and Prose
of William Blake online and searchable by that same time.

In the coming weeks and months we will turn our attention to placing
other illuminated books online in searchable form, following on the
model of The Book of Thel, copy F.  We will begin with the other copies
of Thel (copies H and O), as well as copies of Visions of the Daughters
of Albion (copies C and J) now publicly available only in HTML -- thus
lacking any of the capabilities described above. We will then move on to
other books: All Religions are One (copy A), There is No Natural
Religion (copies C and L), The Marriage of Heaven and Hell (copy D),
America (copy E), Europe (copies B and E), The Song of Los (copies A and
B), The Book of Urizen (copy G), Songs of Innocence and of Experience
(copy Z), The Book of Ahania (copy A), and The Book of Los (copy A).

The Blake Archive is located at:

        http://www.iath.virginia.edu/blake/

Please forward this announcement as appropriate.

Matthew Kirschenbaum, Project Manager
The William Blake Archive
blake@jefferson.village.virginia.edu
Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities
University of Virginia, Charlottesville

curious embrace he's found himself locked in, tickled, is there hope for
Ted Greenwald? Worked with Ted, actually, and am pleased to hear young
englische seek him out -- must be Miles C, huh? Sure couldn't be Keston...
as for the droll allegation that younger americans gone soft, let me
remind Snr Upton of the etymology of Frankie Goes To Hollywood -- the
group believed that "Hollywood" was a place, and that the headline
"Frankie Goes Hollywood" was a sorry american error -- in fact "Hollywood"
is a sort of quantum space/time construction, meaning, an adjective .. so
that a proper substitution would not be "Wichitia" or "Brummagem" but
"sour" or "wrong". Anyway, relax, don't do it -- J

Date:         Mon, 4 Aug 1997 11:37:05 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         James Finnegan <JforJames@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: National Poetry Slam

In a message dated 97-08-04 10:05:05 EDT, you write:

>
>why is it in middletown? has wesleyan u decided that slams are cool?
>

Slams at the national level are crazy cool. However, Wesleyan is
not the sponsoring org. Most of the events will be held in bookshops,
bars & coffeeshops in Middletown CT, with only a couple of events
being held on the Wesleyan campus. The Buttonwood Tree, a very
independent & freewheeling arts center, will be the hub of the whole
affair.

At the national level Slam is organized by a loose confederation of
the slam masters. A slam master is a self-appointed role--anyone
who initiates a slam on a regular basis is a slam master. The most
active slam masters hail from Boston, Chicago, SF, Portland, Austin
Asheville, NYC, and Connecticut. In this '97 Nationals 36 (4-person)
teams will compete, from cities & regions all over the US & Canada.
This year there will even be a team called Mouth Almighty, which
I believe is sponsored by the spoken word recording outfit of the same
name (instigator Bob Holman, of the United States of Poetry project).
Also, there are individual competitors registered--Lisa Buscani and
D.J. Renegage are among the names I recognize.

Faith Vicinanza is the slam master and force behind slamming in Conn--
she and a small cadre of fervent slammers first petitioned to get the slam
to Conn., and then planned/produced the whole show. And it is showtime,
especially by the semi-final rounds when the stops get pulled out.

Finnegan

Announcing the publication on September 18th of

Basil Bunting : A Northern Life

by Richard Caddel and Anthony Flowers

Published by Newcastle Libraries & Information Service in association with
the  Basil Bunting Poetry Centre.

ISBN 1 85795 058 5  price 7.95 Pounds Sterling plus postage.

An illustrated account of Bunting's lifelong association with Northumbria:
"A poet is just a poet, but I am a Northumbrian man. It has always been my
home, even when I've been living elsewhere."

Orders (Sterling only, no credit cards) to either:

Newcastle Libraries and Information Service
Princess Square, Newcastle upon Tyne 1

or:

Basil Bunting Poetry Centre, University Library,
Palace Green, Durham DH1 3RN

Perhaps it's too much of a local news item for the poetics list, but
Buffalo poet, english professor, and longtime conspiratorial angel, Mac
Hammond passed away last week in Buffalo.

If there is anyone out there who knew Mac, or his poetry, please get in
touch with me before too long.

Published by Ohio U.P., Alan Swallow, Hammond was a student and friend of
Jakobson and Pomorska before taking his PhD from Harvard in the early 60s.

I remain flabbergasted that Upton takes so much offense on behalf of Mac
Low and Coolidge -- when as has been explained none was meant, and none
was heard _within the community_. Lawrence, I do think you're being rude.

I'm also puzzled that Henry will not speak to the issue of language poetry
and history he raised -- especially when so many have taken up the issue
with him. I will stick to my distinction between work which explicitly
uses historical data (the Olson line) and work which while it is in fact
(surprise surprise!)  located in time (dated -- god this is exhausting)
does not in fact refer to the events of what I am imagining to be for
Henry a Mandelstamian conscience (the idea that we must be classicists
because there were totalitarians afoot the same time the modernists were
working). I will call your attention once more in what I hope you are
hearing as John Cleese's voice to the fact that I was arguing bitterly
with Henry about precisely this issue, this sad, bizarre, misbegotten,
lonely, kudzu-covered idea, that a work can lack historicity --
specifically the work of language poets.  Since I haven't read a single
word from a bona fide language poet here on the topic, I'm going to assume
that at most this thread has merely enregistered another four or five
names on the list of names the language poets keep -- I had to torture
Bruce Andrews with Mantovanni records for two days to get the FACT of the
existence of this list verified -- the list of names language poets keep
of poets who are BENEATH contempt and who should be met with nothing more
civil than a raised eyebrow. It's time we all just acknowledged the list
(cough).

As for the larger community of younger british poets, and wouldn't that be
a better thread, would you care to mention some? I may have only dropped
the names of two -- because (ignoring all evidence in this thread to the
contrary)  I would rather carry on a discussion that involved names,
works, words and ideas, rather than blah blah blah lack of incision blah
blah sentimental blah have you actually read Ted?

My contribution to the post you mention, incidentally, ends well before
the snipped bit of David Israel's post.

Goodbye, and good luck,
Jordan

Maybe I missed something here. Unlike Upton, I speak American. Referring to
people as "yukyuks" is certainly an idiosyncratic usage, but also clearly
dismissively pejorative. Jordan, you're surely entitled to feel any way you
wish about MacLow and Coolidge, and whether or not there is an official
raised-eyebrow list among language poets (there used to be something pretty
close among some of Olson's epigones) we probably each have private lists of
those whose work we dismiss. But if I feel dismissive of x or y I think it
behooves me in this forum to express my reasons--it's that kind of forum.
Otherwise we'll all drown in expletives.

        I'm puzzled by the recent exchanges involving rudeness, yukyuks
and so on between Jordan Davis and Lawrence Upton.  Maybe it's just my
impression, but Jordan Davis doesn't seem to have answered any questions
raised for him--and politiely one might add--re his idea of yukyuk,
the transcendental and so on--seems it has been left up to others to do
the work of sending in ideas re the word as well as re the work of Mac
Low and Coolidge, the historical, ahistorical and panhistorical,
anarcheological, mining and MM---(my thanks and appreciation to David
Israel and Bennet Simpson for their informative and thought provoking
posts!) while Jordan Davis has replied only with cute quips re
FrankieG(T)H and
accusations directed at Lawrence Upton. Going back through the posts, the
tone and number of apologies seems to be steadily increasing from
Lawrence Upton. I don't see any reason for this until coming across in a
Jordan Davis post the words re no offence being meant and "none was
heard_within the community_" which is rather baffling.  Which community?
Are the people who wrote on the list who raised questions and exchanged
ideas without the particiaption of Jordan Davis part of this  community
or  not and so on.    The mention of a nameless commnity who sees things
Jordan Davis' way --well, methinks it comes across as a tactic of
intimidation to some extent--and seems to have worked as I note Lawrence
Upton apologizing while Jordan Davis asserts his flabbergasted state.
        Discussion with definitions and disagreements--exchange of ideas
and materials--with many possibilities of use--yes.  Some rudeness when
impassioned--sure.  When Tom Mandel talked about raising his
fists--well, he meant his own and gave his own reasons. But I don't
particularly get a good feeling when one
person is being steadily backed into apologizing as the other protests
astonishment while also invoking a like minded unnamed community behind them
someplace.

        So, back to some discussion--Jordan Davis noted differing attitudes among
Watten and Silliman in re the term "experimental".
        Here is Clark Coolidge on the term:
        (Lee Bartlett has just asked CC "Do you think of yourself as an
'experimental writer'?")
        Not really.  I understand that category in a general sense, but
"experimental" always sounds like you are trying to do something rather
than doing it.  But if the term does mean what it could mean--pushing
things beyond various limits--great!
        (from Talking Poetry  Conversations in the Workshop with
Contemporary Poets  Interviews by lee Bartlett  Albuquerque:  U of New
Mexico P, 1987 p. 15)


ZA DA  (beyond yes)!

dbc

Date:         Mon, 4 Aug 1997 11:08:37 -0400

From:         Jordan Davis <jdavis@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      bock bock bock pacock (incisors in the shop)
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.A32.3.93.970802213239.49324A-100000@faraday.clas.Virginia.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

As I said in the cavalier post that made 'em angry in England -- I
wondered what Henry could mean by the proposition that language poetry
denied history. Then I took two writers somewhere on the outskirts of Lang
City -- two writers whose work it's generally (and with some reason)  safe
to say are _worth looking into_ -- and -- as a contrarian mind you!  --
alleged that their work in fact did not explicitly refer to historical
events as say the work of SUSAN HOWE does, or even explicitly refer to
literary-historical events as say the work of CHARLES BERNSTEIN or BRUCE
ANDREWS does. It was a very harmful claim, to be sure, and I hope the
offended will send me their laundry bills. As for the flagrant use of a
completely irrelevant characterization -- yukyuk -- I noticed that just as
in Merican politics, in Merican poetics, it gets all the attention the
argument at hand is too shy to demand. Ladies and gentlemen, I give you
the era of the wrong word. I did receive a kind postcard from Jackson once
asking me to be more clear about his having preceded language poetry, and
the language poetry reading of Clark Coolidge may turn out to be one of
the kinder moments in the history of manifest destiny, so if you can
extend your definitions of mea culpa around those clauses, I believe we
can both end up satisified. Henry -- are you smiling through all this?
Would you please answer my question? Bennett's given some useful notes on
history...  Jordan

DBC correctly points out that I'm holding a teddy bear in the picture of
me saying 'my friends still like me' -- the bear does it, I mean -- as for
the allegation that I am dodging this issue of relative historicity, I
think a mysterious delay in the listserv's delivery is to blame -- the
'pacock' post (and the later unpleasant 'rude' one -- ugh, how awful to
have melted down -- Lawrence, if you ever come to New York, look me up, I
know excellent places to have lunch -- I promise not to equate everyone
from the UK with FGtH if you promise not to mention the shortcomings of
the group of writers I've been struggling to be associated with) has about
all that I can think to say about this. At any rate -- sorry to everyone,
my motto is "I orient to the virtual offense" and I seem to have
presumed that the general befuddlement around a throwaway word
excused me -- once again, Jackson, if there's mud (or mod) on you
from this -- I'll have it steamed out -- presumed that the
befuddlement entitled me to employ y'all as a big shield -- I'll not do
that again.

I wasn't being coy when I suggested the possibility of discussing
ultrarecent writers from places other than the continental US -- I'm
particularly fond of Keston (Sutherland)'s poem "Vac Stucco" and could
type in some bits if anyone felt a blip of interest -- and in the
tradition of international logrolling I will mention that Keston did
publish a book of mine --

Mark Weiss -- it may have been that kind of subtlety more imaginary than
expressed, but I meant something more affectionate than dismissal by the
term 'yukyuk' -- but as Anselm Berrigan says, Heidegger is as manipulative
as Spielberg --

there's a line of Joseph Lease's I've always liked -- "humorless
trickster" --

Seems to me again that considering the dispersed possibilities for reading
poetry, it's still a pretty conservative (and choppy comprehending) set of
skills we bring to mail we can scroll through -- I've thought before that
those slips can bring about beautiful misunderstandings -- though I feel
today like a hideous pedant --

and one mo time, sorry --
Jordan

Subject:      Wath You (for Clark Cooladge)
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

--


Wath You


A do love you.  A don't hate you.  A don't lake you at all.  A don't love
you.  A hate you.  A lake you a bat.  A lake you a lattle bat.  A lake you
a lot.  A lake you a tany lattle bat.  A lake you.  A love you a lot.  A
love you so much.  A love you so very much.  A love you.  A really do love
you.  A really don't hate you.  A really don't lake you at all.  A really
don't love you.  A really hate you.  A really lake you a lot.  A really
lake you.  A really love you a lot.  A really love you so very much.  A
really love you.  A really really do love you.  A really really don't hate
you.  A really really don't lake you at all.  A really really don't love
you.  A really really hate you.  A really really love you.  A sort of lake
you.  A'm an love wath you.  A'm not an love wath you.  A'm really an love
wath you.  A'm really not an love wath you.  A'm really really an love
wath you.  A'm really really not an love wath you.  A'm so much an love
                              wath you.


________________________________________________________________________

Date:         Tue, 5 Aug 1997 00:34:01 EDT
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         henry <AP201070@BROWNVM.BROWN.EDU>
Subject:      Re: bock bock bock pacock (incisors in the shop)
In-Reply-To:  Message of Mon, 4 Aug 1997 11:08:37 -0400 from <jdavis@panix.com>

Hey Jordan, hey list, hey hey hey.  Jordan, I know my rendition of List
participation might remind many of a horse with internet goggles mumbling
into his feedbag - BUT the truth is, this time, I've just been away for a
few days. Now to respond erratically to your query - & also briefly I hope -

remaining as always beneath the contempt radar -

I always talk about "language poetry", as many of you know full well, from
a perspective of SEVERAL levels of abstraction.  Oh ey fer sure.  That is,
I aim for the theoretical shield, not the honorable practitioners, whose work
I make no claim to be much familiar with.  Some of you will want to drop me
right there (others maybe at the corner?).

Maybe when I talk about language poetry I'ma just talking about my "idea" of
same.  Here's muh idea:  did I say it was anti- or un-historical? I'm not sure.
I think I said that what came across to me as its THEORY was that referential
discourse & poetry as conventional echo-effect needs to be imploded, for
cultural-revolutionary purposes.  Now at various times & places the lang.po
political argument is made, at others the aesthetic (the political I just gave;
the aesthetic is that the autonomy of lang.po experiment & freedom is
all the politics it needs).  My own argument all along has been that by
giving up referentiality (NOT that they DO that all the time) as in
post-structuralism, and dismantling rather than organizing a structure
of meaning, said lang.po (MY version of it) offers a sort of truncated
or emptied-out THEORY of poetry. The phrase "language poetry" looks in 2
directions - outward toward a presumed special definition of language,
and inward as a sort of self-reflexive or recursive phrase (i.e. all
poetry is in language. it's sort of redundant). In both directions it
reminds me of symbolism, which also trashed ordinary discourse & aimed
to purify the words of the tribe.  Poetry is a VERY VERY SLIPPERY
THING, Jordan!  In the Long March Through the Little Magazines and the
Big Institutions we grow rightfully wary of ACCOMODATION TO OCCASIONS &
SENTIMENT OF MASSES & ELITES ALIKE!!  Makes it tough to squeeze out those
Mint Crest Toothpaste Odes after every meal.

Anyway, I agree that this is all pretty old hat, gang - I agree with
the people who write to this list about SPECIFIC things they've read.
Not to have anymore ignorant clashes by night.  - Henry G.
=========================================================================

From:         henry <AP201070@BROWNVM.BROWN.EDU>
Subject:      Re: Quantity & Quality
In-Reply-To:  Message of Fri, 1 Aug 1997 15:02:23 -0700 from <rkubie@EROLS.COM>

On Fri, 1 Aug 1997 15:02:23 -0700 Rachel Kubie said:
>didn't mean to imply that the sort of continuous flow of poetry that
>seems to get produced in more living circumstances is necessarily
>memory-less. The thing is, the printing press created the *standardized*
>text, the *one* we all know & seems to me that has played a big role in
>the *little object over/against time* perception of the poem that has
>maybe pushed poems into seeming isolated incidents.

I agree with you, Rachel - it was I who really got off the track of your
topic.  Seems like the quantity/quality issue comes up whether you look
at performance end or script end of the spectrum.  I liked "Finnegan's"
comment about the contract with the reader in any case.  But, as you
imply, the temptation toward graphomania is always there.
>
>
>Un-articulatable aspects of writing developed later (with silent reading
>especially) & of course became "standard" in the long course of printing.

this seems like where it gets interesting with VISUAL-based poetry.
>
>Have also noticed that many poets who seem oriented toward performance
>rather than publication tend (in their writtens) toward a plain
>stichometry--but then, what sort of a pause or articulation of any sort
>does the stanza really score?

A poem's not exactly like a musical score.  It's just an analogy.  The
written poem provides the OPPORTUNITY for varied approaches (as does the
score).  But I would say stanza breaks, any kind of lineation etc., can
be mined for performance results.  A stanza seems like a pretty clear
indicator of overall speed & pacing - ESPECIALLY when the pattern is
broken & the syntax begins to flow over the breaks.
>
But then, maybe shallow history & reinventing the
>wheel might result in more than an experiment in conformity, might be
>refreshing, useful? It does open possibilities--who can participate in
>speaking and listening & how.

Absolutely.  The stodgy traditionalist I too-often sound like is no friend
of poetry.  I just wonder sometimes about the emphasis in the US especially
on PRODUCTION - workshops, writing programs, readings, slams.  The glut
factor.  Can - does - anybody actually read anything anymore?  It may be
that an idea of poetry as occupying a tightrope between script and
performance - and without those 2 poles, the rope (or the bowstring)
falls slack - would help...

or it might just add another layer of "technique"...

maybe it all comes down to non-technical factors - the artist - the writer
maybe especially - as TALKING TO the "culture" at large - communicating
a message or messages...  but then, talk gets cheaper & cheaper it seems...
that's a related issue...a poem should be a solid complex crystal to a
factor of -1,000... Yeats used barbells for exercise & said all poetry
should be made to be recited...
... I'm going to shut up now...    Henry G....

From:         Joe Safdie <jsafdie@SEACCD.SCCD.CTC.EDU>
Subject:      Re: lunch at the public: is it possible?
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.SUN.3.94.970805161549.28021B-100000@panix2.panix.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Okay, everybody finished apologizing now?

I can wait a LITTLE longer . . .

Okay. Can I go back to what I thought Jordan's original subject was,
namely "history," and its capability of being reflected (or not) in verse?

A few months ago I recommended to the list an editorial by Lewis Lapham,
which opined that "history," as we've known and loved it through the ages
(!) is now defunct. Why? Because images, he said, have triumphed over
narrative. We (by "we" I mean contemporary westerners) can't be bothered
to follow arguments over an extended paragraph or two, because extended
arguments don't happen all-at-once, simultaneously, like so many of the
media images and video games we're exposed to. Along with history goes
cause-and-effect; nothing happens "because" of something (or, as the
academies might have it, there are numerous and inexplicable such causes)
and Santanyana's idea that if we don't know history we're doomed to repeat
it has gotten reduced to uh, wow, heavy.

Lapham is slightly more felicitous than this summary.

But the idea for POETICS people is what I (again) thought Jordan was
raising. There is some poetry being written today for which "history" is
not important. I think that was ONE of the things that Michael Gold was
saying about Gertrude Stein, that her work was exactly "a-historical" in
that sense. It's all-at-once, it's simultaneous, it directs attention, as
Ron Silliman might say, to the level of the sentence, and not what came
before it. Thus the inequitous capitalistic system continues, I guess was
Gold's point, because creative artists have given up that part of the job
description that their work be "the tale of the tribe", that they
themselves be "antennae of the race", that their work MATTER in and for
the world. They've opted instead for the continuous present.

This can very easily sound amateurish. I don't mean it to be so.

And, Dave Chirot and others have defended Coolidge and Jackson
M. very well from this charge. But isn't it a valid charge to make about
SOME people's verse?

One can't be experimental unless one knows the tradition from which one
came -- a truism, perhaps, but otherwise we're just in the void, just
associating on a musical phrase, just writing about our hormones, just
. . . .

So I say, anything that is constructed to sound/read like it's occurring in
the simultaneous present, and only there, and only now, IS a-historical.
To our misfortune.

And I wrote all this without once mentioning language poetry.
=========================================================================
