What is preceived to be  a-historical  may not be at all. It's  depends on
ones perspective. History  defined from   one  point of view of   that
single  point on  the  horizon line    maybe  just  as  ahistorical  as
and  not "the tale  of the tribe' as   what   is being  perceived as
"a-historical."

Artists haven't "give  up their job"  they may  just be perceiving
something different.

Every  generation has been   criticized for a  short attention span.  A
hundred years ago   this  was  the complaint   registered against  the
Impressionist and   the Paris  audience. They  were  a "hysterical" group
that couldn't   concentrate.

Date:         Tue, 5 Aug 1997 23:33:54 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Alan J Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      You
MIME-Version: 1.0

(tiny romantic poem, not Jennifer, not Julu, in the strange world of the
Poetics-space, slightly out of place, sometimes I cry myself to sleep)
-++--


You


Your packets and mine, intertwined, subdomains alternating one after ano-
ther, caressing your ascii-encoded limbs, opening your email over and over
again;

holding my breath against your domain address, turning towards, always
towards, your name in my Inbox, reading your full header, pausing at each
stage tracerouting myself to you, and back, journey of space, copper, and
fiber-optic heavens;

calling out your URL in my sleep, dreaming your green words on my black
screen, voicing your writing, speaking it quietly in your absent voice,
and I close my eyes, imagine the play of interrupts from keyboard through
server out to the wide wide world;

wanting you here, no longer driven by pixels bitmapped through checksums
and error-codes, wanting you here;

wanting you here, wanting you here and hating distance and impossibility,
and lags, and message-bases, and five layers of numerous protocols, seven
layers of others, two layers of ascii code, one layer of beating hearts,
filter systems and error warnings, country-code after country code inter-
spersed in the midst of unknown ISPs and Netstorms, wanting nothing more
than the loving touch of an arm, weight of a finger against lips, parted,
and

just about to speak, and silent, and no need to say anything more



_________________________________________________________________________

Now available: Fragmente 7 (1997) ed. Anthony Mellors

New poetry by Frances Presley, Barry MacSweeney, Tony Lopez, John
Kinsella, Kelvin Corcoran, Jennifer Moxley, Andrew Lawson, Robert
Sheppard, Alan Halsey, Anthony Mellors, Peter Larkin, DS Marriott, Tracy
Ryan, Richard Caddel and others...

Hugh Steinberg wrote:

> >>Okay. Can I go back to what I thought Jordan's original subject
> >>was, namely "history," and its capability of being reflected (or
> >>not) in verse?
>
> I'd like to take this from another angle:  why shouldn't a writer
> want to write through/about history?  I can't think of a richer,
> more delicious field to pursue/romp through.  If history is the
> field in which language is embedded in, why not explore that place?

all that stuff about writers abdicating their duty by getting lost in
the contours of the ahistorical present, rather than dutifully
directing the minions of readers to the place where decisions are
made: the world of jostle & bustle & power & schmauer -- could be
usefully turned on its head, in my hysterical opinion (imho).

Possibly the artistic imperative is to get OUT of histoery a little
step or two now & then, eh? -- cf. the sort of ahistorical time =
mythic time (paradoxically, participating in the "true history of the
tribe") suggested by Mircea Eliade in *The Myth of The Eternal
Return*.  To paraphrase, that august historian of the prehistorical
proposes that in storytelling ritual of arcane cultures, the first
and most basic thing that happens is an exit from "profane time" and
an entry into the symbol world of collective mythic events -- in
particular, "what happened" at the beginning of things (i.e., in
another level of reality) that *generated* the historical particulars
of the world we see . . .

Arguably, this manner of radical phase-shift has very much been a
concern of poets of many a stripe & clime & chimney, -- throughout,
um, history . . .

d.i.

Date:         Wed, 6 Aug 1997 07:59:47 EDT

From:         henry g <AP201070@BROWNVM.BROWN.EDU>
Subject:      Re: ahistroical lunch
In-Reply-To:  Message of Wed, 6 Aug 1997 01:47:29 -0600 from
              <hsteinberg@GRIN.NET>

I could be wrong, but I think Jordan's original reference was to a debate
here many moons ago over Mutlu Blasing's book POLITICS & FORM IN POSTMODERN
POETRY, where she criticized the Olson-language poetry vein for following
Pound into a too-easy melding of poetry & politics, poetry & history - in
favor of her own pantheon of "really" postmodernists who more "intelligently"
[my quotes] follow the zeitgeist of ironizing & questioning & ambiguizing
the reality-element or referential quality of poetry, in their poetry.

In this stream, the critical perspective of Blasing, De Man, et al. takes
New Criticism & gives it an extra twist, but the outcome is about the same.

James Longenbach's book on Wallace Stevens has a very good analysis of this
whole issue in relation to politics & poetry in the 30s, when this was all
debated very intensely.  Basically, the issue of the poet's & poetry's place
in "the world" was extremely important to Stevens who wavered between left &
right tendencies [o.k. I know I'm SIMPLIFYING] & came down to the position
that poetry was not the Shelleyan unacknowledged legislator, that politics
and public action is better accomplished by politics & public action, but
that poetry does have a role in a shared collective life by working out
its own special energies.  Stevens was close to Kenneth Burke (another one
blasted by Michael Gold & the dogmatists) & the italian philospher Croce
- ambiguity in poetry was not an expression of language's inherent
nominalism or of some totalizing postmodern language philosophy, but was
a TOOL for really reflecting the many-sided moral complexity of history
& politics.  Only AFTER the 30s did this become New Critical dogma &
the academicization of the poetry industry got underway.

In my own view "history" is just an essential basic quality of time
& that poetry would reflect on it should be taken for granted.  This is
just the beginning of discovering what a particular poem or poet is
saying, doing, making.  It also might be the great theme or deep vision
[or little quirk] of the poem, its essential focus.  I think ambiguity here
is welcome because the arguments that 1) history is just one damn thing
after another and 2) history ignored is complacent stupidity are both right
at some level.  What makes a poem as opposed to a chronicle? - Henry Gould

Thanks, Hugh, Henry, (Alan), and David, for some pointers on
disynchrony/asynchrony I mean diachronics I mean Braudel I mean whatever.
(Whatever is not a code word!) Letter to the New Yorker this week from a
Mr Dye in the nwest who complains that after Auden poetry has ceased to be
memorable speech and has settled for "much less" -- a kind of shorthand
epistemology, esp. in the work of Jorie Graham and John Ashbery.

But isn't the 'how-do-I-know' of Ashbery's work not that far from Stevens
not that far from Coleridge? I mean, can't one take Auden as a kind of
popularizing freak (freak is a code word), a sort of forgiveable (because
surprising) version of Wynton Marsalis? (And aren't there a lot of
audenesque tendencies in Ashbery? the doggerel, the encyclopedic command
of form -- or at least the occasional mention of obscure forms -- these
are not putdowns!)

I mention the New Yorker letter because the symptom I see there, in
Henry's version of Blasing, and all over the place all the time -- is the
complain that poetry loses something .. that it is less than. It is always
less than.

Oh well! As we know, the category of the 'always-already' is a great zone
for arbitrage and not much else. Historin', as a much larger poet used to
say, means to find out for yourself.

Still/here,
Jordan

Seems to me the question is whether & to what degree the micro-political is
historical. I don't think in the end totalizing social-constructivist
arguments hold up-- that's because no context is finite. What's happening &
what happened -- same question? One could say there is a dialectic betweeen
history & not-history relative to artistic activity of any sort & I would
relate that dialectic to a similar (asimilar?) dialectic between sense &
nonsense.

maria, I don't mean to monkeywrench your issue, but is it clear that the
avant-garde is _more_ closed than other non-mainstream movements in
contemporary poetics?  It seems to me that policing is a component of any
contested subfield within the larger field, and that such communities as
"new formalist" and "performance" poetics each have their own forms of
policing.  What, in your view, are the distinguishing marks, if any, of
avant-garde self-policing as such?  Or have I misunderstood your question
(lately, with me, more likely than not)?

the idea of "history" as we know it (progress or retreat over time)
also contains the idea of utopia (what transcends itself).  For a
lot of poets in the midst of 20th cent. utopias/despair the idea of
hope was indeed micro-political, i.e., domestic in different ways.
For Stevens, for example, the humdrum, the everyday, the normal
is where to look for sanity & hope.  the Dutch in him.  Williams too,
in a way.  & Mandelstam talked again & again about the utopia of the
household.  just ONE other aspect of all this.  Justice has a
practical, sensible side... & "divine philology", for OM, was
a bunch of students & a teacher sitting around talking. vodkayaking.

"Literature is a beast, furred by night & winter"  - Mandelstam

>okay all you sweet yukyuks out there, i've got a question: why does "the

Maria, I don't think it's true that there is any unified thing such as "the
avant garde." And I think most people involved in practices which might be
considered such, do not feel such a need to police the borders. I do think
that some of those who might want to so police borders can be quite loud
about such policing. And such loudness gets a lot of attention, at least in
the short term.

But it's just not like a gated community.

charles

For those interested in developments related to the Yasusada
writings, I thought I'd mention the following:

Today, August 6th, the Asahi Shimbun (the equivalent to NY Times in
Japan, circulation 8.5 million), is going to publish an extensive
story on Yasusada and the reaction to his writings in this country.

Recently, there have been other articles (though I haven't seen any
of them yet) in Australia in the Sydney Morning Herald, in England
in the Manchester Guardian and in Poetry Review, in Mexico in
Octavio Paz's Vuelta, and in Spain in Lateral, a monthly from
Barcelona. The Denver Quarterly will soon be publishing a special
section on Yasusada in its upcoming issue, including an interview
with myself and Javier Alvarez and a letter to Tosa Motokiyu from
Mikhail Epstein. Other things are scheduled to appear elsewhere, and
I'll mention them for information's sake as they appear if no
one else does.

Good to be back! I like Maria Damon's question freshly posted: Just
what *is* the "avant-garde"? And what sort of thing does it do?
Kent

Maria=97
I'd like to put in with both Charles & David here for
a closer scrutiny of "avant garde". I take it that the
term is convenient, but dangerous as it quickly leads
to the concept of a *unified* ["muffled"] avant garde,
usually defined as either "pure nonsense", as against
the rich diversity of "traditional" works (& this
argument seems almost always to have something to
do with its being "inhuman" or "asocial", though it
might be of the more general variety Jordan rehearsed
a few moments ago=97!? etime, I guess=97, viz., the
fallenness of contemporary art/man [sic]); or or defined
as "innovative" ["freshness sealed"], as against the
stale practices of the "academicians" or unselfconscious
"mainstream" verse ["oops, another one"].

I think we're all subject to this kind of easy distinction,
at least from time to time (or anyway I am), & that's
fine & useful so long as we acknowledge that "avant garde",
or for that matter the "arriere garde" ["nobody ever said
it, man"], are shorthand for multiple subfields (thanks
to David-Pierre Kellogg!), whose practices don't really
fulfill "the dream of a unified field", & may even be
deeply conflictual.

interesting that you cite "the closedness of the avant garde
tradition" as in part "the way it's construed by most of its
critics"=97I wld say=97ah but it were a lie, being only partly
true=97that necessary policing by critics=97& there's the rub=97
indicates how unstable the use of such ["their"] an umbrella
term really is, & its distance from practice. of course, as
David has already noted, all subfields of a given field (in this
case the field of poetic production, or as he wld call it, "the
poetic")=97& not even just the highly contested ones=97do
their own policing ["the police in voices"].

Chris
..
Christopher W. Alexander etc.
nominative press collective

http://choengmon.lib.utah.edu/~calexand/nonce

Subject:      "*alternative*avant-garde"

>At 09:14 AM 8/6/97 -0500, you wrote:
>>okay all you sweet yukyuks out there, i've got a question: why does "the
>>avant garde" seem to need to police its borders so rigidly?  how does some
>>thing get defined or not as "avant garde?" i'm spozed to give a talk in
>>November and i want to challenge what i see as some of the closedness of
>>the avant garde tradition or at least the way it's construed by most of its
>>critics.--md
>

there's been a lot of talk about this issue of late (here and elsewhere),
and i'm wondering if anyone else feels the same confusion about it / the
spatial analogy here, that the a-g is a particular zone or area of activity
and therefore identifiable by its borders (and its potential policing of
borders) is the main source of my confusion / when did the "avant garde"
come to represent a group or subgroup or "subfield in a larger field" as
David Kellogg puts? -- the classificatory scheme strikes me as fundamentally
at odds with what the a-g has always represented to me, namely a kind of
momentum that infuses artistic activities and (sometimes) instigates change
/ if current notions of an avant-garde stipulate that it exists as a group
among groups (and i agree with Charles Alexander that it is not a "unified
thing"), then clearly there must be an *alternative* avant-garde which
escapes such classification -- which makes it even more confusing  / if the
a-g is the *leading edge* of activity, then how can an edge have a "border"?
not to mention a police force monitoring transgressions / i can't imagine
(literally can't see) the avant-garde in such a context... / wouldn't any
definition of the a-g as a group be a misappropriation of the term?

bill marsh

>

Whoa there.  The continuous present --- the real one, not the fake one of
tv ads and video games --- is a pretty damn good antidote to any inequitous
system, and the level of the sentence is a good innoculator against the
bullshit causality that proudly brings you Northern Ireland,the Balkans
(Bosnia not being the only manifestation of that particular tangle), the
Middle East, Rwanda and Burundi, Afghanistan, the Khmer Rouge, etc. etc.

Spandrift tells me there's a Super Poet named Jeff out there.  Lives near
him in Weast Fareaver Ambiguity, Wyo.  Jeff manages to combine history,
correct politics, political incorrectedness, playful verbal pyromania,
emotive heart-schmoozing, lovable mistakes, insane fury, loose jams
within tight stanzas, experiment WITH traditional mayonnaise, slang in
less than 3 languages, and quick shifts in technique - all in
the form of INNOVATIVE HAIKU!!!  Ashbery has a blurb about him INSIDE
the blurbs on the outside of his latest book.

There was a movie at Sundance about him, called "Where's Jeff?"  I think
it stars Jeff Bridges.  Spandrift looked at me seriously over a lid of
chew the other day and said, "I'd vote for Jeff for President right now -
President of Boulder."  - Henry Gould

From:         Peter Landers <landers@FRONTIERNET.NET>
Subject:      yuk yuk

Clark Coolidge was seeking a personal language. He felt that words came
from others, perhaps he felt they were abused by others, and therefore he
wanted to let them stand alone or in groups without necessarily meaning
what people thought them to mean. The hope was that the words would begin
to work as sound objects. Yuk yuk.

Jackson MacLow is involved in the very historical, or pre-historical
process of poetry-as-shamanism. Sounds, dance, words in new peronal
ritual. Write rite. Yuk yuk.

All best to you, Jordan, but I dig these guys, y'know :-)

Pete

On Wed, 6 Aug 1997, william marsh wrote:

> >At 09:14 AM 8/6/97 -0500, you wrote:
> >>okay all you sweet yukyuks out there, i've got a question: why does "the
> >>avant garde" seem to need to police its borders so rigidly?  how does some
> >>thing get defined or not as "avant garde?" i'm spozed to give a talk in
> >>November and i want to challenge what i see as some of the closedness of
> >>the avant garde tradition or at least the way it's construed by most of its
> >>critics.--md
> >
>
> there's been a lot of talk about this issue of late (here and elsewhere),
> and i'm wondering if anyone else feels the same confusion about it / the
> spatial analogy here, that the a-g is a particular zone or area of activity
> and therefore identifiable by its borders (and its potential policing of
> borders) is the main source of my confusion / when did the "avant garde"
> come to represent a group or subgroup or "subfield in a larger field" as
> David Kellogg puts? -- the classificatory scheme strikes me as fundamentally
> at odds with what the a-g has always represented to me, namely a kind of
> momentum that infuses artistic activities and (sometimes) instigates change
> / if current notions of an avant-garde stipulate that it exists as a group
> among groups (and i agree with Charles Alexander that it is not a "unified
> thing"), then clearly there must be an *alternative* avant-garde which
> escapes such classification -- which makes it even more confusing  / if the
> a-g is the *leading edge* of activity, then how can an edge have a "border"?
> not to mention a police force monitoring transgressions / i can't imagine
> (literally can't see) the avant-garde in such a context... / wouldn't any
> definition of the a-g as a group be a misappropriation of the term?

Isn't the charge of misappropriation itself a form of policing?  I guess
it depends who you're talking to (about).  I realize spatial metaphors
such as the Bourdieu/Foucault "field" have their disadvantages, but they
may tend to counter the possible mystification of "a kind of momentum
that unfuses artistic activities."

Cheers,
David

bill's sense ov (or puzzlement over) the question matches mine,
my idea of a.g. as (b)leeding edge of activity, rather than th
consolidated camps just behind th front lines.  but to carry the
military analogy further, how does the advance guard actually work?
in cadres & cels, with an intense group loyalty & distrust of the
enemy all around...  appropriate and adaptive during th heavy
fighting, but disfunctional afterwords.

and praps that points to the problem--the term "avant garde" gets
attached to certain activity, and then stays stuck long after it's
accurate.  certain aspects of langpo might have been a.g., or free
jazz... but are they still?  well, for some folks probably so--if
bebop is as far as your ears have gotten, than albert ayler is a.g....
sometimes, too, the a.g. designer label is claimed by folks as a
marketing tool, especially in a popular culture such as ours,
that values The New as latest/greatest.  & that too can lead to
the dynamics that maria's pointing to--seige mentality, whether
or no it's "justified"...

(btw, i'm casting no aspersions & making no claims for what poetics
are "legitimatly" a.g., whatever that might mean, & hope no one else will...
that's one slippery slope we've been down several times too often...)

and finally, in maria's initial posting, she referes to "_the_ avant
garde" (emphasis added), and i'm wondering if you'll be more specific, md?
because i don't see a.g. activity, even in areas poetical, as being
singular but rather diverse...  hard for me to imagine a guerrilla
war against the Established Culture launching a frontal offensive,
there are lots ov little forays goin on...  some (i'll mention Mail
Art, fr one) strike me as very unprotective & open.  what specific
a.g.s are you thinking ov?

asever
luigi

Date:         Wed, 6 Aug 1997 22:19:22 -0400

From:         Rachel Levitsky <levitsk@IBM.NET>
Subject:      Re: "*alternative*avant-garde"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

We're not supposed to talk to anyone who isn't going to do the avant garde
thing with this poetics list.  R. Tejada labels a certain something as
"advanced writing" and A. Sondheim asks in response to my question who are
the 'best writers?'  My take and the point I think I was making in my
question about art and advertisement is do we still somehow believe the
'best' gets the job, the hot tub?  What happens to the idea of grass
rootification implied in the abdication of authorship while we are trying to
make a place for 'advanced' or 'avant garde.' I think of performance art that
never got recorded.  C. Harryman told me of a friend whose name I am
forgetting who did performance for an audience of one and no recording (later
a book--it is difficult to resist the notion that ones ideas are good and
should somehow be deciminated).  Are we interested (really) in consciousness
or (post-mortem) fame.  Benjamin says the artist can't make art with an
audience in mind but isn't defining ourselves as 'avant-garde' suggesting we
are reaching to an audience of the future?

Date:         Thu, 7 Aug 1997 01:15:18 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>

From:         Alan J Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      Re: "*alternative*avant-garde"
In-Reply-To:  <33E930AA.1B22@ibm.net>

I make art with an audience in mind; I possess post-mortem fame.

I was walking with my friend
I was walking with my friend Fido, Judith Rodenbeck, down Perry (where my
ex-wife lives with her Japanese boyfriend) (I think) and we were discus-
sing _milieu,_ in particular, the artworld milieu of the 70s.
How it gets reified, edited, year after year.
I knew the curator at the High Museum in Atlanta - he wanted to have a
show called Masterpieces of Conceptual Art

That was the nail in the coffin. Because in life, it's milieu, opposition,
interstices, rumor. Not this dream of phallic men.

Klaus Kertess once said to me it all comes out in the wash. But it doesn't
and boundaries, avant-garde and other - are self-inscribed.

I've yet to meet the artist who did _x_ to shock an audience, but I'd like
to shake her/his hand.

Even the Situationists, or especially the Situationists, were exclusion-
ists. (Word? Word!) Surrealism, Dada, was no better.

Avant-what, by whom?

I couldn't write without the thought of a reader, readers, that the
_thing_ like depression, would take hold, grab ground after death. For
that matter, I've died years ago.

I've never stolen anything - in answer to some rumors I've heard.

Alan

bill marsh sd:
> wouldn't any definition of the a-g as a group be a
> misappropriation of the term?

misappropriation? hmm, on the contrary, I'd
say that's exactly the function the term is serving
in this discussion.

it's interesting that you object to the spatialization
of the "avant garde", as my understanding of the the
term has always been as spatial metaphor (can we
have some help from the francophiles?), as opposed
for instance to the Americanism "before his/her time".
it seems awkward to paraphrase Bernstein here=97or
maybe what's awk. is referring to him as "Bernstein",
when he might be "right here with us" (more spatial-
ization, but I'm reminded more of a seance=97"are you
there, Charles? give us a sign...)=97but one has to
appreciate his assertion that, dammit, no one is
before their time=97ok, *really* paraphrasing=97the
gist of which, as I see it, is partly to bring to mind
the historicity of production, & partly to debunk
the sort of evolutionary narrative that is sometimes
made of the history of (& by extension contemporary)
poetic production.

in fact, I'd be willing to entertain the idea that, whatever
its shortcomings, the spatial metaphor we've been batting
about ["b-b-b- spit it out, kid"], & its attendant theory
(Pierre Bourdieu, Foucault, possibly de Certeau etc.),
might be an effort precisely to escape the apparent
linearity of history, in favor of a more complex view of
(in this case) poetic production as it occurs both in &
at a time. actually, David, I'd be very interested to
hear what you had to say abt. this. (in case some of
you list-folk don't know, David Kellogg has some
very fine articles out there in just this "area", which
I'd recommend, except that I'm @ work & can't give
you the specific citations).

anyway, sorry to pull the plug & run=97or does that
sound like a crude reference to euthanasia?=97, but I'm
signing off for a wk. to help our fellow listee Matthias
Regan move to San Francisco. in fact, he'll be arriving
here in just... 8 hours, give or take. ah, SF=97with such
a pleasant destination, who wldn't take a week, eh?

so, best to all, & I'll look forward to again reading your
scintillating conversation when I return.

Chris

Christopher W. Alexander etc.
nominative press collective

INTERNET, EARLY HISTORY: EXCHANGE STYLE EXAMPLES FROM:

SCENARIOS FOR USING THE ARPANET AT THE INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON
COMPUTER COMMUNICATION

Washington, D.C.
October 24-26, 1972


-------------------------------------------------------------------------


NOTE (Alan Sondheim, 1997): It's clear that the sample dialogs, use of
Weizenbaum's Eliza program, etc., are the ancestors of today's expert
systems - but at this point in time, they were most likely read as in-
cipient artificial mind (classic AI). Already real and virtual subject-
ivities interpenetrate.

The quoted sections above are formatted close to the original.

(Thanks to Alex McKenzie and BBN.)


------------------------------------------------------------------------


EARLY SAMPLE CONVERSATIONS ON BBN TENEX:

====

BBN TENEX === HOST #65

8. To link to the user at TTY7:

@ link [SP] 7 [CR]
LINK FROM ICCC, TTY 103
@ ;hello ray. [CR] _Messages over "link" should be preceded by semi-colon._
@ ;HELLO, WHO IS IT? _Questions and comments from TTY7._
@ ;this is abhay bhushan from mit, can you help me? [CR]
@ ;OF COURSE, HOW ARE YOU ABHAY?
@ ...... _Conversation continues._
@ ;nice talking to you. bye. [CR]
@ break [CR] _Break the "link", please._

====

BBN DOCTOR === HOST #69

3. To run DOCTOR:
@ run [SP] <hacks>doctor [CR}
BBN LISP-10 02-22-71
GOOD AFTERNOON.
TELL ME YOUR PROBLEMS.
PLEASE TERMINATE INPUT WITH A PERIOD OR QUESTION MARK.
* i have a big problem. _The user begins as in a psychiatric interview._
I AM NOT SURE I UNDERSTAND YOU FULLY. _The DOCTOR continues the interview
                                       in a lively fashion._
* my grandother has a gzorenplatz.
IS IT IMPORTANT TO YOU THAT YOUR GRANDMOTHER HAS A GZORENPLATZ?
...........
 _Continue dialog as your spirit carries you._
...........
* goodbye
IT'S BEEN MY PLEASURE, THAT'S $7.15 PLEASE.
NIL
<-

====

SCHOLAR ==== HOST #69

<- scholar() _After (possibly) looking at instructions, start the
              SCHOLAR dialog._

HELLO, MY NAME IS SCHOLAR. I WILL HELP YOU IN REVIEWING THE GEOGRAPHY OF
SOUTH AMERICA. THIS IS ABC REGIONAL HIGH SCHOOL. TODAY IS 24-OCT-72.

IF YOU HAVE CAREFULLY STUDIED YOUR INSTRUCTIONS, WE MAY BEGIN THE REVIEW
NOW.

WHEN YOU ARE READY TO START, TYPE READY --- REMEMBER TO TERMINATE EACH
LINE OF INPUT WITH AN ASTERISK * FOLLOWED BY A CARRIAGE RETURN.
* read* [CR] _Asterisk("*") is SCHOLAR's prompt character. You must,
              repeat MUST, terminate input to SCHOLAR with an asterisk
              ("*") and a carriage return before it will listen to you.
              Use control-a ("^A") to delete characters from your input
              line, i.e., the standard Tenex editing characters._
PLEASE TYPE YOUR NAME---MR., MISS, OR MRS. FOLLOWED BY FIRST NAME, MIDDLE
NAME OR MIDDLE INITIAL, AND LAST NAME.
* YOURNAME* [CR]
NAME OF YOUR INSTRUCTOR, PLEASE:
* warnock* [CR]
LET'S BEGIN OUR DISCUSSION NOW, "YOURNAME"
USE ONE OF THE FOLLOWING:
14400000
3600000
1200000
1800000
TO ANSWER THE QUESTION:
APPROX WHAT IS THE AREA OF BRAZIL?
* 14400000* [CR]
WRONG,
I'LL GIVE YOU ANOTHER CHANCE.
* 3600000* [CR]
VERY GOOD.
.................
   _Continue your dialog as you wish. When tired, type control-c ("^C")
   to return to EXEC on logout.
.................
^c

====


CONVERSATION ON UCLA SEX SYSTEM:


UCLA-NMC SIGMA-7 === HOST #1

5. To use the toy question answering program, TIMMY, type:
! TIMMY [CR]
002 TIMMY STARTED
MY NAME IS TIMMY THE TERMINAL, WHAT'S YOURS?
YOURNAME [CR]
PLEASED TO MEET YOU, YOURNAME   HAVE WE MET BEFORE?
NO [CR]
SORRY, BUT I HAVE A TERRIBLE MEMORY FOR NAMES. ANYWAY, MY JOB IS TO ANSWER
YOUR QUESTIONS SO, ASK AWAY.
WHEN WILL THIS COMPUTER CRASH NEXT? [CR]
ABOUT 5 O'CLOCK.
........   _Ask any number of your own questions of TIMMY._
GOODBY [CR] _Exit from TIMMY._

At 05:57 PM 8/6/97 -0400, you wrote:

David,
>>  wouldn't any definition of the a-g as a group be a misappropriation of

interesting typo in the last line!

as for the charge of misappropriation as "a form of policing", i agree it
depends who i'm talking about, and who i am, in fact, making the charge / am
i inside the avant-garde making the claim, or outside? -- i don't really
know, but the problem implied by this question is basically what i was
hoping to point out / the tendency of late in some criticism to  colonize
the a-g with particular writers or at least writing tendencies--which would
be a necessary prerequisite for any discussion of its border tactics--to me
is a form of policing / pre-established borders and divisions have to be
assumed before anyone can suggest that there are *guards in the garde*

all best,
bill

>
> In the film "Sans Soleil", Chris Marker remarked -
>         "History throws its empty bottles out the window"

to the question "what is history?" poets / poetry has (have) often
answered, it is the story of losses -- our own loss, gradually, of
everything.  This is the immediate & personal level at which
"history" is encountered by a subject in a body -- and isn't it often
at that level (history as what's been lost -- & is, as aftermath,
converted to memory) that "history" lives & works, in poetry? --

Quoth Omar Khayyam (per moi; a selection of half-dozen quatrains) --

  The only thing the pretty stars achieves is pain
  whatever gift the give they take away again
  those beings queing up for birth -- if they should sniff
  what happens here -- would swiftly pour it down the drain

  Mr. Wiseman!  rise & shine!  the morning's here
  see that youngster sifting dust?  now look with care --
  you could lend him sage advice:  "hey, stir it gently
  for both Plato's brain & Picasso's eyes are there"

  If I assumed the cosmic helm
  I'd scrap at once this bitter realm
  installing another in its lieu
  where grief could never overwhelm

  I wouldn't have fetched up here
                                if this required my okay
  now if I had my druthers
                                I most certainly would stay!
  in such a bombed-out bungalow
                                there's nothing could compare
  with never having come or been
                                or gone in any way

  Our coming & our going brings    what benefit?
  life warp suggests a weft   so where's the zen of it?
  in the midst of worlds    how many seekers burn
  to ashes    but what wisp of somoke comes then of it?

  Those souls who plumbed the depths of thought
                                & scaled feelings' height
  in the circle of a Perfect One
                                became like lamps alight
  yet even these could not evade
                                the shadow of demise:
  they spun such brilliant fables always
                                ending with "good night!"

/ / / / /

of course, Khayyam's native city of Khorasan saw the ravages of
"history" of the sort lately noted by Judy Roitman (with a large part
of its population slaughtered) -- but although "history" as it's been
known in recent milennia might (per the unpleasantry) largely
comprise the history of wars, yet such personal conclusions as might
arise from this generality, are -- vis-a-vis poetry -- another
matter; -- the history of imagination (no less than that of memory)
having its own tale to tell betimes . . .

g'morning
d.i.
 .

 |   perfecting a small wild flower
 |                                       (Tagore)

>Clark Coolidge was seeking a personal language. He felt that words came

>wanted to let them stand alone or in groups without necessarily meaning
>what people thought them to mean. The hope was that the words would begin
>to work as sound objects. Yuk yuk.

Now if Mr. Gould is still on line, this is the kind of informative message
he could learn more about by simply crossing the street now & then & visiting
the Harris Collection, which luckily contains most of the poetry in America
including language poetry so-called.  But he insists on wallowing in
grotesque labels & second-third-fourth-hand "knowledge" of various
"groups" writing poetry.  This is probably because he's too self-centered
& lazy to lift his eyes above the current graduate dissertation he's
reading.  Gould is a kind of parasite on the avant-garde - he joins a
language poetry-based innovative chat list & proceeds to fling critical
cliches about it back in their faces.  As Charles Alexander said, it's
not a gated community, yet Gould feels it necessary to plunge into
pestiferous & silly "critical" heroics which are really only a joke.
- Eric Blarnes

- Spandrift

I'm stunned.  I've got to read more of this stuff, I guess.  I thought
we were a "label" culture, not a libel culture.  Publicists are the Faustian
bargain; labels have sticky glue on them; critics are forever adding
butterflies to either Box B or Box C; poetry & the intelligence resist

rawness traveling in reverse channels down Policeman's Ball Creek.
Hey look!  There goes a red-breasted Avant-Garde!  Male or female?

Maria --

> okay all you sweet yukyuks out there, i've got a question: why does
> "the avant garde" seem to need to police its borders so rigidly?
> how does some thing get defined or not as "avant garde?" . . .

one question I have is, what's the history of the term "avant garde"?
-- was this (for instance) first applied to paintings / painters in
the 19th century, then extended to literature & music? --

resonances from one field spill over to another field / or don't --

as concept, "avant garde" suggests having a jump on the generality;
but paradoxically, avant gardes have often been deep-nostalgaic, no?
-- the quest for the lost arcane that (partly) defines(ed) modernism
--

question: what's the relationship between modernity per se & the
(then) avant garde? -- weren't they in fact, at some (lost) time(s),
deemed equivalent? --

anyway, Maria, these are little notes & jottings.  You might find it
of interest to look at David Antin's book *What It Means To Be Avant
Garde* (New Directions) -- transcript of several po-talk / art-talk
performances, in Antin's classic manner.  He does, in the title talk
(as best I vaguely recall) try to come to terms with the relationship
between the idea of the avant garde & the institutionalization of
same (I think) . . .  -- might, at least, afford a few quotes . . . --

d.i.

Date:         Fri, 8 Aug 1997 10:48:14 -0500
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         The Ultimate Autodidact <landers@FRONTIERNET.NET>
Organization: SkyLark Publishing Company
Subject:      Analogue
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

first appeared in ADZ mag sometime in the mid 80's. See if you can find
the dedication which I tuck inside the poem :-)
 =======================================================================

                        =ANALOGUE=
          *
I shall never forget the thrill I experienced when I succeeded
in condensing Heisenberg's ideas on quantum conditions in the
mysterious equation:
       h
pq-qp=___
      2¼i
which is the center of wave mechanics and was later found to
imply the uncertainty relation.
[Max Born, Physics and Metaphysics, Joule Memorial Lecture, 1950]
          *
(c.f. also Kepler, "Omnis locatio mentis est opus.")
.
          *
My mother was active
                 in Cursillo
(a catholic renewal movement)
my father was lay director;
this little course, post-Vatican II retreat
was absolutely evaluated (by me) as pointless,
leading to arguments, silences, leading
to following tiffs, concessions; pointless?
No. Yes. No. Ligatures: family ties, retied;
religion is what they knew; the fell cultures,
fallen cultures, the med student's sabotage.
.
Please put what was known with what is known.
Absolutely!
           The absolute square
                            of the amplitude;
there!
     Point the point! Point the wave the point
the particle the probably the wave the probabilities
the particleness guess
             Yes!
          *
Cursillistas, the little course takers,
the roosters the cluckhens & babechicks,
came to the wake. Process-ion the function,
the first derivative, velocity, second
acceleration, variable, bunched like a snake
at corners, brakes lighting in cause & effect.
I knew few.
          *
          To the ocean,
                    my prayer;
          sing me a mother woe
                    undulating in pulse,
                              in waves
(middle high german: wabern; to be in motion
          ((webern; woven (((in motion))).)).).
          wave: set of probabilities.
You just corpus
          and I'll undo you late,
                    my love; love known.
          *
                    Known? No one knows
          but your hardresser,
who knows nothing about the Nuremburg Trials.
Did you hear? As Florestan in the 2nd act of Fidelio,
          "Nothing lives but me"
And Richard the 2nd,
          "For because the world is populous,
          "And here is not a creature but myself..."
.
          Nothing at all?
          Not even the rats?
          They've all been painted white and
          put in laboratory cages,
        and the cockroaches
        were all lined up
        and hitched to toothpick
        rickshaws
.
          Not even the mold.
          Cat boxed, cyanide, halflife decay,
          a paradox box. The great experiment.
          The cat, rat, chimp mere chemical;
          pain mere effect; laws prohibit this with people,
          but the slave is an animal, a monkey,
          the jew is an insect, vermin,
          wart, dog, worm, disease,
          science can heal
        (science personified
          consubstantial with the father.)
          Accept no gifts from the gods.
          Who said that? Who are they? They, anyway.
          *
          New and improved.
          Rendering everything obsolete,
        especially judgement;
          the bunker is taken, the canon overthrown.
          Your arms, your wrists,
          have all but lost connective tissue,
          unwoven, spin decaying, almost
          leaving orbit,
          we rib each other in physic-
        al sense that
          we sense that loving can come
          back into its faces without conclusion to
          us belongeth confusion, non-existential matters
          even as you are not with me in processing
          to the unposessed whole
          where they'll bury my mother's matter.
          *
          Heisenberg & Bohr took a stroll.
          The matrician writes,
          "Bohr's remark reminded me
          atoms don't exist."
          The prison is a closed universe,
          it faces its back infused,
          the penalty for life is death; escape,
        if you've behaved yourself,
        from the Wheel of 84.
.
           Those unknown people at mom's wake
        convinced me of mortality.
           And for some reason
           the bircalls
         [for Don Byrd]
(tees-tessi-teesi)
in LeSacre
(zray-zray-zray-zree)
made sense
(teacher, teacher, teacher, teacher).
O Mother! Mother! sings Siegfried
(you must drink the blood of the dragon
to understand the language of birds)
brought to Brunhilde by
          "a little bird told me"
which turned out to be his fear;
the undefined, unspecified, unimaginable
which he sought to know.
*
1935, Einstein, Podalsky, & Rosen
posit the paradox
that objective reality exists _a priori_
the principle of uncertainty.
But they couldn't define "reality"
in fact refused,
Physics' limit is the establishment of properties
In effect, "not my job."
_A priori!_ Kant says
     (O come, o come Emanuel!)
 a priori knowledge
is synthetical;
establishing properties is mere analytic
Schrodinger warned against
application of the ideas in quantum mechanics
to the crude macroscopic
.
If you determine the position of Bohr
  and the momentum of Heisenberg
        they change their course;
You can only guess the stroll as wave:
the uncertainty
of principle.
Manhattan, Bikini Atol, Japan,
islands: my name is no man...
Dr. Porsche is fascinated.
The Fuhrer recites his parts list,
fact, fact, fact, fact,
but not one spare part was sent into Russia;
the tanks had to be canabalized for
the integrity of the family.
An architecture epitomizing
the spirit (?) of the new land in the old;
neo-classic.
The second Vienese school of music
banned;
Wozzeck cancelled:
.
*
"Du dein mutter ist tod!"
your mother, your matter, mater, matris.
Must've been something to see,
the slow centuries of hauling goblins to the attic,
werewolves, gargoyles, fatted calves.
Substitutions,
Extensive & Stipulative
Definition:
goblins collect dust while _ubermenschen_ are polished;
for underworld & seventh heaven read Nature,
or this,
which should keep 'em talking for centuries:
Einstein says if you go far enough along one
straight line you will
find yourself facing your back;
an integral with yourself as limits.
.
Rectus Inversus:
    Mayan glyphs a polical statement,
they read, "Jobs and food for the underprivileged
provided by private sector,
pleasure by corporal vanities,
revolt by general discontent."
For the integrity of family Jesus has said,
I've come to set
father against son
mother against...
.
*
My sister read mom's favorite psalm (which one?),
   morning doves cooing outside,
    "Du dein mutter ist tod!"
Bohr's rebuttal to Einstein's paradox:
he has merely explicated
the limits of reason.
Is matrix mechanics a game of darts?
Zeno says,
"Since the dart occupies its own space
even in flight,
it cannot be said to move."
.
Bullseye!
.
I say the eye cannot disprove redness
in the pre-coital clitoris
without first it has
affirmed itself.
.
    All's you can do is guess
    the stroll as wave,
and the woods become fields
where the wave exhibits its properties;
the woods become fields
as the pioneers establish properties,
move to a new house, city;
establish the doctrine
of nomad quarks:
.
    Motion; to move; experienced by commotion.
    Mobility; the potential to act; against entropy.
.
I come to you naked
wonder what you think of
my skinny bod,
erect prick, engorged
with the blood
of the dragon.
    Action; the negation of noun
breast pink where round is soft memory
flesh in the hand the subtle mammary gland
fresh and the thisness of instant Aeneas
Dido I woo you move over...
    Mater is motion's effect; the conglomeration of sense.
.
*
.
Fact, fact, fact, fact,
The number system is valid
when you use circular reasoning:
point the point which contains
no other point. Is that the point
I'm trying to make (latin: factus)
or
am I asking for the anatomy of quarks?
    Quarks consist of infinite clones of Demokritus
thinking the matter of mother
    (or is it the mother of matter?)
    The thought is a tailchasing bitch
facing its back on a straight line
        in the closed universe
of our mystical rationalist.
.
    Oh freedom! When will you return? ask the prisoners
in Fidelio;
it's a carpet for questionbeggars.
Mahler, too, took strolls;
jaw set,
hands clasped
behind the back,
glaring,
walking nowhere with determination;
and only finality stills this constant march
around centerless, unrelenting visions of
laurelled vulvas puking tenants for the ark.
.
*
Mother! Mother! remember me!
    Siegfreid sings again.
    The last concert of the Berlin Philharmonic's '45 season:
Brunhilde's Immolation.
Encore: The peripatetic prick is covered
        by Hitler's folded hands.
Encore: The substance of black holes
      is the teeth of gassed gypsies & jews.
And somedays it seems there is no being
with-in or -out
but a subject/object dialectic of hardliner principles
for wet love.
.
"surge propera amica mea"
Rise up, my love. Affirm yourself.
Are these the magic words Jesus spoke to Lazarus
(& Tim Finnegan)
so that Einstein could think a bottle of Kant
    exploding above the untimely bier of mater...
and you still can't bury her.
.
    *
Untimely!
    The noun is neutered of time, the x axis --
    the y is amplitude;
and you can exchange one axis for the other.
.
In an interview, 1936, Einstein admits the logic
of Bohr's rebuttal, but says he prefers
his own paradox;
less than a decade later, the applied science signature,
and a B-29 bird shat on Japan.
        I AM THE BOMB!
(but he was afraid Hitler'd get it first)
        I AM THE BOMB!
bring me the face of the man
who told you to bring him my face.
(whose last order; Verbrannte Erde,
scorched earth ((Erde, earth mother))...
        I am the bomb asleep
dreaming confusion of face.
...called for the destruction of Germany).
dreaming the face of Whitman's
perfect mother.
.
When they drop the bomb, the bomb,
    first your skin peels off.
Then, they say, your eyes fall out;
    when they drop the bomb.
.
    One hundred and twenty-nine
    thousand,
    five hundred and fifty-
    eight, missing, injured,
    and dead (Hiroshima).
.
"A wondrous trumpet shall intone
through the graves of every zone
compelling all before the Throne."
.
I remember
how similar
it looked,
but it
wasn't her.
.

Pete Landers

That word, avant-garde, was first used by musicians in the 13th c.
Some consider Machaut among them, but in fact he is a progenitor.

Don't we all agree that it's a useless word? Some people form groups and
some groups are formed to take advantage of readers wanting people to
form groups, but we're each alone. Some groups have names, but there is
no group named avant-garde, except those 13th c. composers.

I like what Rothenberg or Joris put in the intro to the new huge
anthology. A list of characteristics of the poems and poets, with the
note that none had all and some had none, or some such. But I recall
they do use that word.

A sad thing about groups is: whose names fall off the list? For
instance, in the intro to the S&M Rakosi book, Neidecker is not
mentioned as an Objectivist.

Why group up at all? I know that I like to read groups. I lump up the
bunch Uncle Ezra was hanging with and read them. I know they are working
in relation to each other. It seems to make understanding them easier. I
do it again with Objectivists, I dismiss the Beats as a group, I lump
and read Black Mountain writers, etc. I do the same with music, like the
3rd Viennese School or the Impressionists. I really don't understand why
I do it, except that it is convenient.

People who are seen as being in a group tend to rebel against the label.
They want to be taken on their own merits. Understandably. I really do
take them on their own merits, even if I read them as part of a group,
except, of course, when I dismiss the entire group.

In any case, there is no group, or clique, called avant-garde. There is
no working definition of the word. It is used more by those who dismiss
new writing (new forms?) than by those who write in a new way.

Pete

p.s. Sometimes the list sounds more like a bunch of critics than poets.
How about some poems? Is Alan the only poet?

A tribute to Tricky Dick, under whose reign I was born.

daniel_bouchard@hmco.com




CRITICAL ONE


Whitman's fury is pent

whereas Whittier
whose outcropping love of heroism and war,
for all his Quakerdom, his verses
at times like the measur'd step
of Cromwell's old veterans

while a California town from which
came a would be capable Cromwell
who fitfully fought Commies
even where they were not

As I wend toward the winter
     I know not

Reply-To:     ARCHAMBEAU@LFC.EDU

From:         Robert Archambeau <ARCHAMBEAU@LFC.EDU>
Organization: Lake Forest College
Subject:      Re: "*alternative*avant-garde"
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

Interesting to see all the different assumptions we have about what we
talk about when we talk about the "avant-garde".  I've always been a bit
edgy about the term because it has seemed to me to have exactly the kind
of "before your time" connotation that, as Chris Alexander pointed out,
doesn't really make any sense.  The image always seemed to me to be of
the advance guard, treading today where the mere herd will tread
tomorrow (okay, that's spatial and chronological, but you know what I
mean, there's some leftover idea of progress buried in the term).

I've been more comfortable with "alternative poetries" since A) this
allows for a multiplicity of alternatives, rather than a
united-in-purpose band of commandos, and B) this admits that all that
other, "conventional" stuff ain't about to go away -- the new formalists
won't be writing langpo in 2005.  Not that this is unproblematic, but it
makes me less uneasy that does a-g.

As for who does the police and in what voices, I don't know.  But while
controversy and infighting don't always help in the world of grass root
politics -- you know the scene: the Neo-Trotskyites streetfight with the
Refounded Anarcho-Syndicalists while the ghost of Margaret Thatcher
seizes power -- they aren't neccessarily bad for poetics.  In fact, we
can, in playing the cop or the robber, come to understand what it is
that we need to do in writing, and where we feel we ought to be going.


--
Robert Archambeau
Department of English
Lake Forest College
Lake Forest, IL 60045
http://www.lfc.edu/~archamb/

See: behind bullet-proof glass, the ruby slippers sparkle.
We do not know the limits of their powers.
We suspect that these limits may not exist.
 --Salman Rushdie

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

A few thoughts on the "avant-garde" in poetry.

The term, "avant-garde," is close to useless because used in too many,
too often conflicting ways--and, as luigi-bob drake pointed out, is
problematically time-dependent.  For informal discussions, we could make
much better use of a typology of poetics schools, each at least roughly
defined by what kind of poetry its members make.  Yeah, once again I'm
pushing my list of poetry schools.

For more serious discussions we need an intelligent taxonomy of poetry
(taxonomy being typology that is systemized).  Then someone like Maria
Damon could ask why the grammocentric poets, say (to use the dopiest of
my taxonomical terms), seem to need to police their borders so rigidly,
and those who accepted the term would know exactly whom she was speaking
of.  (In other words, hurrah for the Port Charlotte, Florida, Institute
of Poetics Taxonomy.)

If she wanted to discuss a larger group, my preferred term would be
"otherstream poetry," which I define as any poetry that has never (to
any serious extent) gotten into an anthology of poetry published by a
"reputable" publisher--like Norton--or been seriously discussed in a
book of criticism published by such a publisher.  So much of "language
poetry" is thus not otherstream--which isn't to say that it's no good,
or that otherstream poetry IS good.  It just means that language poetry
has succeeded in gaining more acceptance than otherstream poetry.
Visual poetry is a prime example of the latter: some of the poetry in
the postmodernist Norton does use visual potry techniques to a slight
degree but none of the poetry in the Norton, that I can see, IS visual
poetry; similarly, some poets in the Norton, such as Ron Johnson, are or
have been visual poets, but their visual poetry is not in the anthology.

Otherstream poetry isn't necessarily "new," just not widely accepted.
Visual poetry, for example, has been around much longer than language
poetry.

The opposite of otherstream poetry is NOT mainstream poetry, it's
"knownstream poetry."  All mainstream poetry is knownstream but not all
knownstream poetry (e.g., rhymed sci fi poetry) is mainstream.

A second way of determining whether a given kind of poetry is
otherstream or not would be by polling college English departments to
find out the national percentage of English courses in which the poetry
was seriously taught--or even so much as mentioned.  Any poetry getting
less than one percent would be otherstream.

Now to a different but related topic to ask why people are so frequently
reluctant to define as "historical," poems that are explicitly and
mainly about history (like "The Midnight Ride of Paul Revere"), and
define as "ahistorical," poems that are entirely without overt
historical references (like "The Red Wheelbarrow," which is about a red
wheel barrow), and agree that many poems contain bits of history, which
keep them from being ahistorical, but have a different central focus
than history, which keeps them from being historical, and carry on from
there.
                                   As taxonomaniacal as ever, Bob G.

----------------------------------***


a soddette's soddet


soddened by the soddest moment of my life
I saddled up to the side of a siddha
and sighed.
he softened his sudden sight
and slid his sodder into my sled.
oh super siddha
I sapped
thank you for slathering my slodden slip
into slothdom and
sifting the sod of my sadness,
lifting me silkenly into satori.
no more sodden sags for me.
I'll sing the song of a sari'd soddette,
a saga of the saved.


(c) 1997 llrussell

Subject:      categorical doggerel

Late in the battle, the rear-guard cracks up:

What do we get when we combine
A fart and a bomb?  The petard.
And when we cross rank and file line
With machine gun?  The avant-garde.

In the confusion, someone delivers an epigram
from the ghost of Dr. Cunningham:

Hot boys accuse me-- academic.
For their fevers call me medic.


This messenger was promptly killed;
Since this was war, more words were spilled
Until the fray was clearly out of hand:
Many poems lay strewn about no man's land.

The chroniclers in vain
Look for signs of remain-
Ing names during the Reign
Of Contested Terrain.

-Gary R

On Fri, 8 Aug 1997 14:27:33 -0500 <GROBERTS@BINAH.CC.BRANDEIS.EDU> said:
>
>The chroniclers in vain
>Look for signs of remain-
>Ing names during the Reign
>Of Contested Terrain.
>

This gets to the essence of "avant-garde".  It's an adjective that gets
loaded for whichever side you're on, or point you're trying to make.

All politics is local, that is, look for the details.  Is your artist a
subversive or a reformist?  A nationalist or internationalist?  Or maybe
in the middle, considering the alternatives, pointing up the differences?
The idea of being politically-responsive artist means very different things
to a Wallace Stevens & an Amiri Baraka, but one could argue they both thought
about it a great deal.   & every poem or work can be considered a mixed thing.
Poem  - edged by ideology, philosophy, propaganda, undigested imitation,
and....    originality, emotion, humor, profundity... & labels & groups are
more than just labels - they're decisions about what language seems right
for the time & the people it represents... (always overdetermined mixed-
motive decisions or undecisions...)  i.e. what do you LIKE...
- Henry Gould

Good idea, Layne & Peter!  Since I wrote this "today" (i.e started it=
 last=20
night, put it in present form this morning) I'll post it.

P.S. - someone here noted that the term avant-garde was first applied=
 to=20
13th century musicians, but it might do well to recall that it origin=
ated as=20
a military term and as such could be thought of as applying to both c=
rack=20
troops and cannon fodder with equal justice. In any event - the idea =
of=20
"Contested Terrain," as Gary points up.

THEORY OF NOSTALGIA

A man is all stealth,
listening does him in.

To move by excess is what
we mean by living.

A man is a knife and the road
he walks on cuts two ways.

Communication by lamplight
is a gesture towards infinity.

The day is a rant,
all fecklessness and high tide.

In Mandelbrot=C9s "entity of infinite resolution"
the demands for clarity grow unbearable.

A man is an entity with a gesture
towards resolution.

To be weary is what the living mean by it:
(the ceded) (the discontained).

Communication in a park with lamps
configures a nostalgia for infinity.

A man is a system of leaves and shadows.
He finds under lamplight the stone alone.


     - Patrick Pritchett

Comments: To: ARCHAMBEAU@LFC.EDU

At 11:11 AM +0000 8/8/97, Robert Archambeau wrote:

>I've been more comfortable with "alternative poetries" since A) this
>allows for a multiplicity of alternatives, rather than a
>united-in-purpose band of commandos
. . . . . . . . . . . . .

>As for who does the police and in what voices . . . they aren't
>neccessarily bad for poetics.  In fact, we
>can, in playing the cop or the robber, come to understand what it is
>that we need to do in writing, and where we feel we ought to be going.

Yes, Robert, I agree!  As I've stated before, even though it may be
unpleasant while one is mired in it, fighting between groups has been
healthy for poetry--like you say, it motivates people to clarify their
positions.  Outsiders rarely understand these vary important distinctions
that the participants feel on such a vital level.  For instance, I'm
thinking of the women of the Spicer/Duncan circle and other non/anti-Beat
women who were included in that Women of the Beat Generation
Anthology--some of them refused and others were vocally conflicted about
being included among the very group they wrote against in their youth.
(E.g., "If I hear the word Beat one more time I'm going to scream!")  Is
stupid attention better than marginalization/no attention?

On another note, I think that the "alternative poetries" of the 90s, rather
than policing their borders, are more inclusive than the "alternative
poetries" of the 80s--for instance, people (like myself) working in
narrative are no longer actively snubbed.  To me it feels more like lots of
people are drawing from lots of different writings, much less a sense of
(a) party line(s).

Dodie

        Whether one agrees with them or not two "standard" places to begin
are Renato Pogglioli  The Theory of the Avant-Garde (Cambridge:
Belknap/Harvard 1968) and The Theory of the Avant-Garde
by Peter Burger (Minneapolis: U Minnesota P, 1984).
        The former has a lot of interesting historical background, the
latter is more theoretical.
        I have been working for a while for fun on a kind of comic
book/visual poetry series  "Instant Classic vs.  Planned Obsolesence".
(inspired in equal parts by Gertrude Stein's "Composition as explanation"
 essay with the famous outlaw to classic the interval is almost not there
equation and Godzilla vs. Mothra, vs. megatron and etc). Perhaps a buried
subtext in there re avant garde?
        Once for fun with a friend we made imitation National Guard
posters changing the words to Avant-Garde but keeping the address and
phone number of a recruiting office on it.
        Visting the office a week or so later they said yes they had
gotten some strange calls about joining.
        Re Gertrude Stein/history/avant-garde etc (she read a lot of memoirs and a
favorite was that of President/General Ulysses S. Grant)--the first
sentence of Stein's Geographical History of America is very interesting.
She notes being born in the same month as Washington and Lincoln.
That is:  two Presidents and Stein are equated:  the "father of His
Country", the "Great Emancipator" and Gertrude Stein!
        Also:  Washington "could not tell a lie" and Lincoln was "Honest
Abe"--so we know Gertrude Stein as well must be giving us the truth--or
the "true gen" in Mr. Hemingway's terminology!
        Gertrude Stein--was she noting the connection between the
military and the avant-garde here?  Washington and Lincoln had "led their
country in times of war" so to speak--
        (U.S. Grant as well--)
        And much of "Compostion as Explanation" is about the
interrelationships among the changes in art and the changes in life
brought about by WWI--that those in art had seen those of the war just ahead
 of time--Picasso seeing a camouflaged tank with its Cubist looking
markings and saying:  "We made that".  (See this in Autobiography of
Alice. B. Toklas--also see Wars I have Known)
        Then there are the the Threes with Gertrude Stein:  Three Lives,
the three Geniuses of AABT--Whitehead, Picasso, Stein--and the three
leaders--Washington, Lincoln, Stein.
        There are over two hundred seventy-five book title entries under
"avant-garde" in library here.
        Yet as one knows from the X Files:  "the truth is out there"
        --out there
        Luigi made good point re this--Mail Art and so on--guerilla and
open ended--
        ZA DA

        dBC

Re Maria's question:  Might a perpetual reluctance to use "avant-garde" be
an example of this policing?  I ask sharing some in this reluctance.  In
high school, Connie Lorman showed us a Cocteau movie in which there was the
line "To break statues you must become one," and then we all had to write
papers on this.  Just jawing here.

Re Hugh Steinberg's questions re writing "through" history and > history is
the field in which language is embedded in <:   I have been working on a
novel of late.  I am constructing a couple of voices that are leagues from
my own, and the whole thing is set in 1979 & 1980.  The exercise of
excluding all language from these voices -- slang or otherwise -- that has
evolved just since 1980 is finally viscerally making clear to me what the
theory never fully did:  the language itself is determining the course of
natural events, to some extent.  I've spouted this for years but with
fingers crossed behind my back.  To see it enacted is eye-popping.

Re Alan's gifts to the list:  Gifts indeed.  And stellar ones.  Many thanks.


Susan Wheeler

>
> maria, I don't mean to monkeywrench your issue, but is it clear that the
> avant-garde is _more_ closed than other non-mainstream movements in
> contemporary poetics?  It seems to me that policing is a component of any
> contested subfield within the larger field, and that such communities as
> "new formalist" and "performance" poetics each have their own forms of
> policing.  What, in your view, are the distinguishing marks, if any, of


Furthermore, both the posts on this issue take an identifiable a-g as a
given....I dunno.  I think among other things, "a-g" is a historical (and
historically specific) construct that is now very old, and tends to pull
all discussions back into institutionally-sanctioned and established
channels.  A good example is a review-essay I read in (I think) the London
Review of Books, last Nov. or Dec. or something, by Fred Jameson,
reviewing several books on the Tel Quel group..One point (which I've seen
others make) was his insistence (he wasn't really conscious that he was
insisting) that "all"  "avant-gardes" are authoritarian and tend toward
having a specific leader (sounds like a theory of fascism, actually); this
is too silly to need refutation, if dada, langpo, Beats, and many others
are taken into consideration.  But this is the kind of thing you get in
established academic (acadominent?) discourse about "avant-gardes"...And
one of the reasons it's necessary to get very specific: which supposed
"a-g" is one talking about?? Many of the the alleged a-g's that have been
most vital to my own life and poetry, over the years, don't seem to have
much to do with Jameson's frame of reference (no surprise, probably)..But
over-generalizations abound in acadominent discussions of the term, and
make me uneasy.

What I and most of my friends do in poetry is still called "a-g" by a
large number of groups out there, but I'd hack off a foot rather than
actively use that term about what we do...Its primary purpose these days
is to keep poets hedged in and labelled so their work can be dismissed and
not read...In light of that claim, it occurs to me that i'm reversing your
original formulation, Maria, and suggesting that often it is *others* who
are policing the A-G borders, M-17 in hand, not the wannabe A-Gers...


Mark
Atlanta

Bill Marsh's point is a good one: the old concept of "a-g" was indeed
fairly (at least) apocalyptic.  It had to do with overthrowing things
pretty substantially.  Don't forget that the term was originally a
military one.  The advance guard of a large attacking force.  That gives
you some sense of what (when it was meaningful) the term connoted...

My argument now is, the term was a contingent fact of history, thrown up
from the roiling human sea.  By now it's definitely sun-bleached and
dessicated.  What Bill's posting reminded me of was that we were all using
"a-g" in a watered-down sense, as a designation of a place in a large
contextual field.  Which if you stop and think about it, is just the
*wrong* spatial image for an "avant-garde," which is the advancing first
wave of an army.

Our use of the watered-down term, is healthy, indicating that we're moving
away from the old "avant-garde" concept altogether...Which I would
advocate.  (Along with axing "experimental" and similar ghetto-talk)

Mark P.
Atlanta

subtext in there re avant garde?

posters changing the words to Avant-Garde but keeping the address and
phone number of a recruiting office on it.
        Visting the office a week or so later they said yes they had
gotten some strange calls about joining.
        Re Gertrude Stein/history/avant-garde etc (she read a lot of memoirs and a
favorite was that of President/General Ulysses S. Grant)--the first
sentence of Stein's Geographical History of America is very interesting.
She notes being born in the same month as Washington and Lincoln.
That is:  two Presidents and Stein are equated:  the "father of His
Country", the "Great Emancipator" and Gertrude Stein!
        Also:  Washington "could not tell a lie" and Lincoln was "Honest
Abe"--so we know Gertrude Stein as well must be giving us the truth--or
the "true gen" in Mr. Hemingway's terminology!
        Gertrude Stein--was she noting the connection between the
military and the avant-garde here?  Washington and Lincoln had "led their
country in times of war" so to speak--
        (U.S. Grant as well--)
        And much of "Compostion as Explanation" is about the
interrelationships among the changes in art and the changes in life
brought about by WWI--that those in art had seen those of the war just ahead
 of time--Picasso seeing a camouflaged tank with its Cubist looking
markings and saying:  "We made that".  (See this in Autobiography of
Alice. B. Toklas--also see Wars I have Known)
        Then there are the the Threes with Gertrude Stein:  Three Lives,
the three Geniuses of AABT--Whitehead, Picasso, Stein--and the three
leaders--Washington, Lincoln, Stein.
        There are over two hundred seventy-five book title entries under
"avant-garde" in library here.
        Yet as one knows from the X Files:  "the truth is out there"
        --out there
        Luigi made good point re this--Mail Art and so on--guerilla and
open ended--
        ZA DA

        dBC

Patrick Pritchett wrote:

In Mandelbrot's "entity of infinite resolution"
the demands for clarity grow unbearable.

These lines from Patrick's "Theory of Nostalgia" reminded me of two very
short poems I had written. Here they are:

CULTURE

Up, ascending,
is heaven.
Down, descending,
is hell.
Or, as I look at it,
up is
the release of memory.
Down is
the furious breeding of further intricacies.


VOLITION

I am
as much impelled
as compelled.

Date:         Fri, 8 Aug 1997 19:44:00 -0600
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Hugh Steinberg <hsteinberg@GRIN.NET>
Subject:      Re: "*alternative*avant-garde"
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Bob writes:

>my preferred term would be
>"otherstream poetry," which I define as any poetry that has never (to
>any serious extent) gotten into an anthology of poetry published by a
>"reputable" publisher--like Norton--or been seriously discussed in a
>book of criticism published by such a publisher...
>
I really like this idea, but I'd argue that it is far more encompassing
than as Bob puts forth in his posting.  I think there are two otherstreams
out there: the first being the type of poetry that isn't widely accepted,
and the other being the kind that is widely (I'd argue predominately)
accepted, but isn't necessarily approved by the various institutions that
support poetry.  I'm thinking of the ordinary act of writing poems that
most people do for personal reasons.  Poems that are written out of a
general ignorance of institution based poems (poems written by people who
don't read poetry).  Most of it is horrible, sentimental, cliched, etc.

But in a discussion of avant-gardes, they're often the real target.  That
is, what are avant-gardes for?  They exist to change the way people think.
The more ambitious the avant-garde, the more people they want to affect.

This otherstream poetry has been influenced by some groups much more than
others, and sometimes it stands traditional categories right on their head.
For example, when an otherstream poem doesn't use rhyme and meter (most
do, as a signifier of poem vs. non-poem), I'd argue it comes more from
writers like Carl Sandburg, Vachel Lindsay, Edgar Lee Masters, et al, than
their much more institutionally respected contemporaries like Ezra Pound or
Gertrude Stein. I know I'm sounding a little perverse here, but in the
otherstream world "Desiderata" can be seen as one of the most influential
poems of the 20th century (as observed by my roommate's girlfriend, who
wrote him a poem that is nothing but a list of unrhymed aphorisms).

I'd be interested in discussion about which groups of avante-garde writers
have been able to impact the otherstream, as well as how (and why) they
were able to do it.

Hugh Steinberg

-




This machine acts alone.
In the cafe, this machine runs, draining the blood from me.
Keys exhale with every touch, every character has received
the caress of delicate fingers.
I am magnetic domain, I am Net domain.
I want to sink in magnet hysteresis, want to slide in Net hysteria.
Without your body I am lost. Machine loops the machine. Julu is crying.
This machine tilts the great empty city. Jennifer is here,
split among us.
Jennifer says to Jennifer, Julu is absent, Alan is hysteric.
Jennifer trembles.
Great wheels gyre above the cafe, spokes cutting lines like knives.
Great wheels in the sky.
Jennifer trembles for Jennifer. What if Alan ...
The machine acts alone.

here's a short avant anygarde poieoym I wrote many yrs ago:

My countrymen   dreaming and drinking down
the livelong day in your smooth Cadillacs
Americans made of nostalgia, playing the clown
on roads past the high school railroad tracks

go on, play the radio, shoot for the moon
your little boy up from grasslands not for hire
is building a tricycle in the backyard, and soon
he'll step inside a brand new chariot of fire

- Henry Gould

thank you all, david k, bill m, david i, charles a, etc. i share many of
your beliefs, such as, that vanguardism (my preferred term) is a process
rather than a coterie or school. however, in my professional life, i've
encountered enough instances where the boundaries are tightly defined to
lead me to believe there is some anxiety about borders.  for instance, i
was recently asked for permission to reprint my bob kaufman essay in an
anthology of essays on "the avant garde."  i said okay, but in my opinion
my essay on poetry by some teenage girls in a boston housing project was
much more interesting, more adventurous, less man-and-his-work formulaic.
the answer was: well i do "cultural studies" myself, but in this project
i'm working with a fairly traditional understanding of the "avant garde,"
so i'll stick w/ the kaufman piece.  for another instance, when i proposed
a paper for the conference i mentioned, on "the poetics of avant garde
poetry," there was some hesitatiion over acceptiing my paper because its
definition of "avant garde" was too broad (won't it render the term
meaningless to broaden it? was the question.)  again, i was advised by
colleagues on the organizing side of things to stress that i was working
with a "cultural studies model," i guess to provide reassurance that there
was some recognized method to my intentions.  also, my introduction to this
list and partcipation, while in some ways broadening (in that i've learned
about poets i didn't know about before) has also been a narrowing, as the
list is quite explicitly intended for discussion of newer poetries (i can't
recall exactly the wording of the bernstein welcome). i don't mean to wax
victimy or snide in these personal anecdotes, i hope you all realize how
much i enjoy learning all this new stuff and getting to know y'all.  these
moments of feeling the barriers come up have been interesting because they
foreground categorical, operative divisions that are sometimes disavowed at
the more overt level.
another line that gets drawn is that of aesthetic judgment, and the
assumption that we all share certain judgments (hallmark card verse is
embarrassingly bad, so is maya angelou's poetry; bpNichol is fabulous, etc
--don't get me wrong, i love bpNichol and i don't buy hallmark cards but i
do find angelou's poetry meaningful, esp when i see how deeply it touches
my students).  as i've said here before, aesthetic judgment has been the
dividing line between me and some of the people i've worked with.  in fact
i tend to trust them cuz i don't trust myself, so i usually concede at the
level of editorial revision, but at the metalevel i'm asking, why is it SO
overridingly important that there be some kind of consensus of aesthetic
judgment? or, why is this consensus the basis of our community or
commonality?

>william marsh wrote:

>>there's been a lot of talk about this issue of late (here and elsewhere),
>>and i'm wondering if anyone else feels the same confusion about it / the
>>spatial analogy here, that the a-g is a particular zone or area of activity
>>and therefore identifiable by its borders (and its potential policing of
>>borders) is the main source of my confusion / when did the "avant garde"
>>come to represent a group or subgroup or "subfield in a larger field" as
>>David Kellogg puts? -- the classificatory scheme strikes me as fundamentally
>>at odds with what the a-g has always represented to me, namely a kind of
>>momentum that infuses artistic activities and (sometimes) instigates change
>>/ if current notions of an avant-garde stipulate that it exists as a group
>>among groups (and i agree with Charles Alexander that it is not a "unified
>>thing"), then clearly there must be an *alternative* avant-garde which
>>escapes such classification -- which makes it even more confusing  / if the
>>a-g is the *leading edge* of activity, then how can an edge have a "border"?
>>not to mention a police force monitoring transgressions / i can't imagine
>>(literally can't see) the avant-garde in such a context... / wouldn't any
>>definition of the a-g as a group be a misappropriation of the term?
>>
>>bill marsh

Dear David,

At Naropa this summer there was a "prose poem" week.  In the dx, Cole
Swenson spoke of writing in the margin, margin between rather than on
the edge of.  Carla Harryman spoke/speaks of 'Hybridity' and Don
Guravich blurts out 'it's all just writing' and many get on the
bandwagon 'no difference' which is as problemmatic as those who say
about race 'what's the problem, we're all human.' One problem with it
that when distinction is not recognized the dominant obliterates the
marginal, the dominant will always assert itself.  So we're left in the
quagmire of naming ourselves when we no that what is ourselves is too
complex to be uniformly named.  I run into this problem calling myself
'Lesbian' when I what I mean by that changes all the time but its more
meaningful than saying 'not straight'

How about 'making strange'?

--Rachel
