Sounding Board

*for Alan Sondheim*


Besides dreaming the woman in question in her room as she described it plus
the convenient addition a plugged in vibrator on her bed laid there as mine
is laid here where I lounge reading text that waivers in and out of a sexual
momentum or coherence.  It is a good life though not necessary.  Now one hand
smells and one does not.  They have been placed strategically to peruse the
meaning of the various holes.  No matter how many you start out with, the
body lays flat in its possible juices.  The ones we eat are not necessarily
the ones we asked for--there is no way to know.

It is too wet to get to the museum but not to wet to go to the museum.  Let
it affect your consciousness,  act nasty or get behind something you care
nothing about.  Later, you’ll laugh about it on that uncomfortable futon the
best you can afford.  The problem with the bad half&half was that it made the
coffee bad.  The same can be said for sex.  Certain combinations are disaster
for the consumer.  Every member of the Happy Clubhouse would tell you this,
but so far few have asked and no one who’d do anything about it.

*Helping them to help themselves*

Like I said, this began with a confusion between money and memory.   Indeed,
if you could hand me either, I can assure you it will be emptied though
righteousness is tenuous.   False memory, The Gap,  I can’t help stealing
from big things when they are costly.  Bargain basements hook me every time.
 How long did you let it sit out?  How long must it be left out?  And if
there is unrelenting rain, the possibilities.  In a flash flood you will lose
things.

*Most victims didn’t buy flood insurance*
*No me quitas pas*

Or as you were saying about the snow.   The amount of weight the branch
permits the leaves to bear before it breaks.  There is much you can figure
out so take upon yourself to prevent certain events there labeled disaster.
Logically, what will happen to the previous losses as they shift position to
the back of the general’s head.  As had happened through the epidemic.  We no
longer considered them.  In the name of, floods, borders, balanced books.

*I don’t want to argue about it.*

Things are again shifted and look, what we call your responsibility.  The
impossibility of growth and/or separate interests.  The Israelis are serious
but have redesigned the protocol.   His shirt burned off by the latest blast,
he sits and waits, looking plainly bitter.  Notice the watch, the numbers
tattooed. Victimhood looks again, a face that aims not for glamour yet is.
More so?  Ruptured protocol reemerges as successful, as color, from black and
white.

*There’s a Movement Underground*

Photojournalism = journalism made history.  Made hippies.  Some mornings I
think I’m a happy person.  Some words get printed. She’s a journalist who
also writes novels. I can’t get past the game of it. I ride in your back
seat[thinking][meditating][labeling][identifying][looking][like] I’m staring
out your window, innocent, inocencia.  Glamour. Love or lose?  Drunk with it
he finally got silent, then again, he was always silent.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------notes:

“Most Victims”--From an AP heading, May 13, 1997
“No Me Quitas--Nina Simone
“I don’t”--Me with the grocery clerk
“There’s a Movement”-- Prescriptions makeup adline, from Fall 94,
blitzkrieged onto the New York subway ad space, seen by me upon returning
from a year in Mexico, after having left New York in 1993 upon the
dissolution of AIDS and Queer Activism.
=========================================================================

Dear Poetics:

I've just been hired to teach at the University of Arizona Extended
University -- a course on small presses, and later this year, a creative
writing class.

Today I received in the mail, among other contract materials, a "loyalty
oath" to sign. I had thought these were a thing of the past. And I thought
maybe people on this list could advise me -- have others here had to sign
such things, has anybody refused, is this only an Arizona conservate thing,
or ??? Particularly, anyone on this list in Arizona -- have you had to sign
such a thing, or have you refused to sign such a thing, and what if any
were the consequences? But I'm interested if this is required in other
states as well. Are you a Minnesota loyalist, Maria? or anyone else
anywhere else? Some answer soon would be great, so I can weigh my options
before I sign or don't sign. (and yes, I know, I should probably talk with
a lawyer about this)

For the record, apprently they would withhold compensation "unless and
until such officer or employee does so take and subscribe to the form of
oath of affirmation set forth in this section."

And that oath reads:

I, _________________________ do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will
support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution and laws
of the State of Arizona; That I will bear true faith and allegiance to the
same, and defend them against all enemies, foreign and domestic, and that I
will faithfully and impartially discharge the duties of the office of
_______________________ according to the best of my ability, so help me God
(or, so I do affirm).



____________________________________________________
(Signature of employee)



thanks,

charles

"Full Maternity Jacket" - an annunciation from John Tranter

I'm happy to announce that Jacket magazine -
free, fast-loading, international, full of stylish writing  -
finally has its own proper and permanent site on the Internet, at

          http://www.jacket.zip.com.au

The first issue contains interviews with English poet Roy Fisher and
Australian aboriginal poet Lionel Fogarty, a look at the 1943 hoax poet
Ern Malley (an old favorite of John Ashbery's and mine, too), work by
Charles Bernstein, Elaine Equi, Pamela Brown, Alfred Corn, Joanne Burns,
Tracy Ryan, Carl Rakosi, Peter Minter, Susan Schultz and Paul Hoover,
reviews of John Berger and Les Murray, the poetry of the late Martin
Johnston, and a glimpse of the Xmas 1997 John Ashbery "special issue",
together with photos and art work.

Jacket # 1 will be added to until the end of September 1997,
when the first issue will be finalised.

Jacket issue # 2 will focus mainly on the work of John Ashbery,
who turns 70 this year, but there will be lots of other material as
well. It will be uploaded piece by piece from early September 1997,
and finalised by Xmas 1997.

Charles Alexander,

Re the loyalty oath you've been asked, in Arizona, to sign: I thought it
was "a thing of the past" too.

From the ACLU's web-site: "a chronology, from 1920 to the present, of the
most important United States Supreme Court victories that involved the
ACLU, either as direct counsel or as a friend-of-the-court."

To wit:

1967 Keyishian v. Board of Regents

"A Cold War-inspired law, requiring New York public school teachers to sign
a loyalty oath, fell as a violation of the First Amendment. The decision,
capping off a series of unsuccessful challenges to both federal and state
loyalty and security programs, rejected the doctrine that public employment
is a "privilege" to which government can attach whatever conditions it
pleased."

I'll be curious to read what tales others on the list have to tell. Here's
William Stafford, a man whose heart was "glad and big," on the subject:

The Star in the Hills

A star hit in the hills behind our house
up where the grass turns brown touching the sky.

Meteors have hit the world before, but this was near,
and since TV; few saw, but many felt the shock.
The state of California owns that land
(and out from shore three miles), and any stars
that come will be roped off and viewed on week days 8 to 5.

A guard who took the oath of layalty and denied
any police record told me this:
"If you don't have a police record yet
you could take the oath and get a job
if California should be hit by another star."

"I'd promise to be loyal to California
and to guard any stars that hit it," I said,
"or any place three miles out from shore,
unless the star was bigger than the state--
in which case I'd be loyal to _it_."

But he said no exceptions were allowed,
and he leaned against the state-owned meteor
so calm and puffed a cork-tip cigarette
that I looked down and traced with my foot in the dust
and thought again and said, "OK--any star."

from TRAVELING THROUGH THE DARK (New York: Harper & Row, 1962)

Bill

William Slaughter
wrs@unf.edu

need to police its borders so rigidly?") which i read to mean policing

not clear to me that the list in general (or any subset in particular)
constitutes an a.g.; nor is it clear that having a (nubuliously definded)
topic of "newer poetries" is th same as "policing the borders".  (praps
you're refering to the recent arrest trial and sentancing ov Kim Dawn?)
but, if yr refering to a general sense (which i share) that discussion
ov nichol is more likely to generate interest than discussion ov angelou--
i'm not sure that conjures the same vision of billyclubing men in blue...

certainly, there are examples...  Fluxus had it's endless lists of
"members", frinstance (tho i mself am not entirely convinced that
those lists werent something of a performance piece by maciunas...).
but, i think any closedness is probably specific to the particular case;
i dont think there's a general answer...

but now, as i go back to th original query--"the closedness of the avant
garde tradition *or at least the way it's construed by most of its
critics*" (emphasis added)...  ah.  arent those two different questions?
and, tho again i'd wanna address particulars, it makes sense to me that
"the critics" might feel a little left out, or left behind, by some a.g.
tendencies? which is not the same as an a.g. is policing its borders...
and i suppose that by saying that i reveal my own perception that
(present company excluded) most critics tend towards th normative
& established...

>thank you all, david k, bill m, david i, charles a, etc. i share many of
>your beliefs, such as, that vanguardism (my preferred term) is a process
>rather than a coterie or school. however, in my professional life, i've
>encountered enough instances where the boundaries are tightly defined to
>lead me to believe there is some anxiety about borders.  for instance, i
>was recently asked for permission to reprint my bob kaufman essay in an
>anthology of essays on "the avant garde."  i said okay, but in my opinion
>my essay on poetry by some teenage girls in a boston housing project was
>much more interesting, more adventurous, less man-and-his-work formulaic.
>the answer was: well i do "cultural studies" myself, but in this project
>i'm working with a fairly traditional understanding of the "avant garde,"
>so i'll stick w/ the kaufman piece.  for another instance, when i proposed
>a paper for the conference i mentioned, on "the poetics of avant garde
>poetry," there was some hesitatiion over acceptiing my paper because its
>definition of "avant garde" was too broad (won't it render the term
>meaningless to broaden it? was the question.)  again, i was advised by
>colleagues on the organizing side of things to stress that i was working
>with a "cultural studies model," i guess to provide reassurance that there
>was some recognized method to my intentions.  also, my introduction to this
>list and partcipation, while in some ways broadening (in that i've learned
>about poets i didn't know about before) has also been a narrowing, as the
>list is quite explicitly intended for discussion of newer poetries (i can't
>recall exactly the wording of the bernstein welcome). i don't mean to wax
>victimy or snide in these personal anecdotes, i hope you all realize how
>much i enjoy learning all this new stuff and getting to know y'all.  these
>moments of feeling the barriers come up have been interesting because they
>foreground categorical, operative divisions that are sometimes disavowed at
>the more overt level.
>another line that gets drawn is that of aesthetic judgment, and the
>assumption that we all share certain judgments (hallmark card verse is
>embarrassingly bad, so is maya angelou's poetry; bpNichol is fabulous, etc
>--don't get me wrong, i love bpNichol and i don't buy hallmark cards but i
>do find angelou's poetry meaningful, esp when i see how deeply it touches
>my students).  as i've said here before, aesthetic judgment has been the
>dividing line between me and some of the people i've worked with.  in fact
>i tend to trust them cuz i don't trust myself, so i usually concede at the
>level of editorial revision, but at the metalevel i'm asking, why is it SO
>overridingly important that there be some kind of consensus of aesthetic
>judgment? or, why is this consensus the basis of our community or
>commonality?--md

I've always thought, literally, that the avant-garde was a jail, a form of
reification ignoring the milieu. That it's useless as a term, since it
almost automatically assumes a while, most often male, etc. etc., striated
culture in the first place, the _avant_ necessitating a reification of the
rest. What happens is a certain exclusionary violence imho. It's a critic-
al move, no matter who applies the term.

Better to inscribe exfoliations of practices, sites of writings, sprays of
signifiers, instead of particulated emplacements - and at the same time to
acknowledge it was a highly problematic but common term, whose time has
past.

Alan

From:         Bob Grumman <BobGrumman@NUT-N-BUT.NET>
Subject:      The Otherstream
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Phooey, what a way to have to start the morning: I have to call for the
execution of Hugh Steinberg.  His offense?  EGREGIOUS MISUSE OF MY TERM,
"OTHERSTREAM."

Actually, I set him up by incompletely defining otherstream poetry as
"any poetry that has never (to any serious extent) gotten into an
anthology of poetry published by a 'reputable' publisher--like
Norton--or been seriously discussed in a book of criticism published by
such a publisher..."  So I hereby redefine it as "any TECHNICALLY
DISTINCT VARIETY OF poetry that has never, etc., etc."  Visual poetry is
always my primary example, though Marjorie Perloff's course in it, and
what Harry Polkinhorn has been doing at San Diego State, and other
developments may be changing that.

I agree with Hugh that there are two (or more) streams of work that are
not widely accepted, but consider only one of them otherstream.  The
second "otherstream" he speaks of--"poems that are written out of a
general ignorance of institution based poems (poems written by people
who don't read poetry)"--is, for me, knownstream because it's not doing
anything technically new.  It's wannabe mainstream, or unsuccessful
mainstream, or left-behind mainstream, or overlooked mainstream (as I
believe Robert Frost was when Pound "discovered" him).

I just thought of a name for it: sundaystream poetry, or the poetry of
weekend poets--though it would also, unfairly, include the poetry of
people working seriously and full-time in mainstream poetry who simply
haven't done whatever is required besides writing good poetry to be
accepted by the establishment.  I did sundaystream poetry for a long
time myself so have nothing against it--and, with Hugh, am most
interested in how it is being affected by other poetries.  But puleeze
don't call it "otherstream."

                                                --Bob G.

From:         dbkk@SIRIUS.COM
Subject:      Anne-Marie Albiach tribute in San Francisco
In-Reply-To:  <33EC190E.33F9@ibm.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

This is Kevin Killian.  Today's the 60th birthday of the French poet
Anne-Marie Albiach and last night here in San Francisco was the Albiach
tribute organized by Dodie Bellamy and Small Press Traffic.  I was there,
in the theater space at New College, and I know you're all curious, how did
it turn out?

Successfully I think.  OK there were a few glitches here and there.  Kush
the marvelous videographer failed to show up, and earlier in the week Small
Press Traffic's office was rifled and the microphone stolen.  However a
tape recorder was available and thus Dodie can prove the event really did
take place, documentation being "everything."  Norma Cole began the evening
by sketching out some of the salient turns in Albiach's career and showed
us a double portrait.  One photo was of the young Albiach in 1969, a glamor
portrait a la George Hurrell on the occasion of the publication of "Etat."
We were all struck by how much she (AMA) resembled the young Katherine Ross
in Curtis Harrington's "Games."  Then another kind of portrait, Jean
Daive's imaginative portrait of AMA done solely through her punctuation.
Cole then read from Albiach's "Gradiva," and read part of AMA's translation
of Louis Zukoksky's "A"-9.  Barbara Guest rose and read what sounded like a
new poem, a "Reverie" for AMA.  Benjamin Hollander combined parts of two
previous essays to create an atmosphere, a theatrical atmosphere which
effectively illustrated what he called the "nocturnal" aspect of Albiach's
writing (and its effect on the reader).  Michael Palmer read an essay
reminiscing on visiting (or trying to pay a visit to) AMA in Paris, she
wasn't home, so, he said, the absence of the non-encounter lived up to the
highest expectations of both parties, and then he read "Five Easy Poems,"
dedicated to AMA.  Mary Margaret Sloan spoke briefly on the influence AMA
has had over the years on the work of North American woman poets, and read
from AMA's book "Mezza Voce."  Cole Swensen read from "'Vocative Figure.'"
Then everyone turned to the cake, the "gateau," and tore that sucker to
shreds (or crumbs, I suppose).  There was much mingling, wine, and etc., if
only Steve Carll were still on this list he could tell you all the names of
the poets and artists who attended.

I thought it would be a case of preaching to the converted but there were
many there who had apparently never heard of Albiach, and all the copies of
"Mezza Voce" were quickly sold out, attesting to the event's success as,
well, a kind of promotion for the glamorous, reclusive diva of
Neuilly-sur-Seine.  However not all were so easily persuaded and one famous
poet afterwards was overheard murmuring that she still disliked Albiach's
writing and what was all the fuss about anyhow.  This made me think of
Rachel Levitsky's post about when "the dominant obliterates the
marginal, the dominant will always assert itself"though I can't piece out
how it applies exactly.

Anyhow, thanks to all who worked on this event behind the scenes, in front
of the podium, in the audience, and thanks to all the US and Canadian poets
who signed the series of tacky Hallmark cards for AMA's birthday, which
were delivered to her ahead of time and which stunned and surprised her and
made her weep with this kind of absent French pleasure.
=========================================================================
Date:         Sat, 9 Aug 1997 11:59:08 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Jacques Debrot <JDEBROT@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: "*alternative*avant-garde" (fwd)

Despite its problematic status, I think it's a mistake to give up -- or to
concede -- the metaphor, "avant-garde."  In addition to the texts that have
already been mentioned over the last several days during the course of this
discussion, let me add 3 more -- the first 2, Hal Foster's "What's Neo about
the Neo-Avant-Garde?" and Benjamin Buchloh's "Theorizing the Avant-Garde" --
go a long way in rebutting the failures Peter Burger attributes to the post
WW2 avant-gardes.  The 3rd, Andrew Benjamin's *Art, Mimesis and the
Avant-Garde,* is an extremely interesting attempt at describing the
avant-garde in terms of what he calls the limit experiences of *the
as-yet-to-be-determined*.  Tradition, by contrast, is seen by Benjamin as a
repetition of a *determination made in advance* -- a legislative/regulative
function which posits a singular and recoverable inner meaning for works of
art.  Of course, Benjamin realizes that, while there is a dominant tradition,
tradition itself is not a univocal term since there are also differing and
marginal traditions. The point is that the traditional *intends* to be
univocal.  However Benjamin does not define the avant-garde merely in terms
of its resistance to tradition.  This would only retain the dominant
dichotomy.  But in an argument that is much too subtle to recapitulate here,
Benjamin conceives of the avant-garde art object as affirming an
"interpretive differential plurality."  In other words the avant-garde work
of art, like the avant-garde itself, is seen as  being in a continual and
inexhaustible state of *becoming.*  Benjamin writes:  "it is the capacity for
an experience of the as-yet-to-be-determined to generate reflection.
 Reflection, in this instance, will emerge at the limit of understanding --
in other words at that point where the percept, object of experience, etc.,
is such that it cannot be automatically assimilated to, and hence only
explicable within, the terms decreed by" tradition.  If none of this seems
convincing the fault is due to my simplistic summary -- but, in any case,
Benjamin's work seems to me to persuasively refute the idea that the
avant-garde has a "policing function."

Date:         Sat, 9 Aug 1997 12:22:22 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         James Finnegan <JforJames@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: "*alternative*avant-garde"

Though the term "avant-garde" can be misapplied, I still find it
of use. I think it's wrong to apply it to any movement
that's not broken with the mainstream and moved
poetry forward/outward in some important way. Language poetry
is/was avant-garde. ("Was avant-garde," if you believe it's run
its course and is now subsumed in the mainstream, has aged
to the point of being old hat, or was a literary dead-end--the
equivalent of the Neanderthal line in ape-human evolution.)

"Avant-garde" should not be applied to movements like
Slam Poetry or the New Formalism. The latter is a retrograde
poetry, though a little freer and less delimited relative to
subject matter than traditional verse had been.
The former, Slam, takes several known poetries--(1)
the socio-political rant and reportage (a Beat mainstay);
(2) the much older and ever-present sentimental poetry
of love, loss and tragedy; (3) the hyper-confessional and
edgy-comic strains of late eighties and nineties--and to these
Slam adds the dynamics of performance and competition.
An innovation, yes, but not really something I would consider
avant-garde.

To me "avant-garde" is certainly as useful a term as the others
proposed--i.e., alternative and otherstream. Neither of which strikes
me as getting to what "avant-garde" is when applied to writing.
"Postmodernist", a broader, more encompassing term, is certainly
even harder to pin down. New Formalism could be the literary equivalent
of Philip Johnson's Chippendale top to his ATT Building, therefore
NF could be a postmodernist movement. And "alternative" was
the New Wave, before Alternative became Modern Rock. (The music
media have their own troubles with "labels"--Is there a Postmodernist
Rock yet?) "Otherstream" is a nice coinage, but could as easily apply
to Slam as to Language writing, thus for me it's less useful.

"Experimental" is the term most often misused. Most experiments
are failures--steeped in the trial & error method. Most writers
worth their salt aren't publishing their "experiments." Rather they are
experimenting toward a new way of the writing, personally
or in the world. Once the work is published, the writer is, in general,
confident the experiment has resulted in a finished text that is achieving,
at least partially or in a way he/she could only dimly imagine, the
intended outcome of his/her initial experiments. The publishing
one's "experimental writing" is tantamount to publishing early drafts
and half-baked, alchemic concoctions of varying and lesser
consequence.

Finnegan

From:         Joe Amato/Kass Fleisher <amato@CHARLIE.CNS.IIT.EDU>
Subject:      Re: "*alternative*avant-garde"
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

maria, hi!... thanx for your questions, time for me to delurk anyway!... to
employ some rather crude distinctions that i nonetheless find theoretically
useful:  i like to think through the questions you pose, re the avant-garde
and aesthetics, in two basic ways...

first, in terms of my own process as a writer:  sometimes---usually (to
date)---i imagine mself working/writing to construct a readership... that
is, the sorts of transformations i seek/anticipate/aspire for---in my
readers---i take to be primarily or largely a function of how they approach
reading my writing... the way they approach, that is, the alphabet as
such---the symbol-sharing experience that swapping same comprises (yes,
there is a utopian drift here)... and in many instances, i just don't think
the "they" exists as such!... it's not a claim i can prove, but it's useful
for me to imagine mself as contributing to an experience---over where you
are---that disrupts at times intelligibility, say...

i have of course worked in forms that seem to me to downplay this aspect of
the experience---that is, in which the so-called matter of "form" itself is
taken for granted, and in which "style" (please note quotes) replaces same
as a distinguishing characteristic... such, in my view, is one way of
beginning to think the discourse of scholars and scholarship in general
over and against the discourse of poets and poetry... though part of my
aim, as i understand my own work, has been to complicate this distinction;
when it comes to prose forms, such as the novel, the distinction may be
even fuzzier... yet i would say this distinction holds, even allowing for
the fact that there are poets *and* scholars who seek to complicate the
reading experience as such, and scholars *and* poets who seem to rely on an
already-understood experience (which is how i understand the
mainstream---again, not in terms of good or bad necessarily, but in terms
of popularity/demographix)...

the point here, in any case, is that work that challenges or speaks to the
reading experience (in terms, say, of the age-old form vs. content dualism)
is, in more popular AND often in academic terms, generally considered (and
critiqued/evaluated/dismissed/worshipped as) avant-garde or experimental or
radical or etc... ez to prove this, too---just TRY to get a trade press (or
an academic press) to pick up formally innovative work (and wrt to this
latter, pick your poison)... it ain't ez...

second, and here i think i'll be *really* idiosyncratic in my choice of
texts, is to think more in cultural studies terms, in terms of reception as
(as you suggest) a cultural-social process:  i'm reminded of that afterword
to pirsig's _zen and the art of motorcycle maintenance_, in which he
distinguishes twixt customary and what he calls "culture bearing books":

"a culture bearing book, like a mule, bears the culture on its back.  no
one should sit down to write one deliberately.  culture-bearing books occur
almost accidentally, like a sudden change in the stock market.  there are
books of high quality that are an important *part* of the culture, but that
is not the same.  they *are* a part of it.  they aren't carrying it
anywhere.  they may talk about insanity sympathetically, for example,
because that's the standard cultural attitude.  but they don't carry any
suggestion that insanity might be something other than sickness or
degeneracy."

i'm not wedded to pirsig's words, now---but if we allow that even "culture
bearing books" are a part of culture, and that there are in fact multiple
cultures, i think there's something in what pirsig is saying here that
might speak helpfully to the notion of contingency and history (he names
_uncle tom's cabin_ as a culture bearing book, but also says "it was no
literary masterpiece"---which latter is of course open to debate)...
provided of course we supplement same with the business aspects of the
writing marketplace etc...

so perhaps the matter of what is deemed avant-garde (term used advisedly)
turns at least in part on circumstances that are, properly speaking, beyond
anyone's control... ergo, the ex post facto nature of that discourse:
"this event turned out to be a seminal blah blah blah" (oh and i find this
latter useful too at times, but less when i'm in the process of writing
than when revising)... we may aspire to same, i mean, in our very process
as writers, we may lay claim to same (as i have at times) in our products,
but might this not comprise a requisite reach beyond one's grasp?... i.e.,
a failure?... even failure can produce some helpful effects, moods...

as far as hanging out with those what think like we do:  that's only human,
but past a certain point, it sure can prove limiting...

best,

joe

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Alan J Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      You, Celine, Die On
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

(I hear a voice ... now she's done it ... now there's no going back ... )



You


I met you in Jerusalem, I met you in Brooklyn ... said that to throw them
off the track ... it was near the Mea Shearim, you were being stoned ...
zealots, eh ... seven thousand miles away, your hair in my mouth ... I
swallow everything you have to offer, I'm not picky ... you give me ad-
jectives, expletives ... I give you gerunds ... they sway like that ...
turn me inside out ... forgot that these dots were stolen ... the walls
were baked hot, there was an omen, white fox darting in front of me ...
twenty years later, sure enough, that one in Cape Breton ... your hair had
silver streaks ... blond streaks ... all that opium I took, you took me to
the hospital, they made me get up off the floor, leave, lunch hour, there
was nothing to be done about it ... taxi-cab out of the city ... twenty
miles away you could smell the atoms ... I've photographed the sheets,
hung them from the window, I've tied myself in knots ... you could see the
building going up in the distance, I thought, why is he pointing a knife
at me, they destroyed the restaurant ... crawled out of the past ... I'm
uninhibited, eh ... what wouldn't I think of doing ... I need to have your
floor under me ... I want to write over and over again, collapse me ...
Jennifer is on my right side, Julu on my left ... they're waiting ... Jenn
goes to the door, looks out ... street's clear ... there's a gunner on the
roof but he's got his weapon down for a change, anyway it's for show,
beret and all .. landmines everywhere, barbed wire ... Julu flies, I
forgot to tell you that ... moved ahead of the rest of us ... fierce, eh,
she knows what's going on ... they've made a landing-strip of my chest ...
I can hear the planes, they're overhead all the time now ... the gunners
are closer to the ground, they don't dare look up ... rat-a-tat-tat, it
would be over, that would be the end of it ... can't have that, eh? Julu's
got moving now, she's really churning air ... that whore in Soho wouldn't
have me, I didn't know what I was doing, I lost sixty dollars, there were
more and more men the farther I went inside, they were watching me ...
lucky to get out with my life ... couldn't get it up anyway, I was tremb-
ling, disappearing down the streets, pathetic ... had to be rescued from
the sidewalk like that, taken in ... she told me I couldn't love her, she
was brown ... pulled a knife on me just like that ... taught school in
Washington DC ... later saw her with a group of people, laughing, had to
get out of there ... Denise wanted to tie me up naked, upside-down, don't
know the pleasure in that ... we picked up the stuff in Pennsylvania,
drove back through a cheating night, I couldn't pretend ... she got the
tape recorders, cords, signed Ginsberg, wanted to borrow everything, that
was the last I saw of them, she made up for the bad times in her own way
... I wasn't ready for this, just a lunch date, really, suddenly currents
change, I'm done with, inside out, upside-down ... later there's an
obelisk or prism, it's six-sided, limestone, about three meters tall, one
across. I can't make heads or tails of it ... it's turning, some sort of
vision ... I think of you again ... "disturbing dream ... Lisa Dilillo and
I were talking upstairs in her loft ... it was really Marcia Resnick's, I
recognized it ... Laurie Anderson lived upstairs, I was always moving ...
but it was dark, dangerous night, I was waiting for you, we were going
out, you'd ring my bell four stories down ... upstairs on the corner of
Canal and the river ... Lisa Dilillo and I in some heavy talk ... I said I
had to go, you were coming, I wanted to be there for you ... started down
the stairs, there were no lights ... just someone standing on one of the
landings ... I hoped it was you ... I felt a knife ... woke to write this,
steal Celine's dots ... his "three little dots ... screw him, he was
trouble ... in highschool someone pulled a knife on me, I grabbed the
blade ... I was filming in Los Angeles, the Sunset Strip, a whore came at
me ...  in Nazareth, an Arab flashed a knife, big problems there, went off
to kill his nephew, avenge us ... it's a long story, had to do with that
restaurant, our friend got beat up, dropped in a Wadi ... I can't pray any
more, eh, I've seen too much, my eyes have volumes in them, there's no end
to it ... Tamara B. and I screwed, I was still married, went off to
Tassie, wrote her, she told me to go to hell, wrote it all over my letter,
it was the final straw ... don't go there sober, eh? ... I'd given up, I
was desperate, turned her down in Irvine, she told me she "had her eyes on
me for a long time ... that was before the anonymous phone calls ... the
destruction of my work ... the letters ... everything in the world heads
towards purity ... that's all there is, a chance to begin again, start
over, head out, fly away, set the sails ... you don't get this often, it's
random, one day you're having lunch with someone for the first time, the
next day you're thinking, this is all there is! ... this is all I want!
...  Wait! Wait for me! ... carpe diem and all that, the Fugs sang it,
they were on my label ... she's never heard my music ... I've gotten
through all of this, what's next, I've got to do the book too ... a couple
of them ... maybe more ... I'll start again if she'll have me ... I'll
give her me on a platter ... on a board ... clothed or unclothed, whatever
she wants ... this isn't a great prize, mind you, a little tarnished, but
some good points ... thinks well maybe, for example ... moves fast ... bit
too intense ... she can take me, do what she will, someone's put the knife
away ... Jennifer and Julu are sleeping, it's late even for them ... smoke
and clouds ... incredible dawns ... I'll wait and see ... what happens to
the night

From:         Steve Evans <Steven_Evans@BROWN.EDU>
Subject:      Impercipient Lecture Series
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Two more installments of the monthly Impercipient Lecture Series (ILS) have
appeared since our initial announcement to the List in June.

Aldon L. Nielsen's "No Saints in Three Acts: On Stephen Jonas" should begin
appearing in mailboxes today.  Nielsen is among the first to give Jonas's work
the careful attention it both deserves and, in light of its fractured political
commitments, demands.  Great archival finds, including a powerful description
of the Baraka/Jonas correspondence, combined with Nielsen's signature ability
to practice a utopic form of close reading that models the desegregated mind
while acknowledging the still-segregated social body, makes this a must read.

Beth Anderson's "Imperturbable Things: On Still-Life Poetics" is a wonderfully
original meditation on the deceptive stillness at the heart of the
linguistic storm
in the work of Wallace Stevens, Barbara Guest, Marjorie Welish, Keith Waldrop,
Ann Lauterbach, and others.  Despite our canny release of this pamphlet in
June,
just as the blockbuster shown on Still Life got underway at New York's Museum
of Modern Art, a handful (literally) of copies are still available.

We've also recently done a small reprint of our inaugural issue, "The Dynamics
of Literary Change" by co-editor Steve Evans.  A fair number of our issue on
Bob Perelman's _The Marginalization of Poetry_ remain in supply.

The two back-issues that are unfortunately out of print at this time are:
1.2     Radical Dogberry and Society Sketches by Chris Stroffolino
1.3     The Ground is the Only Figure by Rosmarie Waldrop

Finally, to all the List-members who have shown support for the ILS through
contributions verbal and financial: Thank You!

Steve Evans & Jennifer Moxley
61 E. Manning Street
Providence RI 02906-4008

Date:         Sat, 9 Aug 1997 18:20:31 -0700

From:         David Bromige <dcmb@METRO.NET>
Subject:      avant ga-ga's
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Rachel, I appreciate yr response. I realize my response has a
'plague-on-all-their-houses' air to it, perhaps akin to donald's 'It's all
writing'. With me, this is due to an impatience with negotiating the space
between the work and the consumer. What is self-evident to the creator is
hardly so to potential readers, yet it's frustrating to take all the
guide-dog/hand-rail/sign-posted material one left out of the poetry for
esthetic cause, & have to recycle it as prose 'trot'/explanatory manifesti.
Perhaps one is more sensitive to this demand when one (as I) earned a
living for a quarter-century providing just such aid to those eagerly (or
perhaps not) seeking to get with the new in poetry. Au fond, it takes place
as an internal conflict, leastwise with me, a constant source of irritation
that leads me to dismissive gestures.

You are helpful with the suggestions of colleagues; Cole's intelligence &
patience are manifest in her reappropriation of 'marginal' so that it
places the writing she practices & whose practice she supports in others,
on a level playing field with 'maindrains' writing. Carla's 'hybridity'
strikes a chord with me--the local hero in sonoma county is Luther Burbank,
and for decades I've spoken to folks around here of the 'grafting' aspects
of the Modern. 'Making strange', your own candidate, makes sense too.

But ....but....  from a poet's p-o-v, it often comes to 'but not _my_ kind
of making strange', understandably, since 'making strange' can never be a
uniform endeavor. And 'not _my_ way of hybridizing' . The case of Michael
Palmer is worth considering here. As was pointed out by 6 poets
collaborating on an essay abt LangPo, Palmer had been in every 'LangPo'
collection and most journals devoted to publishing 'LangPo', so that his
disclaimer, in an i'view, 'I'm always a little outisde of the group, like
Matisse', had a bad-faith ring to it. His case gets more confusing when one
recalls that one of his books was touted by his publisher as being 'by the
leading Language Poet', and that it is declared by his translator in the
french edition of _Sun_ that Palmer 'never was a Language Poet.'

Whatever one thinks of Palmer's conduct of these negotations, one regrets,
for one's own sake, the necessity of them. I understand your point, Rachel,
about the 'dominant mode' more easily obliterating poetry not to its
liking, when that poetry fails to concert itself under some one stunning
rubric. Its a concern imposed by the dominant, it has one already speaking
the opporessor's language, yet it looks to be a dilemma of 'compromise
oneself or die'. To whom do you need to speak of yourself (since you use
this parallel) as 'lesbian'? Is it required in order to let men know not to
bother you, or in order to let others so inclined that you might be
available, or to qualify oneself for those few privileges that can come a
lesbian's way, or....? what is the necessity? Cab't the negotiations happen
on a one-on-one basis without recourse to labels, but instead by way of
declaration of taste and volition? I guess it can be seen as 'Strength in
numbers' and mutual support; as necessary assertion of pride in oneself in
the face of many who would shame one; as 'coming out' as courageous gesture
of commitment in a society still largely uncomprehending? I like your
analogy, and I think it bears further exploration as to parallels.

'Lesbian,' however, is a term whose currency is now well-established, and
so we are still left with the question, 'what is the name for what we
do--what claim to unity with others can we make that doesnt depreciate the
particular 'making-strange' it's one's destiny/fate/choice to have
incurred?' 'Not this', the first sentence of Silliman's poem, does lead, in
its case, to 'What then?' Ron's complex and active awareness of the needs
of the poetry-consumer in a society that offers brief, inadequate
explanations--but that _does_ offer explanations--for anything one might be
supposed to need to purchase, surely helped take him from sentence one to
sentence two. To have stopped with sentence one is an option I for one find
attractive. So that the 'What then?' is spoken, originates, in the reader,
with no further prompting from the poem.

That has the appearance of the idealistic in today's world, though, doesn't
it?

Well, this is long enough already, and coming to no resolution. I can only
hope that it nudges the discussion along a minim. Thanks, Rachel, for the
stimulus. David.

Date:         Sun, 10 Aug 1997 01:26:19 -0400

Subject:      hendecasyllabics' metaphorics
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

on a different note (altho the poem below cd be seen as 1870s avant-garde
now tres derriere...)

for those like me in late-summer doldrums wondering where the time flew,
perhaps a metaphor or two to tease out:

        In the month of the long decline of roses
        I, beholding the summer dead before me,
        Set my face to the sea and journeyed silent,
        Gazing eagerly where above the sea-mark
        Flame as fierce as the fervid eyes of lions
        Half divided the eyelids of the sunset;...
                        [swinburne, "hendecasyllabics"]

now we have flame above the sea-mark: presumably we are already to think
sun and/or sunset.  said flame's fierceness, fiercety?, likened to fervid
lioneyes.  now for the kicker: flame half divides eyelids.  hold on to
that for the moment, let's tend to these eyelids first.  eyelids of the
sunset: possesive or partitive genitive, the sunset /has/ eyelids or /is/
eyelids?  if the sun is the eye (as it has already been associated with
fervid lioneyes), then eyelids can be sky and earth, upper and lower
limits of vision, extinguishing the sun in the slow blink of its setting,
its setting under, its untergehen.

yet flame half divides
eyelids, divides them in
half, keeps them open.
even when closed they
are still divided,

by the horizon, or:
half divides as in
divides only partly,
not completely, half
divided half joined.

even tho i gaze
eagerly above
the sea-mark
the flame is so

fierce, as sky
and earth close
on the sun, i

have to squint,
join my eyelids
together, close
them enough so

that they are
still open.
to the horizon.

J Finnegan - I like your idea or description of experiment as something
that precedes publication.  Though exploratory work will always seem
experimental.

"Avant-garde" seems like a contradiction in terms.  Whenever the really
new has solidified to the point of being a lined-up advance in good order,
it's already crusted over.  Have it for lunch tomorrow.

Progress.  Sure it happens.  Sure there is the new.  Sure people grow off
each other's energy.  But why do you say the New Formalists are "freer"
than the plain old formalists?  Doesn't this betray rather a linear notion?

Close reading will turn a lot of old poetry into very avant-garde material.
Dante, acc'd to my old buddy Mandlestam, is a poet of the future.

The idea that tradition is univocal (not your idea, a different post), is
too abstract to mean anything. Look back in lit history & you see a conti-
nuous nervous fluctuation of attitudes, styles, etc.  "Every significant
movement in English poetry could be interpreted as a reaction to the political
situation." (Stephen Spender, 1940).

Another interesting Spender quote:  "Now the poet is someone who devotes
his life to exactly such a process of self-revelation as drama attempts to
produce in characters: his poems are speeches from the drama of the time
in which he is living."  (1938)

The avant-garde is that portion of the new which has been assured canonical
gluing into "the tradition".  Think about it. Maybe that's the answer to
Maria's question (paranoid though it may be tending toward...)
- Henry Gould

Just a quick blast - Aldon's extended essay on Jonas, which I was lucky
enough to be handed OUTSIDE the Harris collection on Prospect St., is
VERY good work & great reading.  He's done his homework & his
essay is remarkable for the number of issues it touches on (neglected
startling poet - Stephen Jonas; race relations & identity; style in
50s-60s experimental poetry; the visual/textual/WRITTEN as an overall
musical-sharpening tool in Jonas' work after Pound & Olson) -
WITHOUT getting lost in the minutiae or neglecting a considered
assessment of Jonas' achievemnts.

Way to go Aldon!  Now I have to look for that Talisman book of this guy
(Jonas - SELECTED POEMS, Talisman Hs 1994).

Jonas seems to have been an extremely witty writer lost in the fuzz of time.
Beautiful archival digging here.  Witty, highly musical, & violent sharp &
edgy.  But some of the edge seems to be sharpened/softened by his direct
application of blues & jazz in a very deliberate & extensive way.

 - Henry Gould

Curses on me, I've almost always found the opposite to be true - that the
avant-garde is often retrograde - at the same time everyone was praising
Godard's attack on the corporate (and binding women to the sex industry
vis-a-vis the gaze of the director), the same was occurring in hollywood
film after film.

Attacks on systems and classical logics, rationality, came from as varied
sources as Godel, Alexander Bryant Johnson, Vaihinger. Meanwhile avant-
garde groups issued manifestos without questioning the problematic of
writing, say, issues of protocol statements, performativity, etc.

Watching the lure, seduction, objet a of soap operas tends more towards
postmodernity's deconstruction of narratology than, say, Holly Hughes who
I love by the way.

As far as technology goes, I've learned more from say Brenda Laurel begin-
ning with the computer, than from artists, too many of whom think the
Net's equivalent to the World Wide Web.

Sorry to interfere here, but ah, there's another McLuhan bust as far as
I'm concerned...

Alan, up far too late with himself, apologies to everyone

George Bowering wrote:

> Here's another thing i always used to wonder. Does yr US body called the
> House Unamerican Activities Committee investigate activities carried on in
> , say, Sweden, Niger and Reunion?

George, HUAC changed its name to the House Internal Security Committee
in 1969 and was abolished in 1975 (after Watergate), although I think
somebody forgot to tell Gingrich, Helms and Buchanan.  There's a
hilarious chapter on the committee in Jessica Mitford's _A Fine Old
Conflict_ (which is out of print, unfortunately).  Among other
jollities, she reveals that HUAC, in one of its first actions, named
Shirley Temple (then nine) as an unwitting dupe of the Communists, and
later designated Christopher Marlowe as Un-American.

Rachel Loden

Hmmm, another person to execute: James Finnegan for saying that while he
thinks "Otherstream" a good coinage (thanks!), he believes it "could as
easily apply to Slam as to Language writing."  Wrong on both counts.
According to my definition, both Slam Poetry and Language Writing are
KNOWNSTREAM, the opposite of otherstream because they, or poetry in all
essential respects identical to it in the case of Slam Poetry, are in
the establishment press anthologies.  Slam Poetry is probably mainstream
(a substream of knownstream) as well; Language Writing is not.

Subject:      Re: "*alternative*avant-garde"
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.SUN.3.95.970810033440.20404A-100000@panix3.panix.com>

Apparently what you do when you're up late by yourself is confuse
categories. What's avant garde about Godard is and was his montage, not his
politics. Lots of us went to his films for instruction in the former, very
few for the latter.
Are you truly suggesting that only those who are in the vanguard in all
things are worthy? If your mathematicians had conventional table manners
and wrote elizabethan sonnets in secret would you dismiss them?
But to return to politics--artists of most stripes most of the time are
lousy predictors of the future (mathematicians, the writers of soap operas
and even technonerds are not notably more successful). Pound (whatever
avant garde meant, he qualified), fortunately, missed the boat politically.
Many of us learn from his innovations, but few from his politics.
Let's try this one: sometimes artists, no matter how progressive their art,
by the sheer luck of history, wind up clearing the path for an army that
most of us consider regressive. Wagner, who also was as avant garde as you
can get, became after his death the darling of the nazis, who liked his
politics, and there are probably more than a few lost souls who still seek
nourishment of that sort from him. But that's not why he remains for most
composers the most influential composer of the late nineteenth century, and
it's not why most of his audience goes to the opera.

On Sun, 10 Aug 1997, mark weiss wrote:

> Apparently what you do when you're up late by yourself is confuse
> categories. What's avant garde about Godard is and was his montage, not his
> politics. Lots of us went to his films for instruction in the former, very
> few for the latter.

This brings up an interesting point - to what extent are they separable?
For part of the politics of '68 that went into his work revolved around
the reification, self-reflexivity of the filmic process - and this has to
be somewhat centripetal, a site of all forms of contestation which are
interpenetrated.

> Are you truly suggesting that only those who are in the vanguard in all
> things are worthy? If your mathematicians had conventional table manners
> and wrote elizabethan sonnets in secret would you dismiss them?

Oh Heavens no! Seriously, please don't misunderstand. I'm hopefully not
making a value judgement, certainly not one on the basis of "vanguardism"
or "avantgardism" at all. My own reading is widespread; I'm just worrying
the category, and reacting to the notion that the "avantgarde" is somehow
culturally advanced - questioning the somehow.

> But to return to politics--artists of most stripes most of the time are
> lousy predictors of the future (mathematicians, the writers of soap operas
> and even technonerds are not notably more successful). Pound (whatever
> avant garde meant, he qualified), fortunately, missed the boat politically.

I just wish he had taken another boat!

> Many of us learn from his innovations, but few from his politics.
> Let's try this one: sometimes artists, no matter how progressive their art,
> by the sheer luck of history, wind up clearing the path for an army that
> most of us consider regressive. Wagner, who also was as avant garde as you
> can get, became after his death the darling of the nazis, who liked his
> politics, and there are probably more than a few lost souls who still seek
> nourishment of that sort from him. But that's not why he remains for most
> composers the most influential composer of the late nineteenth century, and
> it's not why most of his audience goes to the opera.
>
I can't speak that well to Wagner, but I think in fact the pan-Germanism
of his work did speak, integrate well with imperialism - and for me,
listening relatively carefully at times (not within years however) to his
music, it is also a fanfare for, if not an ideology, at least an
ideological plateau - it's oddly programmatic.

We have had this debate before, and it's always a matter of degree - for
example, I like Heidegger a great deal, particularly his later work, in
spite of his Nazi affiliation.

In other words, I'm not arguing at all for purity in work, nor even for an
ulterior accountability, but again reacting to McLuhan's statement and
other texts which assume that an avant-garde _site,_ so to speak is also
the _site_ of somehow "advanced" thought - without deconstructing the
latter in terms of the culture at large.

Alan

In-Reply-To:  <Pine.SUN.3.95.970810141237.7178C-100000@panix3.panix.com>

Right you are. Self-declared avant gardes are sometimes anything but. The
corrective I offer is that artists like Godard, Wagner, Pound, are, indeed,
"the site of somehow 'advanced' thought," but that thought is to be found
in the process of the films, music and poetry themselves. In the case of
Wagner, who greatly extended the harmonic resources available to composers
and invented an astonishing new way to structure large works (based on the
repitition and combination of motifs--some polyphonic passages become
incredibly rich and complex metaphoric worlds), composers of all political
stripes have continued to learn from his music, notably Verdi, Mahler and
Schoenberg, who were not particularly sympathetic to his politics.

I'm not arguing at all for purity in work, nor even for an
>ulterior accountability, but again reacting to McLuhan's statement and
>other texts which assume that an avant-garde _site,_ so to speak is also
>the _site_ of somehow "advanced" thought - without deconstructing the
>latter in terms of the culture at large.
>
>Alan
>
>

I want to add that I'm in agreement with you here. I do think it can be
difficult to separate one aspect of that thought from others, but I also
think it's absolutely necessary. One of the interesting aspects of wri-
ters like Celine, Pound, Heidegger, Dostoevksy, etc., for me, is that the
anti-semitism is pretty well buried, available elsewhere (for example
Marx's letters) but not necessarily played across the major texts. And I
don't believe in a contamination principle, that "bad-thought _here_"
need result in a loosening of rigour or value "_there._"

Alan

From:         Dan Raphael Dlugonski <raphael@ARACNET.COM>
Subject:      avant-stream
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

avant garde? otherstream?
one of my impressions is being on the frontier, away from the center. doing
things with your art that you don't know of anyone else doing (yes there are
links back, 3rd cousins, you are what you eat, stained by the culture you're
steeped in.)
seems, from the usage so far in this discussion, that avant garde is kind of
a dividing line, beyond a certain pale. the acceptable/center continues to
evolve, to include poets who a century ago would not be tasteable by that
stream.
my longheld (& probably over optimistic) attitude is that good writers write
the way that connects with their beings. for some writers, this truespeak
happens to fit  the mode of most acceptable and that writer prospers wildly.
we are laying down our individual visions, a wide variety outside the pale
than within. some people get their voice right off; most of us going thru
phases of influence, getting our bearings, before the proper pitch begins to
unlock the stream/voice.
but its such a wide filed, this otherstream, the more important labels are
subdivisions--langpo, surrealism, etc., and all those riding rifts along the
ambiguous borders. to recognize the various channels along which poetry
receives/transmits and find those you can work best to open/expand your and
other consciousnesses.
=========================================================================

My question is, is there anything in those documents you disagree with?
Would you choose not to uphold them? If so, signing would be a lie, right?
Do those documents imply that you cannot teach that Zukofsky was a Marxist
or that his "an impulse to action" poem is cribbed out of Marxist texts,
or the showing of those texts, for instance. I think not.

Personally, I took such an oath many years ago, and I meant every word of
it. Still do. Not waving a flag, just that I still have that oath.

I can't stand flags or war, and these documents do try to resolve problems
in bargaining instead of war. I'd feel even better about it if we had
gotten the ERA passed, though. I just want to say that swearing to uphold
such things as free speech and freedom of the press does not mean you have
to agree with the current administration.

Pete

From:         Hugh Steinberg <hsteinberg@GRIN.NET>
Subject:      Re: The Otherstream
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Bob:

Although you seem particularly intent on policing your borders, I beg of
you not to shoot (I still have my whole life ahead of me, I promise to be
good, my parents would be overwrought with grief, etc. etc.).

Fine if you want to keep the term "otherstream" narrow.  I'll even use the
term sundaystream (though it is quite condescending).  But I think this
sundaystream of poetics is important and worth paying attention to,
especially within a discussion of avant-gardes.

Much of the definition of "real" and "phony" avant-gardes revolve around
issues of formal experimentation:  who is the most innovative.

I'd argue that this is not what avant-gardes are about, that innovativeness
is only a subset of the term.  The main purpose, the distinguishing feature
that separates the avant-garde from the experimental is the desire to
effect change in people, first in their view of the artistic or political
medium, and then, more deeply, in the perception and course of their lives.
Surrealism is a classic example.

The reason most people are reluctant to use the term avant-garde anymore is
a general lack of faith that poetry, particularly formally experimental
poetry, has the capacity to change people's lives (with the exception of a
few people here and there).  This is reasonable, as poetry isn't a mass
medium in the U.S.

There is a loophole in this despair.  I'm thinking of another model of
change, of two types of avant-gardes: an impatient and a patient
avant-garde.  The impatient wants big change NOW, a revolution.  From now
on, their manifestos read, everything shall be different.

I doubt that form of avant-garde is feasible in our time.

The patient avant-garde takes a long view.  Instead of fire, it is a seed,
working its way slowly over time, creating change gradually, sometimes
glacially, instead of immediately.  I believe that experiments in writing
can change the way people think and live, and that this patient idea of the
avant-garde has relevance.

The contested field of change in poetics is the sundaystream, as this is
where the most substantial effects of any avant-garde will be felt.  How
will ordinary people think about poetry?  If one is an avant-garde, the
answer to this question is their raison d'etre.

One of the things I find so promising about slam poetics has nothing to do
with form or even content but rather in presentation.  What slams and open
mikes are doing is transforming a fundamental axiom of sundaystream poetry,
that poetry is essentially a private act, meant not to be shared with
strangers.  It desires to move poetry from an individual experience of
reading and writing, to a more public sphere of performance and audience.
No, they are not the first to do this, or even the best at doing this, but
they are doing this, and it is fascinating to see the impact it has made on
the way people write and perceive poetry, art, and even larger issues.

Hugh Steinberg

>what Harry Polkinhorn has been doing at San Diego State, and other
>developments may be changing that.

>not widely accepted, but consider only one of them otherstream.  The
>second "otherstream" he speaks of--"poems that are written out of a
>general ignorance of institution based poems (poems written by people
>who don't read poetry)"--is, for me, knownstream because it's not doing
>anything technically new.  It's wannabe mainstream, or unsuccessful
>mainstream, or left-behind mainstream, or overlooked mainstream (as I
>believe Robert Frost was when Pound "discovered" him).
>
>I just thought of a name for it: sundaystream poetry, or the poetry of
>weekend poets--though it would also, unfairly, include the poetry of
>people working seriously and full-time in mainstream poetry who simply
>haven't done whatever is required besides writing good poetry to be
>accepted by the establishment.  I did sundaystream poetry for a long
>time myself so have nothing against it--and, with Hugh, am most
>interested in how it is being affected by other poetries.  But puleeze
>don't call it "otherstream."

From:         Rebecca Weldon <rcweldon@LOXINFO.CO.TH>
Subject:      avant-garde and the Larousse universel
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

My Larousse indicates that avant-garde is, firstly, a military term
referring to those who prepare the ground (or water) for an attack by ground
or naval forces.  It has come to be used in a figurative sense to refer to
those who prefigure another era in thought, ie. idees d'avant-garde.

The word is of the feminine gender along with avant-premiere, avant-scene
and avant-veille and might be interestingly compared to avant-bec,
avant-coureur, avant-gout, avant-poste, avant-projet and avant-propos, all
of the masculine gender.

And, in it's original meaning, I believe that the military term would be
found in all languages around the world.  It exists in Thai: thap na (the
"h" in "thap" simply indicating an aspirated or hard "t" sound).  The term
is also used figuratively in the same way.

Interesting?

Rebecca

From:         Robert Hale <hale@ETAK.COM>
Subject:      the misery of poetry
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

What Bataille calls "the misery of poetry" should inform why it is that we
don't see too much actual poetry on the poetics list (see Literature and
Evil). To turn unsatisfaction into a permanent object is a hefty job for the
ephemeral e-mail, which renders language into deletable scripts. Do eyes
scan the screen the same way that they read the page? And let's answer that
by NOT getting into any banal cyber vs book space threads.

I for one welcome gb's return to the List from the sunshine shores of
Sechelt, having missed his wicked wit & wide wisdom. The "consumer" poetry
he heard there suggests another name for what one would write : inedible
poetry. It has indelible built into it. I was also shored up by his use of
the word "present," as in, I thought, "Present Poetry." For writing the
present -- re cognizing existence in light of the forward edge of history,
which _has_ an inescapable linearity -- surely is a common injunction, &
cause for avoiding older baffles, technically speaking. (Those baffles
which are precisely (or vaguely) what by gb's term extended, a
"consumerist" audience, would recognize the poetic by). Inedible, indeible:
I am thinking of those of Alan Jennifer Sondheim's poems which, while
coming from a tradition that owes its durability to human nature, the poem
of hopeless longing, do so in terms of a new technology, terms which often
elude my understanding, but which feel fresh, which experience always is,
until put into words.  David

Pete Landers has done something rather astonishing here.  I'm not sure
what exactly it is yet, but one thing he's done is show in an indirect way
the extent of the damage inflicted by the McCarthy era (echoed by the Nixon
era & re-echoed by the Reagan era).

A state college is part of the State.  Only a Helms (& perhaps a New Critic)
would assume that a State job teaching automatically jeopardizes political
and artistic freedom.

Or is it basically intellectual freedom that is at issue?  Should a loyalty
oath be extracted from people in the intellectual professions?  Or in any
profession?  Isn't it a sort of economic blackmail? Or at least a sign of
loose anarchic big brotherism? Or rampant federalism?  I think it has something
 to do with tax money.  Taxes are a downpayment on patriotism for some.
Loyalty oaths protect state funding for education.  If you're for state
funding and approve for the time being of the constitution (rather than
a completely different or no constitution) I agree with Pete why not sign.
- Henry Gould
(because poets are the unacknowledged legislators of a dream republic?)

David--thanks for the long, provocation.  About a month ago, Mahate
asked me what is a lesbian.  Umm, my response: "some _one_ who commits
sex in defiance of 'compulsory heterosexuality,' whose _main_ attraction
is for the female body."  In response to your question, I am personally
more interested in the word as it aids in defying rigid constraints on
sexuality than I am in hitting on women or keeping men away.  Also
important is community, if that's what you mean by few priviledges,
though nothing was worse than small city pot lucks where it is assumed
that you want to be around people simply because they are dykes!  The
variety of NYC a huge relief.  Back to my definition, I am less
interested in exluding unlike bodies, than I am in exluding those of
unlike committment.  Example, bi-sexuals who want to be in on the parade
and have a June wedding to boot.  Not that many homosexuals don't cream
in their pants at the idea of a wedding but if we are on political
ground, there is a hierarchy set up by the priviledging of marriage to
heterosexual pairings.  And political integrity would suggest you can't
sit in both positions at once.  I am interested in integrity.  In Tokyo
there is a group called Wanabes, females who live as males and work in
clubs where they are solicited by straight women.  One of the wanabes
interviewed in the documentary I saw (_Shinjuku Boys_,  Kim Longinotto,
Jana Williams) lived in a partnership with a transexual born male living
female, another wanabe had fallen in love with a client, a straight
woman.   Each couple seemed to be living their own category.  One wanabe
said "I've heard lesbians take off their clothes [in sex] but we wanabes
don't like to do that"
        Maybe this is making no point but to say we are always
redefining our terms.  You ask, "what is the name for what we do?" and
I'd say naming is what we do, and re-naming in good anarchist form.  I
would say that 'making-strange' can be a claim to unity in terms of
committment.  As when M. Damon invokes the(I should say 'a', not all
mid-westerners do this) mid-western meaning of the phrase "it's
different" (or Bernstein "Difference or/*differance*:it's/the
distinction between hauling junk and/removing rubbish, while/I needless
not to say, take/out the garbage".
        And the flip side to the committment of 'making strange' would
be translation, stretch, making communion, sorry for the slippage here.
        Perhaps there was more I wanted to say but ya, ya, enough, the
mire widens!  --Rachel

Date:         Mon, 11 Aug 1997 01:48:26 -0600

From:         Hugh Steinberg <hsteinberg@GRIN.NET>
Subject:      Re: Anne-Marie Albiach tribute in San Francisco
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Much like the gateau, I thought the tribute was most delicious.  Being new
to San Francisco, it was a pleasure to finally meet Kevin Killian in the
flesh.  I spent much of the reading in the second row writing, combining
what I was hearing and thinking (I do this at most readings, though the
choice of row varies, using the material in my own work).  Anyhow, here's
the poem I wrote from that evening.

Two poems after listening to Anne-Marie Albiach


1.

he discerns her portrait in the punctuation from her book.  the type
of energy found in a spiral on a page.  response to different works.
the excavation of a story.  how it happened as an unfolding of
leaves.  as in spring or the manuscript as it becomes a book.  she
says pictures.  photographs.  points stretched in dark weight.  like
ink as it becomes words and punctuation.  as a torch in the glass of
night.  a mime of absence.  so it is in voice several times.  which
was written and revised until it no longer resembled speech.  a fall
or an answer.  to repeat each symbolic body until they are
numerous.  white stars in the evening sky.

2.

to live in steps.  by leaves in a book about to be printed.  in the
letters dead people write each spring.  light gathers in memory
where the pictures were lost.  consider how he was reading.  the
hour of things.  as equated values.  in labor or goods created.  to
count like knuckles.  words in fists.  in muscles which rest.  in the
absence of threat night slips in.  in the creation of darkness through
petty acts and great machines.  of broad and hopeless spaces.  a
promise which was discontinued.  as it is all the same.  ideas which
erase their erasers.  in time as it hurries.  like a transistor between
ghosts and he who is merciless.


Hugh Steinberg


>This is Kevin Killian.  Today's the 60th birthday of the French poet
>Anne-Marie Albiach and last night here in San Francisco was the Albiach
>tribute organized by Dodie Bellamy and Small Press Traffic.  I was there,
>in the theater space at New College, and I know you're all curious, how did
>it turn out?
>
>Successfully I think.  OK there were a few glitches here and there.  Kush
>the marvelous videographer failed to show up, and earlier in the week Small
>Press Traffic's office was rifled and the microphone stolen.  However a
>tape recorder was available and thus Dodie can prove the event really did
>take place, documentation being "everything."  Norma Cole began the evening
>by sketching out some of the salient turns in Albiach's career and showed
>us a double portrait.  One photo was of the young Albiach in 1969, a glamor
>portrait a la George Hurrell on the occasion of the publication of "Etat."
>We were all struck by how much she (AMA) resembled the young Katherine Ross
>in Curtis Harrington's "Games."  Then another kind of portrait, Jean
>Daive's imaginative portrait of AMA done solely through her punctuation.
>Cole then read from Albiach's "Gradiva," and read part of AMA's translation
>of Louis Zukoksky's "A"-9.  Barbara Guest rose and read what sounded like a
>new poem, a "Reverie" for AMA.  Benjamin Hollander combined parts of two
>previous essays to create an atmosphere, a theatrical atmosphere which
>effectively illustrated what he called the "nocturnal" aspect of Albiach's
>writing (and its effect on the reader).  Michael Palmer read an essay
>reminiscing on visiting (or trying to pay a visit to) AMA in Paris, she
>wasn't home, so, he said, the absence of the non-encounter lived up to the
>highest expectations of both parties, and then he read "Five Easy Poems,"
>dedicated to AMA.  Mary Margaret Sloan spoke briefly on the influence AMA
>has had over the years on the work of North American woman poets, and read
>from AMA's book "Mezza Voce."  Cole Swensen read from "'Vocative Figure.'"
>Then everyone turned to the cake, the "gateau," and tore that sucker to
>shreds (or crumbs, I suppose).  There was much mingling, wine, and etc., if
>only Steve Carll were still on this list he could tell you all the names of
>the poets and artists who attended.
>
>I thought it would be a case of preaching to the converted but there were
>many there who had apparently never heard of Albiach, and all the copies of
>"Mezza Voce" were quickly sold out, attesting to the event's success as,
>well, a kind of promotion for the glamorous, reclusive diva of
>Neuilly-sur-Seine.  However not all were so easily persuaded and one famous
>poet afterwards was overheard murmuring that she still disliked Albiach's
>writing and what was all the fuss about anyhow.  This made me think of
>Rachel Levitsky's post about when "the dominant obliterates the
>marginal, the dominant will always assert itself"though I can't piece out
>how it applies exactly.
>
>Anyhow, thanks to all who worked on this event behind the scenes, in front
>of the podium, in the audience, and thanks to all the US and Canadian poets
>who signed the series of tacky Hallmark cards for AMA's birthday, which
>were delivered to her ahead of time and which stunned and surprised her and
>made her weep with this kind of absent French pleasure.
=========================================================================

Subject:      Imperialist running dogs
In-Reply-To:  <199708101510.LAA40658@node5.frontiernet.net>

Charles Alexander: Sign the oath to secure the job and hope to
later have a fulfilling chance to violate the hell out of such a
Stalinist loyalty contract.

Pete Landers: Let's say just hypothetically that twenty years from
now after a few years of deep economic crisis and U.S troops
completely bogged down in the Amazon in Brazil that there is
discontent all over the place and the UPS workers start a strike and
its 1968 France all over again only this time there's an
upstart socialist leadership in the U.S. labor movement which is
class conscious and really pissed off and calls for nationwide
strikes with the idea that the country has been run for the
past two hundred and forty years largely for the pleasures of
capital and there's no need for that to go on any longer and
let's cut they say the military budget by nine-tenths and a big part
of U.S. labor responds and then in a panic a purportedly liberal
Democratic Party administration suspends habeus corpus and the
constitution and avant-garde poetry and everything else and declares
martial law outlawing all public activity by enemies of the United
States foreign or domestic. What say you Pete Landers about that
loyalty contract you meant every word of three decades back? Would
you turn in the elderly poet Charles Alexander if you suspected he
was a friend of the radical and national-security-threatening
AFL-CIO? Would you still uphold his right to freedom of speech? Even
his right to violate his loyalty oath in defense of freedom of speech
and the press (I'm talking for example about Charles Alexander
standing in front of a crowd of angry U of Arizona students and
urging them to defy government instituted martial law)?

Ok, this is all fanciful and maybe you'll say (I hope) yes to my last
question, but the truth is that there are loyalties and then there
are loyalties. Freedom of speech and the press is obviously wonderful
while we more or less have it ("more or less" because of little
publicized but longstanding spying and harrassment activities of
local and national government agencies against legal political
dissidents). But the McCarthyite loyalty oath you are so proud to
have signed does not speak to liberties of speech and the press that
are pure, inalienable, and free from historical contingency. It
speaks to their opposite--hidden, for now, as that opposite may be.
Kent

Subject:      imperialist bow-wows
Mime-Version: 1.0

Kent's hypothesized fascist future reminded me that i wanted to post to the
list the solution to the "flying-saucer" confusion.

There are no such creatures as space aliens (except us).

USAF technology has included, since shortly after WW 2, the ability to use
the electro-magnetic field to suspend gravity. Flying machines that can
hover in place, or go very fast in any direction, that are silent, and that
carry weaponry of an electronic sort, highly sophisticated--can stall cars
from a distance--do exist.

The flying saucer space alien myth has been fostered by the USAF at certain
levels. To keep their technology secret. "Those arent our discs up there."
Now the myth is firmly established, they deny their belief in it. Sound
move.

And here's one possible application: "President Clinton today told the
american people that space aliens who can render themselves invisible via
their technology, now occupy the White House and have their space-weapons
trained on 15 major american cities.

'The carnage would be one hundred times that of Hiroshima or Nagasaki,' the
President declared, the gravity of his concern causing his voice to
tremble.'From this moment on, I am obliged to carry out whatever orders
these spacemen give me. I would be delinquent in my duty as your President,
to do otherwise.

'First, you must labor for less. These space creatures understand finance
and want to increase profits from industry of all kinds. Second, no one may
speak against my Administration.' The President continued with a list of
Alien demands, the text of which can be found on today's Page Three. There
will be a substantially different format to our newspaper starting
tomorrow."

as a footnote : this week's World News, along with the revelation of
Elvis's sexual impotence & fondness for fondling fourteen-year-olds,
carries the transcript of the last words (found on the Alien equivalent of
a black box), translated from Alienese!, of the crew of the space craft
doomed to crash at Roswell in 1947. I was interested to note that one of
them cried "God forgive me for my sins!" while another gasped "We cant
crash! My wife--my children--".

David

Subject:      Re: lunch at the public: is it possible?
