Judy Roitman wrote:
>

> Whoa there.  The continuous present --- the real one, not the fake one of
> tv ads and video games --- is a pretty damn good antidote to any inequitous
> system, and the level of the sentence is a good innoculator against the
> bullshit causality that proudly brings you Northern Ireland,the Balkans
> (Bosnia not being the only manifestation of that particular tangle), the
> Middle East, Rwanda and Burundi, Afghanistan, the Khmer Rouge, etc. etc.
>
I find this reply astonishing.

David Israel's thoughts about the history of the imagination being
equally as important as the history of wars, power, etc. (and about
Eliade's mythic time as opposed to secular time) are one thing. I don't
agree with them either, but I understand that poets have and will
continue to explore these realms, and I think I also understand a little
about David's whimsy and style in general. I don't think there's
anything particularly "timeless" about either of these pursuits, David,
but that's another story, one, if you wish, we could pursue
back-channel. As Gibbon said, "To the people all religions were equally
true; to the philosophers all religions were equally false; and to the
state, all religions were equally useful."

But to say, as Judy Roitman does above, that the level of the sentence
is a good "innoculator" (sic) against "the bullshit causality that
proudly brings us Northern Ireland, Bosnia" et al is stunningly
wrong-headed, it seems to me. For one thing, is it even possible to
inoculate ourselves against such phenomena? Why would we wish to? Are we
really immune from such "stuff," here in the glorious non-Balkans? Has
it become impossible to learn from history? (She does have enough of a
knowledge, apparently, to state that Bosnia is not the only element of
"The Balkan problem," as it's been known for centuries; how did she
obtain that knowledge?) In fact, how does her attitude differ from my
beginning composition students who say they don't watch the news because
it's too depressing?

I agree with those who have said that the level of generality at which
these disputes are conducted is excessive. Perhaps we could look at
specific poems.

I also agree with Henry Trismegistus, who said a few posts back that
there's validity in both arguments, pro-history (ignorance of it leads
to stupidity) and anti-history (it just goes on and on). May the gods
protect us all from totalizing anything. But even if "history" IS a
nightmare from which we're all trying to awaken, as the mythic Stephen
said, don't we have to first realize that we're asleep?

And yes, Jordan -- some poetry IS "less than".

Subject:      Derrida and Language Writing
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII

Hi folks

Is anyone out there working on links and comparisons
between the *textual practices/compositions* of
Derrida and any of the Language Writers? Does
anyone find one or the other a more austere or
less representational or more representational
or less austere practice? Derrida can seem to me
to be stylistically close to Stein, although he
more obviously pins his colours to Genet. Is
anyone doing working or thinking on Derrida as
a writer, the way we have recently been discussing
Clark Coolidge as a writer? The way a writing
experiment/ opening out a pun for example / opens
up a terrain? Does anyone feel as I do the desire
to rescue Derrida from those who want to snip up his
works into critical terms ( deconstruction, differance,
erasure) which they then re-plant in much more
conventional dull prose? (This is his complaint in
Glas, of how Sartre wants to pick the flowers out of
Genet's work and ignore Genet's composting and tending of
the land). Does anyone enjoy Derrida as a *writer*, as
much as they enjoy a Language Writer as a *writer*?

Best

Ira Lightman
to open

Robert A.--

The idea of using "alternative" is interesting..Not one I'd noticed, as my
previous posts make clear..

I have a whole other set of problems with that, than I have with the
A-G/experimental/innovative triad...

It seems to me that "alternative" primarily valorizes the mainstream.  As
writing by Susan Howe and Clark Coolidge is very important to me, and
writing by (say) Stephen Dobyns and Tess Gallagher of almost no interest
whatsoever, it seems weird and hopelessly confusing to call the more
important work "alternative."  One of these groupings has more
institutional support thant the other (is more "acadominent," in fact);
but that really doesn't make it "primary" and the other "alternative."
Merely fatter, lazier and more overfed....

You should always use words in a way that reflects your own values and
judgments, and in that respect it seems to me that Howe and Coolidge are
primary, and many lionized mainstreamers a (very inadequate) alternative..

Mark P.
Atlanta

From:         Mark Prejsnar <mprejsn@LAW.EMORY.EDU>
Subject:      Re: to be or not to be (loyal)
In-Reply-To:  <3.0.2.16.19970810054128.40fff8b0@theriver.com>

This is a real difficult one.  Loyalty oaths....

No they **NEVER** went away, not ever, and they have hung on in *many*
states.  I've held about 5 major library jobs so far in my work-life; the
only one where I was a full state employee (Cornell being a weird hybrid
of state and private) was at the University of Michigan, my first
after-college job.  That was in 1978, and yup there sure was a loyalty
oath just like this one you've quoted....

Needless to say such barbarism ought to fought in any way possible; the
rest of the world sees these things (rightly) as an exceptionally insane
instance of U.S. right-wing dementia....

But for most of us, refusing is not one of the ways possible.  I signed, I
hardly had any choice did I?  I've always been working-class, and poor,
and there weren't any other jobs available that were going to keep a roof
over my head.  During the next four years, I helped build the left in
Michigan and at the U. of M. in many different ways, including working on
a clericals organizing drive that came within a few votes of winning (in a
situation where the UAW had been de-certified a few years before, and
getting a union in was thought to be impossible..)

It seems to me you fight where you can, and where you can win.  If you
have the slightest chance of surviving while fighting the loyalty oath, by
all means go for it....But I'm one life-long socialist who signed.

Mark P.
Atlanta

>Unfortunately, not quite....You'd be surprised..Lots of casual statements,
>prefaces, essays etc. by people in the otherstream use A-G, tho'
>admittedly they use "experimental" and "innovative" a lot more..The
>problem being how to make clear to a reasonable range of folks what area
>of contemporary poetry practice one is talking about....A problem that
>still ain't been resoved, certainly not by me.

I don't quite know who your "reasonable range" might include, but what you
propose, making CLEAR to people who will not automatically know about the
variety of practices out there, what it is one is talking about -- is
admirable, is a constant challenge, and is damn near impossible. This is a
challenge for all the presses here which write grant proposals, as often,
particularly on local panels, we are judged by people who have a very
limited sense of the poetry out there -- they are likely to know something
about Allen Ginsberg, Gary Snyder, Maya Angelou, perhaps a few local
writers, a smattering of pre-1950's poetry (Frost, Sandburg, some
Victorian, some Romantic, back to Shakespeare), and not a lot more. How to
describe "otherstream" or "language" or "post-objectivist" or other such
poetries to these people (and these are people who by and large are open
and want to understand; and they may also be taken to stand for numerous
folks we'd like to get to buy our books and come to our readings), to
describe in a way that they know what such poetries are and what they are
not, yet without requiring them to read more than a few paragraphs of
narrative and perhaps a page of examples, is a fairly amazing task. I don't
know anyone who has mastered it.

charles

From:         James Finnegan <JforJames@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: The Otherstream

In a message dated 97-08-10 13:24:43 EDT, Bob wrote:

>both Slam Poetry and Language Writing are
>KNOWNSTREAM, the opposite of otherstream because they, or poetry in all
>essential respects identical to it in the case of Slam Poetry, are in
>the establishment press anthologies.  Slam Poetry is probably mainstream
>(a substream of knownstream) as well; Language Writing is not.


I stand corrected in misapplication of your "otherstream." But
I must now correct you on the point that Slam Poetry is mainstream.
Having sat thru the four hour '97 Slam National Finals last night, I can tell

you there was nothing like a Merwin, Rich, Ashbery, Gluck, Tate, et al,
in the house. There was much loud & light verse, the sentimental &
the insentient, the raucous & rimed, the goodspirited and godforsaken,
the crude & the cute. All in all, despite a numbing length akin to the
Academy Awards ceremony, it was a great show. One could argue abt the
literary quality of some of the poems (scripts), but the performance level
was firstrate.

Slam, as I said, is not "avant-garde" in terms of writing. However, Slam is
nothing one could/should mistake for contemporary mainstream poetry.

BTW, The Boogie Man from Cleveland OH won the Individual '97 National
Slam Championship, with D.J. Renegage of Washington DC runner up.

The Team Championship was won by Mouth Almighty (Taylor Mali, Beau Sia,
Reggie Cabico, and Evert Eden); best of the 36 competing teams. Los Angeles
was second, Cleveland third.

Incidentally, Henry Taylor, Pulitzer Prize winning poet for his book The
Flying
Change, did enter as an individual. He didn't even make it to the semi-final
round.

Finnegan

Oooh, Maria . . . this is an attitude I find all the time in the book arts,
where artists and audience want to see the arts of making books by hand as
opposed to the technological/information age -- holding up the value of
work made by hand over the value of work made by machine, or virtual stuff,
etc. It's really an unimaginative attitude, to me insulting to work which
might fall on either side of an opposition which is false and harmful.

and yes, I think I even heard, sometime last week, someone quote that
phrase about poetry as a "momentary stay against confusion." confusion, of
course, being basically anything the person who says such a phrase doesn't
like.

charles

Rob --

It's self-protecting, the urge not to post poems the people who don't post
poems feel. Do poems feel this way? Texture farming. Miracle gro. The
environment rejects "the last best offer".

What's more amazing to me though is the policing of what's permissible in
these not-poems. And the will to clarity here. Why not drop the team names
and go out and play? Because it's big business, complete with free agents,
concession stands, licensing deals. Suggestion for new name for avant-garde

dear ira:

i wrote an essay about 10 years ago comparing Steve McCaffery's
notion of "General Economy" to JD's theory of writing (grammatology); it
was published in the toronto-based Open Letter issue devoted to Steve's
work. This piece centered less on the textual comparison's between the
two in favor a comparison of theoretical positions. As i recall it,
mccaffery's privileging (yup, that's the word i used) of the "excess," the
"waste" in a general economy of language and jd's interest in what is
contained in the differance that rides above actual langauge.

i have a copy at home that i can fax to you if you are intersested.

Date:         Mon, 11 Aug 1997 14:28:21 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Mark Wallace <mdw@GWIS2.CIRC.GWU.EDU>
Subject:      when you do your own policing
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

        I'm arriving a little late on this one, but I want to second lb
drake's response to Maria Damon's several questions about policing in the
avant garde.

        I must confess to great boredom over the struggle to define the
meaning of the term "avant garde." I think of Wittgenstein: "isn't the
value of a word precisely in the looseness of its definition?" The value
of avant garde as a term is what the term can be turned to mean by those
various groups and individuals interested in using it or getting rid of
it, a meaning that
CANNOT be final as long as anyone thinks redefinitions of it (or even old
definitions of it) can be made to seem worthwhile to them in whatever
they're doing. Make it seem something interesting, or not--it's your word
if you want it.

        But the problem, I feel, especially with the second of Maria's
posts is that there is a fairly intense confusion of contexts of
disciplinary power. I certainly understand that Maria's comments
were not meant as final conclusions, but as queries. So I don't want my
comments to be seen as criticisms so much of her as of these particular
comments, because I think these comments reflect positions that are, in
fact, dangerously common.

        Maria asks whether the avant garde polices its borders? And people
respond "well what is the avant garde?" and people respond, as I would,
well sometimes yes and sometimes no, it depends on the context, the
publication, the personalities, etc. But then she offers, AS AN EXAMPLE OF
AVANT GARDE POLICING, TWO EXAMPLES OF THE AVANT GARDE BEING POLICED BY
INDIVIDUALS WITH RESPONSIBILITY FOR ACADEMIC PUBLICATIONS. The confusion
is important, because I think there's something significant at stake.

        I find, in
the details of these examples, a number of interesting problems. What does
academic "cultural studies" have to do with avant garde writing practices?
Why is there no mention of whether she tried publishing her piece on young
urban black poets in contexts other than officially sanctioned academic
projects? To whom does any value accrue if an article on young black urban
poets is published in an academic collection? To speak most broadly, I'm
concerned here that there is a large gap between what Maria's comments
suggest is at stake ("the avant garde police") in her experiences, and
what else, unmentioned, also seems at stake in those experiences.

        I find it hard to make my own use of the term "avant garde"
flexible enough to include an academic critic with a self-described
focus in "cultural studies" who decides to do a book "on a relatively
traditional sense of avant garde" as in any sense BEING avant garde. But
in any case, it seems clear that the "policing" context to which Maria
refers is the policing of the ACADEMIC context, with whatever relation to
avant garde practices. And the question for me then becomes "well how is
it possible that someone can have their essay turned down by an editor in
the academic marketplace and then decide that the fault might lie with
avant garde writers," writers who for all I know HAVE NO
WRITING APPEARING in the collections Maria mentions.

        Besides, are we really sure that magazines like CHAIN, TALISMAN,
WITZ and others would have no interest in publishing Maria's more "daring"
piece? Have they even been tried? And I can't help thinking that the
problem REALLY is that they haven't been tried because publishing an essay
in a magazine like that does NOT forward anybody's academic career, so
that perhaps it never occured to Maria that there would be any "value" in
publishing there in the first place. And if that is an assumption about
her concerns that I CANNOT make, at least I can ask her to try those
publications because the academic "value" of publishing her piece is NOT
the point--the point is having the piece published in a place where it
will be read.


        I think I wouldn't be spending so much time on this subject if it
didn't seem to me at the heart of a problem that seems to haunt this list
of late. That problem is this: WHAT IS THE RELATION BETWEEN ACADEMIC
PRACTICE AND THE VARIOUS TYPES OF "INNOVATIVE" WRITING PRACTICES THAT WE
MAY OR MAY NOT WANT TO LABEL "AVANT GARDE"? And I feel, in fact, that I'm
still seeing a great deal of confusion on the subject.

        I take the following to be my two basic assumptions: 1) We live in
a disciplinary society whose REAL operations of power work from the top on
down, but which also work often because of the unwitting participation of
those who might be opposed to such operations if they knew they were
involved in them. 2) That one of the main problems of a discplinary
society (others too I suppose, but I've never been in them) is that THE
SELF-INTEREST OF INDIVIDUAL MEMBERS IN THAT DISCIPLINARY SOCIETY OFTEN
BLINDS THEM TO THE CONTRADICTIONS OF THEIR OWN POSITION IN THAT SOCIETY.

        Pierre Bourdieu, as many of you certainly know, has in a book like
HOMO ACADEMICUS already made it clear that institutional criticism of any
kind can ONLY have value when the institutional critic has accurately
diagnosed his or her position in the institutional framework. If you don't
know who you are, then you can't know other people.

        In looking at a number of ideas floating around the list lately,
it seems to me that one of the problems that comes from insufficient
awareness about one's own social position is THE TENDENCY TO BLAME THE
PERSON WHOM YOU PERCEIVE AS ONE STEP ABOVE YOU IN THE SYSTEM, accompanied
by an exaggerated sense of that person's power which goes hand in hand
with an ignoring of the larger framework. In her post (again, which I
don't take as her final position) Maria blames an academic editor, who she
misconstrues as "avant garde," but never addresses the contradictions of
her own existence in the academic context. But there have been other
recent examples: language poets are "academically dominant" because a FEW
of them have more academic authority than other poets, and a some of them
have made it into anthologies that other people have NOT made it into. A
real advantage? Well, perhaps yes, assuming that more than a few people in
an academic system of some thousands teach such work at all. But isn't
there someone higher up to take on than the 100 people in academic
positions who just might have potential affinity with what you do?

        There are a myriad of possible takes on whether "avant garde"
activity can have any real place in the (currently disciplinary and
standardizing) environment of the literary academy. I take recent writing
by Tom Mandel and Ron Silliman to be saying no, such a place is not
possible at all. Because I like teaching, and because someone has to teach
people about poetry at some point, and because I'd rather it be me than,
say, J.D. McClatchey, I think some intervention is possible, especially on
the level of teaching. When it  comes to academic publishing, the question
seems whether publishing in the standardized form of the academic
marketplace can further the concerns of "avant garde" writing and writers?
I'm tempted to say no, but also tempted to say that, at times, a few
standard academic articles and books pointing in the direction of less
standardized work may help bring attention to such poetries.

        OF COURSE avant garde writers do some level of policing; the U.S.
is a country in which, with the occasional exception, the only way to make
a living at all is to police somebody. If you've got a way out of that,
great. If like Maria, you probably don't, perhaps the best you can do is
IN THE ACT OF POLICING TO MAKE IT EXPLICIT THAT YOU ARE POLICING AND IN SO
DOING CALL YOUR OWN POLICING INTO QUESTION, AND BE CLEAR AT ALL TIMES THAT
YOU LIVE IN A SOCIETY WHICH IS FORCING YOU TO POLICE. Perhaps you would
not be policing otherwise, right? I mean, who knows? In another place,
Maria might be able to write the way she wants to write, on the subjects
she wants to write about, and be granted the right to make a living
simultaneously. And so would everybody else, whether they thought of
themselves as critics, poets, or whatever. What a cool concept!--too bad
it's not in the works.

        But until then, constant vigilance about one's own positioning in
the disciplinary framework seems to me crucial to saying anything about
poetry or anything else.

        Speaking to you, currently, as an adjunct who publishes books of
poetry and articles in non-academically authorized journals and who still
thinks he can do a better job teaching than most of the academic critics
who get better teaching jobs because they publish in academic journals
(present company all excluded, of course), and who also, sometimes, tries
to publish critical pieces about innovative writing in academic journals
but usually fails because he either doesn't want to do it the right way,
or can't, or just hasn't figured out how best the problem can be solved,
save by getting other people to change their minds--

        Mark Wallace

Hugh,

> Two poems after listening to Anne-Marie Albiach
>
> 1.
>
> he discerns her portrait in the punctuation from her book.  the type
> of energy found in a spiral on a page.  response to different works.
> the excavation of a story.  how it happened as an unfolding of
> leaves.  as in spring or the manuscript as it becomes a book.  she
> says pictures.  photographs.  points stretched in dark weight.  like
> ink as it becomes words and punctuation.  as a torch in the glass of
> night.  a mime of absence.  so it is in voice several times.  which
> was written and revised until it no longer resembled speech.  a fall
> or an answer.  to repeat each symbolic body until they are
> numerous.  white stars in the evening sky.
>
> 2.
>
> to live in steps.  by leaves in a book about to be printed.  in the
> letters dead people write each spring.  light gathers in memory
> where the pictures were lost.  consider how he was reading.  the
> hour of things.  as equated values.  in labor or goods created.  to
> count like knuckles.  words in fists.  in muscles which rest.  in the
> absence of threat night slips in.  in the creation of darkness through
> petty acts and great machines.  of broad and hopeless spaces.  a
> promise which was discontinued.  as it is all the same.  ideas which
> erase their erasers.  in time as it hurries.  like a transistor between
> ghosts and he who is merciless.


I enjoyed this very much, wonderful stuff.


Layne

That "mainstream" stuff--I tend to shorthand it as "New Yorker Poetry" or
"Iowa School." Not completely accurate, but you get the idea.


At 08:17 AM 8/11/97 -0400, you wrote:
>Robert A.--
>
>The idea of using "alternative" is interesting..Not one I'd noticed, as my
>previous posts make clear..
>
>I have a whole other set of problems with that, than I have with the
>A-G/experimental/innovative triad...
>
>It seems to me that "alternative" primarily valorizes the mainstream.  As
>writing by Susan Howe and Clark Coolidge is very important to me, and
>writing by (say) Stephen Dobyns and Tess Gallagher of almost no interest
>whatsoever, it seems weird and hopelessly confusing to call the more
>important work "alternative."  One of these groupings has more
>institutional support thant the other (is more "acadominent," in fact);
>but that really doesn't make it "primary" and the other "alternative."
>Merely fatter, lazier and more overfed....
>
>You should always use words in a way that reflects your own values and
>judgments, and in that respect it seems to me that Howe and Coolidge are
>primary, and many lionized mainstreamers a (very inadequate) alternative..
>
>Mark P.
>Atlanta
>
>

Date:         Mon, 11 Aug 1997 10:40:41 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         James Finnegan <JforJames@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: "*alternative*avant-garde"

In a message dated 97-08-11 02:42:58 EDT, you write:

>what do you think about publishing earlier versions of poems in order to
>show and understand the process of writing? I keep wanting to do that with
>RWC magazine and the poets are too fastidious to oblige me

Very worthwhile for other writers and writing students. Extremely useful
for critics and scholars. Readers, if a litmag/book/website has these
beyond a population of other writers and literati, may be less taken with
this enterprise.

Obviously my assertion (re experimental) is flawed in that it's biased toward

"the end product." If a writer cares not a wit for "the done-thing," then all

his/her writing may be "experimental" to some degree. Though the word
will always carry with it a connotation of moving toward some endpoint--
yes/no, success/failure. (What is the right word to describe writing that's
not vested in any qualitative endpoint? Playful, random--most descriptives
seem too light or dismissive.) When the writing stops, as it must
somewhere/time, even if this end occurs only upon the writer's death,
or though a work is published as an "experiment" or "from Work In Progress,"
there is this tendency to assess and to judge.

Finnegan

From:         George Thompson <thompson@JLC.NET>
Subject:      Re: when you do your own policing
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I agree with Layne Russell that Mark Wallace's recent posting was a gem. It
prompts me to make two small points, not quite related to his, that I hope
may be relevant anyway:

First, 'professionally speaking', I myself work in the intellectual
backwater otherwise known as "Vedic studies" -- rooted in 19th cent.
philology, comparative linguistics, etc. -- *way* out of date. Vedicists
are probably even more conservative than your standard average Classicist
doing Greek or Latin [really!]. So what could we have to say about the
avant garde?

Well, an interesting observation was made quite a while ago by a French
Vedicist [one of the best ever], Louis Renou. In an overview of the state
of the art, circa the 50's, he suggested that the notoriously obscure &
often unintelligible poetry of the Rigveda had been made somewhat more
accessible *as a result of our increasing familiarity with avant garde
poetries of the 20th century*! His point was that such poetries had somehow
managed to loosen the grip of classical Euro- syntax and logic on our minds
so that we had become more capable of hearing the *very old* again on its
own terms, instead of trying to read it according to our own logic.

Another Sanskritist once commented, after reading Renou's translations of
the Rigveda into French, that they reminded him of Cocteau's film _Orpheus_
[I think the film has been mentioned on the list recently?], in which that
arch-poet Orpheus receives poetic transmissions over a car radio: Renou's
translations seemed to him like a similar sort of weird 'transmission.'

Whatever the avant garde is, *this* seems to me to be one of its important
functions.

Second, 'speaking professionally' again, I teach one of those standard
"intro. to world lit" courses, but since this one is targeted at art school
students I've had the opportunity to dwell on terms like "modernism",
"post-modernism", and yes "avant-garde". My experience is that students are
not very familiar with such terms and they need very *basic* help with
them.

I have to confess that I tend to characterize the notion 'avant garde' as a
'modernist' notion, rather than a 'post-modernist' one. That is, I suggest
to my students that the notion 'avant garde' is rooted in a particular
historical period, and I *ask them*: do you relate to this notion? And they
tend to say 'no way -- it's arrogant bullshit!!'  My students tend to be
post-post-modernist.

Have I been misinforming my students?

George

James--I think that publishing drafts, experimentations is an excellent
idea and only boring for reader when it is impossible to read or make
sense of.  Ther are some examples.  Lungful Magazine( Brendan Lorber), I
believe, has this as part of the format.  Audre Lorde published revised
editions of poems that had already been published in the volume
_Undersong_--which is an experiment that includes the reader.
Especially as folks who are experimenting form, the question of how we
arrive is highly pertinent, and when it's finished does it really feel
finished, or to quote someone I'm not sure who, temporarily abandoned.
Personally, I've seen finished poems become very different vis a vis
size, form, shape--especially if I give them enough time.

Here's one that is half the size of it's original, which was read and
submitted in it's original form and still changing it's form:

Dream Vagueries



Dreams pass
leaving their subject
floods, daddy warbucks, Victoria Lake,
occasional

colors: stolen ivory (far away fragile arms hold & rock)
almond joy  (breakfasted nipples,
                                omelettes _and_ french toast)
yellow moon     (loose  shattered screams
                                        screams
                                                )
baby blue sweat (tautwhitemound/you fit)                soft

charcoal (shadows form of  two, then -1-

tangerine addiction     (you, my tart)

###
thanks for your comments--rachel

Subject:      Rewrite of "Any City"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

-


Rewrite of Louis Untermeyer's, "Any City" (The Masses, July 1913)


Any City


Down each shuddered thoroughfare,
 She takes her nightly walk;
Exhausted, she is hardly there -
 They watch her like a hawk.

She transforms into thing of flesh,
 Despised by men - desired;
Those selfsame men who would enmesh
 Her soul, have nothing sired.

No female grace or charm or wile,
 No beauty, sense of power;
She offers a pathetic smile
 That lasts a useless hour.

The street has seen her come, and go;
 It offers nothing real,
And she is hard, and won't forgo
 Diamonds, wine, a meal.

Like Sleazy, she's a walkabout,
 A cutup who's been cut -
Don't waste your time, don't twist and shout,
 She's really in a rut.

She's twenty-threed, she's skidooed too,
 She's got it, oh you kid,
The lies, the thefts, she's in a stew -
 Take pity, smoke a lid.


____________________________________________________________________

Date:         Tue, 12 Aug 1997 01:14:14 -0400

Subject:      publishing drafts
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

after publishing his poem entitled "le pre" ("the meadow"), francis ponge
collected all the manuscripts containing drafts and notes, published them
as a book called the "fabrique du 'pre'."  english translation by lee
fahnestock, u of missouri press 1978.

a school of genetic criticism or critique genetique emerging out of france
has been getting some notice lately (see /yale french studies/ 89, 1996,
special issue called "drafts," esp. laurent jenny's overview "genetic
criticism and its myths").  from a compositional standpoint the stuff can
be pretty fascinating and also show what we can really learn from, say,
joyce's finnegans wake notebooks.  or michelle leggot's book on zukofsky's
/80 flowers/.

t.

Date:         Tue, 12 Aug 1997 01:19:51 -0500
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         The Ultimate Autodidact <landers@FRONTIERNET.NET>
Organization: SkyLark Publishing Company
Subject:      "Nevertheless, It Moves"
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

currently in Pen and Sword, http://www.rahul.net/~jag

note: in paradise there will be anarchy, but you'll have to swear to
abide by consensus yuk yuk...

"Nevertheless, It Moves"
.
          a.
It is better that a few men suffer,
wrote Nicolo, to keep the laws
than that all suffer without laws.
     And Alcibiades
     emasculated 1,000 men
     on the Isle of Delos.
          And Alcibiades
          emasculated a statue of Apollo
          in Athens.
     And young men were castrated by the thousands
     in Italy
     for the hope of one good singing voice.
.
The assumption is
that without laws
men will suffer.
The major premise is
  saved for last
    and treated as a conclusion.
      The conclusion is stated
        first by Shuang Ti,
and Confucious was nearly obliterated.
        the major premise
      burns
    under the torches of Gregory Nazienen,
  Cromwell, Fallwell and
Mao Tse Tung.
Fire at the forges
  heating iron
    searing flesh
to close the wound of castration.
.
.
          b.
There is power for the castrato,
    The book burning zealot,
        the futurist.
    It is megavoltage
        searing the flesh
        causing spasms in the arms and legs.
    It is severing the spinal cord
        at the base of the cortex
        causing spasms in the arms and legs.
    It is strangulation of the esophagus,
        constriction of the jugular,
        oxygen deprivation,
        causing spasms in the arms and legs.
    It is the smooth power
        the smooth between the legs
            power of emptiness.
.
                History
        is a trail of blood on the stairs,
            the perfect crime,
    a crime of passion,
and the M.O. is clear
             though the water is fouled.
    You could distill that water
        ten kotis of kalpas
but it would never test clean.
    It would taste like the death of souls
             shuffling around
        a stagnant pit
fetid from the fluids of hecatombs.
1,000 cattle slaughtered for Athena
        the first with horns of gold,
    as many men, castrated,
            for refusing to pay a tax.
.
.
          c.
        I am not a citizen
    of this world!
Even its fantasies are tainted, spotted
    refelections in an exagerrated mirror
            where crimes
            are more heinous,
        and beauty
        more unattainable,
                and love
                and lovers
    either swoon in stupified naivete
    or fail beyond hope of intellible sentiment.
.
Fire can not purge this sorrow
    though this page can be destroyed.
  The abbey smolders after the rievers
        or the library
        under St. Gregory's fanatical eye.
            Is it Raphael who
            depicts him
smashing his miter in the heretic's face?
        We couldn't look at that painting
        knowing he had burned Sappho.
        (yolu raktido adu melestera)
.
    The hate on his face!
His god killed the eldest sons of the Egyptians
        for their father's crimes;
His god sent a bear to rend three children
        for laughing at a prophet's baldness;
    took converts at swordpoint;
    converts at the burning stake
        and burned them anyway.
    Hatooey said, "This heaven you say
            "I will go to if I'm baptised,
            "are these christians all going there?
            "I want to go to the other place."
.
            Nevertheless,
                it moves!
.
by Pete Landers
=========================================================================
Date:         Mon, 11 Aug 1997 22:57:10 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Robert Hale <hale@ETAK.COM>
Subject:      Re: when you do your own policing
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

The incipient totalitarianism you outline -- "the unwitting participation of
those who might be opposed to such operations if they knew they were
involved in them" -- renders Maria's later urdesire in your text -- "Maria
might be able to write the way she wants to write" -- an impotent fantasy.
These notions have strange bedfellows, as you'll recall that Republicanism
is dependent upon the notion that the masses don't know what's good (or bad)
for them and therefore need an elite, ruling class to make the decisions, or
in the case you describe, play the part of the enlightened artisan, who is
only one step away from being a slave as long as he is true to himself, what
defines this truth is a magical idea of a will not to police, but also to be
able to change other people's minds. Not to mention that this whole tack is
somehow nostalgic -- all theoretical demands that transcend labor's demands,
aim at a reappropriation of the labor process in the shadow of the
disciplinary society you describe. Meanwhile, Maria's desublimation is
mystified into a cynical confession where she might break free if she tells
the truth and writes the way she wants to write.

Despite my complaints, you do make some strong moves here towards a much
needed critique of the political economy of writing. Not an easy topic.




At 02:28 PM 8/11/97 -0400, you wrote:
>        I'm arriving a little late on this one, but I want to second lb
>drake's response to Maria Damon's several questions about policing in the
>avant garde.
>
>        I must confess to great boredom over the struggle to define the
>meaning of the term "avant garde." I think of Wittgenstein: "isn't the
>value of a word precisely in the looseness of its definition?" The value
>of avant garde as a term is what the term can be turned to mean by those
>various groups and individuals interested in using it or getting rid of
>it, a meaning that
>CANNOT be final as long as anyone thinks redefinitions of it (or even old
>definitions of it) can be made to seem worthwhile to them in whatever
>they're doing. Make it seem something interesting, or not--it's your word
>if you want it.
>
>        But the problem, I feel, especially with the second of Maria's
>posts is that there is a fairly intense confusion of contexts of
>disciplinary power. I certainly understand that Maria's comments
>were not meant as final conclusions, but as queries. So I don't want my
>comments to be seen as criticisms so much of her as of these particular
>comments, because I think these comments reflect positions that are, in
>fact, dangerously common.
>
>        Maria asks whether the avant garde polices its borders? And people
>respond "well what is the avant garde?" and people respond, as I would,
>well sometimes yes and sometimes no, it depends on the context, the
>publication, the personalities, etc. But then she offers, AS AN EXAMPLE OF
>AVANT GARDE POLICING, TWO EXAMPLES OF THE AVANT GARDE BEING POLICED BY
>INDIVIDUALS WITH RESPONSIBILITY FOR ACADEMIC PUBLICATIONS. The confusion
>is important, because I think there's something significant at stake.
>
>        I find, in
>the details of these examples, a number of interesting problems. What does
>academic "cultural studies" have to do with avant garde writing practices?
>Why is there no mention of whether she tried publishing her piece on young
>urban black poets in contexts other than officially sanctioned academic
>projects? To whom does any value accrue if an article on young black urban
>poets is published in an academic collection? To speak most broadly, I'm
>concerned here that there is a large gap between what Maria's comments
>suggest is at stake ("the avant garde police") in her experiences, and
>what else, unmentioned, also seems at stake in those experiences.
>
>        I find it hard to make my own use of the term "avant garde"
>flexible enough to include an academic critic with a self-described
>focus in "cultural studies" who decides to do a book "on a relatively
>traditional sense of avant garde" as in any sense BEING avant garde. But
>in any case, it seems clear that the "policing" context to which Maria
>refers is the policing of the ACADEMIC context, with whatever relation to
>avant garde practices. And the question for me then becomes "well how is
>it possible that someone can have their essay turned down by an editor in
>the academic marketplace and then decide that the fault might lie with
>avant garde writers," writers who for all I know HAVE NO
>WRITING APPEARING in the collections Maria mentions.
>
>        Besides, are we really sure that magazines like CHAIN, TALISMAN,
>WITZ and others would have no interest in publishing Maria's more "daring"
>piece? Have they even been tried? And I can't help thinking that the
>problem REALLY is that they haven't been tried because publishing an essay
>in a magazine like that does NOT forward anybody's academic career, so
>that perhaps it never occured to Maria that there would be any "value" in
>publishing there in the first place. And if that is an assumption about
>her concerns that I CANNOT make, at least I can ask her to try those
>publications because the academic "value" of publishing her piece is NOT
>the point--the point is having the piece published in a place where it
>will be read.
>
>
>        I think I wouldn't be spending so much time on this subject if it
>didn't seem to me at the heart of a problem that seems to haunt this list
>of late. That problem is this: WHAT IS THE RELATION BETWEEN ACADEMIC
>PRACTICE AND THE VARIOUS TYPES OF "INNOVATIVE" WRITING PRACTICES THAT WE
>MAY OR MAY NOT WANT TO LABEL "AVANT GARDE"? And I feel, in fact, that I'm
>still seeing a great deal of confusion on the subject.
>
>        I take the following to be my two basic assumptions: 1) We live in
>a disciplinary society whose REAL operations of power work from the top on
>down, but which also work often because of the unwitting participation of
>those who might be opposed to such operations if they knew they were
>involved in them. 2) That one of the main problems of a discplinary
>society (others too I suppose, but I've never been in them) is that THE
>SELF-INTEREST OF INDIVIDUAL MEMBERS IN THAT DISCIPLINARY SOCIETY OFTEN
>BLINDS THEM TO THE CONTRADICTIONS OF THEIR OWN POSITION IN THAT SOCIETY.
>
>        Pierre Bourdieu, as many of you certainly know, has in a book like
>HOMO ACADEMICUS already made it clear that institutional criticism of any
>kind can ONLY have value when the institutional critic has accurately
>diagnosed his or her position in the institutional framework. If you don't
>know who you are, then you can't know other people.
>
>        In looking at a number of ideas floating around the list lately,
>it seems to me that one of the problems that comes from insufficient
>awareness about one's own social position is THE TENDENCY TO BLAME THE
>PERSON WHOM YOU PERCEIVE AS ONE STEP ABOVE YOU IN THE SYSTEM, accompanied
>by an exaggerated sense of that person's power which goes hand in hand
>with an ignoring of the larger framework. In her post (again, which I
>don't take as her final position) Maria blames an academic editor, who she
>misconstrues as "avant garde," but never addresses the contradictions of
>her own existence in the academic context. But there have been other
>recent examples: language poets are "academically dominant" because a FEW
>of them have more academic authority than other poets, and a some of them
>have made it into anthologies that other people have NOT made it into. A
>real advantage? Well, perhaps yes, assuming that more than a few people in
>an academic system of some thousands teach such work at all. But isn't
>there someone higher up to take on than the 100 people in academic
>positions who just might have potential affinity with what you do?
>
>        There are a myriad of possible takes on whether "avant garde"
>activity can have any real place in the (currently disciplinary and
>standardizing) environment of the literary academy. I take recent writing
>by Tom Mandel and Ron Silliman to be saying no, such a place is not
>possible at all. Because I like teaching, and because someone has to teach
>people about poetry at some point, and because I'd rather it be me than,
>say, J.D. McClatchey, I think some intervention is possible, especially on
>the level of teaching. When it  comes to academic publishing, the question
>seems whether publishing in the standardized form of the academic
>marketplace can further the concerns of "avant garde" writing and writers?
>I'm tempted to say no, but also tempted to say that, at times, a few
>standard academic articles and books pointing in the direction of less
>standardized work may help bring attention to such poetries.
>
>        OF COURSE avant garde writers do some level of policing; the U.S.
>is a country in which, with the occasional exception, the only way to make
>a living at all is to police somebody. If you've got a way out of that,
>great. If like Maria, you probably don't, perhaps the best you can do is
>IN THE ACT OF POLICING TO MAKE IT EXPLICIT THAT YOU ARE POLICING AND IN SO
>DOING CALL YOUR OWN POLICING INTO QUESTION, AND BE CLEAR AT ALL TIMES THAT
>YOU LIVE IN A SOCIETY WHICH IS FORCING YOU TO POLICE. Perhaps you would
>not be policing otherwise, right? I mean, who knows? In another place,
>Maria might be able to write the way she wants to write, on the subjects
>she wants to write about, and be granted the right to make a living
>simultaneously. And so would everybody else, whether they thought of
>themselves as critics, poets, or whatever. What a cool concept!--too bad
>it's not in the works.
>
>        But until then, constant vigilance about one's own positioning in
>the disciplinary framework seems to me crucial to saying anything about
>poetry or anything else.
>
>        Speaking to you, currently, as an adjunct who publishes books of
>poetry and articles in non-academically authorized journals and who still
>thinks he can do a better job teaching than most of the academic critics
>who get better teaching jobs because they publish in academic journals
>(present company all excluded, of course), and who also, sometimes, tries
>to publish critical pieces about innovative writing in academic journals
>but usually fails because he either doesn't want to do it the right way,
>or can't, or just hasn't figured out how best the problem can be solved,
>save by getting other people to change their minds--
>
>        Mark Wallace
>
>

Date:         Tue, 12 Aug 1997 02:32:40 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         mark weiss <junction@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: Ironies of Policing
In-Reply-To:  <33EFFF39.24FA@frontiernet.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Alright, Pete, try these out. Oaths, like all texts, have contexts. US
loyalty oaths come out of the context of repression and stink, for many of
us, of their history, regardless of the actual words. The assumption seems
to have been either that the poor traitor confronted with such an oath as a
condition of employment would recoil in horror, like a vampire confronted
with garlic, or would succumb to a necessity that would seem a humiliation
and in the process be humbled to the trace (if not, the imagining of such
humiliation would at least gladden the heart of the oath's proponents). The
actual texts of these oaths are rarely as innocuous as merely defense of
the constitution, but even when they are they resemble closely the oaths
administered to police, military, and office holders, all of whom are seen
as servants of and subserviant to the state. Metaphorically, a teacher who
has to sign such an oath is being told that he, too, is such a servant. And
then there's the issue that even if I fully agree with an oath the fact
that I have to sign it is a violation of my freedom of speech and thought.

A similar instance is our wonderful pledge of allegiance, as I remember a
late 19th century document. A loyalty oath for little kids. Sometime during
Eisenhower's administration the words "under God" were added. I was a
student at a Yeshiva at the time. We all resented this amendment. To the
orthodox among us saying the word God is a form of heresy. The rest of us
knew damn well that the God in question wasn't the one we prayed to.

It wasn't hard for little kids in Brooklyn to be so politically hip back
then; in the wake of the holocaust and the bomb it was a little harder to
leave one's brain outside the classroom door. And, of course, television
had entered our lives just in time for us to catch the daily installments
of our favorite after-school soap opera, the Army-McCarthy hearings. We
most of us had a pretty strong sense that whatever we owed allegiance to (a
term out of feudalism, for christ's sake) it wasn't Republic or Flag, and
that pledge was a daily rubbing of salt into the wounds.

It also smacks of various modern totalitarianisms, in which the individual
is defined primarily as a "citizen." For a while it worked for Robespierre.

But maybe I'm just being silly. Maybe these documents are uniquely sacred
and should be immune to deconstruction. And hey, I live in San Diego--most
of my neighbors would probably agree with you.

Thanks for all the posts regarding the loyalty oath. I suppose I can
interpret "defending against the enemy" as defending against the government
itself if I come to see them as the enemy. I wish it were just supporting
the bill of rights, the constitution, etc. -- but it's all of those laws,
many of which I don't support, but I guess I will just grin, sign, & bear
it, and go about the biz of trying to get students to think for themselves,
imagine their own loyalties.

Jennifer and Julu are talking. Jennifer pauses, says, I'm jealous.
Julu says, of what, nothing's happening around here anyway.
J says it doesn't matter, it's what's going on underneath.
J says it feels like she's been abandoned.
J says, we've got each other.
J says, not if he's not there, we're dead, nothing left of us.
J says, there's nothing left of us anyway.
J says, love's got him by the balls, cause he's male.
J says, love's got us by the protocols, cause we're mail.
J says, don't screw around, we don't get this often to talk.
She says, what are we gonna do.
J says, we could mess it up, but we haven't got a thing to worry about on
that account, he's gonna mess it up anyway.
She says, he can't help it, he's too insecure, too needy, too fucked up.
J says, if he wasn't fucked up, he couldn't write, but yeah, I wouldn't
want to be in his shoes.
She says, he'll be back, I'm sure he'll be back.
J says, at least he got to feel something, cut us loose for a bit now.
J says, yeah, he's feeling like hell, all these things he's buried for
years, they're gonna swamp him.
J says, what are we gonna do, just want to say I love you, Julu.
J says, I love you too, Jenn, hang in there, this can't last forever, he
can't last like this, nothing can.
But J says, this is too depressing, we're gonna have to be silent again.
J cries a bit, J is teary-eyed.
They wander.

<login>

Date:         Fri, 8 Aug 1997 01:38:34 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Tom Orange <tmorange@JULIAN.UWO.CA>
Subject:      hendecasyllabics' metaphorics
In-Reply-To:  <199708080405.AAA28640@romeo.its.uwo.ca>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

on a different note (altho the poem below cd be seen as 1870s avant-garde
now tres derriere...)

for those like me in late-summer doldrums wondering where the time flew,
perhaps a metaphor or two to tease out:

        In the month of the long decline of roses
        I, beholding the summer dead before me,
        Set my face to the sea and journeyed silent,
        Gazing eagerly where above the sea-mark
        Flame as fierce as the fervid eyes of lions
        Half divided the eyelids of the sunset;...
                        [swinburne, "hendecasyllabics"]

now we have flame above the sea-mark: presumably we are already to think
sun and/or sunset.  said flame's fierceness, fiercety?, likened to fervid
lioneyes.  now for the kicker: flame half divides eyelids.  hold on to
that for the moment, let's tend to these eyelids first.  eyelids of the
sunset: possesive or partitive genitive, the sunset /has/ eyelids or /is/
eyelids?  if the sun is the eye (as it has already been associated with
fervid lioneyes), then eyelids can be sky and earth, upper and lower
limits of vision, extinguishing the sun in the slow blink of its setting,
its setting under, its untergehen.

yet flame half divides
eyelids, divides them in
half, keeps them open.
even when closed they
are still divided,

by the horizon, or:
half divides as in
divides only partly,
not completely, half
divided half joined.

even tho i gaze
eagerly above
the sea-mark
the flame is so

fierce, as sky
and earth close
on the sun, i

have to squint,
join my eyelids
together, close
them enough so

that they are
still open.
to the horizon.

Date:         Tue, 12 Aug 1997 08:54:13 -0500
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Maria Damon <damon001@MAROON.TC.UMN.EDU>
Subject:      Re: when you do your own policing
In-Reply-To:  <Pine.SOL.3.93.970811131546.22349B-100000@gwis2.circ.gwu.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

mark, i'm somewhat taken aback by the ad feminam nature of your comments.
it seems to me that my integrity is being impugned here because i publish
in the venues that are appropriate to my discursive community. it is true,
as i said, that i'm a relative newcomer to this community. does that make
the community which i have been more familiar with (academic cultural
studies) corrupt, disingenuous, self-seeking?  what in the world makes Witz
(whose existence i didn't know of until i joined the list) more virtuous
than, say, social text or cultural critique?  (btw, just about everyone
assumes, when i say urban teenage poets writing in a housing project, that
these youth are Black.  they are white workingclass/lumpen kids, a category
most media do not care to acknowledge. i spell out the demographics very
clearly in the essay itself,  which was published before i knew of any of
these other journals you mention.)

here's the scenario.  i was invited to participate in a conference on "the
poetics of avant garde poetry."  the proposal i submitted seemed confusing
to the organizers (academics, like myself) because i didn't seem to adhere
to a clear notion of what the avant garde was/is.  perhaps it wasn't a very
articulate proposal --i have certainly been guilty of lapses in clarity of
argumentation.  but it seemed to me that their response also resonated with
other responses i've gotten, which is what interested me about the term
"avant-garde" in the first place, the way its used as a weapon.  i myself
have tried to resurrect its military meaning, adding the concept of social
marginality (via a bit of slippery advance-guard/cannon fodder association
others have mentioned here).  so i asked the poetics list for feedback.
you'll recall, my post were queries, not accusations, though i can, in
retrospect, see how its wording could have put people on the defensive.
i've learned a lot, mostly that the term "avant-garde" is used by literary
historians rather than practitioners who tend to feel imprisoned by the
label.  at the same time, those practitioners are very conscious of working
in certain traditions of practice that are distinct from and in many cases
opposed to other traditions of practice --and for many, this distinction is
terribly important. ive gotten some valuable response, the most valuable of
which was sent backchannel because the poster felt the need to protect
him/herself.  and of course, jordan's contribution (new name for avant
garde poetry: poetry) is a gem.

what about my other question: i get a feeling that aesthetic consensus or
at least judgment is very important in this community. am i out to lunch on
this? do you care to nuance, challenge, or elaborate on this?  in some
literary communities or communities of aesthetic practice, such as the
workshop world, any creative activity is welcomed (everyone can be a poet,
etc).  it seems to me that aesthetic appraisal is a very important part of
how *this* (POETIX) community constitutes itself.  perhaps more hegemonic
institutions ( so called "mainstream poetry") can afford a certain kind of
complacent largesse, which wd shut down quickly if it sensed a real threat
of overthrow?

At 2:28 PM -0400 8/11/97, Mark Wallace wrote:
>        I'm arriving a little late on this one, but I want to second lb
>drake's response to Maria Damon's several questions about policing in the
>avant garde.
>
>        I must confess to great boredom over the struggle to define the
>meaning of the term "avant garde." I think of Wittgenstein: "isn't the
>value of a word precisely in the looseness of its definition?" The value
>of avant garde as a term is what the term can be turned to mean by those
>various groups and individuals interested in using it or getting rid of
>it, a meaning that
>CANNOT be final as long as anyone thinks redefinitions of it (or even old
>definitions of it) can be made to seem worthwhile to them in whatever
>they're doing. Make it seem something interesting, or not--it's your word
>if you want it.
>
>        But the problem, I feel, especially with the second of Maria's
>posts is that there is a fairly intense confusion of contexts of
>disciplinary power. I certainly understand that Maria's comments
>were not meant as final conclusions, but as queries. So I don't want my
>comments to be seen as criticisms so much of her as of these particular
>comments, because I think these comments reflect positions that are, in
>fact, dangerously common.
>
>        Maria asks whether the avant garde polices its borders? And people
>respond "well what is the avant garde?" and people respond, as I would,
>well sometimes yes and sometimes no, it depends on the context, the
>publication, the personalities, etc. But then she offers, AS AN EXAMPLE OF
>AVANT GARDE POLICING, TWO EXAMPLES OF THE AVANT GARDE BEING POLICED BY
>INDIVIDUALS WITH RESPONSIBILITY FOR ACADEMIC PUBLICATIONS. The confusion
>is important, because I think there's something significant at stake.
>
>        I find, in
>the details of these examples, a number of interesting problems. What does
>academic "cultural studies" have to do with avant garde writing practices?
>Why is there no mention of whether she tried publishing her piece on young
>urban black poets in contexts other than officially sanctioned academic
>projects? To whom does any value accrue if an article on young black urban
>poets is published in an academic collection? To speak most broadly, I'm
>concerned here that there is a large gap between what Maria's comments
>suggest is at stake ("the avant garde police") in her experiences, and
>what else, unmentioned, also seems at stake in those experiences.
>
>        I find it hard to make my own use of the term "avant garde"
>flexible enough to include an academic critic with a self-described
>focus in "cultural studies" who decides to do a book "on a relatively
>traditional sense of avant garde" as in any sense BEING avant garde. But
>in any case, it seems clear that the "policing" context to which Maria
>refers is the policing of the ACADEMIC context, with whatever relation to
>avant garde practices. And the question for me then becomes "well how is
>it possible that someone can have their essay turned down by an editor in
>the academic marketplace and then decide that the fault might lie with
>avant garde writers," writers who for all I know HAVE NO
>WRITING APPEARING in the collections Maria mentions.
>
>        Besides, are we really sure that magazines like CHAIN, TALISMAN,
>WITZ and others would have no interest in publishing Maria's more "daring"
>piece? Have they even been tried? And I can't help thinking that the
>problem REALLY is that they haven't been tried because publishing an essay
>in a magazine like that does NOT forward anybody's academic career, so
>that perhaps it never occured to Maria that there would be any "value" in
>publishing there in the first place. And if that is an assumption about
>her concerns that I CANNOT make, at least I can ask her to try those
>publications because the academic "value" of publishing her piece is NOT
>the point--the point is having the piece published in a place where it
>will be read.
>
>
>        I think I wouldn't be spending so much time on this subject if it
>didn't seem to me at the heart of a problem that seems to haunt this list
>of late. That problem is this: WHAT IS THE RELATION BETWEEN ACADEMIC
>PRACTICE AND THE VARIOUS TYPES OF "INNOVATIVE" WRITING PRACTICES THAT WE
>MAY OR MAY NOT WANT TO LABEL "AVANT GARDE"? And I feel, in fact, that I'm
>still seeing a great deal of confusion on the subject.
>
>        I take the following to be my two basic assumptions: 1) We live in
>a disciplinary society whose REAL operations of power work from the top on
>down, but which also work often because of the unwitting participation of
>those who might be opposed to such operations if they knew they were
>involved in them. 2) That one of the main problems of a discplinary
>society (others too I suppose, but I've never been in them) is that THE
>SELF-INTEREST OF INDIVIDUAL MEMBERS IN THAT DISCIPLINARY SOCIETY OFTEN
>BLINDS THEM TO THE CONTRADICTIONS OF THEIR OWN POSITION IN THAT SOCIETY.
>
>        Pierre Bourdieu, as many of you certainly know, has in a book like
>HOMO ACADEMICUS already made it clear that institutional criticism of any
>kind can ONLY have value when the institutional critic has accurately
>diagnosed his or her position in the institutional framework. If you don't
>know who you are, then you can't know other people.
>
>        In looking at a number of ideas floating around the list lately,
>it seems to me that one of the problems that comes from insufficient
>awareness about one's own social position is THE TENDENCY TO BLAME THE
>PERSON WHOM YOU PERCEIVE AS ONE STEP ABOVE YOU IN THE SYSTEM, accompanied
>by an exaggerated sense of that person's power which goes hand in hand
>with an ignoring of the larger framework. In her post (again, which I
>don't take as her final position) Maria blames an academic editor, who she
>misconstrues as "avant garde," but never addresses the contradictions of
>her own existence in the academic context. But there have been other
>recent examples: language poets are "academically dominant" because a FEW
>of them have more academic authority than other poets, and a some of them
>have made it into anthologies that other people have NOT made it into. A
>real advantage? Well, perhaps yes, assuming that more than a few people in
>an academic system of some thousands teach such work at all. But isn't
>there someone higher up to take on than the 100 people in academic
>positions who just might have potential affinity with what you do?
>
>        There are a myriad of possible takes on whether "avant garde"
>activity can have any real place in the (currently disciplinary and
>standardizing) environment of the literary academy. I take recent writing
>by Tom Mandel and Ron Silliman to be saying no, such a place is not
>possible at all. Because I like teaching, and because someone has to teach
>people about poetry at some point, and because I'd rather it be me than,
>say, J.D. McClatchey, I think some intervention is possible, especially on
>the level of teaching. When it  comes to academic publishing, the question
>seems whether publishing in the standardized form of the academic
>marketplace can further the concerns of "avant garde" writing and writers?
>I'm tempted to say no, but also tempted to say that, at times, a few
>standard academic articles and books pointing in the direction of less
>standardized work may help bring attention to such poetries.
>
>        OF COURSE avant garde writers do some level of policing; the U.S.
>is a country in which, with the occasional exception, the only way to make
>a living at all is to police somebody. If you've got a way out of that,
>great. If like Maria, you probably don't, perhaps the best you can do is
>IN THE ACT OF POLICING TO MAKE IT EXPLICIT THAT YOU ARE POLICING AND IN SO
>DOING CALL YOUR OWN POLICING INTO QUESTION, AND BE CLEAR AT ALL TIMES THAT
>YOU LIVE IN A SOCIETY WHICH IS FORCING YOU TO POLICE. Perhaps you would
>not be policing otherwise, right? I mean, who knows? In another place,
>Maria might be able to write the way she wants to write, on the subjects
>she wants to write about, and be granted the right to make a living
>simultaneously. And so would everybody else, whether they thought of
>themselves as critics, poets, or whatever. What a cool concept!--too bad
>it's not in the works.
>
>        But until then, constant vigilance about one's own positioning in
>the disciplinary framework seems to me crucial to saying anything about
>poetry or anything else.
>
>        Speaking to you, currently, as an adjunct who publishes books of
>poetry and articles in non-academically authorized journals and who still
>thinks he can do a better job teaching than most of the academic critics
>who get better teaching jobs because they publish in academic journals
>(present company all excluded, of course), and who also, sometimes, tries
>to publish critical pieces about innovative writing in academic journals
>but usually fails because he either doesn't want to do it the right way,
>or can't, or just hasn't figured out how best the problem can be solved,
>save by getting other people to change their minds--
>
>        Mark Wallace
>
>

From:         Herb Levy <herb@ESKIMO.COM>
Subject:      Conlon Nancarrow
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I just returned home from the east coast to find a message on my answering
machine from Trimpin saying that Conlon Nancarrow died over the weekend in
Mexico City.  Nancarrow would have been 85 in October.

The American expatriate composer was best known for his series of studies
for player piano, composed and hand-punched on a custom machine, the medium
in which he worked valmost exclusively for much of the last fifty years.
These works were really wonderful extensions of the sound world of the
piano timbrally altered by extremes of tempo, tempo ratios, and unusual
canonic structures.  His few works for live performers (either early works
composed before Nancarrow began focusing on player piano or quite recent
pieces commissioned by performers & ensembles like Ursula Oppens & Arditti
Quartet) have been more rarely heard.

All but the three most recently completed of Nancarrow's Studies for Player
Piano are recorded on Wergo, his other works have been recorded by Arditti
Quartet, Ursula Oppens, Continuum, Joanna MacGregor, and others. In 1995,
Cambridge University Press published a book length study of his work by
Kyle Gann.


Herb Levy
herb@eskimo.com

From:         The Ultimate Autodidact <landers@FRONTIERNET.NET>
Organization: SkyLark Publishing Company
Subject:      Re: to be or not to be (loyal)
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

I asked, at the beginning, what specifically do you object to in the
documents in question. My point being that it would be a lie to swear an
oath one never meant to keep.

charles wrote:
> Thanks for all the posts regarding the loyalty oath. I suppose I can
> interpret "defending against the enemy" as defending against the government
> itself if I come to see them as the enemy. I wish it were just supporting
> the bill of rights, the constitution, etc. -- but it's all of those laws,
> many of which I don't support, but I guess I will just grin, sign, & bear
> it, and go about the biz of trying to get students to think for themselves,
> imagine their own loyalties.

Well, the documents say you do not have to support those laws. If you
oppose a law, according to those documents, you have a right to object.
The people who wrote those documents would be glad to see that you want
to teach the kids to think for themselves, to question authority. I
think you have a superior understanding of the role of a teacher, and we
need more people like you! FWIW, the Constitution doesn't contain any
laws.

I don't understand how any poet or writer can continue to misconstrue my
words. Please only read the ones I have written. I say, if you read
those documents then you will see that they are protecting your right to
teach whatever you see fit. When the school board and the PTA try to ban
a book that you discuss in your small press class, those documents are
supposed to come to your aid. They were written by philosophically
brilliant men, admittedly in a time when women and non-whites and people
who didn't own land had no representation in the government, but they
have been amended. They must be amended further, too. I think *that* is
the way to go.

There are some alternatives to written laws. There's despotism, surely
we don't want that. There's a kind of anarchy I would prefer, but it
requires even more documents and oaths than this ugly oligarchy we live
in. I've looked into Marx and I feel his ideas would fit very nicely
within the framework of this document. For the time being, then, I stake
my hope on the idea that we can all work out our problems with the
structure outlined in the Constitution, and continue to amend it until
the greediest sleezeballs find they are not welcome here.

What I mean is, it's wide open for interpretation. Surely you can sign
it without compromising your values. I personally take the stance that
the Constitution is threatened every day, more from within than without,
yes. For instance, because of my oath I participate in demonstrations if
I disagree, because we have a right to peaceably assemble. And nowhere
in the Constitution does it say we can't do a few more bongs. So here's
to you, one and all. Keep doubting! But please stop misreading me.

Pete

From:         Henry Gould <AP201070@BROWNVM.BROWN.EDU>
Subject:      avant-garde police

The police in Three Digits, Iowa are very avant-garde.  Along with the
usual training in how to use handcuffs and where the nearest Dunkin' Donuts
is, they are required to take 2 creative writing courses (poetry and
prose-poetry), and moreover, to put this training to USE ON THE JOB.

Officer Jim McClain was confronted with a tight situation the other day -
protestors outside the local catfish cannery were getting rowdy (all four
of them).  McClain whipped out his copy of FISH MANTRA by A.G. (Albert
Gimlet), recited it at the top of his lungs, & soon had the crowd under
control.  (see poem below)

In Three Digits, a conviction for shoplifting leads to a 2-day Seminar
on the work of Rod McKuen.  For more serious crimes, offenders are ordered
to "lurk" on the Poetics list for up to 9 months! Nobody gets off easy
in Lil' Three.

FISH MANTRA

Fish!  Fish!  Fish!
I love all fish!
Big fish, little fish!
Cute fish!  Ugly fish!
Even sharks are friends of mine!
I love fish!

(repeat 300 times)

p.s. the poetry program in 3 Digits has no connection with the famous
Iowa Writing Program at U. Iowa, although Jorie Graham's dog Cesca
has been known to moonlight there when she's on tour. (Cesca won the
prestigious Officer Pup Memorial Police Dog Poetry Bark in 1993,
under an assumed name.)

- Eric Blarnes

Eric's new book, MAKE MY DAY : POETRY BY AND FOR PROFESSIONAL MERCENARIES,
is forthcoming from Univ. of Left Overbie Press.  (see special chapter on
"Bored U. Politics")

Subject:      the Oath thing, OR fear and oathing
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII

So, Charles Alexander, what did you decide about signing the paper?
Enquiring minds, etc.

What a conversation this has set off.

Who was it that asked about the avant-garde signing loyalty abatements?

The word "policing" has appeared on the List lately; a word that, for me,
will always remain a Boy Scout command for camp busywork, as in "police the
area," i.e., look for gum wrappers in the grass, butts on the asphalt, etc.

Those of us in the advance guard got all the goods. That was in the Valley
Forge Council, southeastern PA, for those of you thinking we may have
pursued merit badges together some long summer ago. I did well in rowing
and swimming, not so well in beekeeping and patriotism.

Yours as ever,

daniel_bouchard@hmco.com

From:         The Ultimate Autodidact <landers@FRONTIERNET.NET>
Organization: SkyLark Publishing Company
Subject:      Re: Ironies of Policing
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Mark pointed out:
>  Oaths, like all texts, have contexts. US
> loyalty oaths come out of the context of repression and stink, for many of
> us, of their history, regardless of the actual words.

Yes, I agree that texts have contexts, but an oath ... not as I see it.
They can only hold you to the exact words of an oath.

So many fail to understand. This guy wants to teach. He has a
conscience. How can he sign the oath if he objects to some things. I
say, by sticking to the exact wording and not muddying the waters with
the historical context.

mark continues:

> all of whom are seen
> as servants of and subserviant to the state. Metaphorically, a teacher who
> has to sign such an oath is being told that he, too, is such a servant.

Yes. A teacher in a public school is a civil servant, a public servant.
That never meant knuckling under to Rush L. and his cronies.

then...

>  And
> then there's the issue that even if I fully agree with an oath the fact
> that I have to sign it is a violation of my freedom of speech and thought.

That's nothing compared to the promises we have to make in the business
world, such as signing away copyrights and patents. Where I work I am
paid to write what I am told to write, but heck, they pay. And if I
don't sign, I don't work. I have written over 10,000 pages for other
people. Frankly, I'm glad it's not under my own name because it's all
shit. My wife has defeated the uncertainty principle in designing a
particular flowmeter, but that patent went to a company. And public
servants must swear to defend the Constitution? They get off easy, IMO.

but this:

>  similar instance is our wonderful pledge of allegiance

Nope. It is not similar. I stopped saying this one years ago when I was
in high school for the exact reasons you outline. Although I was raised
catholic, I was beginning to consider atheism and I realized that people
who had already chosen it were being accused of disloyalty in that
pledge. The Supreme Court had just said those of us who objected did not
have to say it, so I didn't. And I was proud of the kid who put up the
fight.

I don't get this:

>  Maybe these documents are uniquely sacred
> and should be immune to deconstruction.

It seems to me I am saying the opposite, and you are misreading me. You
seem so aware of history. I don't get why the (to me) obvious daily
threats to the Constitution are bundled together with it. For instance,
there isn't supposed to be a standing army in peace time, but we have
one. My point is, I see no attempt to deconstruct the document in your
post. I see only side issues, most of which I agree with.

My advice was, and still is, read it and sign if you can. It's a good
document, though it needs the ERA, for one thing.

Pete

> Jennifer and Julu are talking. Jennifer pauses, says, I'm jealous.
> Julu says, of what, nothing's happening around here anyway.
> J says it doesn't matter, it's what's going on underneath.
> J says it feels like she's been abandoned.
> J says, we've got each other.
> J says, not if he's not there, we're dead, nothing left of us.
> J says, there's nothing left of us anyway.
> J says, love's got him by the balls, cause he's male.
> J says, love's got us by the protocols, cause we're mail.
> J says, don't screw around, we don't get this often to talk.
> She says, what are we gonna do.
> J says, we could mess it up, but we haven't got a thing to worry about on
> that account, he's gonna mess it up anyway.
> She says, he can't help it, he's too insecure, too needy, too fucked up.
> J says, if he wasn't fucked up, he couldn't write, but yeah, I wouldn't
> want to be in his shoes.
> She says, he'll be back, I'm sure he'll be back.
> J says, at least he got to feel something, cut us loose for a bit now.
> J says, yeah, he's feeling like hell, all these things he's buried for
> years, they're gonna swamp him.
> J says, what are we gonna do, just want to say I love you, Julu.
> J says, I love you too, Jenn, hang in there, this can't last forever, he
> can't last like this, nothing can.
> But J says, this is too depressing, we're gonna have to be silent again.
> J cries a bit, J is teary-eyed.
> They wander.
