Pete: I, too, stopped saying the pledge when Ike slipped in "under
God"--I was 10 or 11 at the time. Good for us.

Charles: I remember that this issue came up at Buffalo in the '60s,
notably with Gregory Corso, who'd been hired without any credentials but
his poetry [hooray for Al Cook, who served as chairman at the time, if
memory serves]. He was teaching Shelley, & was a real pleasure [he
included Newman Ivey White's biography as well as a collected works].
Everything went well for the first few weeks; we adjourned to
Bitterman's bar across the street a few times, & the class went on till
we all knew it was over, not when the bell rang. The University wanted
GC to sign an oath of loyalty to the Constitutions of the United States
and of the State of New York; he assented to the former, but said he'd
not read the latter, & requested a copy. It took a while for someone to
produce the state constitution, & it was very long. CG told the
University he had no time to read it, since he was teaching the class.
So he got canned. A great loss to his students, though it made an
important point at the time to people who thought it made an important
point. The point? Sign it, already: take the money & run. Hungry? Eat.
"Got a headache? Take an aspirin." I signed one to get a teaching
fellowship, without which I couldn't have afforded graduate school &
would have turned my back on a career in which I've managed at least to
present critiques of the USA & beyond; whether I've personally
radicalized anyone, I'm not sure, but I've tried. _A Man for All
Seasons_ makes a great play, but Thomas More was playing for much higher
stakes than anyone today asked to take an oath like the one you've been
asked to take. More important not to betray yourself by letting a
government full of people who daily violate the same oath purge you.
No more Gunga Dins!
--Dan Zimmerman

Yesterday we received in the mail the lavish color flyer for the u of
arizona's performance series. One of the performances is of a Phillip Glass
version of a Cocteau tale. The flyer described Phillip Glass as an
"avant-garde superstar."

That makes me want to drop the term "avant-garde" altogether, even though I
haven't been predisposed to dropping it before that.

God (I mean this as an expletive), I hope this my last contribution to this
thread.

1. As long as memory persists, historical context remains attached to the
words that issued forth from that context. That's why the Supreme Court is
interested in legislative and constitutional history and all courts are
interested in common-law precedent.

2.Police, soldiers and elected and appointed government officials are
servants of the state in a different sense. As they are variously armed,
the state built on the constitution is threatened by overthrow if they
allow their personal opinions to rule their actions on the job. A soldier
in battle may think the commander's strategy is dumb, but he's not legally
allowed to act on his disagreement--the chain of command, which ultimately
goes back to Congress (declarations of war and appropriations) and the
Commander-in-chief, is protected by his understanding of his oath. He has
to subordinate his will to the authority established by the document he
swears to uphold. His general or a group within government could easily, as
they do in most countries, circumvent the document's process by organizing
a putsch--it has been hoped that their oath and the culture of their
professions will restrain them from doing so, and for the most part that
hope has been rewarded. Teachers may subvert the minds of the innocent, but
they don't have tanks or access to same. That's why until recent decades no
one ever required an oath from them, whereas these other guys have been
swearing on the bible as a condition of employment for a long, long time.

3. As to your work situation, I feel your pain.

4. I'm not trying to deconstruct the constitution, although that might be
fun. It's the oaths and pledges I'm after.

4.

Just published--FIRST INTENSITY #9. Contributors (partial list): Diane
Wakoski, Duncan McNaughton, Mike Boughn, Spencer Selby, X.J. Kennedy, Dallas
Wiebe, Michael Gottlieb, Will Alexander, Jean Monod, Vincent Ferrini, Drew
Gardner, Lizbeth Keiley, David Gilbert, Gloria Frym, John Isles, Rochelle
Ratner, et al. Cover art: A hand-drawn, and used, "shooting target" by S.
Clay Wilson, aptly entitled "Bounty Hunter" with the caption: "Grab the sky
you junky polecat" (dedicated to William S. Burroughs, who helped the artist
put holes in the target this past June); also six paintings by William S.
Burroughs, with an introduction by Jim McCrary and recent and
characteristically terse comments by Burroughs on the topic of cloning. This
is likely the last journal to publish anything of William's prior to his
death on August 2nd. 168 pages, perfectbound; $9 (+$2.00 p/h). Order from the
publisher: Lee Chapman, FIRST INTENSITY, P.O. Box 665, Lawrence, KS 66044.

Date:         Tue, 12 Aug 1997 15:39:51 -0500
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Jack Foley <JFOLEY@CRS.LOC.GOV>
Subject:      MEDIOCRITY in Contemporary POETRY
Comments: To: POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU.
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain

Dear Friends, Poets, and All Others:

                    Web Chat SUNDAY, AUGUST 17, 8 p.m. (EST) on
                THE TROUBLE WITH MEDIOCRITY
                                    (On Contemporary Poetry)
                       http://webdelsol.com/SOLCHAT/solchat.htm
                                     (Netscape 3.0 or higher)

       Announcing the first of a three part series sponsored by FlashPoint
(webdelsol.com/FLASHPOINT) and Web Del Sol entitled THE TROUBLE
WITH MEDIOCRITY, PART I.  Carlo Parcelli, a writer, bookseller, and the
editor of FlashPoint--a new and bleeding edge litzine based in the
Washington, DC area--will host and moderate the discussion, focusing
primarily on topics noted in summary-blurbs below, i.e., L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E
poetry, the bureaucracy of poetry, The Rule of the Poet Tyrants, and the
comic tragedy of poetry's "self-betrayal."

Also, less specifically on what Carlo and many others feel to be a condition
of mental and artistic palsy effecting the state of American poetry today.
As Carlo so aptly puts it:

"There is the ubiquitous school of  ... "Lawn Mower Poets", the "Simpering
Sonneteers" or the "I-I-ME-ME-I-ME Advanced School of Navel Studies."  Their
only referent is his or her upper-middle class sentimentalized "personal
crisis" -- hairline, waistline, on-line, supermarket line, whatever. ...
[They] ... are agonizingly self-absorbed and solipsistic.  How can people
barnacled with such bourgeois excesses speak to injustices or address
historical events? ... Can they offer third world nationalist movements
anythingin the way of counsel other than capitulation?  [Their] poems have
their solipsistic origins at the poet's window, looking to his/her favorite
tree(s), or more appropriately the poem arises from the poet's couch potato,
psychoanalytic, etc.  Any scrap of history becomes just another referent for
their suburban angst.  ... The language is gassy and loose, as though the
poems were written after a hearty meal.  There are few dynamics, few
allusions that might indicate a world beyond each poem's enervated mass and
tranquilizing cliches."

PART I of THE TROUBLE WITH MEDIOCRITY will take place on August 17, 8
PM
Eastern Standard Time at
http://webdelsol.com/SOLCHAT/solchat.htm   Netscape 3.0 or higher is
necessary to take part.

Room on the Java server is limited (or so I am told), so the earlier the
arrival the better chance for a seat at the table.  No reservations or
holding before 7:45, please.  The Java chat function is fairly intuitive.
Wait till the Java chat applet is fully loaded, then type in a log-on name
and voila.

-----------------

PART I: Excerpts from Bernstein vs. Stern---Featherweight Division (and
other matters)


"My greatest disappointment in the years I have spent involved with
poetry has been its lack of collegiality. The institutions of poetry
have demonstrated a diffident and exclusionary cunning arising from a
vast critical and editorial insecurity. The public structure of poetry
is filled with frightened bureaucrats.  This is largely because,
mimicking  more successful disciplines, poets at great imaginative cost,
have created tiny fiefdoms for themselves. "


"One could point out that institutions by their very nature
are exclusive and inhumane. But this only prompts the question---What
are poets doing there?  Today's poetry by betraying its own ethos
renders itself weak and ineffectual."


"I was once given a transcript of a symposium of critics and poets. I
have forgotten the time and place of the gathering, but what I do
remember is an awkward exchange between Gerald Stern and Charles
Bernstein on the nature and/or role of poetry, with Marjorie Perloff
serving as an impromptu referee. Stern's position was that of the
soporific and mawkish sentimentalist who found any reflection on the
legitimacy of his poetry an incomprehensible intrusion. Bernstein, on
the other hand, described a set of theoretical notions that he could not
work into any context other than L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E poetry's tautological
elegance. In the argument, Stern, by default, was awarded the world as
subject. Bernstein was left sputtering. The whole exercise was
embarrassing . . ."


(time not yet scheduled for Part II)


PART II: Douglas Hofstadter  Disses  John Cage (and more)


-- Carlo Parcelli

Subject:      loyalty oath of a different color
Content-Type: text

Charles pointed out to me, backchannel that the oath said:

I, _________________________ do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will
support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution and
laws
of the State of Arizona; That I will bear true faith and allegiance to the
same, and defend them against all enemies, foreign and domestic, and that
I
will faithfully and impartially discharge the duties of the office of
_______________________ according to the best of my ability, so help me
God
(or, so I do affirm).

The clinker there is "and laws" which is not in the New York State oath.
So *I* am the dolt who misread. Apologies all around.

If I had to sign that, I would balk, too. It seems to me that a teacher
shouldn't have to support laws. Kids should know about the possibility of
civil disobedience. Laws can't have domestic enemies, for instance, and
any text that says such is lame-brained. I'd say it has always been a duty
to oppose laws that one disagrees with. Now I think that the oath is
un-Constitutional.

Since you and others must get past this hurdle in order to teach, sign it,
anyway, and if they nail someone with it, if for instance, adultery laws
are used to fire a teacher, or someone is fired for teaching Thoreau, then
there's a case for the courts, if you want. IMO, the oath foreswears
itself by its own un-Constitutionality.

And Mark, I agree on many points, but which is better, to sign or not.
Shall we make a federal case for Charles or for the Corso case? I bet,
given the same predicament, you would choose one ot the other. And I'm
sure you have not finished saying your peace on this and other important
issues. Or at least, I hope not. Basically, I don't think McCarthy
invalidates Jefferson, but beyond that we're almost 100% agreed.

with respect for all (but the kid who called me a running dog),

Pete

From:         Nuyopoman@AOL.COM
Subject:      National Slam Finals
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=unknown-8bit
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Controversy (& Poetry) Reign as Mouth Almighty
Wins National Slam Championship
Da Boogey Man Becomes First Male Slam Champ

(Aug. 10: Middletown CT) In a series of poetry slams marked by official
protests and concluding with boos mixed with thunderous applause, Mouth
Almighty came back from a semifinal defeat to Chicago to win the 8th National
Poetry Slam held in the huge Freeman Auditorium before 900 screaming poetry
lovers. The scores of the Finals looked like this: Mouth Almighty: Mouth
Almighty 115, Chicago 110, Cleveland 109.8, Worcester 105.85.

The protests were both lodged against Mouth Almighty, a team of New York City
all-stars; both were disallowed. They pointed, however, to a deep concern in
the Slam Family about corporate sponsorship (Mouth Almighty is the world's
first major poetry label), as well as to the all-star nature of the team:
Regie Cabico, Evert Eden, Taylor Mali, Beau Sia, with Bob Holman as coach.
“This begins the era of the Super Team!” shouted an ecstatic Cabico, whose
coming out to Mom poem, performed as a duet Mali, was the evening’s final and
highest scoring poem.

In the Individual Slam, Da Boogey Man, stalwart of the Cleveland team which
was undefeated going into the Finals, read two powerful, slow-paced poems
which resonated strongly in the air hanger fieldhouse. Patricia Smith, who
along with Slam Founder Marc Smith was hosting the Individual Finals,
announced that this was the first time in the history of Slam that a man had
won the prize. DJ Renegade of Washington, DC finished second for the third
year in a row, with Glenis Redmond-Sherer of Greenville, NC, taking third.

Date:         Tue, 12 Aug 1997 09:45:52 -0500

From:         Joe Amato/Kass Fleisher <amato@CHARLIE.CNS.IIT.EDU>
Subject:      Re: when you do your own policing
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

it occurs to me (slow-witted that i am) that one of the problems lurking
just beneath the surface of the avant-garde thread has to do with how one
understands oneself...

i mean, if you define yourself simply as a "writer," on the basis of doing
different sorts of writing for different sorts of audiences on different
sorts of presses at different times, you'll likely find any tag a
restriction of sorts, mebbe even an ontological restriction... b/c at any
moment, you may find yourself outside or inside a particular network of
writerly affiliations, or if you wish, community...

one of the problems i have with academic-scholarly writers (that is, with
those who define themselves as such, which is occasionally a function of
their failure to define themselves as such!) is that they sometimes take
for granted their position as writers within the academic publishing
system... which sometimes leads to a sort of pooh-poohing of motivations,
if not articulations, that seem to these folks to fall too far afield...
and of course, these days, contemporary poetry in general generally falls
too far afield...

one of the problems i have with more avant-garde writers---most of whom,
owing to the sort of work they do, *are* acutely aware of public perception
and reception (and again, i'm using a-g w/o any critical interference, as a
descriptor)---is that they sometimes dig in on the aesthetic issues in
particular... as though community itself turned on towing a certain
aesthetic line... which, for me, has always been a questionable way of
forging human relationships, though i'll grant that things can be
rough-going when you really don't like somebody's work!... i've always
mself felt a particular affinity for folks who work hard and get little
public acclaim---by the general public, i mean... and end up barely making
artistic ends meet...

one of the problems i have with more conventional writers, trade press
writers---some or perhaps many of whom simply do not understand the degree
to which their aesthetic is one among many aesthetics---is that they often
achieve "success" without a whole lot in the way of identifying why... that
is, what registers they're playing, *as* registers... which translates, for
one, to me being able to appreciate their work, while they don't seem to
appreciate mine...

i guess i have problems with all sorts of writers!... and having written in
all three categories (only recently trying to make the transition into more
conventional work), it's fair to say that i feel the stresses and strains
attendant to each... moreover, i teach technical and professional
writing---and it's really easy from this vantagepoint to see how these
different sorts of commitments, motivations, publishing realities can work
to obscure what different publics perceive as "good" or "bad" work...

i hope i'm clear on one point, anyway:  that though pluralism is not w/o
its attendant risks, one can inhabit multiple spaces---or to drop that
geometric metaphor for a moment---multiple processes... i would think that
what's necessary is a capacity for not bullshitting oneself into believing
that one is doing x while in actuality one is doing y... but of course x's
and y's are negotiable too---sometimes shit happens...

best,

joe

round."

I hope I'm wrong, but I somehow can only read that as a snide bit against
Henry Taylor. He is, after all, a "mainstream" poet (get thee behind me
terminology). Yet, Henry Taylor is *really* an experimental poet. That is,
he experiments with his poetry and how he writes and presents it (using
experiment in the loose and unrelated-to-science meaning the word is given
in the arts). He's had a long-term correspondence with Jackson Maclow and
written very well on Jackson's work and written work of his own using
techniques similar to/inspired by/identical to/something like... Jackson's.
The engagement proceeded from seeing a book of Maclow's at a yard sale (I
think), buying it and allowing its foreignness to anything he'd
done/thought up to that point to operate as inspiration.

I assume his jumping into the slam pool (I sure as hell wouldn't do it [did
anyone see Kim Dawn there?]) reflects the same sinew and flex. Good for him.

Jordan, is this part of the "everything is always less" slipknotjestreamthread?

the Nw Yolker had an article about Frank Gehry [note the Nagram] avoiding
architectural/critical debates & just making things.  Here's someone who
turns back the technical in the most advanced degree of a profession into
the handmade. See the titanium museum just put up in Bilboa Spain.
the space of the handmade poem.  [Avoidance was not neutrality, just
attention.]

Avant-garde = handmade.

Avant-garde = homemade.

Avant-garde = unprocessed, unscreened.

the faded Bhagavad by G. Stein on the Himalayan hillside rocks.

Dan Bouchard's MASS AVE was in my mailbox today.  He's done a very simple
handmade thing - put a magazine together of a few poets, not too much of a
miscellany, just the poems.  very simple.  foregrounds the poems.  easing
the mind.  homemade lemonade.  walking home today there were two blonde
sisters, must have been six & eight, by the side of the road selling a
"Moth Show".  I thought it was lemonade at first - but no, a moth show.
they had some little cartons - one had some grass in it, they said the
caterpillar had crawled away.  The other had a little dead blue moth in it,
which they said was a butterfly because it was prettier than the moths
[I said some moths are like that, but they could be right.]  Then they had
a big jar with 2 live brown moths.  The small one said, "My sister will
show you the cemetery we made for the dead moths."  I said that's o.k., I have
to get on home.  They had 2 handpainted signs - one said 15 cents, the other
55 cents - I said, which is it?  They said 55.  But they didn't have change,
so I gave them a dollar.  The show was worth it.  I would have liked
to have met their mother - they both had blue-green eyes.

- Henry Hank

From:         David Bromige <dcmb@METRO.NET>
Subject:      imperialist bow-wows/avant-ga-ga's/abduction by aliens
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Kent, at last! someone i know (in the cyber-sense) who has been abducted. I
want to tell you what your experience was like.

It was like everyone else's. Who has been taken up into a USAF anti-gravity
craft. The laser beam that carries the anti-gravity charge 'beamed' you up.
The distortion imposed upon vision by the anti-gravitational field made
humans in spacesuits resemble the 'alien' as often described. They probe yr
orifices because thats what they find the most fun to do, its not for
science its to kill time while you have an abduction experience so that you
will talk about it later & further the space-creatures myth.

These flashbacks you have been having, that cause you to doubt yr own
perception f reality, will cease thanks to this explanation i am giving to
you. There will be no more Yasusadas. And those wishing to continue
discussing Yasusada One will do so until there is no one left who wishes to
discuss it with them. People will stop talking during movies. Drivers will
rediscover the use of the turn signal.Instead of applying the term "avant
garde" or any substitute therefore to contemporary poets, people will name
that poet and name any other poet they wish to associate with him/her.
Instead of "The avant garde writers Susan Howe and Clark Coolidge..." we
will read "The writers Susan Howe and Clark Coolidge...".
Readers who dont know the work of the named writers will have to look it
up. If one or more of them exclaims to him/herself, "Great God, Carruthers,
Avant-gardistes !", this cry will not reach us where we sit.

You know how sometimes a post comes via e-mail that has 40 other e-ddresses
in its header, along with your own? Well _that_ is how scholarly books and
articles will look, with 40 or more names of poets lumped together wherever
the author needs to make a general statement that applies to each of them.
"As Robert Hass, Brenda Hillman, Robert Pinsky, Tess Gallagher, Stephen
Mitchell, Jane Hirshfield, Diana O'Hehir, Bob Perelman, Aldon Neilsen, Doug
Powell, Cydney Chadwick, Ron Silliman, Lyn Hejinian, Steven Vincent, Jack
Foley, Dodie Bellamy, Kevin Killian, Richard Silberg, Joyce Jenkins, Jack
Hirshman, Kathleen Fraser, Steve Tills, Jennifer Moxley, Steve Benson,
Michael Davidson, Todd Barron, Douglas Messerli, Mark Wallace, Lisa
Robertson, Deanna Ferguson, George Stanley, Joe Napora, Marilyn Chin,
Lucille Clifton, Dianne Di Prima, Steve Farmer, Victor Hernandez Cruz,
Duane BigEagle, Nick Piombino, and David Bromige demonstrate, the linear,
like the aerial on a Buick Park Lane, can be bent without being snapped
off." Or "unlike," as experience dictates. It is a pleasure to write the
name of a poet. There will be more pleasure in the writing of scholarly
articles. Some of these will consist only in a list of names. Soon all of
them will consist only in a list of names. But only with the coming of the
fascist world state will these lists be identical.

Poetry will be classified into just two categories: safe and unsafe, as in
sex. So it will be an allowable shortcut to refer to "the unsafe poetry of
Barrett Watten" or "the safe poetry of Dana Gioia." It will be a redundancy
of sorts, but it holds the possibility of humor, so lets keep it.

Yes, it is a bright future we contemplate, but one day the alien myth will
be used to shut everything down and world fascism will be accomplished.

We will still have music--but it may not be Mary Martin singing "My heart
belongs to daddy."

David

Date:         Tue, 12 Aug 1997 11:37:14 -0500

From:         Tom Mandel <tmandel@SCREENPORCH.COM>
Subject:      avant academe
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Mark, your post on the relation of avant garde to academy is really
wonderful and even better it is useful. A person reading it can use it in
thinking about her/his life.

A couple of points, however. There is a tendency to think of academy as
institution (correct) and avant garde as... anarchy/utopia/individualism/?
Just a tendency, mind you. And this leads you to formulate a picture of
unestablished avantgardists pointing envy (or whatever) at established
avantgardists because of their position *in the academy* -- i.e. in another
institution.

No this is intra-institutional politics. The avantgarde (non-mainstream
poetry, cosa nostra -- call it what you want) is an institution, and
position in it is critical to and at stake for all those committed to the
institution.

I believe the point important, because it allows one to ask what the
relation is of a practice of writing ----- which hopes (by whatever means
and to whatever end *other* than institutional acceptance) actually to *be*
avantgarde, using whatever loose re-denotation you want for the term: i.e.
to be "new" "sui generis" "experimental" whatever ----- to the
institution(s) in which it cannot escape participation.

The utility of this question -- not of an answer, just of the question --
is that it dissipates complaint.

I conceptualize people who view others (more established others) with envy,
for example, as having a view of social space on the model of a Go or chess
board. It's finite, structured, and occupied. You want to occupy space you
gotta force somebody out of the space you want to occupy. Institutional
space is always like this in some sense, in some retrospective sense.

In fact, the social space of an institution (e.g. such as avantgarde
poetry) is more like legos or tinker toys (for those who remember them).
It's additive, and the more you add in a given direction, the more you move
the center of the institution in that precise direction. There's nothing
ambiguous about it.

Hence, it doesn't do to conclude that we must constantly monitor our
policing positions in the institutions which entail us. Constantly monitor
equals self-police, and in the hermeneutic circle of this thought Mark is
thinking, that very self-monitoring begins to found the so-called
hierarchical discipline/punish society we occupy in which "the only way to
make a living at all is to police somebody" (that is, it founds *a vision*
of society along these lines).

I think I've allowed myself to become too abstract; what is the question
here? How to become independent as a poet, let us say. How to cut or at
least loosen the leash? The noose?

If you are a really good teacher, then teach. If you are a really good
poet, then write. But, "I am a really good poet" provides you with no
rights whatever to be published. Ditto, "...good teacher." If you are a
good writer you will find readers however. And a teacher finds students.

Tom Mandel

>to get on home.  They had 2 handpainted signs - one said 15 cents, the other
>55 cents - I said, which is it?  They said 55.  But they didn't have change,
>so I gave them a dollar.  The show was worth it.  I would have liked
>to have met their mother - they both had blue-green eyes.
>
>- Henry Hank

In a message dated 97-08-13 02:10:21 EDT, you write:

>I hope I'm wrong, but I somehow can only read that as a snide bit against

Tom, thank's for correcting my D.J. Renegade typo.Yes, D.J.'s one of
the best on the slam scene--for the last three years he's been runner-up
in the Slam National Individual Finals. His writing (I know only the handful
of pieces that I've seen him perform) would probably "hold up" of the page,
as well.

I am a fan of Henry Taylor's poetry, though I have trouble seeing him as
"out there" or "on the edge," if that's the sense you mean by "experimental."

I find it strange to tag work with "the finish" of Henry Taylor's as EXP.

It was certainly a surprise for certain slam poets to see H. Taylor at the
Nationals,
I can tell you that Bob Holman (Nuyurican/Mouth Almighty) was very
deferential
and praising of Taylor the night of the Semis, when Taylor, already knocked
out,
served as judge. Most of the poets and slammers at the Nationals didn't know
Henry Taylor from a hole in the ground. Some (emphasis on "some") don't read
much.

I applaud Taylor for participating. I didn't get to talk to him enough to get
at his
real intent--was it: a serious attempt to win it all; to study, field work
on, so to
speak, the slam phenomenon; or just curiousity, and an interest in exploring
his
work as performance before large and appreciative crowd? As I said, he got
knocked out by the second round--however, the night I saw him recite
("Landscape With Tractor"), he was applauded with vigor and sincerity.

Finnegan

Here's the text of Taylor Mali's first round poem. Sans head jerks on "like"
(and head jerks that "replace" or "place" the "likes" as Lilly is weaned),
parachute opening "uhwHOOMp," and tight gesture choreography, for your sheer
textual enjoyment.

B>Like Lilly Like Wilson
by Taylor Mali

I’m writing the poem that will change the world,
and it’s Lilly Wilson at my office door.
Lilly Wilson, the recovering like addict,
the worst I’ve ever seen.
So bad the whole eighth grade
started calling her Like Lilly Like Wilson.
‘Til I declared my class a Like-Free Zone
and she could not speak for days.

But when she finally did, it was to say,
Mr. Mali, this is . . . so hard.
Now I have to . . . think before I . . . say anything.

Imagine that, Lilly.

Its for your own good.
Even if you don’t like . . .
it.

I’m writing the poem that will change the world,
and it’s Lilly Wilson at my office door.
Lilly is writing a research paper for me about how gays
like shouldn’t be allowed to adopt children.
I’m writing the poem that will change the world,
and it’s Like Lilly Like Wilson at my office door.

Lilly’s having trouble finding sources,
which is to say, ones that back her up:
They all argue in favor of what I thought I was against.

And it took all four years of college,
three years of graduate school,
and every incidental teaching experience I have ever had
to let out only,

That’s a real interesting problem, Lilly.
But what do you propose to do about it?
That’s what I want to know.

And the eighth-grade mind is a beautiful thing;
Like a new-born baby’s face, you can often see it
change before your very eyes.

I can’t believe I’m saying this, Mr. Mali,
but I think I’d like to switch sides.

And I want to tell her to do more than just believe it,
but to enjoy it! That changing your mind is one of the best ways
of finding out whether you still have one.
Or even that minds are like parachutes,
that it doesn’t so much matter what you pack them with
so long as they open
at the right time.

I want to say all this but manage only,
Lilly, I am like so impressed with you.

So I finally taught someone something,
namely, how to change your mind.
And learned in the process that if I ever change the world
it’s going to be one eighth grader at a time.
=========================================================================

Date:         Wed, 13 Aug 1997 15:12:18 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Mark Wallace <mdw@GWIS2.CIRC.GWU.EDU>
Subject:      D.J. Renegade, Henry Taylor, etc.
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

        I want to second Tom Mandel's comments about the interest of the
work of D.J. Renegade and Henry Taylor, but perhaps also to expand a
little about them.

        D.J. is a D.C. poet who, about a decade ago, more or less
"chose" to become homeless for several years, so that instead of spending
all his time at annoying jobs
to make enough money to live in D.C., he could spend all his time reading
up on the history of poetry and much else in D.C's many public libraries,
including the Library of Congress. At this point he's quite well
known both here in D.C. and on the national slam circuit. He was the
subject of a feature length article, with front page photograph, of one
issue of Washington's City Paper, a widely-distributed free weekly that
reaches several hundred thousand people with every issue. Along with much
else about him, that issue dealt in great detail on the way he had
recently lost two national slam championships--the reason for both losses
being ONLY that he exceeded the time limit for the reading by a few
seconds in each case. Either that's a silly thing to do, or a silly rule
in the first place--my own sense is probably the latter.

        With a few exceptions, I've never been all that convinced about
his poems on the page. But he is a truly electrifying performer when he
chooses to be, capable of taking listeners on a real roller coaster ride.
To my mind, though, the subject of gender is something of a problem in his
work--women tend for the most part in his work to be people he is trying
to love but who don't love him back, althugh he doesn't quite go so far as
objectifying them, at least usually. Probably this would be a flaw in
anyone's poetry, but it seems particularly important in the context of the
identity issues that motivate much of his work.

        I agree with Tom that Henry Taylor's essay on Jackson Mac Low is
very strong, and Henry's own work using some of Mac Low's methods is quite
interesting. I published one of those pieces in Situation #12. As he
himself has said, that part of his work is TRULY mystifying to the more
traditional formalist poets who tend to be his compatriots. Still, there's
something perhaps troubling about it--the ONLY kind of of more
structurally innovative work that he's done is work using computer
methods. I'm a big fan of such work, but I get the sense, sometimes, that
there may be the implication that he doesn't see the difference between
computer generated texts and ALL "avant garde" poetry, as if, to put it
into terms that he might use, he still hasn't put into practice the idea
of consciously CRAFTING poems in other than traditional structures. He'll
let computers generate alternative structures, but he won't try to "write"
in such structures the way he will "write" in traditional ones.

        Both D.J. and Henry have been invited to read, and did read, in
several of the reading series we sponsor here in D.C. for "avant garde"
work, as well in the venues of slam poetry (and, in Henry's case, for
academic audiences). Recently, there was a reading at Border's in which,
according to the promotional information, "slam poets" directly challenged
"academic poets" to a performance slam--who "won" depended, in this case,
on which kind of work people liked better in the first place. But this was
only one of a recent group of events in which these two "groups" appear
together on the same stage. A CD, compiled by Jeffrey McDaniel, features
work from the slam series "Live at the Black Cat" (I may not have this
title correct) that has Henry, D.J., and others on it--I would appreciate
anyone who can remind me of the label.

        Although Tom says he probably wouldn't dare perform at a slam, Rod
Smith, Buck Downs, myself and several others have performed our more
"avant garde" (if you will) work at quite a few Black Cat slams. We've
done things like multi-voice pieces and other approaches, and I even read
once from my new Edge Book NOTHING HAPPENS AND BESIDES I WASN'T THERE
while sitting on the floor with my back to the audience. We got good
applause--my own personal highlight in applause came at the point that I
gave the audience the finger. They loved it. Our work didn't make it onto
the CD, although Jeff McDaniel later said to me he thought he had made a
mistake in leaving it off. I don't see it so much as a conscious attempt
to leave "avant garde" poetries out as it was, perhaps, a failure to think
about including such work.

        When Jeff left D.C. for L.A. last year, the Black Cat series seems
to have died, and the D.C. slam scene has been a little harder for me at
least to track down, because I don't hear from anyone who tells me where
they're going on, and they're not as well advertised as they used to be.
Still, I think it's at least partly true to say that while there seem to
be more meetings between "slam poets" and "academic poets" on the D.C.
slam
scene these days, avant garde work for the most part is NOT part of that
scene, although again, that's not because anyone's being PREVENTED from
reading. But it's a scene, and to be part of it you have to be part of it,
and to feel like there's some value in your being part of it.

        On a side note, Robert Hale seems to have "cautioned" me twice now
not to forget that historical limiations on the very possibility of what
writing can be make it impossible for someone to write "what they want."
It's a point I've looked at a number of times myself, although Robert
can't be faulted for not knowing that. Still, Robert, if you'll
backchannel me with
your mailing address, I'd be glad to send you a copy of my recent chapbook
of poetics dialogues with Jefferson Hansen, which brings up the issue many
times. Having said all that, though, the fact that there may literally be
some things our historical moment prevents us from knowing about what
writing might be (although I assume also that we can't know what we're
prevented from knowing, because otherwise we'd know it), I don't think
that that makes the idea that one might write as one wants a "fantasy."
One chooses what one wants to write from all the available options one can
imagine--such options may not be endless but one can still choose to want
them. So, frankly, I DO write what I want. Of course, the next step after
that is that one will be faced with the consequences of that choice.

        Lastly, I'm sorry if Maria Damon or anyone else perceived me to be
attacking her "personally." That was not my intention, nor was it my
intention even to analyze the totality of her involvements. Rather, I was
analyzing what I saw as the confusions in a few
particular comments, with an eye not so much to attacking anyone as to
contributing to the chance of thinking through what seems to me an
important problem. I still stand by my analysis, although it was meant
as no more final than anything else on this list. But to the extent that
any of my previous comments actually DID attack her personally (which I'm
still not sure they did), or even to the extent that they can be construed
as such, I certainly apologize for that aspect, at least, of what they
said.

        Mark Wallace

Date:         Wed, 13 Aug 1997 08:50:24 -0400
Reply-To:     Mark Prejsnar <mprejsn@law.emory.edu>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Mark Prejsnar <mprejsn@LAW.EMORY.EDU>
Subject:      Re: avant academe
In-Reply-To:  <3.0.1.32.19970812113714.008d33c0@cais.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

>
> A couple of points, however. There is a tendency to think of academy as
> institution (correct) and avant garde as... anarchy/utopia/individualism/?
> Just a tendency, mind you. And this leads you to formulate a picture of
> unestablished avantgardists pointing envy (or whatever) at established
> avantgardists because of their position *in the academy* -- i.e. in another
> institution.
>
> No this is intra-institutional politics. The avantgarde (non-mainstream
> poetry, cosa nostra -- call it what you want) is an institution, and
> position in it is critical to and at stake for all those committed to the
> institution.
>
Tom--
This is interesting, vis-a-vis several of my previous points; first off,
it reiterates that interesting spatial image of "avant-garde" as a
relatively static zone, rather than an advancing attack...Thus showing
again how most of us have toned-down the original feel of "avant-garde"...

But more peculiar and fascinating is the claim that "a-g" is an
institution...I think it is probably more a series of fragmentary zones of
activity...

In other words, it's important to be clear whether we're talking about a
sociological phenomenon, an identifiable social grouping we can study (as
in your post) or a series of esthetic engagements and projects.  In the
former sense, both "workshop poetry" and non-mainstream writing are of
course institutional matrices, with magazines, imprints, sources of
funding; there is of course a huge disparity in available resources, and
one is closer to the basic economic life of things, can provide more jobs,
etc.--is linked as it were to *other* institutions, that provide a support
structure.  But in the latter sense of these terms, neither a workshop
poet nor an "experimental" (hate that word) poet, is necessarily absorbed
by an "institution."  I've known (indeed know) practitioners of both
approaches, who for various reasons are marginal to or outside the
institutional frameworks--whether APR/university or Sun and
Moon/Naropa--and in this sense, there is not a single
economicosociological network, that automatically encompasses everything
written in a given style or tendency.

Also, the emphasis on "envy" etc. is interesting (like the original
phrasing of this thread in terms of "policing")...Some of the most
remarkable writers I know seem to have very little concern with shoving
and scuffling for position; their concern with the activity and the work,
and relative lack of concern with rewards and ego, can be quite
striking...

mark p.
atlanta

Date:         Wed, 13 Aug 1997 15:02:15 EDT
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         henry gould <AP201070@BROWNVM.BROWN.EDU>
Subject:      avant-garde

some interesting quotes from Mikhail Epstein's wonderful book AFTER THE
FUTURE:

"A.M. Pachenko, a specialist in Old Russian culture, writes, 'The life of
the holy fool is a conscious negation of the beautiful, a rejection of the
customary ideal, or, more precisely, an inversion of this ideal and an
elevation of the ugly to an aesthetically positive level.' But the same is
brought as an accusation against the avant-garde by its critics from the
standpoint of 'good taste' and 'high ideals' (examples my be found in the
work of Marxist and Orthodox religious writers alike).  The avant-garde
is a holy fool's art, consciously going forth to its own humiliation, to the
mutilation of its own aesthetic face, even to the point that a urinal may
take a sculpture's place on display, and a pathetic, twisted 'dyr bur schil
ubeschur' may take the place of beautiful poetic harmonies."

"Clearly, such holy foolery is an anti-aesthetic phenomenon, but may also
be positively defined as a religious phenomenon... the significance of the
avant-garde as a religious negation of art by artistic means becomes clear.
Art becomes impoverished, pathetic in order to partake of God's fate..."

"The artist bespatters his public with spit and abuse, so as to provoke its
indignation and mockery in return.  As for the holy fool, 'he continually
provokes his viewers...casts stones, muck and filth at them...outrages their
sense of propriety.'  This characterization of a holy fool may equally well
be applied to the scandalous conduct of the Russian and Italian futurists, the
French dadaists and surrealists.  Scandal, a flagrant toppling of social norms,
exposes a more deeply paradoxical system of values, wherein the high takes on
the visage of the low."

"Alexei Kruchenykh's 'dyr bul schil ubeschur' or Velimir Khlebnikov's
'gzi-gzi-gzeo' are akin to glossolalia and oblique mutterings, comprehensible
to the holy fool alone... obliqueness is a device for expressing the
inexpressibility of the inexpressible - things that do not yield themselves
to the tongue..."

Epstein links the avant-garde to the iconoclastic radicalism of the 2nd
commandment (thou shalt not make any graven image...):
"Avant-garde art is closer to the icon than to artistic painting, and
still closer to the characters & signs found in monotheistic churches,
than to the icon: its subject is the passing away of the world, rolled
up and sealed like a scroll... This is the realism of an apocalytpic age
that has realized the unstable and spectral nature of all worldly
arrangements.  This is apocalyptic realism."

But Epstein doesn't rest in a dramatic or overblown characterization of
the avant-garde.  He concludes this particular essay with a closer look
at some contemporary conceptualist poets (Rubinshtein,
Prigov, & others) & finds their essence in a kind of humility, or
dispersal of bombast.  "It becomes clear that the role of
the contemporary avant-garde and of conceptualism in particular is to aid
in the process of self-purification that Russian culture must undergo.
The tendency toward avant-gardism in our sociopolitical history is both
underlined and crossed out.... Conceptualism is the gloomy but gay funeral
procession of all the ideas that tormented the soul of the people for
centuries, with their mania for power, unity, victory, and obligatory happiness
.  But as it sends false faith down to defeat, conceptualism declines to
utter its own.  Without making any assertions about God, it acknowledges
deviation from him."


Epstein's essay is perhaps already "dated" in its reflections on 80s &
early 90s Russian poetry.  But it seems clear that he is presenting
a more historically and otherwise-specific definition of "avant-garde"
than we have been throwing around.  & for us "scandal" would take on
another meaning in a culture in which art is very much in fashion, trendy,
and the power to shock is "played out" in order to show there is no longer
any such power (over & over), no scandal (unless the scandal of "failure").
The anti-aesthetic was co-opted here long ago, it seems.  Or maybe just
echoed over megaphones.
- Henry Gould

Subject:      Re: the misery of poetry
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

The only Thai poets I know who use computers work in academia and most
budgets do not provide for email.  The only one I know with email works for
a large marketing firm.  Most poetry here is handwritten and sung, not read.
One of Thailand's finest poets is known as one of its finest painters; his
written work is sealed in the darkness of the frames.  I know because I ran
Chiang Rai's one and only gallery: Ahimsa (fallen victim, unfortunately, to
the disintegration of the Thai economy); for three years I hung these poems
facing the wall so that the paintings would sing.

this is to let you know that the CybpherAnthology of Discontiguous
Literatures project is in the process of being updated; an index has
now been added that includes Potepoetzine 1 thru 3 and Potepoettext
1 thru 5, edited by Peter Ganick.

these include work by: Andrew Levy, Dan Raphael, Nick Piombino, Shiela
E. Murphy, Ron Silliman, Clemente Padin, David Bromige, Cydney Chadwick,
Andrew Mossin, Kim Dawn, Loss Pequeno Glazier, Douglas Barbour, Nico
Vassilakis, Bob Harrison... among others.  if these names sound familiar
(but the work behind 'em is not), you're invited to stop by:

     http://www.ims.csuohio.edu/va/VAIntro.html

you are also all invited to contribute to the critical conversation
that the project is aimed at instigating.  see the intro for more info,
or contact me direct.

asever
luigi, etc.

Date:         Thu, 14 Aug 1997 04:13:46 -0700

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         David Bromige <dcmb@METRO.NET>
Subject:      avant garde (chax)/to swear a mighty oath
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I wouldnt want anyone judging my poetry who hadnt ever speculated about the
similarities among drag, draw, drawl, crawl and trawl. There needs to be an
exam these persons must take & pass before they can judge poetry. You dont
get to be a judge at a musical recital w/o knowing about chords keys
modulation pace pitch or at least playing scales. But people think (?)
because language "comes right out of them" thats all it takes to know
poetry. But they dont think an ability to recognize a fart qualifies them
to judge music. Just because i can differentiate (with difficulty, I admit)
among singles, fives, tens and twenties, doesnt make me a financial
adviser. Its hard enough to find a jury of one's peers (due to the
balkanization of american poetry) : a jury of the frost-bitten or the
sandburged is intolerable. How has this been allowed to come about? Its
like, the less you know, the less prejudiced you will be. I think _I_
should administer the Pentagon black budget.  AAggghh.


Likewise, how can persons less sensitive to the ramifications of a word,
have the right to make you swear to be loyal to the state? They cant hear
the nuances, present & potential, of those words. To them it means
something between love your mother & dont make waves. Or put your head in
this trap. They dont hear the history singing in it, they dont see the
stupidity lying in wait within it. Noone should draw up a loyalty oath who
hasnt written essays on the words loyalty and oath, and those essays
awarded A's by a panel of linguists, poets & political scientists of all
stripes. When the pretense of equality reigns, stupidity is enthroned.
Stupid people have a right to live, thats what civilization must mean, but
the tonedeaf shouldnt be sitting in judgement on child prodigies. Existence
makes the law an ass. Noone should be allowed to flush a toilet who hasnt
cleaned an outhouse. Who hasnt gone a day without water in the desert. Who
hasnt dug a well all morning long, until the drops of dew disappear from
the desert rose and reappear on his forehead. Noone should be permitted to
judge a poetry contest who fails to diagram that last sentence. Who is
custodiating the custodians? Who has to clean up after the janitors? I have
nothing against the demotic--just give me a break. Cut me sone slack, here.
How did everything get turned ass-backwards? Why are these drooling
nonentities ruling our minds? And when are we going to send the marines to
switzerland and reclaim the savings & loan money that belongs to you & me
--$20 grand per person? Dont get me started.  David
=========================================================================

From:         henry gould <AP201070@BROWNVM.BROWN.EDU>
Subject:      Re: avant-garde
In-Reply-To:  Message of Wed, 13 Aug 1997 15:02:15 EDT from
              <AP201070@BROWNVM.BROWN.EDU>

let me revise my previous statements. in our society the power to shock
is both still around AND co-opted.  Witness the attacks on arts organizations
around the country by fundamentalist groups.  In a sense these political
organizations "co-opt" scandal by incorporating it into political power
strategies of name-calling & scapegoating.  At the other extreme,
corporations co-opt scandal (or sexuality) & use it to sell products.

let me repeat, in my lexicon avant-garde = handmade.  I view art as
manual labor, blue-collar work, also cottage industry, self-employment.
Necessarily local though not necessarily parochial (in fact ultimately
cosmopolitan in a rooted sense).

homemade space is space made home.  this is dangerous talk for
blind corporations, parasite institutions & old boy's clubs.
Imagine community empowerment reining in corporate power.
Oral history poetry theater.  "Bring back New Bedford fishing."
Hey, there goes Maximus...
- Henry Gould

Date:         Fri, 8 Aug 1997 13:46:58 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Steve Evans <Steven_Evans@BROWN.EDU>
Subject:      Impercipient Lecture Series
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Two more installments of the monthly Impercipient Lecture Series (ILS) have
appeared since our initial announcement to the List in June.

Aldon L. Nielsen's "No Saints in Three Acts: On Stephen Jonas," should begin
appearing in mailboxes today.  Nielsen is among the first to give Jonas's work
the careful attention it both deserves and, in light of its fractured political
commitments, demands.  Great archival finds, including a powerful description
of the Baraka/Jonas correspondence, combined with Nielsen's signature ability
to practice a utopic form of close reading that models the desegregated mind
while acknowledging the still-segregated social body, makes this a must read.

Beth Anderson's "Imperturbable Things: On Still-Life Poetics" is a wonderfully
original meditation on the deceptive stillness at the heart of the
linguistic storm
in the work of Wallace Stevens, Barbara Guest, Marjorie Welish, Keith Waldrop,
Ann Lauterbach, and others.  Despite our canny release of this pamphlet in
June,
just as the blockbuster shown on Still Life got underway at New York's Museum
of Modern Art, a handful (literally) of copies are still available.

We've also recently done a small reprint of our inaugural issue, "The Dynamics
of Literary Change" by co-editor Steve Evans.  A fair number of our issue on
Bob Perelman's _The Marginalization of Poetry_ remain in supply.

The two back-issues that are unfortunately out of print at this time are:
1.2     Radical Dogberry and Society Sketches by Chris Stroffolino
1.3     The Ground is the Only Figure by Rosmarie Waldrop

Finally, to all the List-members who have shown support for the ILS through
contributions verbal and financial: Thank You!

Steve Evans & Jennifer Moxley
61 E. Manning Street
Providence RI 02906-4008

this horse has probably been well beaten here but i'll add my bit anyway.
i think the phenomena is similiar to that seen with respect to liberal
(discussed
on this list earlier this year).  They both have become so entangled in the
popular
press that they have been turned into pejorative mudslinging terms that have
little
relation to the original sense of the terms.  In turn, their adherents become
more so ('liberal'->radical or 'avant-gardeish') and the spiral continues.
am i making sense?
is there a term for this cultural phenomenon?

moved to post this from a sunny rural spot with the kids back in school in
rural TN
after hearing last night of the reaffirmation of the KKK here and knowing i
will soon hear from my pre-adolescents "You can't make me, you old liberal
avant-garde _____, you."
tom bell

At 08:50 AM 8/13/97 -0400, Mark Prejsnar wrote:
>>
>> A couple of points, however. There is a tendency to think of academy as
>> institution (correct) and avant garde as... anarchy/utopia/individualism/?
>> Just a tendency, mind you. And this leads you to formulate a picture of
>> unestablished avantgardists pointing envy (or whatever) at established
>> avantgardists because of their position *in the academy* -- i.e. in another
>> institution.
>>
>> No this is intra-institutional politics. The avantgarde (non-mainstream
>> poetry, cosa nostra -- call it what you want) is an institution, and
>> position in it is critical to and at stake for all those committed to the
>> institution.
>>
>Tom--
>This is interesting, vis-a-vis several of my previous points; first off,
>it reiterates that interesting spatial image of "avant-garde" as a
>relatively static zone, rather than an advancing attack...Thus showing
>again how most of us have toned-down the original feel of "avant-garde"...
>
>But more peculiar and fascinating is the claim that "a-g" is an
>institution...I think it is probably more a series of fragmentary zones of
>activity...
>
>In other words, it's important to be clear whether we're talking about a
>sociological phenomenon, an identifiable social grouping we can study (as
>in your post) or a series of esthetic engagements and projects.  In the
>former sense, both "workshop poetry" and non-mainstream writing are of
>course institutional matrices, with magazines, imprints, sources of
>funding; there is of course a huge disparity in available resources, and
>one is closer to the basic economic life of things, can provide more jobs,
>etc.--is linked as it were to *other* institutions, that provide a support
>structure.  But in the latter sense of these terms, neither a workshop
>poet nor an "experimental" (hate that word) poet, is necessarily absorbed
>by an "institution."  I've known (indeed know) practitioners of both
>approaches, who for various reasons are marginal to or outside the
>institutional frameworks--whether APR/university or Sun and
>Moon/Naropa--and in this sense, there is not a single
>economicosociological network, that automatically encompasses everything
>written in a given style or tendency.
>
>Also, the emphasis on "envy" etc. is interesting (like the original
>phrasing of this thread in terms of "policing")...Some of the most
>remarkable writers I know seem to have very little concern with shoving
>and scuffling for position; their concern with the activity and the work,
>and relative lack of concern with rewards and ego, can be quite
>striking...
>
>mark p.
>atlanta
>
>

Date:         Thu, 14 Aug 1997 11:19:11 +0000
Reply-To:     layne@sonic.net
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Layne Russell <layne@SONIC.NET>
Organization: Socopoets & Russian River Writers Guild
Subject:      poem
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

This poem is written in 7 stanzas of 3 lines each.  Email will show it
with wrapped lines because the lines are long.  Please imagine the lines
in their full extension.  Thanks!

Layne
-----------------------------------------------***


Sushila's shawl


dear Sushila your shawl how you gave it to me how I wore it
December in Bombay December in south India how you wrapped me
in the spring peach shawl a cotton so fine falling like water in the sun

how we met by the temple of Hanuman and you gave me saris white and blue
the handsewn white petticoat your white laughter and dark eyes
your stories of the great one in a village of south India

in the hanging gardens by the Arabian Sea how you told me secrets
whispers on a wood bench splashes on dark rocks
full Indian moon falling like water down warm slopes of Bombay night

how I listened to every word to every pause to the light in your hands
and eyes
to the movement of the shawl the movement of my breathing and yours
the movement of the water below and our feet on the stones

how I still have the shawl oh how I still have it how I took it to south
India
laid it out on the hill above the village that night after seeing the
great one
how I sat under the moon slept there woke in deep Christmas night

how no one understood the shawl the hill the moon or my going
but you did Sushila back in the city you took me in and your father gave
me his bed
his place on the screened porch above Bombay streets with the shining
black birds

how I stayed with you till it was time to go how I fit it all into my
pack
the saris the petticoat the books the little buddha the stories the moon
and the shawl
falling like water in the sun Sushila like water in the spring peach sun



© August 1997 llrussell

From:         Alan Jen Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      Re: dangerous virus
In-Reply-To:  <v01540b01630b648cf4a7@[205.138.228.205]>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Again, the story is this. You can't get a virus from email. You can get a
virus from downloading things like the freeaol, but you shouldn't do that.
If you get a Word Perfect or Word document, you might have macros embedded
in it that can cause problems.

Ordinary email has no problems at all. At one point, there were things
called ASCII-bombs, or email-bombs, but those holes have been filled years
ago.

You can send out an email message with escape codes that can change the
color of the type, and even create invisible type. If someone sends you a
message with an invisible type commmand, you might find your inbox
appearing oddly empty. But there's no damage at all when this happens; the
mail's still there and readable.

And that is about it. By the way, there's a minor sub-sub-field called I
believe steganography which is all about embedding secret texts in .gif or
.jpg files.

Alan

Date:         Thu, 14 Aug 1997 23:01:24 -0500

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         KENT JOHNSON <kjohnson@STUDENT.HIGHLAND.CC.IL.US>
Organization: Highland Community College
Subject:      dead oath
In-Reply-To:  <33EFFF39.24FA@frontiernet.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

On 12 August, Pete Landers wrote, referring back to the loyalty
thread and in reference to me:
> Isn't this the same clear thinker who says taking an oath to defend the
> Constitution means turning in my colleagues if they speak out against a
> gov't that suspends the Constitution?

Well, I never did "say" such a thing, but hurrah for Weiss and
Bromige on this issue. And not to beat a dead oath, but I do feel
there's something more worth saying here: No Constitutional scholar
me, but Article I, Section 9 of the Constitution states that in
cases of "rebellion," where the "public safety may require it," that
the writ of habeas corpus may be suspended (which would
effectively amount, of course, to cancelling any guarantees of
freedom of speech, press, association, etc. that the Constitution
enshrines). Thus we have a paradox, which Pete, so far as I can tell,
doesn't quite see, because he is adamant about only reading "the
words" of his oath "as they are" and not thinking about the
implications of those words in differing contexts.
  In other words, suspension of the Constitutional liberties that
Pete rightly holds so dear need not be Constitutionally construed
under certain extraordinary circumstances (a Civil War, for example,
or a "rebellious" challenge to the rule of capital) as at all
"unconstitutional." Thus, loyalty oaths that call on one to pledge
allegiance to the Constitution against domestic and other enemies do
not *necessarily* mean that one is pledging unqualified allegiance to
freedom of speech and of the press. "These may need to be," the
Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff says to USA Today in
2027, "sacrificed under Constitutional law for an expedient time in
order to save the future of the Constitution."  Sort of like the
dictatorship of the proletariat, when you think about it, to ensure
the future of the greatest democracy of all, communism.
  Anyway, this is the unacknowledged potential contradiction I was
trying to point out to Pete with my revolutionary fantasy post,
written in a fit of syndicalist rapture and breathlessly, with not a
single comma. Maybe it was the lack of punctuation that angered Pete
so much and prompted him to start calling me a whatchamacallit. But I
asked the questions I asked because there were assumptions in Pete's
first reply to Charles Alexander that I found self-satisfied and
simplistic.
  Pete accuses me of illogic for asking what I asked; but I was
actually trying to point out (in my own idiosyncratic way) that
ideology sometimes reveals itself as most insidious inside the plain
words that seem most logical. That's an old one, but none of us can
remind ourselves of it too often.
Kent

Hello all,

Given the recent request for more poems, I thought it would only be
fitting to make my first post to the list a poem.


When she is gone, I say with certainty:
the sky has never cupped the sullen clouds
that never sighed as stars and moon would crowd
into the wild seclusion of her back;
the earth goes round the sun, all cats are black,
dark houses slump their shoulders under snow,
all shutters closed, the only birds are crows.
When she returns, Copernicus is wrong;
the warm loops of her walk move crows to song,
the rooflines straighten, cats dress themselves in white,
sheer curtains breeze on open-windowed nights,
as she lies here, and mumbles dreams to me.


Joseph Tate
Graduate Student
Department of English
University of Washington, Seattle

Just to add briefly--people have been interested in DJ Renegade, a/k/a
Joel Dias-Porter--

Working with Kenny Carroll, he was one of the pioneering members of DC's
WritersCorps program, the only arts-related program of Americorps, which
put teachers of creative writing into DC schools, St. Elizabeth's, several
homeless shelters, and other places in need of "what is found there." DJ
helped put together an anthology of writings from the kids in the schools
where he taught. By all accounts, he enjoyed the hell out of it and so did
the kids.

I always thought Renegade would be an interesting person to design a font
for--something Bodoni-ish to start with, with the extreme stroke-weight
contrast, tall and a bit skinny (per the original), but with a rather '70s
roundness to the serifs and just enough trendy edge fragmentation to have
that urban look.

Gwyn

From:         henry gould <AP201070@BROWNVM.BROWN.EDU>
Subject:      Re: dead oath
In-Reply-To:  Message of Thu, 14 Aug 1997 23:01:24 -0500 from
              <kjohnson@STUDENT.HIGHLAND.CC.IL.US>

On Thu, 14 Aug 1997 23:01:24 -0500 KENT JOHNSON said:
>  Pete accuses me of illogic for asking what I asked; but I was
>actually trying to point out (in my own idiosyncratic way) that
>ideology sometimes reveals itself as most insidious inside the plain
>words that seem most logical. That's an old one, but none of us can
>remind ourselves of it too often.

Mikhail Epstein has an interesting chapter in AFTER THE FUTURE on the
structure of ideological logic, or ideo-logic as he calls it.  It's
basically a win-win kind of power speech which Machiavellian-like
(& Orwell-like) plays off extreme positions against each other and
equates opposites, i.e.:

freedom - slavery
discipline - anarchy

Soviet communism would support socialist freedom over capitalist slavery but
proclaim socialist discipline against multi-party anarchy.  This is one of
the most basic "tetrads" which makes the Party master of the ideological
language field.  (Epstein, following many others, defines ideological
language as words which are inherently value-laden used without explanation
or proof [my own paraphrase here]).  The tetrads get much more subtle
and complicated.

I think the point Pete was emphasizing is that when faced by such a coercive
thing as an oath, we still have a choice.  It seems to me (based on my own
reaction & on several initial responses to Charles' first message) that
our FIRST reaction is, this is a case of repressive government intrusion.
What I found "astonishing" about Pete's response is that he opened up another
dimension to this situation - that is, we might actually support the
Constitution to the point of signing an oath to that effect. This does
not really occur to us when we take individual liberties for granted and
regard ALL government as an intrusion on the latter.  This attitude,
paradoxically, is just as much a prelude to tyranny as mindless
loyalty.  Pete's suggestion that we read what we're asked to sign onto
is a reminder that we are part of "da system", whatever form it takes,
& we bear some responsibility for the form it does take.
- Henry Gould

                             Reuters New Media

     _________________________________________________________________

   Thursday August 14 4:12 AM EDT

Poet Ruffles Feathers In Scotland With Record, MTV Deals

   By Jill Serjeant

   EDINBURGH, Aug 14 (Reuter) - With his long dark curly hair and frock
   coats, he looks like Britain's 19th century romantic poet Lord Byron.

   But that's about as far as the comparison goes for 28-year-old Murray
   Lachlan Young, a previously unpublished bard whose snappy verses about
   sex, drugs, and rock and roll are set to make him a millionaire.

   Young, an American-born Scot with a flair for the melodramatic, has
   taken the elitist world of poetry by storm by winning a $1.6 million
   deal with EMI Records and a $395,000 contract with MTV.

   The deals are unheard of in the world of British literature, where
   poets are still thought of as living in garrets, scraping a living
   from a lonely trade conjuring up pictures in the mind.

   Young, however, is one of the new breed of "performance poets," who
   declaims his contemporary verse to the sounds of a solo cello, seaside
   music or rock groups.

   EMI says it has never signed a poet before, but hopes Young's album
   "Vice and Verse" will sell about one million copies.

   "Taking on a new young artist is always a risk but we think he is a
   brilliant poet, a brilliant performer and very, very funny," said Tony
   Harlow, EMI marketing director.

   "He's three-dimensional. We could have sold him as a performer, as a
   stand-up comic or as a poet," Harlow said.

   Young's subject matter is perfectly attuned to the 1990s. One verse is
   about the Rolling Stones, another titled "Casual Sex," and in "Simply
   Everyone's Taking Cocaine" he satirises high society drugs culture.

   "Well I saw Aunt Milly in last season's clothes,

   She said car, house and yacht had gone straight up her nose.....

   Simply everyone's taking cocaine."

   He anounces his "MTV collection" of short verses aimed at the youth
   market as "no longer than 30 seconds, with no big words."

   APPEARANCE AT EDINBURGH FRINGE

   Staged to dramatic lighting and sound effects from a cello, Young is
   going down well with audiences at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe before
   he embarks on a series of "performance tours" in Britain and the
   United States.

   Fellow poets and some critics have not been so kind.

   The Financial Times called his work "puerile." Guardian newspaper
   critic Dan Glaister said his poetry failed to challenge the mind.

   "It is comforting, reaffirming stuff but there are no broader truths
   lurking beneath the whimsy," wrote Glaister.

   Established poets are skeptical, if not jealous, of the hype that has
   propelled Young to the front pages of newspapers and magazines.

   "For a new poet to land deals like this is unheard of. Much of it may
   be to do with marketing and hype and my instinct is to disapprove of
   the whole thing," said Peter Thorpe editor of the Poetry Review.

   Young, in performance as passionate and brooding as any
   self-respecting romantic poet should be, rejects the notion that he is
   all hype.

   "I'm trying to get an audience for poetry," he said. "Too often people
   who write poetry seem like they are divulging some terrible secret or
   slipping you something when you are depressed.

   "If you can show people interesting poems performed in a dynamic way
   then they might move on to Blake," Young said.

   But he is keenly aware of the pitfalls ahead of him. In a satirical
   poem written a year ago about another of Britain's much talked about
   artists -- Damien Hirst of dead sheep in glass boxes fame -- Young may
   unwittingly have written his own epitaph.

   "Whatever you do, whatever you are,

   Make sure that you never, never, never believe in your own PR."

a virus in an email message is a persistant myth. *Not* possible. Please
lets not discuss here what's been debunked and blah-ed to death worldwide
for half a decade.

It is a sticky one, tho. I got an email message this spring from Harry
Mathews warning me that email with the subject "Good News" contained a
virus. That exact suggestion has come to me repeatedly over 3-4 years, like
a chain letter through my brain matter. I guess the repetition is the virus.

Tom

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

was the "original feel of 'avant garde'" that of an "advancing attack" as
Mark P. seems to be saying?

I *think* that militarily the avant garde would rather be scouts, or even
spies, rather than any kind of attack. Scouts checking out undiscovered
territory or spies sent into an alien camp.

More appealing ideas than that of being cannon fodder. Or, as I so often
hear in the high tech industries, "a pioneer is a guy (sic. -- usually)
with an arrow in his back."

Tom

Subject:      dead oath drugs

I just received an e-mail from Eliot Weinberger, and he tells me
that during the Reagan days NEA recipients had to sign two oaths:
allegiance not to produce pornography or insult any (any) religion
and then also a separate promise not to take any drugs. Anybody out
there asked to sign one of these? I've never even applied for an NEA,
but if the above is the case, it makes the Constitutional
loyalty oath we've been talking about look pretty innocuous!
Weinbeger says *everyone* except two or three poets he knows who got a
grant in those eight years signed?

I don't know, if I'd gotten one of these, I may have well signed on
myself, hypocrite that I am, but holy cow, all of a sudden Pete
Landers looks like Bakunin.
Kent

As I said, macro viruses are possible with Word Perfect and Word
documents; they don't come through standard ascii email. An attachment is
binary, 8-bit, not what's called lower ascii, 7 bit.

Alan

Subject:      asteroid to hit earth

In my post referring to Eliot Weinberger's statement that only "two
or three poets" had refused to sign the terrible NEA pledge during
the Reagan years: I apparently got it wrong. The two or three people
who refused to sign during these years (the texts of the gov't
pledges are contained in EW's _Outside Stories_, pages 124-25) were
not poets but artists of other kinds. According to Weinberger, _all_
poets signed.

Now doesn't that make you feel like standing up and saluting the
flag?
Kent

Date:         Sat, 16 Aug 1997 00:32:35 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Rachel Levitsky <levitsk@IBM.NET>
Subject:      Re: a revision
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

In the spirit of James Finnegan's desire to have poets show their
process, here's a revision of an earlier piece I posted.  I got a lot of
help on this from Ike Kim.

Sounding Board

        for Alan

it is a good life though not
necessary.  now one hand smells
and one does not.  they have
been placed strategically

to peruse the meaning of
various holes.  no matter how many
you start out with the body
lays flat in its possible juices.  the ones
we eat are not necessarily the ones
we asked for--

there is no way to know.
it is too wet
        to get to the museum
but not to wet
        to go to the museum

it affects your consciousness,  act nasty
or get behind something you care nothing about.
later, you’ll laugh about it
on that uncomfortable futon
the best you can afford.

the problem with the bad half&half was
it made the coffee bad.  the same
can be said for sex.  certain combinations
are disaster for the consumer.
every member of the Happy Clubhouse
would tell you this,
but so far few have asked and
no one who’d do anything about it.

        *Helping them to help themselves.*

like I said, this began with a confusion
between money and memory.   indeed,
if you could hand me either,
I can assure you
it will be emptied though
righteousness is tenuous.
false memory, The GapÔ,
I can’t help stealing from big things
when they are costly.  bargain basements
hook me every time.

How long did you let it sit out?
How long must it be left out?
and if there is unrelenting rain, the possibilities.
in a flash flood you will lose things.

*Most victims didn’t buy flood insurance*
*No me quitas pas*

or as you were saying about the snow.
the amount of weight
the branch permits the leaves
to bear before it breaks.

there is much you can figure out
so take it upon yourself
to prevent certain events,
those labeled disaster.  logically,
what will happen to the previous losses
as they shift position
to the back of the general’s head.

as had happened through the epidemic.
we no longer considered them.  in the name of,
floods, borders, balanced books.

*I don’t want to argue about it.*

things are again shifted and look,
what we call your responsibility.
the Israelis are serious but
have redesigned the protocol.
his shirt burned off by the last blast,
he sits and waits, looking plainly bitter.
notice the watch, the numbers tattooed.
victimhood looks again, a face that aims
not for glamour yet is.   reconfigured, made so.
Ruptured protocol reemerges as successful,
as color, from black and white.

*There’s a Movement Underground*

photojournalism = journalism made history.
made hippies.  some mornings
I think I’m a happy person.
some words get printed. she’s a journalist
who also writes novels.

I can’t get past the game of it.
I ride in your back seat
[thinking][meditating][labeling][identifying][looking][like]
I’m staring out your window,
innocent, inocencia.  glamour. love or lose?
drunk with it he finally got silent,
then again, he was always silent.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
notes:

“Most Victims”--From an AP heading, May 13, 1997
“No Me Quitas--Nina Simone
“I don’t”--Me with the grocery clerk
“There’s a Movement”-- Prescriptions makeup adline, from Fall 94,
blitzkrieged onto the New York subway ad space, seen by me upon
returning from a year in Mexico, after having left New York in 1993 upon
the dissolution of AIDS and Queer Activism.
-end-
