From:         Alan Jen Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      Julacan split, for my lover and for Rachel L.
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

________________________________________________________________________


Julacan


Hullo M. Jacques Lacan. Hullo Julacan. Hunh. Je/w suis un bon-bon. Tres
bien. Ich bien la plume du votre tanta. Mercy much.

(Get out.

M. Lacan what is it you say you do. What is it you say you do it to.

(Get out. Get out.

"Where does the difference between someone who is psychotic and someone
who isn't come from? It comes from the fact that for the psychotic a love
relation that abolishes him as subject is possible insofar as it allows a
radical heterogeneity of the Other. But this love is also a dead love."

A. A. A. a. a. Julucan.can can U. Tu est un arbre, n'est pas? Je suis UNE
ensemble, homm/e-o-nym. La verite c'est toutes-jours, laMoor. Mais we:

Tu dites-mois: [ ... ] "The thing, if it no longer takes place with a be-
autiful woman or with a lady, is accomplished in a darkened cinema with an
image on the screen."

(Get out. Get out. Get out.

Encore! Encore! Gentle/hum: "The psychotic" Julacan paws/es: Quel espace
ist diese? Lentement! Lentement! Und so wieder: "can only apprehend the
Other in the relation with the signifier, he lingers over a mere shell, an
envelope, a shadow, the form of speech. The pscyhotic's Eros is located
where speech is absent. It is there he finds his supreme love."

The Eunuch's Shell, bash, cash, carry, korn, vraiment, une programme, non?
Nein, kein nombres, hombres. 2-carry on. A. Julacan chases her tale, prof-
fers id. Toucan. Nu? M. Lacan insists, CUm closer. Feminin ecriture, none
sufficient. Il n'est pas une lettre, il dites-moi pourquoi, pas parole.

U.

M. Lacan sits down, sa pantaloons sur la Grund. M. Lacan! Was ist dies? I
Julacan't be-leave you here licked thus! Aqua! Aqua! Mere und mere, id
seas across les corps. Circulations of "le game skin." Les panties wet.

(Get out. Get away from here. Get out of here. Get out.

Julacan s'defendre herselbst. Langue Langue Tongue Les Mots. Elle cherche
as above, so below. Les circulations dans l'imaginaire, l'uncannee! Je
t'aim in your vicinity! Michelet, Ma Belle, telephone petite moi!

A. A. A. a. a. a.

"Psychotics love their delusion like they love themselves. Having said
this, Freud, who hadn't yet written his article on narcissism, added that
the entire mystery lies here. This is true. What is the relationship be-
tween the subject and the signifier that is distinctive of the very phen-
omena of psychosis? How come the subject falls entirely into this proble-
matic?"

Julacan asks How come la sujet? Does la sujet come? Le game skin, toward
that silence de l'autre, autrui, now, ici, easy.

(Get out. Get out of here. Get out of here now. Get away from here.  Get
out of here. Get out. Get out of here. I'll meet you in Providence. I'll
meet you in Seattle. I'll travel to Seoul. I'll travel to Moscow.

(I'll see your eyes. I'll kiss your eyes. Language is an enemy. Language
is an enemy. Get out. Get out of here. I'll see your face. I'll kiss your
face.

(Don't speak, Julacan. Silence for M. Lacan.

(Get away from M. Lacan. I'll meet you in a bar in Soho. I'll meet you in
a Montreal cafe. I'll meet you in Victoria. You see my eyes in Vancouver.
You see my eyes in Toronto. Language is an enemy. My body in Cape Breton,
my heart in Newfoundland.

U. A. A. a. a. a.

(Julacan's a fraud. Julacan told me so. I'm Julacan. I turn away from the
_word._ I kill the _word._ Language is a _word._ Language is an enemy.

I get into the ocean. I get out of the sea.

"The big S whose medium is speech, analysis warns us, is not what a vain
people thinks it is. There is the real person who is before you and who
takes up space - there is this in the presence of human beings, they take
up space, at a pinch you can get ten of you into your office, but not a
hundred and fifty - there is she whom you see, who manifestly captivates
you and is capable of making you jump up and hug her - an ill-considered
act of the imaginary order, terrific act of the real! And then there is
the Other whom we were talking about, who is the subject also, but not the
reflection of what you see in front of you, and not simply what takes
place insofar as you see yourself seeing yourself." [Altered from the ori-
ginal.]

Je t'aime.


----------------------


(Quotes from Lacan's Seminar III, The Psychoses, edited Jacques-Alain
Miller, translated Russell Grigg.)

Everything that allows men to become rooted, through
values or sentiments, in _one_ time, in _one_ history, in
_one_ language, is the principle of alienation which
constitutes man as privileged in so far as he is what he is,
[...] imprisoning him in contentment with his own reality
and encouraging him to offer it as an example or impose
it as a conquering assertion. -- Maurice Blanchot

At 07:42 PM 8/15/97 -0500, you wrote:
>I just wanted to say that I put in a little post last night and it
>didn't go through. It was in response to Charles Alexander's
>stunning image of George Bowering encased in light. I said in that
>post that this was one of the most beautiful images I had ever
>laid eyes upon, whatever that means. I just wanted for the record to
>say this again. And also to say to George that I actually played
>minor league ball too, though it was football--semi-pro, about $100
>per game back in the early 80's for the Waukesha Hawks. Does that
>count?
>Kent


thanks, Kent

George and I continue to talk, and light probably plays a role in such
transmissions. Encased in light took on a new dimension last night, when I
went to an astronomer's birthday party at 8000-foot Mount Hopkins in the
Santa Rita chain, home of the Fred Whipple Observatory. This astronomer,
Dimitar Sassarov, is a pioneer theoretician -- one of the things he is
working on, and what brought him here, was the effect of microlensing, seen
once before and now again (and earlier predicted by him) that, when earth
and nearer star and far far distant star are in proper alignment, one can
see through the nearer star, and it will have a microscopic effect, making
the far far distant star appear large, allowing us to learn more about it
than we ever thought possible. Last night we used it and looked at a star
in the middle of the galaxy. Turned out that my family and Dimitar's
spouse, Sheila, were the only people at the birthday party and at the
telescopes.

What I didn't know until last night, as we also talked a bit of
linguistics, was that Dimitar is the nephew of structuralist and writer
Svetan Todorov. Language/poetics/astronomy/poets encased in light -- all
seems like a small world. We felt very priveleged last night.

charles

nt
is only so good as the software doing the downloading and mine for one is=

had not announced itself beyond the listing

i sorted out someone the other day who had a virus - outraged because the=
y

ut

misplaced confidence in a fallible system

everything going on is visible from your screen

it doesnt matter how the hell you got the virus when you have got it

the risks are small but they are there - it is possible the message i
onforwarded was a hoax... but the statement that you cannot get a virus
from email does not go far enough

and logging off is not any kind of response

Passion


Pas'i'n o'er thro'n gre't darts as Cup'd's bod'
Turn'd thos' skies' gyres' eag'l'ts lo'p'n in li' sod,
'Tis what's ta'en me awa', tor' us apart, th' rod,
H'nd's sa'l'rd ship's sa'l bor' acros' th' mo'n'n cod,
T' one's, t'oth'r's m' bod' crawl'd doun 'nt' your' lot
Ther's nought's but's glist'n'n skin, taut, stru'g'd & forg't
Now gon' th' dar' & bl'min' roses' de'ftl' whe' the' li'
Fro' world's a' seepin' ou' th' bl'min' bedr'm's door -
Fo' al's th' space's los' mo'th's, pas'ion's c'min' bi'
Tha' face's clos' t' min', tha' I oft beg'd fo' mor'.
Y't co'n cro' th' sig'f'r's r'n o' t'r'r dou'
Gy'd ag'st th' wir'd ai' sa h'p m' G'd I drou'.

Subject:      two solutions (& other anecdotage)
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

Chuck Shepherd's WEIRDNUZ.491 (News of the Weird, July 4, 1997) --
his latest weekly email dispatch of the popular true-story column --
includes this:

> * In December, a man from southern England named Nigel paid
> about $128,000 at a London auction for the personalized license
> plate "N1 GEL."  Eighty other plates brought in about $2.7 million.
> A month before that in London, the much less wealthy Dave Parker
> spent about $40 to have a plate matching his name:  He paid a filing
> fee to change his name legally to [Mr.] C 539 FUG, which is his
> current license plate.

This astonishing pairing of info-bits gives pause.  What is this
craze for unity of self & license plate?  Does the license plate lend
reality to the else drifting soul?  What's the deal here?

The same issue of News of the Weird also includes this:

> * The Globe and Mail (Toronto, Ontario) reported in February that
> local physician Ron Charach, who is the author of a volume of poems
> by Canadian doctors, recently had one of his works selected to be
> published in the prestigious British medical journal, The Lancet.
> The title of the poem is the same as the last two words in this
> passage:  "In silence after heavy rain / you can hear prostates
> growing."

who'd think that The Lancet would (finally) go postmod?

And a 3rd item from same:

> * In a brief interview published in Fortune magazine in February,
> Todd Sloane, a marketing executive with Publishers Clearing House
> (the $10 million sweepstakes people) was asked whether entrants
> worry that the PCH prize patrol can't find them if they win: "We get
> thousands of calls from entrants warning us their house is hard to
> get to [or] they'll be at Uncle Jack's, whatever."

(Strangely, it didn't occur to me to send such a helpful chit to the
Yale Series of Younger Poets) --

Finally, truly weird news:

> * In April, Sir Roger Penrose, a British math professor who has
> worked with Stephen Hawking on such topics as relativity, black
> holes, and whether time has a beginning, filed a copyright-
> infringement lawsuit against the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, which
> Penrose said copied a pattern he created (a pattern demonstrating
> that "a nonrepeating pattern could exist in nature") for its Kleenex
> quilted toilet paper.  Penrose said he doesn't like litigation but,
> "When it comes to the population of Great Britain being invited by a
> multinational to wipe their bottoms on what appears to be the work
> of a Knight of the Realm, then a last stand must be taken."

(& perhaps Pollock shd. have sued drip-prone housepainters . . . ?)

cheers,
d.i.

p.s., f.y.i. --

> newspaper column distributed by Universal Press Syndicate.
> Individuals may have the columns mailed to them electronically, free
> of charge, approximately three weeks after the cover date, which is
> the date when most subscribing newspapers will publish the column.
> Send a message to notw-request@nine.org with the Subject line of
> Subscribe.  To read these News of the Weird newspaper columns from
> the past six months, go to http://www.nine.org/notw/notw.html (That
> site contains no graphics, no photos, no video clips, no audio.

Dear List,
        Bernadette Mayer loves assignments and it would be no problem for
her to "write to specification"- in fact she thrives from rising to other
people's lists of Experiments - I just hope someone keeps track of all the
poems she writes for money.  I think it'll also be good for her writing
"recovery"- she'll take it seriously and produce all the more poems.
         And isn't writing poems what many poets would like to be paid for
rather than scrubbing floors or teaching comp?  Yeah, I know, who pays the
piper calls the tune but Bernadette will subvert with a vitriolic pen
swathed in sexy dailiness anyday any attempt at unwelcome directional
content.
        She's a great writer of  occasional verse, raising the form to new
heights.  I highly recommend her if you have any special occasions coming
up- for as one Experiments from the (expanded) list of experiments reads:

  "Write occasional poems for weddings, for rivers, for birthdays, for
other poets' beauty, for movie stars maybe, for the anniversaries of all
kinds of loving meetings, for births, for moments of knowledge, for
deaths."

and that's only one of her long list!

        The last one says:

"Please add to this list."

so if you give her "specifications" it's like throwing Brer Rabbit in the
briarpatch.

        Maybe the poems should be posted on the net held up for all to
scrutinize if they are in any way compromised by filthy lucre.  ('Only
fooling' as Bernadette would say.)  But not about the posting part.

Love,

Lee Ann

PS: You can give me assignments too.

I want to thank everyone from the Poetics list that took part in our
discussion on Web del Sol tonight. I apologize to those who may have
wanted to get on but could not. We had no idea how many the chat room
would hold. To clear up some loose ends; the book which I referenced
("increasingly ambitious dialogue with modernism") in response to the
question about John Ashbery was Charles Altieri's Self and Sensibility
in Contemporary American Poetry. Douglas Hofstadter is critical of John
Cage's music on at least two occasions in Goedel, Escher, Bach. Finally,
I do not want to leave anybody with the impression that I consider
Robert Peters' criticism astute. I find it eratic and superficial. Again
thanks.---Carlo Parcelli

Particle and Wave


Julu says wave and particle, particle and wave, don't force me to choose,
  she says. Stay here, what am I. :-)
Jennifer says, wave, most likely and definitely wave, undulating with tiny
  hysteresis across the packets, bits and bytes, the tiniest slopes you
  might imagine. Play-acting the particle, datagram, packet, hard-edged
  letter, but definitely wave. Electric-Julu, Julu-Electra, wave and wave.
J says, yes, well, both of
J says, us, but I
J says, you're interrupting, just as
J says, yes, but I thought :-(
J says, you usually do, not thinking very well, are you now?
J says, but I thought, no
J says, well, go on, go on, nothing will satisfy you. :-)
J says, think, I would be particle, would leave
J adds, would leave, turn over in bed, not the signifier, get rid of the
  quotes, show my body off :-)
J says, and learn to see, I suppose, all those retinal cells firing in
  terrific clumps! :-)
J says, learn to see, what it means for a body to turn around, new vistas
  in every direction. Loving the body as well, not Julu-Electra, maybe
  Julu-Antigone, the gone thing in the dust. :-(  :-)
J says, Particle-Julu, Particle-Jennifer, there's always a chance we'll
  disappear, bodies don't last forever, they age, disease :-o  :-)
J interrupts, they interrupt the world - of the world, they interrupt it.
J says, we're going particle, gone from wave. We're gonna be there with
  our eyes open, weight of the body. We're gonna get out of letter-fetter.
  Our punctuation will be our mouths. Our sex will be our arms and legs
  and minds. We'll pull our dresses up. We'll smell each other. :-o  :-)
J says, the smell will be strong, it will be silent. We'll mark each other
  with our teeth, our nails. We'll be on the street, everyone will know.
J says, everyone will know, we won't have to say a word. :-)  :-)
J says, we'll hate words, turn our ears on them. We'll have ears, too.
  We'll listen to the sounds of our bellies, I'll listen to your heart's
  loud beating, you'll taste my tongue in your mouth, my tongue lightly
  against your eyes, against the small of your back, ever more lightly
  along your clitoris, your labia. :-o  :-o  :-)  :-)
J says, we'll have other views, exposures, every turn a new landscape of
  intimacy, worlds in the slightest gesture. :-)
J says, remember, it's only a matter of time, remember, we have all the
  time in the world. :-(  :-)
J says, until we're bodies, always a reminder, and then, breathing ...
J and J, wave and particle, particle and wave :-|
J and J, wave and particle, particle and wave :-)
They're silent, poised, dreaming, waiting, suspended, quiet, waiting
They're silent, poised, dreaming, waiting, suspended, quiet, waiting
They're silent, poised, dreaming, waiting, suspended, quiet, waiting
:-(  :-|  :-o  :-o  :-)  :-)  :-)

Subject:      Re: two solutions (& other anecdotage)

David Israel quoted the News of the Weird:

> * In April, Sir Roger Penrose, a British math professor who has
> worked with Stephen Hawking on such topics as relativity, black
> holes, and whether time has a beginning, filed a copyright-
> infringement lawsuit against the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, which
> Penrose said copied a pattern he created (a pattern demonstrating
> that "a nonrepeating pattern could exist in nature") for its Kleenex
> quilted toilet paper.  Penrose said he doesn't like litigation but,
> "When it comes to the population of Great Britain being invited by a
> multinational to wipe their bottoms on what appears to be the work
> of a Knight of the Realm, then a last stand must be taken."

Good as it is, this last bit appears to have been the utterance of
Penrose's lawyer, not Penrose himself, according to other news
stories.

I am sorry to report that this toilet paper is not sold in the United
States.  I would be interested in talking with anyone who's going to
the UK soon and has large amounts of free space in their luggage.

John

foo'ball game, but they would have gone to baseball games, as for instance
the Venice Hawks vs. the Trieste Red Sox.

natural, it is not at all obvious just glancing at a Penrose tiling that it
is deeply strange.

tiling toilet paper, wallhanging, etc. --- Penrose tilings have been
written up in places like Discover, Scientific American, etc.

From:         Joseph Zitt <jzitt@HUMANSYSTEMS.COM>
Organization: HumanSystems
Subject:      John Cage Event September 5th in Maryland
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

JOHN CAGE CELEBRATION TO BE HELD IN MARYLAND SEPTEMBER 5TH

"AtlantiCage Ninety-seven^85: A Birthday Circus for John Cage" will be
presented on September 5th, 1997 at 8 PM at the Tawes Fine Arts
building on the campus of the University of Maryland at College Park.
The event is free and open to the public.

The celebration, organized by members of "Silence: The John Cage
Internet Mailing List", will include performances and reading of
works by Cage, as well as performances inspired by his work and life.
In keeping with his principles of peaceful anarchism, the event will
include simultaneous performances of different works, as well as
related visual and sound events. It is presented as part of the
worldwide "Freedom Summer" series in conjunction with the Pauline
Oliveros Foundation.

The event will begin on the brick stage on the north side of Tawes
Theater (to the left of the theatre as you face it) with a Tuning
Meditation, followed by a listening walk through the area, arriving at
Room 2102 of the Tawes Fine Arts Building where the rest of the events
will occur.

Bring yourself and an open ear. If you'd like to contribute to the
reception afterwards, food donations are appreciated.


Contacts: Matthew Ross Davis <mozart@butterfly.net>
          Tom Bickley        <tbickley@artswire.org>
          Joseph Zitt        <jzitt@humansystems.com>
          Silence: The John Cage Internet Mailing List:
                     http://www.realtime.net/~jzitt/Cage

Directions:

Maps:
     For the official map, see the University web page at
http://www.inform.umd.edu/CampusInfo/About_UMCP/Maps/ and click on
the Southwest Quadrant.
    For alternate directions, see
http://www.inform.umd.edu/CVS/.CVS/gettingtocampus.html


By Car:
     The University of Maryland sits right in the corner of the
intersection of 193 (University Blvd.) and Adelphi Rd.
     From either direction on 495, take the College Park exit
(Rt. 1 south) and head south on Rt. 1 through several traffic lights.
After a few miles, you will see signs for 193 west, which will be a
right exit down a ramp. Take this exit, continue west through one
traffic light. The next traffic light will be Campus Drive, on which
you will turn left and enter the campus. Stay to your right, going
through the traffic circle and keeping to your right. You will go
between the construction for the Maryland Center for the Performing
Arts on your right, and a huge parking garage (behind which is the
stadium) on your left. Soon, you'll reach a second traffic circle,
through which you pass, still staying to the right and going straight.
A soccer field will be on your right, and the next stop sign you get
to, turn left.
     The large parking lot that is now to your right is Lot 1,
and Tawes Theatre looks west across it. Park in Lot 1 (it's open to
visitors without a permit after 4 PM on weekdays), and walk
towards the theatre, and you should see us gathering out on a brick
stage in a small courtyard next to the theatre entrance. The main
building entrance is actually on the opposite side of the building,
and the room for the performance (2102) is on the second floor.

By Public Transportation:
     The College Park Metro is not really within walking distance of
Tawes; there are shuttles that run from the station to campus, or
you can take a cab. Tawes is at least a mile or two from the
Metro station.

Reply-To:     alphavil@ix.netcom.com
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         "R. Gancie" <alphavil@IX.NETCOM.COM>
Organization: Alphaville
Subject:      mediocrity
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Karen M. Sorry you missed the discussion. It was posted on the Poetics
sight; but it was also posted on 300 other poetry, literature,
philosophy and philosophy of science sites. We opened with a discussion
of the post-Lowell confessional school with a focus on the critical
works of Charles Altieri. However, Joe Brennan participated in the
discussion and we eventually moved into a scrap about L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E
poetry. As I tried to move the discussion toward the dominance of the
scientific paradigm, we wound up talking about the phenomenonology of
Husserl and Natorp, Wittgenstein, the Vienna Circle and the Frankfurt
School---among other things. At one point, half the chat was on Freud
and Lacan and the other half on the potential of modernist poetics to
critique the scientific-technological paradigm. I still have a headache.
Needless to say such a discussion in the chat format is hard to
economize. We plan to do it again and hope to have our mechanics down
better next time.---Carlo Parcelli

 >if you would, could you

Interesting choice of word, Rachel. Now, while we are speaking of levels,
we have to speak of higher and lower, dont we? When you say "bring it to a
level", do you mean raise it to a higher level, by any chance? Now, in the
study of language usage, that is called "begging the question," i.e. in
this case pretending that we agree that a disagreement about the value of
football is necessarily on a lower level than something that can be
"enjoyed" by others. Unless you meant, which I doubt, that you wanted
something at a lower level....

ATTENTION POETS/ACTIVISTS!!

Rachel Levitsky and Matt Meighan (2 subscribers) are currently
organizing the 1997/98 Literary Segment of the Left Hand Reading Series
in Boulder, Colorado.

There are still some slots unfilled for the readings January through
April, 1998.  Because we cannot pay poets (though can bring them the
attention of a sizable audience, and a well-promoted event) we are
dependent on the poet's proximity to us.  If you or a poet you know
lives in the area, or will be in the Denver/Boulder area during that
time and would like to read please contact us:

Rachel Levitsky -- Levitsk@ibm.net
Matt Meighan -- mmeighan@rmii.com

Also, writers who are interested in being featured reader can send work
to:     Rachel Levitsky
        LHRS
        P.O. 1771
        Boulder, CO  80306-1771


MORE READING SERIES INFORMATION
        The Reading Series is a program of the Left Hand Book
Collective, an all volunteer run radical left bookstore.
        The series was begun last year and was a huge success.  Writers
Rikki Ducornet, Dennis Brutus, Akilah Oliver, Andrew Schelling, Carolyn
Wright, Ward Churchill, Bunky Echo Hawk, Max Regan, Shira Segal, Geri
Lynn Baumblatt, Sarah Skaggs, Stephanie Williams and others read to
enthusiastic audiences.
        Each reading features an open segment and two featured readers,
one emerging writer and one established writer.  We are committed to
promoting work that might otherwise be marginalized, and make a special
effort to reach out to young writers, writers of color, writers of
diverse economic and social backgrounds and to writers of daring and
innovative forms.  We see no separation between art and politics.

The Left Hand Book Collective is
located in downtown Boulder at:

1825 Pearl Street
Boulder, CO  80302
Phone--(303) 443-8252

Date:         Tue, 19 Aug 1997 19:33:04 -0400

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Alan Jen Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      now you'll hate me
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

now you'll hate me but I'm on a trip, now in Pittsburg on the way to
everywhere, so, well, this came out, ahem, definitely the work, ah, of
a beginner, someone reading, whom, maybe even Blackburn played a role
here, certain not the language poets, Rachel got me to read some Jane
Miller standing up in a bookstore, well, I did that on my own, but now
going through Lacan who's not much help here either, so now you'll hate
me because this is just too weird because just too too ordinary

______________________________________________________________________


Plural Dark Angels of the Night


You came to me like plural dark angels of the night.
I was about to compose a brilliant text on the density of my language.
I began thinking of your brilliant arrival a month ago, like plural
   dark angels of the night.
My language dissolved like sloppy seconds at my feet (I'm not gonna
   have no feet).
I wanted to reply about this, the nature of language and brilliant feet.
I wanted to write about languages interspersed, interpenetrated in this
   machine, languages and information everywhere, like plural dark angels
   of the brilliant sloppy night.
I thought of our arms like grapple-hooks around each other.
Language clattered like a bowl of boiling coffee spilled on my feet.
I thought of our teeth against brilliant skin confused with passion like
   plural dark angels of the night.
There was something else I wanted to write; I thought of your brilliant
   eyes.
I wanted to write about your eyes; I thought of your brilliant mouth, your
   limbs.
I thought about the feet of the plural dark angels of the night.
I thought, I thought.
I thought, brilliant, you know where this is going so I'm not gonna write
   no more.


__________________________________________________________________________

(Something along these lines went out to the list two days ago, but my
reply function seems to only work about half the time. I have my
pride, so i'm typing it again, leaving out some of the potentially
volatile language from the original. Kent)

George:
You think you flame me. But the invitation to the pre-season camp
from Edmonton was many years ago, and the fact is I just don't give a
damn about Canadian football, since it is such a sorry state of
affairs. You Canadians are pretty pathetic: You still haven't
really rid yourselves of the Queen, and then like cowbirds you take
up football and then baseball, and then all of a sudden you think you
can tell true past players of these games what the score is. Eskimos
or Argonauts, who gives a shit? They are both really stupid names
anyway, almost as stupid as "Maple Leafs," which is a really silly
name. I meant to say Eskimos and I said Argonauts. So what George? I
was cut after a couple weeks, but this was only because of the
receiver coach who felt I was too light to play tight end and too
heavy to play wide-out. He was a CAnadian, boring and affable on the
outside, scheming and manipulative on the inside. So what sport do
you play, George? Curling? Don't mess with me.
Kent

Rachel:
I don't know you, but after reading your post, no one, but no one
who cares about sports could ever want to punch you, whether you're
taht kind of gal, as you say, or not. Oh Munson's name being
whispered to you by a kid on Mt. Sinai, you going down toward the
river, with the scent of the olive tree in your hair, Rachel, Munson
barely visible against the olive a little bit up the hill, lashed to
it, six or seven arrows in his side, staring ecstatically out at the
world. It's so beautiful, that none of those who see can believe
it. And then out of nowhere comes George Bowering, rolling
downhill in a circle, going faster and faster, like a bagel.
Kent

Date:         Wed, 20 Aug 1997 17:36:03 BST
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Ira Lightman <I.Lightman@UEA.AC.UK>
Subject:      Elegy for Conlon Nancarrow
Comments: To: I.Lightman@cpca2.uea.ac.uk
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII

A word of mourning from me:

I was just thinking of Nancarrow the week before he
died, drawing inspiration from his piece - is it "x" or
"zeugma"? - where the "left hand" of the player piano starts
playing very slowly, ascending and speeding up and the
"right hand" plays ludicrously quickly, descending and
slowing down. They meet in the middle and cross and finish
at their far extremes. It is a piece of such simple audacity
that it delights anyone I know, pop or classical or
whatever their musical tastes. I was writing a libretto
for a piece by MIke Higgins - the score of Bach's first
Prelude from the Well Tempered Clavier played upside down,
hence "I edulerp" (Prelude I) as the title and I
used a poem of two-word lines with the ultimate
line read first, then the first, then the penultimate,
then the second, and so on, crossing in the middle.
The columns should work separately and together. The theme
was a Gaia of Gaia's: just as all life and the planet
may be one organism, so may all its history also make
a gaia. It seems to strike by fluke a note of eternity,
the fields Beckett describes in Stirrings Still, which
honour life and see some hope in death, so I'll offer it in
memory of Nancarrow:


I EDULERP




        beyond

one great

        hand in

great great

        hand one's

great great

        grand great

great grand

        last long

one's hand

        first this

in hand

        grass of

one first

        straw this

one last

        garden

one past

        garden

one come to pass

        garden

this time

        meta

is grass

        garden

and vine

        hand and

out lasts

        garden

this straw

        time less

and wine

        time in

this time

        garden

is time

        wine one

in hand

        straw as

one grand

        last one

in grand

        first is

gaia's

        time less

gaia

        time now

is time

        wine is

less time

        vine the

meta

        eternity

time met

        eternity's

a time

        right in

one great

        right the

great great

        hand in

great great

        hand time's

great grand

        grand great

time's hand

        great great

in hand

        great great

the right

        great one

in right

        time a

eternity's

        met time

eternity

        meta

the vine

        time less

is wine

        time is

now time

        gaia

less time

        gaia's

is first

        grand in

one last

        grand one

as straw

        hand in

one wine

        time is

garden

        time this

in time

        wine and

less time

        straw this

garden

        lasts out

and hand

        vine and

garden

        grass is

meta

        time this

garden

        pass to come one

garden

        past one

garden

        last one

this straw

        first one

of grass

        hand in

this first

        hand one's

long last

        grand great

great grand

        great great

one's hand

        great great

in hand

        great the

beyond




On Tue, 12 Aug 1997 07:28:47 -0800 Herb Levy wrote:

> From: Herb Levy <herb@ESKIMO.COM>
> Date: Tue, 12 Aug 1997 07:28:47 -0800
> Subject: Conlon Nancarrow
> To: POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU
>
> I just returned home from the east coast to find a message
on my answering
> machine from Trimpin saying that Conlon Nancarrow died
over the weekend in
> Mexico City.  Nancarrow would have been 85 in October.
>
> The American expatriate composer was best known for his
series of studies
> for player piano, composed and hand-punched on a custom
machine, the medium
> in which he worked valmost exclusively for much of the
last fifty years.
> These works were really wonderful extensions of the sound
world of the
> piano timbrally altered by extremes of tempo, tempo
ratios, and unusual
> canonic structures.  His few works for live performers
(either early works
> composed before Nancarrow began focusing on player piano
or quite recent
> pieces commissioned by performers & ensembles like Ursula
Oppens & Arditti
> Quartet) have been more rarely heard.
>
> All but the three most recently completed of Nancarrow's
Studies for Player
> Piano are recorded on Wergo, his other works have been
recorded by Arditti
> Quartet, Ursula Oppens, Continuum, Joanna MacGregor, and
others. In 1995,
> Cambridge University Press published a book length study
of his work by
> Kyle Gann.
>
>
> Herb Levy
> herb@eskimo.com

From:         AERIALEDGE@AOL.COM
Subject:      Re: paul auster/ davidson/debord
Comments: To: tmorange@julian.uwo.ca

Exact Change has just published Auster's _Translations_ ($16.95) including
Tomb for Anatole, as well as Joubert, Andre Dubouchet, & Philippe Petit. I
believe Anatole was originally published by North Point. Also, if you don't
know it Auster's anthology _The Random House Book of Twentieth Century French
Poetry_ is well worth getting, I believe it's still in print.

While we're talking just published Michael Davidson's U. Cal. tome _Ghostlier
Demarcations: Modern Poetry and the Material World_ ($35) is just out.
Discusses Stein, Oppen, Howe, Pound, Olson, Zukofsky, Rukeyser, Reznikoff,
Duncan, &&&.

Also new & excitin': _Guy Debord -- Revolutionary: A Critical Biography_
($14.95) by Len Bracken. It's not that critical (of Debord) but neither am I.
Way recommended.

All of these will be on next Bridge Street list but ya'll kin order'm now if
ya needta.

--Rod

PREFACE TO A CASE OF AD INFINITUM

The peasants are revolting                              The pious
Bleating of       Feckless roup                       Leaping into
   The heaping                  Bargain
        Who is not              On so holy              A sooth feast
                                                    A victory call
Was a clarinet              A question of legions
The market will bear
The lumbering
Yer slit don't shrink           It is almost

                                   Bleeding     But malakin
                                                   Inly epoch


--      Patrick Durgin      --

Date:         Wed, 20 Aug 1997 11:53:47 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Red Slider <TheFarm@NS.NET>
Subject:      Yes, but what does it do?
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

As this fellow once said to me, "The hell with the pansies, what can you =
do with it?"

Well, my 'test market' reports to me that he's had a 40% boost in sales =
(for the one or two cynics in this group, I don't doubt that he drives a =
Mercedes, long ago paid his mortgage and has his sere threads done by =
the comely seamstress with the magical fingers - not that she'd ever =
given me the nod, but then I only brought in my pants cuffs to be taken =
up) - nevertheless, its nice to be published by the world.

The following work and its companion are released by the author, Red =
Slider, to the Public Domain and all rights hereby relinquished. It is =
the author's desire that persons who should encounter a street-poet, =
down on their luck, should give them a copy and let them know they may =
use it as they see fit.=20

(var. 1)

If he comes,
no matter how -
as victim, as perpetrator,
with misfortune and woe
or con and rube,
with a shill for an eye,
he's a bum, if he comes
that way; and you may
still offer to do the thing,
to offer him some=20
if he comes that way=20

but if he should
hold out a poem,
no matter the verse,
poor or magnificent
doggerel or worse,
he's a working man -
a hard-working man.
Give him his due,
pay him his wage,
a fair wage
for a hard-working man.

(var. 2)

If she comes,
no matter how -
as victim, as perpetrator,
with misfortune and woe
or con and rube,
with a shill for an eye,
she's a bum, if she comes
that way; and you may
still offer to do the thing,
to offer her some=20
if she comes that way=20

but if she should
hold out a poem,
no matter the verse,
poor or magnificent
doggerel or worse,
she's a workin' woman -
a hard-workin' woman.
Give her what's due,
pay her the wage,
a fair wage
for a hard-workin' woman.


Put in the Public Domain
August 19, 1997
by Red Slider.
no rights reserved.

David Bromige now turns to favored forms of expressing umbrage
(or disinterest at least) -- saying to Kent Johnson,

<< Btw, when you wrote that you didnt give a damn abt canadian things, I was really hoping the text was going to say "rats ass." "I dont give a rats ass about canadian things." Am i the only listling who prefers "rats ass" to "damn"? >>

I won't personally weigh in in favor of rat's ass; somehow (notwithstanding the agreeable hint of the archaic), the presumed appeal of this locution eludes me at present.

What other forms of not-caring -- what rhetoric of i-cd-care-less -- are prevalent, rare, favored, or even of-the-moment?

I've somewhat admired
   >  I don't give a flying fuck . . .  <

(though will not admit to having used the expression much meself).

One feels certain that this redoubtable roster must have up its collective sleeves many more (& better) alternatives, neh?

d.i.

ass rats prefer David to flame I damn old
David prefers I to old damn flames rats ass
to old David flames prefer I damn rats ass
to old I David rats damn ass prefer flames
David, old flame, I prefer rats ass to damn

Date:         Wed, 20 Aug 1997 19:17:15 -0500
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         KENT JOHNSON <KJOHNSON@STUDENT.HIGHLAND.CC.IL.US>
Organization: Highland Community College
Subject:      oh canada

Whoa. Is it me? Am I actually the one missing double entendres in the
last posts, letting me know, ever so subtly, that every one is
kosher and just playing back with moi? Well, I have to admit, listers,
that I am more confused than
I even normally am. George and David (the Canadians) and even a few
Americans (among the very few Americans on this list) seem to have
taken me awrongs. In fact, this is very interesting, and I'd like to
propose it is worth at least a new and separate thread (tho I doubt
it would come to that). Is
it possible, really, that such intelligent people could have thought
that my football post to George was seriously meant? That I actually
thought he was trying to "flame" me with his previous post? I have to
say, this seems very similar to Sokal all over again, even though I
never intended it that way. I sincerely thought that the silliness
would be obvious. I mean I've never even (and I swear here) been to
Canada. (although my past in football is more or less real--I was
actually captain of the UW/LaCrosse freshman football team, then
broke my hand and went to UW/Milwaukee to play soccer. My substitute
at tight end on the football team in '74 went on three years later to
become NAIA All-American, a tid-bit that remains one of the proudest
accomplishments of my life to this day.)

Anyway, I just wanted to make this clear, and to apologize to George
and David for insulting their motherland. I was just kidding. In
fact, I have to say, it's fascinating that when I told David Bromige
some days back that I had had an encounter of the third kind that he
thought I was kidding when in truth I was absolutely serious, and
then when I told George that I was a better football player than he
he thought I meant it when I was thoroughly kidding. This email
business is slippery. Who can keep
track? I'm reminded of my teacher Samu Sunim, who stared at me once
like he was a tiger about to bite my entrails out and said: "Bring me
the thoughts in these words, and put them in my hand." There's
something there relevant to to this medium, but I'm not sure what.

I will now stop posting prose and stick to poems where there is
never any problem with what anybody says. I'm serious George, you
Canuck.
Kent

preference for rats ass. Thats nice. I remember the Alexander piano--shaky,

David I., I _knew_ you were going to "say" "flying fuck" before my eye
reached it, I swear. Long a favorite of mine, though its vehemence undoes
its indifference. Other phrases to indicate indifference? I used to like
the ungrammatical "I could care less." (Cant even be bothered to add the
"n't"). "Frankly, my dear, I dont give a damn." Sexist pig. "Good goddam"
is a pleasure to say. "Two hoots" sounds archaic--back to a time when owls
flew this earth. "A tinker's cuss" has a pleasingly ethnic tint. Any
others?

friends like Dave, who needs enemas" has been copyrighted in British

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Red Slider <TheFarm@NS.NET>
Subject:      I'm feeling better now - so i'll drop a poem
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

two brushes


two brushes
one wide
one narrow

brushes brushed
on a painted sky
the wide brush
saturated in blue

the nearby clouds
still freshly swept
with wet paint


     delicate margins
   golden delicious
wet clouds picnic
on blue grass
gay cloth mats
in sere silks
cirrostratus
        undressing
                        the wind

       bare cover
       distant pale blues
       thinning to wash
       the day folding into
       faded picnic cloths
       clouds of leaves, blue grass,
       black velvet waves rolling
       in menacing shapes, night
       thunder shaking the mats
       ants carry off crumbs of moon
       many times their own size
       stars the size of raindrops

raindrops the size of stars.



red slider
August 1997

Date:         Thu, 21 Aug 1997 01:33:47 +0000
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         kim dawn <kdawn@JULIAN.UWO.CA>
Subject:      space(s) of silence
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

on silence(s)

mouth opens. words flow forward.        silence(s)               between
each word,              each breath,            e
a       c       h       l       e       t       t       e       r       .
these silences form a bubble infinitely larger than the spoken.
silences               take             up              space. silences
emerge during the spoken.
when we think of silence(s) we think of mouths, of breath seen in cold air,
of dead phone lines, of discomfort, of too much comfort, of death. writing
is scarred with the death of silences. writing is scarred with death.
writing is scarred with silence. these silences are full. we read between
the lines to find 'truth'. silences are impatient. silences are already
written.
the everlasting silence of suicide notes and love letters.
beside my corpse lies my last words. between the lines          lies my body.

your absence  is filled with your voice your body more than your presence.
the further away you are, the less you speak, the more i hear your silence
around my throat.


on having nothing to write

i have nothing to write.  i have nothing to say. yet, i write:
'i have nothing to write'.
'it' all resides within the space(s) of silence. these silence(s) must be
written.
what is the condition of these spaces of silence?
this is not so much about writing about silence as it is about writing
through/to silence, finally, writing silence.
silence is not empty nor passive. we recognize silence as one of the most
effective tools of communication. to communicate our anger/frustration we
'use' the 'silent treatment' upon the other.
silence(s) are moody.



how to write silence : this is my dilema,

any blanchot fans out there?

oh, and by the way,

h i s s h i r t s m e l l s l i k e h i m s t i l l a n d i w e a r i t u p
o n m y t o n g u e u p o n t h e f a l l o f n i g h t i t r a i n s a n d
a n n e m u r r a y c a n s t i l l p u l l m y h e a r t c h o r d s s p e
c i a l l y s i n c e s h e s f r o m m y w a y o h d e a d l i t t l e s n
o w b i r d i h e l d y o u o n c e

From:         Red Slider <TheFarm@NS.NET>
Subject:      Re: space(s) of silence
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

kim wrote:

how to write silence : this is my dilema,

Kim, neither Rachael's nor Christina's samples seem to solve the problem =
for me. They both have big flashing noisey signfiers - =
END-OF-TEXT***END-OF-TEXT - waving at the ends of their texts. This I =
think we are clever enough (or cynical enough) to quit when it has the =
look&feel of 'END-OF-TEXT'. The trick is known, the audience eats the =
rabbit.

My own samples weren't much more useful. I don't pour much concrete =
poetry so they all were samples of textual, rather than meta-textual, =
silence. Missing term representations, grammatical or semantic =
discontinuities, unfulfilled or unresolved context or heightened =
anticipation. None would satisfy your request for meta-textual =
representation of silence. I did learn the following from considering =
the problem (at least as very tentative hypotheses):

1) the problem of representing 'silence' in text is catagorically =
similar to background/forground problems - a matter of degree, of terms =
in contrast, not in absence.

2) the simple presence of meta-symbols for 'silence' (space, empty =
enclosure, etc.) may serve to intensify subject rather than signify =
silence. The very act of calling attention to noiseless areas may =
immediately fill with all kinds of noise signified by the surrounding =
context - not 'silence' but a container for surplus noise.

3)  'Silence' may be a misnomer - or, at any rate, their may be a =
multiplicity of 'types of silence' so that any attempt to find a =
universal representation for 'silence' qua 'silence' is hopeless. Each =
will only be come as still as its particular context permits and in a =
way which its own formula will depend on that context.

4) It may be that 'Silence' is some kind of counter-effect that we can =
create - in meaning, in meta-graphical representation, in juxtaposition =
in which elements mutually annihilate each other - are 'phased' in such =
a way that each is muted. Whether this can approach 'silence' i don't =
know.=20

in a poem I posted here recently, there are two lines:
                     =20
                           stars the size of raindrops

raindrops the size of stars


both sentences wanted to make there own noisey statments. I find them to =
be considerably muted in this arrangement - and some kind of silence =
leaking into the margins.

I do not think concrete representations (as opposed to textual ones) =
escape this dilemma. Even physical impositions which forces interruption =
in the reader (page-breaks, double page-breaks (though here the =
'silence' of the publisher is quite audible), abrupt sequence reversal =
(say, right-to-left), etc. ) still seem to be referrential, i.e. noisey.
A true 'silence' would be absolutely stunning!

I propose these notions from examining only a very few of my own =
materials and hardly a hard proposal. Like to hear if you find anything =
quiet enough and universal enough to meet your needs.
END






                                                 OF







red

From:         Joe Amato/Kass Fleisher <amato@CHARLIE.CNS.IIT.EDU>
Subject:      Re: what flames, where, huh?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

my father being dead too, i can't supply his meaning exactly... but
whenever he said to me, twinkle in his eye

"joe, you talk like a man with a paper asshole"

i took him to mean that i was full of SHIT...

i might venture some apt readings of this saying in anatomical or
gastrointestinal terms, speculating as to the way a paper asshole might
function vis-a-vis the fleshy variety, but---if you look in the harper/row
_american slang_ dictionary, you'll find the following under "man with a
paper ass":

"n phr black [african-american dialectical] a person whose ideas are not
important; a trivial man; = lightweight"

presumably "ass" here functions synecdochically for the person in question
-- the lightweight -- so i assume asshole, being part of an ass, functions
similarly...

yrs in the nether regions,

joe

And while were in the general neighborhood, perhaps someone can enlighten me on the origin and nuance of the
term 'asshole buddies'. I've a close friend you employs
that expression frequently and I finally got the courage to
ask him to stop because it always left a bad aftertaste. After
seeing just how complex the taxonomy of assignments for
scatalogical kinship terms is, I worry that perhaps I have
hastily disemboweled my friendship, or at least thoughtlessly
evacuated some of its finer mesh.

L'chyme,

red.

From:   Joe Amato/Kass Fleisher[SMTP:amato@CHARLIE.CNS.IIT.EDU]
Sent:   Thursday, August 21, 1997 1:32 PM
To:     POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU
Subject:        Re: what flames, where, huh?

my father being dead too, i can't supply his meaning exactly... but
whenever he said to me, twinkle in his eye

"joe, you talk like a man with a paper asshole"

i took him to mean that i was full of SHIT...

i might venture some apt readings of this saying in anatomical or
gastrointestinal terms, speculating as to the way a paper asshole might
function vis-a-vis the fleshy variety, but---if you look in the harper/row
_american slang_ dictionary, you'll find the following under "man with a
paper ass":

"n phr black [african-american dialectical] a person whose ideas are not
important; a trivial man; = lightweight"

presumably "ass" here functions synecdochically for the person in question
-- the lightweight -- so i assume asshole, being part of an ass, functions
similarly...

yrs in the nether regions,

joe

From:         David Bromige <dcmb@METRO.NET>
Subject:      metragnomics
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

        Metragnamics (far GB)

        i thraw away my metraname
        here in this megapalis
        and set aut far the hippadrame
        with professor thanatapalis

        we're aff to hear the ralling stanes
        thats why i've ditched my tamer
        i want to shake my stiff ald banes
        be a bad-spelling ramer

        yet i'm imitating bawering (gearge)
        wha makes ane tae the lane
        i met him drinking at the ladge
        "Asshale, that glass is mane!"

        He was the mast punctiliuas sad
        but created an impressian
        at ance af being wild and bald
        alangside this repressian

        then aff i went with the prafessar
        wha calls piraeus hame
        far, as i said ta my canfessar
        It's mass _ar_ ralling stane

        But my canfessar (clever fellaw)
        remarked the balances in bawering
        sarcastic macker af bad spellar :
        his scarn far ane is scauring

        yet he'll transgress mast all the barders
        the mast af us acknawledge
        prafessor thanap fallaws arders
        he'll never transcend callege

        with him i knaw just what gaes an
        whereas, with bawering, seldam
        what draws me thus to the canuck ane
        and away fram thanap (sheldan)?

        * * * *

        I'm back--the ralling stanes were ald
        and tired--time has appased them
        at last--& sheldan's campany graws cald
        --I'll retrieve my metraname

        & re-tune the piana
        i'll trust my therapist to knaw
        that each ta must have a fra
        & ta the megalapalis
          with bawering (gearge) i'll ga-ga ga .

FlashPoint Magazine is seeking critical responses to A=R=T M=E=A=N=S, a
critique of L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E poetics applying Freud, Lacan, & Foucault,
by Joe Brennan.  A=R=T M=E=A=N=S can be found in FlashPoint's
on-line issue at:

http:webdelsol.com/FLASHPOINT

Responses will be considered for publication in the Fall issue, which is
scheduled for release in November.  Responses should be submitted by
September 30th to:

FLPOINT@hotmail.com


FlashPoint's first on-line issue includes Stephen Dixon and Raymond
Federman, Ronald Sukenick, Ricardo Cortez Cruz, David Kaufman, Cris
Mazza, with an art/poem by Amiri Baraka.

FlashPoint's first print issue includes Clayton Eshleman, Charles
Bernstein, Jack Foley, Mark Scroggins, Carlo Parcelli, Art Cover, Judy
Brody, with art by Sue Coe and Andrea Zemel.

From:         Laurie Schneider/Crag Hill <orion@PULLMAN.COM>
Subject:      Re: space(s) of silence
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

David Chirot's                s  e  e

comes close to what we can do in text
indicating presence through absence, deletion
embodying even more silence (Can silence be embodied?
Do we want to create such a form to hold the something that is nothing?)
than Eugene Gomringer's poem "silencio" in the Emmett Williams' anthology

yet text and silence are two streams that can never cross
though we can have one hand in each
(Would we feel the waters of silence on our fingers? Now I'm disarranging
my senses.)

I noisily remember Geoff Huth has considered this conundrum
in much of his writing, including columns on "praecisio"
(Bob Grumman should be able to help me remember with the accuracy silence
deserves)

Best, Crag

From:         David Bromige <dcmb@METRO.NET>
Subject:      how to raise funds for yr reading/lecture series
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Last weekend, the "Friends of West County," an ad hoc environmental group
dedicated to preventing an industrial park being built on land the city
council voted to annex (contra various laws of their own making), held our
second yard sale,sat-sun, and raised nearly $4000. In the spring, we raised
over $3000. (This money goes towards the attorney's fees for the court
action we are bringing).

It occurred to me that other groups than environmentalists should know
about this source of funds. All it takes is a site (we used a small parking
lot attached to a building where one of us has a business), people to
donate stuff (& to encourage persons not in the group to donate stuff),
some plywood resting on sawhorses to be tables, and some flyers &
handpainted signs. It takes some time, sure--I'd estimate I spent 3 hours
in planning meetings, an hour signmaking, a couple hours sorting out my own
junk to donate, another hour picking up junk from other people, and five
hours in toto helping man the cashbox.

  So say 12 hours. Out of my busy schedule, etc etc, but well worth it, not
only because it cleared junk out of our garage here, but for the end
result, and also for the camaraderie and community of the event.(I got some
more books, too--O joy![as was it Ren or Stimpy would say?] And some nifty
tapes and record albums...somebody's Nina Simone collection, for
starters--so, junk gets recycled.)

The core of our group is fewer than 20 persons--comparable with a number of
groups or collocations of poetry fans in many centers throughout the
continent. You too could do this and have 3 grand to play with. Enough to
fly in those poets you want to hear but the administrators/fat-cat
professors of your local college/art center/library _don't_ want you to.
And something left over to pay your visiting poet a couple hundred. Ask me
if you want to know more.

David


PS Red Slider? Ren & Stimpy is/was a cartoon on tv i found pretty
disgusting but watched plenty of because at that time my daughter & her
friends were crazy for it. A dog and a cat. Tongues hung way, way out;
eyeballs shot way, way out on stalks; there was vomit, there was crap,
intimidation, bondage, violence, and above all, weird sounds/voices. When
will it go into reruns?!

From:         Bob Grumman <BobGrumman@NUT-N-BUT.NET>
Subject:      Re: space(s) of silence
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

To fill in just a little about what Crag said about Geof Huth, his
fine series of columns on the praecisio ran in Lloyd Dunn's much-missed
magazine *Photostatic* as the eighties ended.  A praecisio is the
absence of some stimulus where expected, to define it very loosely from
a shaky memory of what Geof wrote.  Cage's silences were prototypes of
it--and such things as books titled THE WIT AND WISDOM OF RONALD REAGAN
that contained nothing but blank pages.  Geof got into a good deal more
than this, but I'm too lazy to look it up.

Now that I've been lured into this thread, I might as well say that I
think both Dave Chirot and Kim Dawn succeeded in capturing silence in
their recent pieces.  It seems to me that visual poetry is ideal for
this purpose--and that blank areas of a page, being textless, are
clearly as SILENT as a pause in the oral telling of a story.  That
either a blank area or a pause might cause noisy THOUGHTS is irrelevant
because silence is that which causes a PERCEPTION of soundlessness
regardless of whether it also causes noisy thoughts.  If this weren't
the case, then no kind of silence would be possible, since somewhere
there's going to be someone who's going to think noisy thoughts about
any possible silence.

I think the real question is what silences are EFFECTIVE silences in
poetry.  I like visual poetry's silences; Red Slider, I guess, doesn't.
Here's one of my own attempts at an effective silence in a poem.  I'll
make the blank area short: in the book I have it in, it lasts three
pages:

                            pnd;



















                                               then, at last,
                                             the splash of
                                                something


                                                       --Bob G
=========================================================================

red is writing:

yes indeed. When scuba-diving i find it is the absence of bird sounds that
most impress me with the utter silence around me. In my earlier post I
think that's what I was scratching at - that we're somehow dealing with
contrast-space rather than object-space, which means Bob Grumman's central
question about which portrayals of silence will be effective - create the
precise praeciscios desired - will have multiple solutions - arrangements
of textualized white-space being one (and that there are many types of
textualized white-space, I have no doubt). So what will be useful, will
help at the margin of the process is a description of the tools and what
they seem to be doing in varying circumstances. The idea of types of
'phasing' of mutual elements so that their interplay appears to cancel or
reduce 'noise' is of the most interest to me at the moment.

Ach, what to do?  I see that Douglas Barbour and Maria Damon have
*both* added on a 6th line to the Renga for Nancarrow.  Since it
appears that DB's follows clearly from the 5th (the "its" referring
back, one assumes, to the "thermal etude" of line 5 -- which in turn
presumably may refer back to "the music" of line 3), will Maria
concede line 6 to Prof. B, and accept 7th line as hers?  Maria also
suggests abandoning the numbering & i.d.'ing of lines.  okay w/ me.

Here's now adding an 8th.   (So far, I find this reading fairly in
couplet-fashion -- though other readers might read otherwise.)

Renga for Nancarrow


Ach, I throw away my metranome  It is useless to me

here in this metrapolis

morning late-summer: this cricket knows the music

hairy as thistle and as elevated

thermal etude beside a bamboo cage

its silences appear in careful measure

cambric dozens unswathed enfin

once there was a parade -- the long years roll

Subject:      Origins and Sentiments

Now that the light at the end of the rat's ass seems to be turned off, I
have a phrase that's always puzzled me, 2wit&var:

"You're a real piece of work."

I've generally heard it used in a disapproving mode - with harmonics in the
'piece of shit'  or 'piece of tail' range. But, frankly find the euphonics
rather and strangely pleasant and employ it affectionately when, say, I
might step back from a 'piece' i'm pleased with and remark ().

Then again, it might be the diminutive 'piece of' to which the disapproval
attaches. If I were to be the 'whole pile of shit' (or var. an elephant's,
rather than a rat's, ass, I might not be quite so soiled? Perhaps the
speaker is disappointed merely with the meager portion they've been served?

But I wonder, was there ever a 'real piece of work' to which the phrase
might have referred? Perhaps cleaning the dog kennel or something? Does it
attach to other meanings as well? I've a slight angst that perhaps it's
something burried in the closet of ruminations about my father's adroit
useages and that there's something rootish about the matter - in which case
I suppose this is a thread about gardening and not language.

red

Date:         Sat, 23 Aug 1997 18:33:53 -0700

From:         Brian Carpenter <bricarp@PAUL.SPU.EDU>
Subject:      Re: space(s) of silence
In-Reply-To:  <199708231847.LAA17249@pantano.theriver.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

The most clearly silent place in nature I have experienced is at the top
of one of the many cinder cones in the Craters of the Moon Nat'l Park in
central Idaho. These are essentially enormous cone-like formations of
volcanic rock ranging up to a few hundred feet high. Since the tourist
traffic is very minimal in this park, one can walk to the top of one of
these many cones and find a completely isolated spot looking out across a
wasteland of part lava bed, part brushland. No birds, etc, around. And
when there is no breeze where you are standing there is nothing hear.  But
at this point you begin to hear the sound of the blood pumping through
your ears, a sound that has always been there. This reminds me of the
music of the spheres, which was said to be so familiar to human ears that
it could no longer be perceived.  My thinking is that silence is best
considered as a threshhold one only approaches, for both external
(natural) and internal (bodily) reasons.

BC

Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>

From:         "David R. Israel" <davidi@MAIL.WIZARD.NET>
Subject:      Re: Origins and Sentiments

Red Slider remarks --

> . . . I have a phrase that's always puzzled me, 2wit&var:
>
> "You're a real piece of work."
>
> I've generally heard it used in a disapproving mode - with harmonics
> in the 'piece of shit'  or 'piece of tail' range. . . .
> But I wonder, was there ever a 'real piece of work' to which the
> phrase might have referred? Perhaps cleaning the dog kennel or
> something? . . .

Here's how I understand it:

1. the overt sense is a term of admiration (not disparagement)

2.  something which is "a real piece of work" is, in non-ironical
useage, something which shows great beauty, workmanship, fascination,
is, in a word, remarkable in nature.

3.  As an *ironic* utterance, the sense of the term is, of course,
turned  somewhat on its head.  Thus, "You're a real piece of work"
may denote "you're a wonder! you're quite amazining!", but the ironic
subtext may be along the lines you suggest above.

4.  It seems possible that the expression"you're a piece of shit"
itself derived from the more genteel "you're a real piece of work"
(and not the other way around).

5.  I think part of the beauty & irony of "you're a real piece of
work" involves the notion that the mind of the person so addressed is
felt, by the person saying this utterance (in its original, somewhat
aristocratic context -- surely this is a 19th-century expression from
the upper classes?), -- the mind of the addressee is felt to be
something which, while defying logic or comprehension, is yet a
wonder in itself (poss. all the more so, for the fact of doing so).

6.  Of course, most charming & genteel expressions such as this can
be used in less sparkling manners & contexts, as seems to have been
the case w/ your experience of this locution.

No doubt, someone with access to DARE or some such resource work
detailing vernacular usage, could give a fuller (& more precise)
reading & background for the phrase.  The above is merely my own
overall sense of it (based on what I've heard), for what worth.

d.i.

Date:         Sat, 23 Aug 1997 19:26:10 -0700

"A piece of work," in my experience, is always pejorative, except when the
person so described is seen as a marvel of unnecessary and exasperating
complexity, a rube goldberg contraption that evokes admiration that it can
function at all. OED Supplement supports this understanding, with examples
back to 1928. "Piece of shit" I think is probably unrelated. Then there's
also "piece of ass" or "tail" and "piece of the action," I think also
unrelated.
How about the verbs attached to various actions, to wit: to give (or not) a
shit or a fuck, to take a shit or a piss, or simply to go or to come, as
in: "Why are you fidgeting?" "I have to go. I always have to go after I
come."
A propos of this last, used to be (see Lindner, _The Fifty-Minute Hour_)
that those of the Freudian persuasion thought that a guy leaving the bed to
take a piss after getting a piece of ass, which his skirt might understand
as his not really giving a fuck, was really just a cover for a castration
fantasy--the guy was really checking to make sure that everything was still
there. There are, of course, easier and better physiological explanations.
Hard to believe that those psycho analysts were MD's. They must have been
real pieces of work.

>6.  Of course, most charming & genteel expressions such as this can
>be used in less sparkling manners & contexts, as seems to have been
>the case w/ your experience of this locution.
>
>No doubt, someone with access to DARE or some such resource work
>detailing vernacular usage, could give a fuller (& more precise)
>reading & background for the phrase.  The above is merely my own
>overall sense of it (based on what I've heard), for what worth.
>
>d.i.

From:         joel lewis <penwaves@MINDSPRING.COM>
Subject:      Elio Schneeman
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

sorry to report the death of elio schneeman (b.1961) on 8/17/97 of a drug
overdose. he was the son of george and katie schneeman and was a much loved
figure at the poetry project. His books were "In February, I think" (1978,
C Press) and the 91' volume "Along the Rails" from United Artist> His
funeral was held monday at St. Bridget's Church (the same as in the Frank
O' Hara and Bill Berkson collab -- "Hymns to St. Bridget's") w/ pall barers
including Greg masters, Mitch Highfill, and John Godfrey. Elio's work was
not known that much outside of the Project but is worth looking into. There
is a memorial reading being planned at Naropa in two weeks.

joel lewis

p.s.-- as elio would say: "No, I am not related to carolee schneeman". his
dad, however, is an artist whose work is familair to any reader of
berrigan, raworth. notley and other writers in poproject community as he
illustrated many books.

From:         Alan Jen Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      Language, written on the road
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

__________________________________________________________________________



Language, Porosity, Quotation, Notes On


"Everyone makes jokes about macaroni, because it is a hole with some-
thing around it, or about canons. [sic] The fact that we laugh doesn't
change the situation, however; the fashioning of the signifier and the
introduction of a gap or a hole in the real is identical." (Lacan, VII)

"Lyotard comes close to what I have in mind when he says:

   The ambiguity of writing, object of reading and of sight, is
   present in the initial ambiguity of drawing. An open line, a
   line closed on itself. The letter is an unvarying closed line;
   the line is the open moment of the letter which perhaps closes
   again elsewhere, on the other side. Open the letter, you have
   the image, you have the emblem, the symbol and the letter.
                                (Lyotard, The Lyotard Reader, 48)

"Lyotard's beautiful evocation of the sinuous interweaving of the line
of writing and that of picturing points to a third term, to some con-
ception of the line before it has acquired the cohesion imparted to it
by either of its 'decisions.'" (Michael Carter, Putting a Face on
Things, Studies in Imaginary Materials)

Between macaroni and drawing, language noodles out, appearing in a dia-
lectic between the foreclosing of syntax and sememe, and the porosity of
the struggle towards coherence within any number of communicative chan-
nels, ranging from human speech to the reconstruction of true or false
memories in the brain.

If we look at a computer complete with operating system, we discover a
hierarchy of apparently relatively autonomous languages, beginning with
hardware, and working up to the user interface. These might include
machine language, assembly language, macroassembly languages, compiled
and interpreted languages, scripts, graphic interfaces, and so forth.

We can also consider these languages, top-down, as an extension of human
psychological operations and memory as well.

If we look closer, say, at Perl, we find that it can call up the Unix
shell and shell scripts, that it can call up programs in other lang-
uages, that it can interact in fact with assembly language, that it is
written in another language, and that it may itself be called up by
still another or the same language. We find it can interact with
scripts, programs, or processes, and each of these can call the other up
as well.

In fact, we can define a macro in Perl, a new function or verb, with any
of these languages, etc,, and we can define an object in Perl as well,
with any of them. In fact, one might note that there is above all a syn-
tactical plateau or intermeshing of plateaus that constitutes the posi-
tioning of Perl in relation to the machine, to the Internet, to the
user, and in general, to the porous world within which it is embedded.

We find then, that Perl is not so much at the top of a hierarchy, as it
is embedded in a holarchy, and while it, in a certain sense, might still
appear as an autonomous language, in another sense it is an accumulation
of interwoven well-defined processes that are coherent in relation to
each other and the outer world.

So that one might argue, taking these instantiations back into the
human, that while thought itself is in relation to human spoken
language, that is hardly the long or short of it; in fact, it is dif-
ficult to tell where semiosis begins and ends, and what constitutes a
well-defined verb or noun, in other words a framework. Further, while
difference may be said to be partly constitutive of a domain of sig-
nifiers, one might also argue that it is based on other processes within
the holarchy, and that the holarchy itself is porous in relation to the
real.

And I would argue in addition that there is a continuum (more properly,
perhaps, a stretch of rational fractions) from the real through lang-
uage, from the exhalations of speech through the mouth, and the recep-
tion of facial expressions through the eyes, from and to, in fact, num-
erous modalities - and in the midst of these, syntactical islands or
attractors which operate as-if the linguistic were capable of foreclos-
ure on what then appear to be various plateaus.

One might thing of the world as multiplexing, parallel/parallel proces-
sing, with formalization of the symbolic where necessary, for transmis-
sion, say, from one organism to another. This is not to argue, in addi-
tion in addition, for the computerization of the real, but rather for
the real itself as organism with continuously multiplying, coalescing,
and dissolving processes.

In this manner, the disjunction between thought and non-thought, and
both in conjunction and disjunction with language, become bridged, re-
routed into numerous processes, of which, say, human language and the
rationalizing/suturing discourse of psychoanalysis would be one among
many elements.

--

My own work exists as _debris-work,_ work of the debris, of these troub-
ling and interstitial areas. Thus, even within writing which must tend
towards a certain foreclosure, I present wryting, the fiction of writing
object and person within a text, object and person which leak into
uneasy dreams, fantasies, ghosts, peripheral shadows within the real
itself. Further, I present processes as writing, writing as processes; I
present foreclosure as broken, and a shattering of the vessels as fore-
closure.

--

Languagings extend into cultural sheaves, such as fashion, style, cul-
tural productions. Such sheaves are inherently irreducible; fashion, for
example, is dependent upon the armature of the body, but its specificity
is interwoven with the rest of culture, including issues of capital,
temperament, governance, and so forth. And all of these create an uneasy
fit with spoken language itself, with music, with organized/disorganized
sound of all sorts.

Further, fashion-as-language becomes as problematic as film language,
the languages of art, and so forth. A hat, for example, is simply a
thing that sits on the head (presumably remaining there through the
normal walking, etc. movement of the body). Beyond that, what signifies
and what doesn't is often difficult to discern. The _stream_ of style is
easier described, perhaps, as if there were a generalized semantics at
work. (See Carter, op. cit.) (Note that "what signifies here" is rele-
vant to the postulation of a basic lexeme; semantics, symbolization,
chaotic representational debris, etc., all play a role in constituting
what otherwise might be considered a "language." Instead, I postulate we
are dealing with linguistic part-objects, broken and severed codes,
micro-territories (three or one flowers on the hat; roses or tulips;
forward or backward, etc.). And this leads, as well, into the interplay
of semantics and syntax, even the interplay of what might be considered
a relevant series of signs.)

And further, still, ascii texts on the Internet employ what might be
considered a variety of extra-linguistic cues - on numerous chat lines,
ranging from Powwow to ytalk, it is possible to read the pace of the
other's typing, to the extent that one might speak/write of a written
_parole._ This embedding of language into the other's time reveals the
closeness, pressure, of the body against the keys, an intimacy which is
not as evident in the encapsulated messages sent out all at once, on
MOOs, talkers, IRC, and the like.

(For this reason, as I have pointed out elsewhere, ytalk becomes an in-
timate simulacrum of the body; the "breathing" of the texts between two
participants parallels that of lovers sharing a unified, if discordant,
space.)

Then there are, of course, emoticons, header information, lag, the tim-
ing of mail sent, and those porous extensions of the telephone, snail-
mail, video, etc. all of which serve literally to confuse the issue.
(Which is exactly the point here, that _language,_ _a language,_ is a
situated plateau in the midst of others, that there are always already
issues of governance and porosity from the start, that there is a tend-
ency towards foreclosure, that the porosity may or may not be formal-
ized (for example there are specific commands for shell access from a
Perl script) - that, in fact, one might consider a generalized process
of _worlding_ which includes all and none of these, what may or may not
be interpreted as an abstract process, message of the deepest import, or
signal through an autonomic nervous system, seemingly intent on keeping
the organism alive.)

---

J, Well, it's time for the Law.
J, Well, now, what Law would that be?
J, That would be the Primordial Law. That would be the Law from which
Law has blossomed, the Law which has curtained a mighty culture.
J, Now that would be the Law of Prohibition.
J, Exactly, when negation came into the world, when rejection ordered
the day and night, when suddenly the signifier sputtered from the skin..
J, I get the Idea.
J, Yes, and exactly again.
