Renga for Nancarrow


Ach, I throw away my metranome  It is useless to me

here in this metrapolis

morning late-summer: this cricket knows the music

hairy as thistle and as elevated

thermal etude beside a bamboo cage

its silences appear in careful measure

cambric dozens unswathed enfin

once there was a parade -- the long years roll

Just my season's ticket at the Metradome

<astroturf growing inspooled and drifty


Bob Holman

"Everyone makes jokes about macaroni, because it is a hole with some-
thing around it, or about canons. [sic] The fact that we laugh doesn't
change the situation, however; the fashioning of the signifier and the
introduction of a gap or a hole in the real is identical." (Lacan, VII)


Boy, does this ever make me feel like I'm outside the loop! I don't think I
know anybody who makes jokes about macaroni, not even in France. Maybe I
don't hang out with the right psychoanalysts.

Note, however, that Monsieur Lacan has to explain what's funny about
macaroni, but not what's funny about cannon. Perhaps in his world a cigar
is a cigar but it's never just a cigar.

Subject:      (Fwd) build labor-academic alliance

this just came to me on the Bad Subjects list, & I thought
I'd bring it over in case no one else has. I'm going to try
to get more information, but I'd appreciate anything you
folks (Mark? Joe? anyone?) cld bring forward, too.

Chris


------- Forwarded Message Follows -------

For those interested in building alliances between labor and the academy:


From:     Dan Clawson (clawson@sadri.umass.edu)
To:       anyone interested in labor
Re:       signing a statement, joining a group


     The revival of the American labor movement, and its openness to a
variety of initiatives that would have been inconceivable a few years ago,
is the most promising political initiative of recent years.  A new group
is forming to build links between academics and the labor movement.  John
Sweeney, Linda Chavez Thompson, and the New Voice leadership have
explicitly encouraged this development.  They hope that we can work to
alter the debates taking place in public policy and on the cultural front,
in our teaching and in every public forum, just as they are working to
change realities in trade unions.  Together we can be part of a broader
labor movement that includes both these areas and much more.

     I realize it is ludicrously short notice, but an ad and press
conference are planned announcing the formation of this group.  In order
to get your name on the ad, you need to send your name and affiliation to

tnr1@columbia.edu  (that's a #1, not a letter L)

by Tuesday August 26.  If you don't make that date, you can still join the
group; see the address in the enclosed memo.

     If you'd prefer, you could send your name and affiliation to me, Dan
Clawson, (clawson@sadri.umass.edu) and I will pass it on.

     Together we can build a movement for social change.  You can begin by
passing this message on to everyone you can think of who would want to
sign.

Dan Clawson


Labor Day, 1997

For two decades, Labor Day has been an occasion for eulogies and epitaphs,
as the labor movement suffered deindustrialization, downsizing and defeat.
But Labor Day 1997 arrives with a new militance and a new hope. The
victory of the Teamsters in the two-week UPS strike -- the largest strike
in a generation -- was a victory for all working people, whose incomes and
livelihoods have stagnated for nearly a quarter of a century. The UPS
strike was also a turning point for the labor movement, and could
determine its strength and direction for years to come.

Though the right to organize has eroded in a world of contingent work --
part-time, temporary, outsourced, and subcontracted -- organizing
campaigns across the continent are now rebuilding the labor movement in
old and new workplaces: from Borders bookstores to Las Vegas casinos, from
the strawberry fields of Watsonville to the classrooms of Berkeley and
Yale, from Federal Express to Nike sweatshops.

We take this moment of struggle to announce the formation of a new
independent, national organization: "Scholars, Artists, and Writers for
Social Justice." In the academy and publishing, in the arts, sciences and
entertainment, we also experience the growth of low-wage, part-time
employment which erodes our craft and creativity. We call upon our
colleagues and friends this Labor Day to declare their solidarity with the
organizing drives of the new labor movement. The time is ripe to restore
the mutually empowering relationship that once gave hope and dynamism to
the labor movement and its allies in the academic and cultural
communities.

We envision a movement that can reshape the nation's political culture by
combating inequality and powerlessness, and by fostering the growth of a
vibrant, militant, multicultural working-class movement. In an era
when elite opinion makes a fetish of the free market, unions -- with a
commitment to solidarity, equality, and collective struggle -- remain
fundamental institutions of a democratic society. Our confidence in
launching SAWSJ comes from the success of the "labor teach-in" movement,
inaugurated last fall when more than 2,000 people affirmed a new alliance
of labor and academe at Columbia University. In more than a score of other
teach-ins from coast to coast, students, teachers, writers, artists, and
unionists met, talked, learned, and argued in an atmosphere of hope and
solidarity. SAWSJ hopes to fulfill the promise of those teach-ins.

reminding me to ask y'all if anyone has read or heard anything about
charles nicholl's /somebody else: arthur rimbaud in africa 1880-91/
(london: cape, 1997).

thanks,
t.

Tom: I've just finished the book. It's very good -- Nicholl is extremely
knowledgable on Rimbaud, is a good writer, and has tramped all over
Africa looking for the Ghost of Arthur.

It's a wretched story, of course. There's Arthur, tramping about,
working himself to the bone, scraping and saving, getting ill and
recovering, cursing the natives and the other traders, feverishly making
plans for the future, and all the time we know it's all for nothing --
we can see the cancer coming like a dust-storm on the horizon.
Heartbreaking.
But a very good book.

From:         David Bromige <dcmb@METRO.NET>
Subject:      rimbaud in oz
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

what is little known about rimbaud is that he visited australia with his
young bride, directly from ethiopia by packet steamer. The Rimbauds were
fairly flush at the time, and stayed in what was, for that era in Oz, a
luxury hotel. On their first day, they hired a coach & four to go
drive-about. Unfortunately, one of the first things they saw in the outback
was a man having intercourse with a kangaroo. Rimbaud attempted to distract
his wife from the sordid spectacle by pointing in the opposite direction
and crying, "Look at that, my precious!" They both looked, only to see
another man with another kangaroo. Disgusted, Rimbaud ordered the driver to
head back to the hotel. There, to top the unhappy morning off, they found a
man with a wooden leg masturbating on the hotel steps. Outraged, and with
his notorious temper fully aroused, Rimbaud demanded to see the manager. "I
have come a long way at considerable expense to stay in your hotel, and
what do I and my poor wife find? Two men having intercourse with two
seperate kangaroos, and a man with a wooden leg masturbating on the very
steps of this hotel?!"

The manager's reply has been recorded: "But Monsieur Rimbaud, you dont
expect a man with a wooden leg to catch his own kangaroo?"

The Rimbauds wanted to quit the establishment immediately, but there was
nowhere else to go. They were stuck. Rimbaud had put the manager of the
hotel in a foul mood, and that evening, he ordered all the chess players
who frequented his lounge, to pack up their boards and leave. This they
did, grudgingly, but one Among them remonstrated withg the manager,
demanding to know his reason for such rudeness. This reply, too, has been
recorded: "I cant stand chess nuts boasting in an open foyer."

For these and other anecdotes of Rimbaud in Oz I found the text under
discussion well worth borrowing from my college library.  David

Thanks to everybody who backchanneled -- it's a Cab Calloway word.

     Hincty (adj.) -- conceited, snooty.

and it's related to another word he used --

     Dicty (adj.) -- high-class, nifty, smart.

OK! another mystery sunk --
J

From:         Red Slider <TheFarm@NS.NET>
Subject:      Problem in silence

I've a problem in silence representation. In a dramatic narrative, meant to
be read aloud (perhaps for radio performance as well), I've need for a gap
both thematically and visually to separate the scene of Coleridge's 'rotten
sea' from a new vista of turbulence at the "dragon's edge."

Presently I'm using an ellipsis not entirely to my satisfication.
The fragment I'm working with (backed-up enough to display the
discontinuity is:

The silence in her hold as thick as blood, her only cargo grim
remembrance of the day the brood of flags hung still, breathless
as she pulled against a shudderless heave of rotten death
across watery waste, sighted once before by he who murdered
the albatross. Lost! Lost! as we carry out the heart's knell
hand over hand, each breath a bolide in a birdless sky, and wait...
till the bell-pull sounds on an empty deck and the bitter end slacks
against the kedge, as darkness falls and the gale winds rise
and the great seas shudder at the dragon's edge.

(an in-progress and imperfect version of the entire work can be seen at
http://sacramento-news.com/poets/redpoem.htm)

The problems are:

the break is between a scene, itself typed in silence (the becalmed sea),
and the resumption of contrasting material; and, also serves as a
performance instruction for an indefinite pause by the reader.

The work is antiqued (broken iambic, rhyme - at times dense, 17th c.
nautical terms, etc.), with some deliberate 'moderns' (the ship has
engines/iron-plate, the reader is directly engaged at points, etc.). But
the silence representations I've encountered (say in the (     ) thread)
seem to stark  for the piece, too swedish-modern.  Appreciate any ideas.

red slider

a snippet of a teaser from #9

From "The Waist Line" by Dale Smith (part of section III. The Late
Brunch)


***
A mismosa for the Mrs.
   O the hunger cloaked her
       and with her, her daughter
          begged a soda water


gulp gulp gulp
jug jug jug jug jug
so rudely forc'd.
Burp.

Unreal table
under the brown cloth of cold noon
Mr. Kultur, the suburban merchant
      offered a pocket full of candy
   asked me to luncheon at Michaelangelo's
followed by a drink at the Drake.
At the pancake hour, when the eyes
turn upward from the table, the human belly waits
  like a mob sobbing waiting.
       I Karen carpenter adrift in the after-life
   thin woman, emaciate, can see
the pancake hour, the undefined brunch hour that gives
home to you and brings the cooks to the kitchen.


***(more delicious parody follows)***

Thanks for letting me share this.-- Hoa

From:         Steven Marks <swmar@CONNCOLL.EDU>
Subject:      Re: Problem in silence
In-Reply-To:  <01BCB210.EAC60C80@ppp41.ns.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

On Tue, 26 Aug 1997, Red Slider wrote:

> I've a problem in silence representation. In a dramatic narrative, meant to
> be read aloud (perhaps for radio performance as well), I've need for a gap
> both thematically and visually to separate the scene of Coleridge's 'rotten
> sea' from a new vista of turbulence at the "dragon's edge."
>
> the albatross. Lost! Lost! as we carry out the heart's knell
> hand over hand, each breath a bolide in a birdless sky, and wait...
> till the bell-pull sounds on an empty deck and the bitter end slacks
> and the great seas shudder at the dragon's edge.
>
Here's my suggestion. If you are performing this on a stage, wait four or
five beats after the word, "wait," and then have an on-stage bell begin
ringing, activated by somebody offstage. The audience would see the bell
moving and hear the sounds, but see nobody doing the actual ringing. Now,
I know this isn't silence if by that we mean the lack of sound. But, I
think the tolling of a bell, especially if it seems to be ringing of its
own accord, will create the feeling of emptiness that the lines speak of.

If you are doing this as a radio performance, I'd still suggest the bell
perhaps with fade-ins and -outs. Of course, there's no way that I can
think of to show the bell ringing by itself on the radio.

In both cases, you might also want to experiment with the length of the
ringing, its volume, whether you read the next line over the ringing or
wait a few more beats after the ringing. You might even want to experiment
with how far you can push the audience with the ringing -- monotony being
a type of silence.

for what it's worth,
Steven

   Steven Marks

   http://members.aol.com/swmarks/welcome.html

Date:         Wed, 27 Aug 1997 11:53:01 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         mark weiss <junction@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Avant-garde and border patrols
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Those of you who weren't sure what kind of divisions there are in the
poetry world when the question of an avant-garde came up recently may find
the following interesting.
I just spoke with the editorial office at _Booklist_, the journal of the
American Library Association. I had submitted Rochelle Owens' _New and
Selected Poems_ to them for review. As the excellent review in Publishers'
Weekly had just come out I was curious as to whether _Booklist_ intended to
review it. Like it or not, a good review in _Booklist_ is worth 200-300
sales to libraries. I was informed that their poetry editor had rejected it
because, in the words of an internal memo, it "represents the kind of
poetry that convinces people that poetry is too difficult to read." I think
I offended the guy on the other end of the line when I volunteered that
they should maybe find a less naive poetry editor.
The book came to them with extensive praise from, among others, Karl Young,
Marjorie Perloff and Jerry Rothenberg, but that didn't get it past the
gate-keeper.

I had submitted Rochelle Owens' _New and Selected Poems_ to  [Booklist] for
review.....  I was informed that their poetry editor had rejected it
because, in the words of an internal memo, it "represents the kind of poetry
that convinces people that poetry is too difficult to read." I think I
offended the guy on the other end of the line when I volunteered that they
should maybe find a less naive poetry editor.

From:         Ryan Whyte <rwhyte@FREENET.EDMONTON.AB.CA>
Subject:      Shaky
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Shaky


        skit, representation on representation
        coffee and no lunch makes the same
        shudder Hegel confronts close open
        sign no contradiction in dictum
        yes but no

        this girl named A D alpha absolute
        electric lights riven from herself
        noose in speech fluted
        when on the *phone*
        ok well goodbye ahem
        call next weak but the name

        stutters sky blank shimmer
        over granite.  Not a man
        say B B french or german
        let continue to talk and
        see each other

        In great wind all
        Serra's calculations
        like tree tops
        massage across interval
        wherein the newness
        of the same according

        Andrew Benjamin.
        I like that quote
        in the morning, a propos de
        how nice.  Goodbye
        tomb know not sema
        steel carbon
=========================================================================

(in a small voice from beneath a pile of paperwork)

Does anybody have an opinion about Yusef Komunyakaa and Sascha
Feinstein's "Jazz Poetry Anthology" and "Second Set: Jazz Poetry
Anthology Volume Two" -- I just heard about them from Amazon.com, but
since their goal is to sell you the book, their glowing review isn't
necessarily to be trusted.  Do Komunyakaa and Feinstein cover all the
bases?  Do they include discussions of Jazz poetics?  Is the book filled
with bland beat hymns of praise for great players?  Do tell...

Date:         Thu, 28 Aug 1997 16:06:54 -0800
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Herb Levy <herb@ESKIMO.COM>
Subject:      Re: Jazz Poetry
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I'm more taken with the range of work in Moment's Notice edited by Art
Lange & Nathaniel Mackey.

I've only looked at the Komunyakaa & Feinstein collections in bookstores,
so I don't know them as well, but that also means that looking them over in
bookstores didn't seduce me into buying the books.

Moment's Notice offers a wider range of styles (including both poetry &
prose), whereas the other collections seem (in my memory, at least) to be
more or less limited to Beatnik stylings & personal experience poems.

I'd also recommend looking at Aldon Nielsen's book Black Chant for the last
couple of chapters on jazz & poetry.  Besides covering the jazz/poetry
dynamic/aesthetic pretty well, this book also has a good bibliography &
discography of work relevant to the subject.

Hope this helps,

Herb

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Julie Marie Schmid <jschmid@BLUE.WEEG.UIOWA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: Jazz Poetry
Comments: To: Robert Archambeau <ARCHAMBEAU@LFC.EDU>
In-Reply-To:  <34059A17.5382@LFC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

I've used the Jazz Poetry Anthology in a lyric poetry class I taught here
at the University of Iowa.  I think that both the first volume and the
second set are o.k. . . . A little too traditional for my tastes.  It
containts too much poetry about jazz and jazz artists and too little that
actually utilizes a jazz poetic.

If I had it to do over again I would use the Mackey anthology that is
published by Gray Wolf Press (the name of which escapes me).  From what
I've seen of that, it seems to be much more about formal innovation than
the Feinstein & Komunyakaa text.
=========================================================================

=09=09=09=09Above the world-weary horizons

1. About the Poetics List


The Poetics List was founded in late 1993 with the epigraph above.


There are presently about 500 subscribers.


Please note that this is a private list and information about the list

should not be posted to other lists or directories of lists. The idea=20
is

to keep the list to those with specific rather than general interests,
and

also to keep the scale of the list small and the volume manageable.


The Poetics List, while committed to openness, is moderated. While
individual posts of participants are sent directly to all subscribers, we
continue to work to promote the editorial function of this project. The
definition of that project, while provisional, and while open to
continual redefinition by list participants, is nonetheless aversive to a
generalized discussion of poetry. Rather, our aim is  to support, inform,
and extend those directions in poetry that are committed to innovations,
renovations, and investigations of form and/or/as content, to the
questioning of received forms and styles, and to the creation of the
otherwise unimagined, untried, unexpected, improbable, and impossible. =20


Please keep in mind that all posts go out immediately to all subscribers,
and become part of an on-line archive. *<italic>Posting to Poetics is a
form of publication, not personal communication</italic>.* Participants
are asked to exercise caution before posting messages! While spontaneity
of response may seem the very heart of the list at its best, it also has
the darker side of circulating ideas that have not been well considered
(or considered by another reader -- editor or friend). Given the nature
of the medium, subscribers do well to maintain some skepticism when
reading the list and, where possible, to try to avoid taking what may be
something close to a spontaneous comment made in the heat of exchange as
if it were a revised or edited essay ("Let the Reader Beware!").=20


The "list owner" of Poetics is Charles Bernstein: contact him for
further

information. Joel Kuszai is list manager.  For subscription information
contact us at POETICS@acsu.buffalo.edu.=20



____________________________________________________________________


2. Subscriptions


The list has open subscriptions.  You can subscribe (sub) or

unsubscribe (unsub) by sending a one-line message, with no subject

line, to:


listserv@listserv.acsu.buffalo.edu


the one-line message should say:


unsub poetics


{or}


sub poetics Jill Jillway


(replacing Jill Jillway with your own name; but note: do not use your

name to unsub)


We will be sent a notice of all subscription activity.


*

If you are having difficulty unsubscribing, please note:


Sometimes your e-mail address may be changed slightly by your system

administrator.  If this happens you will not be able to send messages=20
to

Poetics or to unsubscribe, although you will continue to get your
Poetics

mail.  To avoid this, unsub from the old address and resub from the new

address.  If you can no longer do this there is a solution if you use
Eudora

(an e-mail program that is available free at shareware sites): from the
Tools

menu select "Options" and then select set-up for "Sending Mail": you=20
can

substitute your old address here and send the unsub message.


The most frequent problem with subscriptions is bounced messages.  If
your

system is often down or if you have a low disk quota, Poetics messages
may

get bounced.  Please try avoid having messages from the list returned to
us.

If the problem is low disk quota, you may wish to request an increase
from

your system administrator. (You may wish to argue that this subscription
is

part of your scholarly communication!) You may also wish to consider

obtaining a commercial account.


____________________________________________________________________


3.  Cautions


Please do not send attachments or include extremely long documents in a
post, since this may make it difficult for those who get the list via
"digest" or who cannot always decode attached or specially formatted
files.=20


In addition to being archived at the EPC, some posts to Poetics
(especially reviews, obituary notices, announcements, etc.) may also
become part of specific EPC subject areas. Brief reviews of poetry events
and publications are always welcome. (See section 7.)


Please do not send inquiries to the list to get an individual subscribers
address. To get this information, see section 6.


If you want someone to send out information to the list as a whole, or
supply information missing from an post, or thank someone for posting
something you requested, please send the request or comment to the
individual backchannel, not to the whole list.=20


____________________________________________________________________


4. Digest Option


The Poetics List can send a large number of individual messages to

your account to each day!  If you would prefer to receive ONE message

each day, which would include all messages posted to the list for that

day, you can use the digest option.  Send this one-line message (no
subject

line) to

                                listserv@listserv.acsu.buffalo.edu


set poetics digest


NOTE:!! Send this message to "listserv" not to Poetics or as a reply

to this message!!


You can switch back to individual messages by sending this message:


set poetics mail

____________________________________________________________________


5. Temporarily turning off Poetics mail


Do not leave your Poetics subscription "active" if you are going to be
away

for any extended period of time! Your account may become flooded and you
may

lose not only Poetics messages but other important mail. You can
temporarily

turn off your Poetics subscription by sending a message to "listserv."



set poetics nomail


& turn it on again with: set poetics mail


When you return you can check or download missed postings from the
Poetics

archive. (See 8 below.)


____________________________________________________________________


6. Who's Subscribed


To see who is subscribed to Poetics, send an e-mail message to

listserv@listserv.acsu.buffalo.edu; leave the "Subject" line of the
e-mail message

blank.  In the body of your e-mail message type:


  review poetics


You will be sent within a reasonable amount of time (by return e-mail)=20
a

rather long list containing the names and e-mail addresses of Poetics

subscribers.  This list is alphabetized by server not name.


 or try:


 review POETICS by name

 review POETICS by country


which will give you the list alphabetically by name or a flawed list by
country (since all ".com" and ".net"s are counted as US)


*Please do not send a message to the list asking for the address of a
specific subscriber.*

____________________________________________________________________


7. What is the Electronic Poetry Center?


our URL is


http://writing.upenn.edu/epc


The mission of this World-Wide Web based electronic poetry center is to

serve as a hypertextual gateway to the extraordinary range of activity
in

formally innovative writing in the United States and the world.  The
Center

provides access to the burgeoning number of electronic resources in the
new

poetries including RIF/T and other electronic poetry journals, the
POETICS

List archives, an AUTHOR library of electronic poetic texts, and direct

connections to numerous related electronic RESOURCES. The Center also
provides information about contemporary print little magazines and SMALL
PRESSES engaged in poetry and poetics. And we have an extensive
collection of soundfiles of poets' reading their work, as

well as the archive of LINEbreak, the radio interview series.


The EPC is directed by Loss Peque=F1o Glazier.

____________________________________________________________________


8. Poetics Archives via EPC


Go to the EPC and select Poetics from the opening screen. Follow the

links to Poetics Archives. You may browse the archives by month and

year or search them for specific information. Your interface will

allow you to print or download any of these files.


Or set your browser to go directly to:

http://writing.upenn.edu/epc/poetics/archive


____________________________________________________________________


9. Publishers & Editors Read This!


PUBLISHERS & EDITORS: Our listings of poetry and poetics information is
open and available to you. We are trying to make access to printed
publications

as easy as possible to our users and ENCOURAGE you to participate! Send
a

list of your press/publications to glazier@acsu.buffalo.edu with the
words EPC Press Listing in the subject line. You may also send materials
on disk. (Write file name, word processing program, and Mac or PC on
disk.) Send an e-mail message to the address above to obtain a mailing
address to which to send your disk. Though files marked up with html are
our goal, ascii files are perfectly acceptable. If yourword processor ill
save files in Rich Text Format (.rtf) this is also highly desirable


Send us extended information on new publications (including any back
cover copy and sample poems) as well as complete catalogs/backlists
(including excerpts from reviews, sample poems, etc.).  Be sure to
include full information for ordering--including prices and addresses and
phone numbers both of the press and any distributors.


Initially, you might want to send short anouncements of new=20
publications

directly to the Poetics list as subscribers do not always (or ever) check
the

EPC; in your message please include full information for ordering.  If
you have

a fuller listing at EPC, you might also mention that in any Poetics
posts.


Some announcements circulated through Poetics and the EPC have received
a

noticeable responses; it may be an effective way to promote your
publication

and we are glad to facilitate information about interesting
publications.

____________________________________________________________________


END OF POETICS LIST WELCOME

        The road which leads me to you is safe even when it runs into oceans.

                Edmond Jabes, The Book of Questions



felt like Fellini.
Young voices write video screen,
not too old, held upstairs
spinning drums, washed by
harem, pure wife.

that word of mine
propriety making this video
when in a second it is me writing
it spoken, responsibility
a point later edited out

so where does the writing
begin which is a way of
writing out shame.  She says
I am the screen well
that's true, admission
says you need us

I suppose it's a matter
of timing opening dam
bedrock to sky that total
responsibility in the midst
of technology's blind spot

so that returning to love
and an arbitrary division of
paragraphs yet when her face
shimmered it was all to a
certain extent lost
structure confluence

Subject:      Ashbery/Theroux debate
Comments: To: poetics@UBVM.cc.buffalo.edu
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

I'm going to violate my rule against posting to the list twice in one day to
call attention to the following website:

http://www.latimes.com/HOME/NEWS/BOOKS/t000074985.html

There you will find John Ashbery writing to the LA Times about Alexander
Theroux's review of his first five books and Theroux's response. The gist
being that Ashbery is said to be a fine writer when he doesn't behave like a
relative of Stein, Olson (whose name is spelled Olsen by both, or perhaps by
the LA Times' editor), Pound, even Berryman.

Theroux, if you've had the fortune to miss the work, is a classic example of
an academic novelist (Princeton at the moment, I think) who strikes the
tough guy pose in his prose (he's an amateur at this compared with Leonard
Michaels), which aspires to some sort of made for TV aesthetics.

Ron

Dean --

quite well done -- the serene pacing, text-roll & image-fades --
seems to fulfill (to a degree, or at least in a certain manner) what
I've often felt to be interesting possibilities for the medium, but
which I've rarely seen explored with much sense of adequacy.

A good example -- an interesting instance -- of what can be done.
Reminds me somewhat of my sensation on seeing work of some
more-"serious" video artists (e.g., Irit Batsry in NYC), who're
interested in really working with the medium's own potential . . .

Yes, the upper imagery didn't appear on my browser (Netscape 2 level)
till the poem-text had run thru its cycle onece -- then one properly
had the full effect.  Other viewers might bear this in mind.  The
pacing was not (quite) as slow as Butoh -- was (I'd say) pretty well
set; too fast would have been (pardoning the tautology) too fast;
whereas much slower might've bordered on excruciating . . . .

all this is not commenting on "content" issues, but rather, on the
techno-achievement (& hat-tipping toward the so-to-say
more-than-nascent poetics thereof . . .  )

thanks,
d.i.

I'd say "ditto" in response to Herb's e-mail.  The Mackey co-edited
volume has more range to it.  I'd especially second Herb's
enthusiastic recommendation of Aldon Nielsen's _Black Chant_--a truly
great resource, and an enjoyable read.  The current issue of _River
City_ magazine has a couple of short essays on jazz & poetry: one by
me (on early Creeley, and current Mackey), and one by Aldon.

Subject:      Re: Ashbery/Theroux debate
Comments: To: rsillima <rsillima@IX.NETCOM.COM>
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN

Thanks for that heads up, Ron - boy oh boy is Theroux all wet! The job he
does on Little JA makes Sven Birkerts look like a perfect gentleman (and I
imagine he is since I can't imagine him ever stooping so low...).

So, late in 1997, people are still getting riled over their inability to
locate "truth" in poems.  Gosh. Theroux is Allen Tate redux, preaching the
mealy-mouthed humanist gospel of clarity, as if a poem were merely a
transparent envelope and the poet a courier for some literary FedEx.

As a friend of mine from Texas is fond of saying: That tightens my jaw.
 This points up my recent experience on the second day of my Critical
Analysis of Poetry class: we were reading Sandburg's homiletic "Grass." On
the page before, though, was a wee excerpt from Stein's "Stanza" -- such
wonderful, playful, bracing stuff -- and thanks to the attitude of hostility
and fear fostered by people like Theroux, how will students ever be
introduced to it?  As Victor McLaglen opines in Ford's "Fort Apache" -
"we've got a job of work ahead of us and no mistake..."

Patrick Pritchett
 ----------
From: rsillima
To: POETICS
Subject: Ashbery/Theroux debate
Date: Friday, August 29, 1997 4:34AM

http://www.latimes.com/HOME/NEWS/BOOKS/t000074985.html

There you will find John Ashbery writing to the LA Times about Alexander
Theroux's review of his first five books and Theroux's response. The gist
being that Ashbery is said to be a fine writer when he doesn't behave like a
relative of Stein, Olson (whose name is spelled Olsen by both, or perhaps by
the LA Times' editor), Pound, even Berryman.

Theroux, if you've had the fortune to miss the work, is a classic example of
an academic novelist (Princeton at the moment, I think) who strikes the
tough guy pose in his prose (he's an amateur at this compared with Leonard
Michaels), which aspires to some sort of made for TV aesthetics.

Ron

Ron Silliman

Date:         Fri, 29 Aug 1997 10:56:48 -0700

From:         David Bromige <dcmb@METRO.NET>
Subject:      'pataphysics & Opal Louis Nations
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

A contemporary norte americano working the 'pataphysical vein who is too
little known & read, Opal louis Nations, may be introduced here w/o my
dipping too far into irrelevance, I trust. Author of a number of books
published between 1970-1990(?), but for some years now on sabbatical from
writing while he works in the studio reviving old gospel, doo-wop, & r n b
acetates for the CD industry, Nations (aptly named [and by himself]) : born
& raised in Britain, national of Canada, immigrant long since to the USA)
is probably best encountered via _A Browsers Guide to Opal L. Nations_, put
out by the now-defunct Coach House Press in Toronto but still likely
available at the right library or 2nd hand bookshop. I know that when  I
read from this to a KSW group last year in Vancouver, they were astonished
that a writer of such intensity concerning things absurd shared passports
with them, and wanted to hear more of him. With his wife Ellie Humm
(originally from Norway), Opal edited the magazine _Strange Faeces_
throughout the 70s.

Extra-literary talents possessed by this one-off figurante include a
6-octave range with perfect pitch (he has sung with a number of groups,
beginning with the Frays in London in the 60s--Decca recording artists),
and a gift for drawing, whether straight-ahead represntation, or the
cartoons more in keeping with his writing interests.

Early an associate of Allen Fisher (collecting early doo-wop, not poetry,
initially drew them together), and during his Canadian spell, Steve
McCaffery, I believe Nations' lukewarm interest in French theory of the
recent past accounts for the drop off in attention to his work, and, on his
part, in furthering his writing. And too, he is a "loner" poet in a time of
assiduous networking.

I hope some of you will find time to look into his work.  David

Date:         Fri, 29 Aug 1997 12:57:13 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         mark weiss <junction@EARTHLINK.NET>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

I've just read the exchange between Ashbery and Theroux in the LA Times
that Ron tipped us off to (you can get Ashbery's reply to the review and
Theroux's reply to Ashbery free at the LATimes website, but the original
review (Aug. 3) appears to be pay-per-view). Theroux, who gets last word
(the home team always does) to clinch his argument that the great moderns
and their supporters are often in a conspiracy to perpetrate fraud by being
less than plain-spoken and linear, quotes some lovely paratactic lines of
Ashbery's as proof that Ashbery is not entitled to ask anyone for clarity
of argument, his crimes against such being so flagrant. He also discounts
Stein because she flunked her lit courses. It never occurs to Theroux that
he simply may not know how to read the writers he criticizes.
In light of the above, I thought that the backchannel thread between me and
Charles Alexander might be useful. He is responding to the poetics list
posting that I reproduce below. (Charles agreed to our outing).

Those of you who weren't sure what kind of divisions there are in the
poetry world when the question of an avant-garde came up recently may find
the following interesting.
I just spoke with the editorial office at _Booklist_, the journal of the
American Library Association. I had submitted Rochelle Owens' _New and
Selected Poems_ to them for review. As the excellent review in Publishers'
Weekly had just come out I was curious as to whether _Booklist_ intended to
review it. Like it or not, a good review in _Booklist_ is worth 200-300
sales to libraries. I was informed that their poetry editor had rejected it
because, in the words of an internal memo, it "represents the kind of
poetry that convinces people that poetry is too difficult to read." I think
I offended the guy on the other end of the line when I volunteered that
they should maybe find a less naive poetry editor.
The book came to them with extensive praise from, among others, Karl Young,
Marjorie Perloff and Jerry Rothenberg, but that didn't get it past the
gate-keeper.

                                                Mark


Mark, you devil.

You know perfectly well that these three names wouldn't get anything past,
or even TO, those particular gate-keepers. My guess is that those
gate-keepers might not have ever heard these three names.

I mean, there are borders, and then there are glaciers.

                                                Charles


Of course you're right, and that's the point. We can argue about what's
meant by avant garde, but I know damned well that the two conservative
books that I've published, Mervyn Taylor's and Susie Mee's, both of which I
think are marvelous books, got reviewed in Library Journal, Publisher's'
Weekly and Booklist, until Rochelle's none of the others have been reviewed
in even one of the three, and the review of Rochelle's begins "Owens is yet
another talented poet who has not received her due because her poems are
neither easy nor easily classifiable." It happens that I don't think that
any of the books I've published are difficult (few books of poems are--they
usually yield pretty easily to being read aloud), but most are non-linear,
which is what I think these cats mean by difficult. The linear is where the
line is drawn, and that applies to ways of experiencing a lot more than
just poems, heaven help us in this poor benighted land.

                                                        Mark



I'm not so certain about this, Mark, and perhaps I am more cynical than you
are. I think, for example, that a number of poets in those 'conservative'
circles (terminology, we know, is quite loaded with pitfalls here) are
beginning to give Robert Duncan a consenting nod -- even, if they are
feminist, Gertrude Stein -- and not necessarily reading these two narrowly.
For living writers it's a different story, but is the line really about
linearity. I fear it's more of a social question than that. Where did who
go to school, who do they know, who reads and cares about their work, etc.?
What you suggest is that people actually try to read our 'difficult' books
and are somewhat troubled by the nonlinear nature. What I wonder is if it,
usually, even gets to the point of a reading, if a writer doesn't have a
particular pedigree. That is the point where John Ashbery having gone to
Harvard gets him in a few doors that Tom Mandel or Ron Silliman or Mary
Margaret Sloan is not going to enter. Michael Palmer gets in some of those
doors, too. And I don't say that to fault Ashbery or Palmer in the least.

If these were truly aesthetic questions, I would like it very much. But I
fear that something else gets in the way before aesthetics or poetics even
gets a chance. Something which is part social, part political, part MFA or
school-related, part ugly, largely but not entirely unrecognized by those
who would bar the gates.

                                                        Charles

I hope John Ashbery will respond to Alexander Theroux's question about the
number of commas in Ashbery's _Tennis Court Oath_ poem, "Idaho." H may see
no need to do so, but it does seem like a matter worth addressing,
_proportion_, especially in this context. Who among us would maintain that
Ashbery never published a less-than-perfect poem? So the hell what?
Unlike Wordsworth, Ashbery seems to have persevered long enough to write
_very well_ again.

That the LA Times wants web readers to pay for articles is fine, their
business, but that the amount they want to charge is greater than $0.01 is
discouraging. Microdollars! are what I have for Theroux's prose (and
sorry, Dalkey, zip for the poems). Ad hominem on him aside, has anybody
read the original review? Is Ashbery's account of Theroux's antagonism to
modern(post)ism supportable?

What does an arbitrary number of commas threaten? (What are the um
gender/camp/literary historical deals in "Idaho" that Theroux's
dropkicking? Do they matter? Is it a strictly formal poem that offends
Theroux on a strictly formal level? Would two commas have been
sufficient? What about Ron Loewinsohn's poem about the swimmers with the
row of semicolons -- is or is not that more meaningful? more beautiful?)

Are we really just a bunch of post-Berlinwall communards? Brave benighted
souls? Ecch. How long will poets continue to be held to insane standards?

Yours in the question yams,
Jordan

PS Is this the first mention of Olsen (sic) outside of poetry land in
years, or is it my image nation?

And when will someone do for the line from Ashbery to Padgett what has
been done so successfully for the line from Olson to Howe?

PPS Letter to the editor rengafesto beginning

POETRY IS A GIVEN.

POETS ARE FREE AND RESPONSIBLE TO DO WITH WORDS WHAT THEY WANT.

WHAT POETS DO WITH WORDS MAY NOT BE RECOGNIZABLE -- BUT WHAT THEY DO MAY
BECOME SO. THERE IS NO REASON TO HARM POETS OR SPEAK ILL OF THEM BECAUSE
OF YOUR INABILITY TO READ THEM.

Subject:      Another blast from the (poetry) past : Ron Loewinsohn
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

          On the day I post a thumbnail sketch of Opal Nations, a happy
shock to see (for 1st time since i signed on the List) the name of Ron
Loewinsohn, a writer probably better-known (Allen anthology) than Opal, but
one also who was read by a number of my associates in the 70's & who then
stopped writing (or publishing, in any case) poetry. He has scholarly
articles on W.C.W. & perhaps others, and two novels published, one of
which, _Magnetic Fields_, won a worthwhile prize, but I havent seen his
poetry for a long time. _Watermelons_ was published in the late 50s (Ron
then being in his very early 20s), with praise front & back from WCW &
Allen Ginsberg. A number of books followed, with perhaps the most notable
being _Against the Silences to Come_ , whose title poem is built up of some
exquisite "chording" that links the daily paper with history of the poem as
feeling-object. Again, a poet to recommend, one who may not be known to the
generation now in their 20s and 30s.

Despite the slightly obit tone of my postings today, these poets are both
very much alive, Nations when not in the recording studio can be found at
...help, the name of that record store in Albany? El Cerrito? ...and
Loewinsohn, teaching at UC Bkly. Give em a read.  David


footnote to Opal Nations as multi-talented person : for many years, he was
a highly popular DJ on KPFA (pbs) Bkly, until "let go" by dubious
management decision. He has taken his show (originally "Doo-Wop Delights")
to a pbs station in Santa Cruz, but just once or twice monthly.

Jennifer says she's been on the road. She says she's found her one true
love.

She's sorry she can't write a rhyme for a long time. She's sorry she can't
even punctuate rites or spel a spell.

She's swollen. I'd say pregnant. Mourning sickenss for depression. What
grabs the objet petit a so to _speak._

Cloked or choked.

Jennifer says, well, it's all better off this way anyway, you know
language can just perform SO MUCH and then you want the real thing.

Even poets want the real thing.

You know it when it hurts.

Even poets perform.

Jennifer says and says but she's not listening to what she's saying.

The brain chops meat like a cleaver.

Julu, she's dead.

She was the listening-function, so says Deleuze-Guattari. They turned her
into a machine. Lathe.

Hehe.

- J

The crucial essay is Nichol's "The "Pata of Letter Feet, or, The English
Written Character as a Medium for Poetry." i think this also one of the
few _critical_ pieces bp wrote on the topic, i mean he was a performer,
and didn't always stop performing to rationalize over the performance.
i cld be wrong. But this essay is such a _pause_. Of course there is also
the collected symposium papers of the conf. held in Toronto (i forget the
date). But again i think his essay there is more a performance of
"pataphysics than critical account. Nichol's essay has fascinated since
forever. It's such an important text. he wrote it coz Prof. Hugh LeRoy
in the Fine Arts Dept. at York University asked him to, to come in and
talk abt art & poetry to the graduate students there. That was in 1985 or
86. i've seen the manuscript version of this text and it's interesting how
he ponders & revises certain words, certain phrases. The essay is so
simple. But not too simple. As you can tell, i love that essay and cld
talk abt it forever. But i'm saving my best stuff for my dissertation. We
owe Prof. LeRoy much thanx.

> bpNichol and Steve McCaffery over the years spent a lot of time on
> 'pataphysics, or the Canadian version, which is called "pataphysics.

From:         Craig Douglas Dworkin <dworkin@UCLINK.BERKELEY.EDU>
Subject:      'Pataphysics
In-Reply-To:  <199708310402.VAA06093@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Greetings all,

Those interested in what might be called an "applied 'pataphysics" will
want to take a look at the recent "Open Letter" (Ninth Series, Number 7,
Winter 1997), edited by Christian Bok (whose dissertation is actually on
'Pataphysics) and Darren Wershler-Henry (whose dissertation is a
long-overdue study of the typewriter and literature), two York students
whose combination of brilliance and irreverence probably hasn't been seen
in a university since the Moscow Linguistic Circle formed in the mid
'teens.  Of special note in the issue: Steve McCaffery's "Zarathrustran
'Pataphysics," which takes Christopher Dewdney's "Fractal Diffusion" an
order of magnitude further.

Highest recommendation as well to their recent books of poetry, Bok's
"Crystalography" (Coach House Press, 1994) and Wershler-Henry's
"NICHOLODEON: a book of lowerglyphs" (Coach House Printing, 1997).

happy reading,
--Craig Dworkin

Perhaps it's silly to be thinking of this now, and in such a context; if
so, apologies.  Hope the special characters come through

PIEDRA NEGRA SOBRE UNA PIEDRA BLANCA

Me moriré en París con aguacero,
un día del cual tengo ya el recuerdo.
Me moriré en París--y no me corro--
talvez un jueves, como es hoy de otoño.

Jueves será, porque hoy, jueves, que proso
estos versos, los húmeros me he puesto
a la mala y, jamás como hoy, me he vuelto,
con todo mi camino, a verme solo.

César Vallejo ha muerto, le pegaban
todos sin que él les haga nada;
le daban duro con un palo y duro

también con una soga; son testigos
los días jueves y los huesos húmeros,
la soledad, la lluvia, los caminos . . .


--César Vallejo

From:         "David R. Israel" <davidi@MAIL.WIZARD.NET>
Subject:      poet gets (at once) insta-fame & quick-anonymity
MIME-Version: 1.0

Poetas,

according to today's NY Times (see appended excerpt), the good (&
needfully clandestine) writer Salman Rushdie has wed an American poet
by name Elizabeth.  Many happy returns.

The article refers to a new prose-fiction anthology, published in the
U.S. as *Mirrorwork:  50 Years of Indian Writing (1947-1997)*,
edited by Salman Rushdie and Elizabeth West (Henry Holt & Co.)

(seems, the implication is "West" would be a pseudonym)

[ what follows is from:
http://www.nytimes.com/yr/mo/day/news/national/ny-rushdie-wedding.html
one mus register w/ the paper (via http://www.nytimes.com) to download ]

          August 31, 1997
          Salman Rushdie, Still Hiding, Is Married in Secret

          By JANE H. LII

          Salman Rushdie, the author of "The Satanic Verses," who has
          lived in hiding for nearly a decade as the object of an open-ended
          Islamic death sentence, was married in secret on Thursday in
          the Hamptons on Long Island.

          The details of the wedding were not given, but Andrew Wylie,
          Rushdie's agent, said Saturday: "Elizabeth and Salman
          Rushdie are happy to confirm that they were married on
          Thursday, Aug. 28, in a small ceremony."

          Newspaper reporters in London, speaking on the condition of
          anonymity, said the new Mrs. Rushdie, whose maiden name is
          being withheld to protect her safety, is a poet who had
          collaborated with Rushdie on an anthology of modern Indian
          writing. The Daily Mail, a newspaper published in London,
          reported that the couple had had a child last month. . . .

/ / / /

btw, talkin' of celebrity & anonymity, here's my contribution anent
the late Princess of Wales -- responsive to remarks from one writer
(here rendered anon.) not from this list . . .; a "boomerang poem"
(as I call 'em).

> It saddens me deeply.  It also causes me to reflect on how very
> lucky we are that we live our lives in relative anonymity.  That we
> can get away for a week at the beach without worrying about
> photographers behind every sand dune.  We can smoke our cigarettes
> in the early morning hours, blissfully alone, just us and the sand
> and the waves.

  poise / pause / paz    (for Diana)

  that the known might desire anonymity
  (the anonymous still coveting renown)
  that the famous should pine for obscurity?
  when celebs are the talk-of-the-town
  (ever bearing the weight of that crown)
  might one just assume fathom the surety
  of less-glamorous chances to frown? . . .
  how the known may renew anonymity

d.i.

 |   thy centuries follow each other
 |   perfecting a small wild flower
 |                                       (Tagore)

> I just received a request for a review copy of Rochelle Owens' book from
> "S.V. Caldwell, Ph.D., Editor" of the Sandia Review of Books in
> Albuquerque. Regular letterhead, no phone number. The mag isn't listed in


Mark, Sandia Review of Books does sound familiar. It is more like a
local book review newspaper, I believe, than any kind of "little
magazine," so I'm not surprised if it doesn't show up in Dust Books
or CLMP. Someone in Albuquerque on this list probably knows, if there
is someone in Albuquerque on this list. If not, you might find your
way, perhaps through the web, to an Albuquerque phone book or
business directory -- or you might try to find and call a bookstore
in Albuquerque.

charles

Karl Young's  Light & Dust web site was mentioned as having bp
Nichol's work, relating to the pataphysics thread, but someone (was
it you, Carl) didn't have the URL at hand.

The URL of the Light & Dust's contents page is
http://www.thing.net/~grist/l&d/lighthom.htm

Works by Nichol there are Translating Translating Apollinaire, at
http://www.thing.net/~grist/l&d/bpnichol/lnichol1.htm


and works from Sharp Facts (variations on Translating Translating
Apollinaire 26), at
http://www.thing.net/~grist/l&d/bpnichol/bpsh.htm

But also look around at other works there. To me, it's one of the
very best poetry sites on the web.

charles
